abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The start of September means a return to school around here, and for some people — not you! You never stopped! — that means a return to serious reading, the kind of immersive sinking into a book that leaves you better informed than you were when you went in, chewing over a topic or an idea or just the intricacies of a good story well told. There may be a syllabus involved: For the high schooler in my house, the start of the semester has been marked by the rhythms of “Beowulf” in Seamus Heaney’s excellent translation. There may be some extracurricular reading: If you’ve already finished “Beowulf” and want to know what to pick up next, you might branch out to John Gardner’s 1971 novel “Grendel,” which retells that epic from the monster’s perspective — as villain origin stories go, it beats “Joker” by a mile.

headline: With Peltola’s Defeat of Palin, Alaska’s Ranked-Choice Voting Has a Moment
abstract: Mary Peltola won by appealing to Alaskan interests and the electorate’s independent streak. But Alaska’s new voting system played a big role, too.
lead_paragraph: Mary Peltola, whose victory in a special election on Wednesday makes her the first Democrat in nearly half a century to represent Alaska in the House, won the contest for the remainder of Representative Don Young’s term with an upbeat campaign that appealed to Alaskan interests and the electorate’s independent streak.

headline: Marcus King, a Bluesy Rocker Who Stared Down His Own Crossroads
abstract: The 26-year-old singer and guitarist saw terrifying signs and symbols during the making of his new album, “Young Blood.” He steadied himself, and put it all in the music.
lead_paragraph: Ours is an improbable world, in which Birkenstocks and tie-dye — once signifiers of hippie anti-style, as glamorous as trail mix — are now more chic than ever.

headline: Labor Board Official Says Amazon Effort to Overturn Staten Island Warehouse Election Should Be Rejected
abstract: The labor official concluded that Amazon’s objections to the election should be set aside and that the Amazon Labor Union should be certified to represent workers at the warehouse.
lead_paragraph: A federal labor official who presided over Amazon’s challenge to a union victory at a Staten Island warehouse has recommended that the challenge be rejected, the National Labor Relations Board said on Thursday.

headline: Here’s how to watch Biden’s prime-time speech.
abstract: The address will begin at 8 p.m. Eastern and air live on television and online.
lead_paragraph: At 8 p.m. Eastern on Thursday, President Biden will deliver a prime-time speech from Philadelphia that is set to address extremism and its threat to American democracy.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Detective Investigated After Knocking Woman to the Ground
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams said the detective showed “great restraint” during a fractious arrest of the woman’s boyfriend, but activists called for the officer to be disciplined.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer is under investigation after social-media video surfaced showing him knocking a woman to the ground during a scuffle as her boyfriend was arrested, prompting accusations of brutality and a vociferous defense on Thursday from the mayor.

headline: Zelensky says Russia prevented independent journalists from observing the I.A.E.A. mission.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine hailed the arrival of United Nations inspectors at the occupied Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant on Thursday but said Russia was undermining the inspection by preventing independent journalists from observing it and by intimidating residents in the surrounding town.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine hailed the arrival of United Nations inspectors at the occupied Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant on Thursday but said Russia was undermining the inspection by preventing independent journalists from observing it and by intimidating residents in the surrounding town.

headline: Can You Drown Government in an Empty Bathtub?
abstract: What Jackson, Miss., tells us about America.
lead_paragraph: Mississippi has long been America’s poorest state, with real gross domestic product per person only about 60 percent of the national average. The United States, however, is a rich country, so Mississippi doesn’t look that bad by international standards. Specifically, it’s roughly on a par with southern European countries: a bit poorer than Spain, a bit richer than Portugal.

headline: Experts Brave Shelling to Reach Imperiled Ukrainian Nuclear Plant at Last
abstract: The team from the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog reached the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia plant for the first time since the war began, despite fresh shelling each side blamed on the other.
lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — A U.N. inspection team finally reached the embattled nuclear power plant in Russian-occupied southern Ukraine on Thursday, after an artillery bombardment forced operators to shut down one reactor and switch another to emergency power, highlighting the immense risks of combat around a site loaded with radioactive material.

headline: If an Alternative Candidate Is Needed in 2024, These Folks Will Be Ready
abstract: If the two parties go off to the edges, there’ll be a ticket running up the center.
lead_paragraph: What happens if the 2024 election is between Donald Trump and somebody like Bernie Sanders? What happens if the Republicans nominate someone who is morally unacceptable to millions of Americans while the Democrats nominate someone who is ideologically unacceptable? Where do the millions of voters in the middle go? Does Trump end up winning as voters refuse to go that far left?

headline: Palin Lost a Shot at a House Seat, but She Has a Second Chance
abstract: Mary Peltola, a Democrat, defeated Sarah Palin, a well-known Republican, in a special House election. But they will enter a rematch in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin’s bid for a political comeback just got a lot harder.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Calls Gingrich to Testify, Saying He Had Role in Trump Plot
abstract: In a letter to the former House speaker, the select committee said the Georgia Republican had deliberately incited anger among voters with false claims of election fraud.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Thursday asked former Speaker Newt Gingrich to sit for a voluntary interview about his involvement in former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: The Day Gorbachev Made D.C. Stand Still
abstract: The Adventures of Mikhail Sergeyevich: An astrologer, an anaconda and a backward motorcade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There have been two surreal visitations in Washington that left people quivering with excitement.

headline: Trump’s Tastes in Intelligence: Power and Leverage
abstract: President Donald J. Trump’s interests during classified briefings have a new resonance amid the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into his handling of sensitive documents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As president, Donald J. Trump showed the most interest in intelligence briefings when the topics revolved around his personal relationships with world leaders and the power available at his fingertips.

headline: Former Idaho Lawmaker Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison for Raping Intern
abstract: Aaron von Ehlinger, 40, will have to serve eight years before being eligible for parole and register as a sex offender once he is released from prison.
lead_paragraph: A former Idaho state representative continued to claim his innocence in a courtroom on Wednesday but was ultimately sentenced to 20 years in prison after a jury convicted him of raping a 19-year-old legislative intern after a dinner last year.

headline: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
abstract: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
lead_paragraph: Road trips are never easy, but they are far more unpleasant when your child repeatedly vomits in the back seat because they’re carsick. I know, because that’s what happens whenever I drive more than an hour with my 8-year-old. She’s now had enough practice to neatly throw up into a plastic bag, but I feel for her every time it happens and wonder what I can do to ease her misery.

headline: McCarthy embraces Trump’s assault on the Justice Department over the Mar-a-Lago search.
abstract: The House Republican leader sought to invert President Biden’s themes into an attack on Democrats and their policies.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the Republican leader, on Thursday aligned himself with former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to undercut federal law enforcement over the search of Mar-a-Lago, condemning the court-ordered seizure of classified documents from the former president’s home as an “assault on democracy.”

headline: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Officer Gets 10 Years for Jan. 6 Attack, Longest Sentence to Date
abstract: “I think you were caught up in a moment,” a federal judge said as he sentenced Thomas Webster, an ex-Marine who once served on the protective detail of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: A retired New York City police officer who swung a metal flagpole at a Washington officer during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison, the longest sentence yet in a case stemming from the riot.

headline: The Williams sisters, after a tight first set, are overpowered in doubles.
abstract: Serena and Venus Williams lost the first set even after having a set point. They eventually were defeated, 7-6 (5), 6-4, by Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova of the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: What was supposed to be a prime time, packed-house celebration of the Williams sisters at the U.S. Open turned into something rather less festive than planned on Thursday night.

headline: Biden Says Trump-Led Extremism Threatens Democracy
abstract: In a speech outside Independence Hall in Philadelphia, President Biden warned that America’s democratic values were under assault by “MAGA Republicans” loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In a speech outside Independence Hall in Philadelphia, President Biden warned that America’s democratic values were under assault by “MAGA Republicans” loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Landing Spot for a Bee
abstract: Claire Rimkus offers us a good reason to try solving Friday puzzles.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I used to be terrified of themeless puzzles. There, I said it.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: John Ewbank sets us up with his first New York Times cryptic crossword.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — It’s great to welcome someone new into the small but mighty variety puzzle coalition. Today’s constructor, John Ewbank, makes cryptic crossword puzzles for The Times of London. He broke into our daily puzzles with a couple of excellent themed grids that had wordplay galore — a Thursday debut and a Monday collaboration with Jeff Chen — but regular crosswords, naturally, have plenty of standard clues that make a scaffold for solvers. A cryptic makes us climb right up the wall.

headline: Argentina’s Vice President Unharmed After Assassination Attempt
abstract: A man tried to fire a gun inches from the head of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s most prominent leader, but it did not go off.
lead_paragraph: An assassination attempt on Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina failed on Thursday night as a man pointed a pistol at her head and tried to pull the trigger, but the gun did not go off, according to video footage and a statement from Argentina’s president.

headline: Four takeaways from Biden’s speech in Philadelphia.
abstract: The president tacitly acknowledged that his predecessor still looms over the politics of the moment.
lead_paragraph: Just before the traditional Labor Day launch of the political season, President Biden inserted himself into the midterm elections on Thursday with a fierce speech castigating former President Donald J. Trump and his followers but ending with optimism for the nation’s democratic future.

headline: A Rematch of Biden v. Trump, Two Years Early
abstract: Dispensing with his unity message, President Biden reached into the 2020 file cabinet and vowed to win “a battle for the soul of this nation,” the cornerstone of his successful election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By this point in his term, President Biden figured things would be different. His predecessor would have faded from the scene and the country would have restored at least some semblance of normalcy. But as he said on Thursday night, “too much of what’s happening in our country today is not normal.”

headline: Full Transcript of President Biden’s Speech in Philadelphia
abstract: The president described what he viewed as threats to democracy, which he said stemmed from the actions of former President Donald J. Trump and “MAGA forces.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered remarks in Philadelphia on Thursday about what he described as ongoing threats to democracy in the United States. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: After a Nudge from Aziz Ansari, a First Date
abstract: Meredith Davis and Elliott Poppel connected on the dating app the League, but did not meet in person until after a comedy show where the actor Aziz Ansari read their messages on the app aloud.
lead_paragraph: Not long after joining the dating app the League, Elliott Poppel attended a show at the Comedy Cellar club in Manhattan, where the actor Aziz Ansari performed as a surprise guest.

headline: A Proposal Seven Years in the Making
abstract: It took a little more than a 45-minute call and $400 in texting fees for Mitchell Karp to know he liked Barry Katz.
lead_paragraph: Mitchell Jay Karp’s marriage proposal to Barry Katz was not a simple affair. There were opera singers, a silver rose and a tremendous amount of planning.

headline: In Sickness, Proving the Health of Their Relationship
abstract: Nicholas Baldo proposed to Viktoria Cupay in an intensive care unit after she had suffered a life-threatening health complication. Three years to the day of their engagement, they married.
lead_paragraph: When Nicholas William Baldo and Viktoria Angela Cupay started dating, their biggest concern was that they lived hundreds of miles apart: he in San Francisco, and she in Beach Park, Ill., about an hour from Chicago.

headline: I Broke My Knee, Which Fractured My Marriage
abstract: A stray flier for roof repairs sent me crashing into concrete — and my husband into an almost affair.
lead_paragraph: I think I have a condition where I think I have a condition. I have to go to the hospital, or the doctor’s office, or on Google, more than most.

headline: In Harlem, Detroit Natives Find a Love That Feels Like Home
abstract: Mike Taylor Jr. said Celeste Northern was “the Detroit girl I had always been looking for.” The two began dating after they both relocated to New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mike Taylor Jr., knew he wanted to get to know Celeste Northern better when they first met at a Detroit Pistons home game in December 2017 while both visited family for the holidays. He wasn’t necessarily looking for a girlfriend, though. He mostly wanted to find new friends.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Water Crisis Highlights a Nationwide Threat
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Sept. 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “They can’t flush the toilets. They can’t bathe. They’re working in dirt and mud, and they have no water.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 2, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about colonial reparations misstated the timing of a visit by King Philippe of Belgium to the Democratic Republic of Congo. It was in June, not last month.

headline: His U.S. Open Run Could Influence Tennis in China
abstract: Wu Yibing became the first Chinese man to reach the third round of a Grand Slam since 1946. He says it’s his “responsibility” to pick up where the retired champion Li Na left off in growing the game.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Wu Yibing made tennis history on Wednesday by becoming the first Chinese man to reach the third round of the U.S. Open, a tournament that dates to 1881, he was informed that his name was on fire on Chinese social media platforms like Weibo and WeChat.

headline: ‘Condemned to Lead’ Europe, German Chancellor Struggles for Impact
abstract: Facing its worst crisis since World War II, Europe is looking for leadership. Olaf Scholz is trying to take up the role, but faces a tepid response.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Four days after Russian forces rolled into Ukraine, Olaf Scholz, the new German chancellor whose robotic style had earned him the nickname “Scholz-o-mat,” did something out of character: He surprised people.

headline: Schools of Thought Control
abstract: Two new middle grade novels with academic settings have a message for students: Beware adults who claim they only want what’s best for you.
lead_paragraph: Any middle-schooler who’s run afoul of a mean teacher knows that bureaucrats make great villains. They’re the ones angling for absolute control.

headline: Let’s Go, Mets? Sure. But How About Those Starry Knights!
abstract: In this league, the Mets are from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Whitney Houstons sport the singer’s image on their uniforms.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a little-known softball league made up largely of workers from the city’s museums. We’ll also get an update on the Gateway tunnel project from New Jersey to Midtown.

headline: Behind the Scenes of an Afghan (Australian) Soccer Story
abstract: The story of a keeper and her teammates, as they fled and found new lives.
lead_paragraph: When the Taliban took over Afghanistan in August 2021, I read stories online about members of the Afghan women’s national soccer team fleeing the country.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: President Biden speaks on democracy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden addressed the U.S. in a prime-time speech last night. He spoke about the threat to American democracy, warning that the country’s values are under assault by those loyal to former Donald Trump.

headline: The U.N.’s nuclear agency is limited in its ability to enforce its recommendations on Zaporizhzhia.
abstract: Five remaining inspectors from a U.N. watchdog agency were assessing the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine on Friday, a day after making a risky and long-awaited trip to the imperiled facility to ensure critical emergency equipment was operational. But it remained unclear what steps the agency would be able to take to prevent the dangers of fierce combat around the plant.
lead_paragraph: Five remaining inspectors from a U.N. watchdog agency were assessing the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine on Friday, a day after making a risky and long-awaited trip to the imperiled facility to ensure critical emergency equipment was operational. But it remained unclear what steps the agency would be able to take to prevent the dangers of fierce combat around the plant.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Writing About Serena Is Writing About America’
abstract: As Serena Williams competes in what is most likely her last tennis tournament, The Times is tracking her legacy and influence on sports and culture.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the tennis star Serena Williams walked onto the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York before a crowd of nearly 24,000. It was the opening night of the U.S. Open tournament, which she has won six times. Public figures including President Bill Clinton, Queen Latifah and Anna Wintour watched from the stands. The buzz was palpable, the air in the stadium, electric — those watching knew it would probably be Ms. Williams’s last tournament.

headline: Serena Williams Prepared a Little Differently for This U.S. Open
abstract: Analytics, scouting first-time opponents, additional coaching input, new footwork drills and treating doubles like practice — so far it’s adding up to winning.
lead_paragraph: An underdog with the oddsmakers against the No. 2 seed, Anett Kontaveit, on Wednesday, Serena Williams will be back on familiar ground as the favorite against the unseeded Ajla Tomljanovic on Friday.

headline: Gig Workers Tire of Waiting for Action From Biden’s White House
abstract: The administration’s plans to strengthen their labor protections have been slowed by Congress, the courts and a lobbying blitz.
lead_paragraph: As a part-time Lyft driver in 2020, Nicole Moore was listening carefully when Joseph R. Biden Jr., a candidate for president, said the refusal by ride-hailing companies to treat their drivers as employees “deprives these workers of legally mandated benefits and protections.”

headline: 6 New Paperbacks We Recommend This Week
abstract: This week’s roundup brings together a variety of styles and tastes, from a dynamic pandemic novel to the biography of a French modernist.
lead_paragraph: This week’s roundup brings together a variety of styles and tastes, from a dynamic pandemic novel to the biography of a French modernist.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 2, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including "The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power" on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including "The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power" on Amazon Prime Video.

headline: Beneath the Surface: A Peek at Private Pools
abstract: Swimming pools have been carved into basement floors of townhouses and apartment buildings in New York City for decades, and they are spectacular.
lead_paragraph: Swimming pools have been carved into basement floors of townhouses and apartment buildings in New York City for decades, and they are spectacular.

headline: Amazon Really Believed It Could Sell You a Health Care Fantasy
abstract: There is no technological miracle that will fix decades of bad policy.
lead_paragraph: What if you could get health care as quickly and easily as you order socks and cat litter? It sounds fanciful in a country where people die waiting to see a doctor, but Amazon believed it could do for health care what it had done for shopping. Hailed as “the future of medicine,” the Amazon Care telehealth and house-call service was pitched to employers as “high-quality care, convenience and peace of mind.”

headline: How to Have Fun Again
abstract: An illustrated guide to letting loose.

headline: Why Did Some Cubans Inject Themselves With H.I.V.?
abstract: “Sacrificio,” a novel by Ernesto Mestre-Reed, imagines an extreme counterrevolutionary movement during desperate times.
lead_paragraph: Suffering extreme economic hardship, hundreds of Cubans inject themselves with H.I.V.-infected blood in order to gain admittance to the nation’s AIDS sanitariums.

headline: Just Put It in a Bowl
abstract: Yes, even pizza.
lead_paragraph: When Papa Johns debuts a menu item that evokes the top of one of its pizzas, scraped into a tray and presented as a meal, is it time to rethink our embrace of bowl culture? Have bowl meals — the food fad we’ve come to know and love (or know and hate) — finally reached peak saturation?

headline: What Urban Planners Can Learn From This Idealistic Coffee Shop
abstract: Can a pay-what-you-want cafe exist in a gentrified Gowanus?
lead_paragraph: By any measure, the area around an industrial patch of Ninth Street in Brooklyn, straddling Park Slope and Gowanus, ought to emerge as an urbanist’s utopia — a space where painters, poets, craftsmen, professionals with artsy jobs and working-class people live and connect and thrive. It should be the kind of place where small businesses holding dear to collectivist values serve a polylithic community deeply invested in itself. In late June, Katie Bishop, a 33-year-old former Marine and bassoonist with an advanced degree in music theory opened a coffeehouse — Principles GI — on Ninth Street with precisely such a vision in mind.

headline: Sex Ed Emerges as Core Issue for N.J. Republicans as Midterms Approach
abstract: New education standards that touch on gender identity have caused a stir in New Jersey. Some Republicans are trying to keep the conversation alive.
lead_paragraph: A 30-second ad from New Jersey’s largest teachers’ union has reignited a debate over the state’s new sex-education standards, putting the issue front and center weeks before pivotal congressional midterm races.

headline: Hugh Jackman Swaps West Village Home for Chelsea Penthouse
abstract: The actor and his wife bought the penthouse for $21.1 million. The biggest closing in August, atop the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue, sold for $53.4 million.
lead_paragraph: The actor Hugh Jackman is trading in his sprawling West Village triplex for something a bit smaller in Chelsea but with equally impressive Hudson River views.

headline: With the PGA Tour Season Over, LIV Golf Looks to Strengthen Its Foothold
abstract: Cameron Smith, the No. 2 player in the world, is among six veteran players who will make their debuts for the breakaway series at an event outside Boston this weekend.
lead_paragraph: BOLTON, Mass. — Roughly 11 weeks ago in the Boston suburbs, men’s professional golf welcomed the game’s best players to the 122nd U.S. Open. Five days before that event began, the inaugural LIV Golf tournament in England was ending; it was largely treated as an anomalous curiosity.

headline: Trying to Sell Your Old Peloton Bike? So Is Peloton.
abstract: As its business slumps, Peloton is trying something new: selling its bikes to “value-minded” customers. It faces stiff competition.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Edwards Jr. bought a new Peloton bike in 2020, his life looked pretty different. He had just received a stimulus check from the federal government and was spending most of his time at home. But lately, busy with an infant son and an in-person job at his family’s grocery chain in Little Rock, Ark., he and his wife barely use the bike.

headline: A Constellation of Stars From the Latin Art World
abstract: Holland Cotter, co-chief critic, on the bounty of Latin American and Latino art coming our way for the fall and winter season, as well as important shows on South Asian and Indigenous art.
lead_paragraph: Of the powerhouse exhibitions headed our way this season, “Murillo: From Heaven to Earth” at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth (Sept. 18-Jan. 29) heads my list for its title alone. Given the state of our combusting, war-racked planet, we could use some outside help, and in the painterly cosmos of the 17th-century Spanish Baroque painter Bartolomé Esteban Murillo it’s there: Angels and saints beam down to succor ordinary folk, and everyone looks touched by grace. A popular art of immense sophistication in a one-stop-only show.

headline: Ask a Flight Attendant: Middle-Seat Etiquette, Drunk Passengers and Jet Lag
abstract: Where is the best seat if you’re airsick prone? Why don’t flight crews eat the same meals? And the age-old question: Can middle-seat passengers really claim both armrests?
lead_paragraph: As we say farewell to summer, travelers are surely hoping to say “so long” to the chaos in the skies too.

headline: What Brittney Griner’s Income Says About Women’s Basketball
abstract: As her attorneys appeal her conviction in a Russian court, questions remain about why she and other W.N.B.A. stars play abroad to supplement their incomes.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. eight-time All-Star and two-time Olympic gold medalist, remains in a Russian jail, nearly 200 days after she was arrested on Feb. 17 for possessing less than a gram of hashish oil.

headline: I Was Onstage With Salman Rushdie That Day, and What I Saw Was Remarkable
abstract: I felt the power of the rush of readers who ran to the stage when Salman Rushdie was attacked.
lead_paragraph: Violence against writers was the topic I was about to interview the novelist Salman Rushdie about at the Chautauqua Institution on Aug. 12. We were being introduced onstage when out of nowhere, like a scene from Mr. Rushdie’s novel “Shalimar the Clown,” a knife-wielding man rushed onto the stage and began to stab him.

headline: Is Andy Murray About to Become Andy Murray Again?
abstract: Like Serena Williams, Andy Murray, finally healthy and fit, has given glimpses of yesteryear at the U.S. Open. Unlike Williams, he has no intention of walking away.
lead_paragraph: A Grand Slam champion, one of the great players of this era, battles back from the brink of retirement and major physical setbacks to challenge the best players in the world once more in the face of widespread — and justified — skepticism.

headline: Marcus Freeman is 36. He’s Also in Charge at Notre Dame.
abstract: Freeman’s first full season as a head coach will unfold in one of the most high-profile institutions in American sports. First up: No. 2 Ohio State, Freeman’s alma mater.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Freeman spent years as a coach to watch: a star linebacker at Ohio State who played in the N.F.L. before he emerged as one of the college game’s defensive wizards.

headline: David Milch Still Has Stories to Tell
abstract: The TV producer and creator of “Deadwood” recounts his tumultuous upbringing, his trailblazing career and his experience with Alzheimer’s disease in “Life’s Work.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The door to a room at an assisted-living facility swung open, and out darted one of its occupants: a cat named Mignonne, who was eager for some fresh companionship. Then, with more deliberation, came the apartment’s primary resident, David Milch, who was similarly happy to have visitors.

headline: The Contentious Vote in Chile That Could Transform Indigenous Rights
abstract: The proposed constitution would enshrine some of the world’s most extensive Indigenous rights. But those reforms have become the focal point of the campaign to reject the new text.
lead_paragraph: TEMUCO, Chile — The Mapuche people beat back Inca invaders. They fended off Spanish colonizers. And centuries later, they have continued to wage a battle for the recognition of their territories in modern Chile.

headline: How Much Does That Oligarch’s Yacht Actually Cost?
abstract: An accounting, down to the hull and the Picassos.
lead_paragraph: It’s still yacht season in the Mediterranean, a favorite time of year for paparazzi and close readers of David Geffen’s Instagram. On any given sun-and-Champagne-drenched day, one might see Elon Musk frolicking shirtless on Ari Emanuel’s yacht, or Drake spotted aboard a $660-thousand-per-week superyacht in Saint-Tropez.

headline: Stephen Curry Said Davidson Changed His Life. He Changed Davidson.
abstract: Curry, the N.B.A. superstar, returned to Davidson College, where he first showed how great he could be. The college, and its community, still feel his impact over a decade later.
lead_paragraph: DAVIDSON, N.C. — On the first day of the fall semester in 2007, Stephen Curry sat in a class on gender and society at Davidson College, a small, liberal arts school 20 miles north of Charlotte, N.C.

headline: New York’s Communal Summer Ritual: Grilling
abstract: Throughout public parks in the city, families, friends and neighbors gather around smoking grates and celebrate the season.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Our City series, about how urban communities around the country use public and communal spaces to celebrate and spend time together.

headline: ‘Magic in Her Hands.’ The Woman Bringing India’s Forests Back to Life
abstract: Tulsi Gowind Gowda has spent most of her more than 80 years planting and nurturing trees in southern India. “I like them more than anything else in my life,” she said.
lead_paragraph: HONNALI, India — She has walked for miles, deep into tropical rainforests, carefully cutting healthy branches from hundreds of trees and replanting and grafting them. Her eyes light up when she talks about rare seeds or a sapling. And when she dies, she would like to be reborn, she says, as a big tree.

headline: Strikes Sweep Britain as Workers Demand Better Pay
abstract: Backed by unions and tired of years of low wage growth, workers are making bold pay demands to cope with the rising cost of living. Some say this is just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: For eight days in late August, the Port of Felixstowe — usually a scene of constant motion as Britain’s busiest container shipping dock — was almost devoid of activity, with few goods coming in or out. For the first time in more than three decades, its workers were on strike.

headline: Fed Officials May Be Encouraged by the Latest Labor Data
abstract: Policymakers are looking for signs that interest rate increases are cooling off the labor market, affecting wages, purchases and ultimately prices.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are likely to see the August jobs numbers as a sign their policies are working — though not that their job is done.

headline: Job Market Cooled but Was Still Strong in August
abstract: The monthly employment report suggested that the Federal Reserve might be able to tame inflation without causing a recession.
lead_paragraph: Job growth slowed in August but remained strong, offering fresh hope that policymakers will be able to bring down inflation without causing a recession.

headline: Step Right Up, Mr. Tough Guy, and Try Enduring Menstrual Cramps
abstract: A campaign in India aims to end the shame and silence around monthly periods and to introduce better hygiene products.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— Faheem Rahman clutched his stomach tight and winced in pain. When after a couple of minutes he could not bear it any more, he shrieked, throwing his head back.

headline: Vancouver’s Unconventional Approach to Its Fentanyl Crisis
abstract: The Canadian city has taken the concept of harm reduction to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.
lead_paragraph: An influx of Fentanyl, a highly lethal synthetic narcotic, has aggravated the opioid crisis in the United States and prompted communities to scramble for ways to lower the skyrocketing rates of overdose deaths.

headline: A Fair Auctioned a Beloved Goat. Its Owners Filed a Federal Lawsuit.
abstract: A Northern California woman said her young daughter bonded with a goat named Cedar that she was caring for. Sheriff’s deputies hauled it away to slaughter.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, Jessica Long’s young daughter was taking care of the baby goat until it could be auctioned as livestock at the sprawling Shasta District Fair in Northern California.

headline: The Serena Effect
abstract: An improbable run at what may be her final U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of those sports stories that has become big enough to fascinate even people who don’t normally follow sports. At 7 p.m. Eastern tonight, Serena Williams’s improbable run at what seems to be her final U.S. Open will continue. To put it in context, my colleague Kurt Streeter — a Times columnist who played competitive tennis when he was young — is taking over today’s newsletter. — David Leonhardt

headline: How Californians Feel About Ripping Out Their Lawns
abstract: To some, a grassy front yard remains a beloved symbol of economic success. To others, they’re nothing more than a blight.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday. You told us how you feel about ripping out your lawns during the drought. Plus, California lawmakers approve a wave of aggressive new climate measures.

headline: Myanmar Gives More Prison Time to Its Best-Known Convict
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the politician and Nobel laureate, was found guilty of election fraud on Friday, a sign that the junta has no intention of easing its pressure on her.
lead_paragraph: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader who was detained in a coup last year, was sentenced to three more years in prison, with hard labor, on Friday when a court found her guilty of election fraud in a case that the army brought against her after her political party won in a landslide in 2020.

headline: Meet Starbucks’s New Chief Executive
abstract: Laxman Narasimhan most recently led Reckitt Benckiser, where he was tasked with turning around the consumer products conglomerate.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, DealBook broke the news that Starbucks had chosen Laxman Narasimhan as its next chief executive, a hire that puts the 55-year-old in line to run the world’s largest coffee chain and a global corporate giant. With unionization drives, rising inflation and other issues to contend with, that’s a venti-size job for anyone — but who, exactly, is Narasimhan?

headline: A Trip Home With Moneybagg Yo, Trap’s New Ambassador
abstract: The 30-year-old artist, whose last album topped the Billboard album chart, has grown into the biggest rap star to emerge from Memphis in a generation. His fifth LP is due this fall.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Moneybagg Yo — Bagg to his friends — doesn’t get back to his Memphis hometown as much as he’d like anymore, so when he returned one Friday in July, he was primed for the occasion. His top, shorts and sneakers: Louis Vuitton. His chains and earrings: weighty and bright. His nails: freshly buffed to a shine. His Cadillac Escalade: bulletproof.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Premiere Recap: All Is Not Calm in Middle-Earth
abstract: Amazon’s ambitious “Lord of the Rings” prequel series has finally arrived. Here are seven takeaways from the first two episodes.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Amazon bought the television rights to J.R.R. Tolkien’s “The Lord of the Rings,” committing to spend around a billion dollars — at least — to make a five-season prestige drama series, set thousands of years before the events in Tolkien’s novels. Since then, Tolkien fans have obsessed over every tease of the show’s possible story lines and characters. Meanwhile, industry-watchers have questioned whether Amazon’s Prime Video service can deliver a “Game of Thrones”-level action-fantasy event.

headline: Price Cap on Russian Oil Wins Backing of G7 Ministers
abstract: The proposal aims to stabilize unsettled energy markets in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. But it faces considerable obstacles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top officials from the world’s leading advanced economies agreed on Friday to move ahead with a plan to cap the price of Russian oil, accelerating an ambitious effort to limit how much money Russia can earn from each barrel of crude it sells on the global market.

headline: Beware of Scammers Trying to Capitalize on Student Loan Forgiveness
abstract: The recent action on student debt is fodder for spam callers, who often try to trick borrowers into paying for loan cancellation.
lead_paragraph: Shady callers are acting quickly on President Biden’s announcement last week to cancel up to $20,000 in federal student debt for millions of borrowers. As Americans await more details about the plan, these callers are already dialing consumers, misleadingly warning them that time is running out.

headline: A price cap on Russian oil wins the backing of G7 ministers.
abstract: WASHINGTON — The top economic officials of the world’s leading advanced economies agreed on Friday to forge ahead with a plan to form an international buyers’ cartel to cap the price of Russian oil, accelerating an ambitious effort to avoid a price shock while draining President Vladimir V. Putin’s war chest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top economic officials of the world’s leading advanced economies agreed on Friday to forge ahead with a plan to form an international buyers’ cartel to cap the price of Russian oil, accelerating an ambitious effort to avoid a price shock while draining President Vladimir V. Putin’s war chest.

headline: A Van Carrying Factory Workers Crashes in New Jersey, Killing 4
abstract: The vehicle overturned on Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., early Friday. In addition to the deaths, eight people were injured.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed and eight injured when a passenger van overturned on the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., early Friday, according to the police.

headline: Nellie Mae Rowe Levels the Wall Between Insider and Outsider Art
abstract: The artist has been a major — if underrecognized — American talent. But the biggest look yet at her achievement gives it a whole new stature.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve paid any attention to that roiling mass of talent variously known over the past century as folk, naïve, primitive, Art Brut, self-taught or outsider, chances are you’ve come across the infectious creations of Nellie Mae Rowe (1900-1982). They rivet the eye with bright, dense colors, ingenious patterns and thickets of line and buoyant, sometimes bulbous figures and animals. Arranged in the topsy-turvy manner of a patchwork quilt, these elements fill the page and push forward with an energy that is both modern and primal.

headline: The Jobs Report Could Be Seen as Good News for Biden
abstract: Slowing job growth and rising worker participation follow the president’s road map for economic transition
lead_paragraph: Slowing job and wage growth, alongside rising labor force participation in August, is good news for President Biden and his hopes for a smooth transition to a more stable economic expansion.

headline: Biden calls on Americans to resist threats to democracy.
abstract: In a prime-time speech on Thursday evening, President Biden warned that America’s democratic values were under assault by forces of extremism loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In a prime-time speech on Thursday evening, President Biden warned that America’s democratic values were under assault by forces of extremism loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: David Sedaris’s Diaries
abstract: The essayist talks about his book “Theft by Finding,” a selection of diary entries spanning 25 years that helped him find and shape his voice as a writer.
lead_paragraph: For the next few months, we’re sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcast’s archives. This one was originally published on June 2, 2017.

headline: In Kenyan Elections, the People Decide First. Then Come the Judges.
abstract: The Supreme Court is expected to rule by Monday on whether the recent election of William Ruto as president, now mired in a welter of conflicting accusations, should stand.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — With its hefty price tag and sophisticated anti-rigging measures, Kenya’s recent presidential election was supposed to be among the best that money could buy — an elaborate system that experts said was more transparent than those in many Western countries, posting online tens of thousands of results in a matter of hours.

headline: Money to Burn: Lessons From the Premier League’s Transfer Window
abstract: English teams awash in cash broke records for players and prices this summer, proving again that they operate on a plane apart from their rivals.
lead_paragraph: To take just one snapshot from just one day in a whole summer of indulgence and excess, there was a point, last week, during which all of these things were happening at the same time:

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a medical nightmare come to life, a rural tale of time travel and ghosts, and a spooky Arctic boat trip.
lead_paragraph: Watching Seth A Smith’s debut feature is a grueling experience. But since “Tin Can” is a hybrid of science fiction and body horror, consider this praise. The film begins with the news that an untreatable disease dubbed Coral is spreading uncontrollably, covering the afflicted in Cronenbergian growths that look like creepy white plastic grafted onto flesh. Just as the scientist Fret (Anna Hopkins, “The Expanse”) has a breakthrough in her search for a cure, she is knocked out and wakes up, after an indeterminate amount of time, hooked to various tubes in a small capsule. Shot almost entirely in punishing close-ups, the scene might trigger oppressive claustrophobia in some viewers. Not that the rest of the movie pulls away all that much. Smith complements the suffocating visuals with an elaborate sound design involving an anxiety-inducing assortment of squeaks, gurgles, moans, whispers, whimpers and clangs that make “Tin Can” well worth watching with headphones. Explanations are dispensed in a slow drip — the idea of rich people getting themselves put under until Coral can be controlled is all too credible — but the movie succeeds as a medical nightmare come to life.

headline: The Many Lives of Martine Syms
abstract: The polyphonic artist finds ways to enjoy the harrowing business of putting herself, or versions of it, on display.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As self-portraits go, the video “DED” by Martine Syms is a bit masochistic. The artist’s digital avatar strolls across a flat, featureless limbo, enduring several gruesome deaths. Seppuku with a chef’s knife. Crippling, fatal allergies. Diarrhea so explosive she rockets into the sky like a rag doll, then dies from the fall. Then, somehow, she gets up and keeps walking.

headline: In a Surprise, Russia Says the Gas Pipeline to Germany Will Remain Closed
abstract: Nord Stream 1, operated by state-owned Gazprom, won’t reopen Saturday as expected, heightening fears Russia will step up its use of energy to pressure Europe.
lead_paragraph: Gazprom said on Friday that it would postpone restarting the flow of natural gas through a closely watched pipeline that connects Russia and Germany, an unexpected delay that appeared to be part of a larger struggle between Moscow and the West over energy and the war in Ukraine.

headline: How and When to Watch NASA’s Giant Rocket Launch to the Moon
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about Artemis I and the second attempt to launch the Space Launch System and Orion capsule.
lead_paragraph: This article is now outdated. Read more about the scrubbed NASA moon launch.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A review of “The Rings of Power.” Also in this edition: how pizza rolls were hit by supply chain issues, and the mink that became a YouTube star.
lead_paragraph: A review of “The Rings of Power.” Also in this edition: how pizza rolls were hit by supply chain issues, and the mink that became a YouTube star.

headline: An A.I.-Generated Picture Won an Art Prize. Artists Aren’t Happy.
abstract: “I won, and I didn’t break any rules,” the artwork’s creator says.
lead_paragraph: This year, the Colorado State Fair’s annual art competition gave out prizes in all the usual categories: painting, quilting, sculpture.

headline: A Times Climate Event: Can Technology and Art Inspire Change?
abstract: Hear from business leaders like Laurene Powell Jobs and John Doerr, along with storytellers and food innovators in a livestreamed Times event in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Where might solutions for addressing climate change come from? How might innovation and arts and culture spark change? What’s the role of the everyday person?

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Bryan Washington brings us a recipe for bánh cuốn, and we have lots of options for the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Hi! It’s not Sam. Or Melissa. Or Priya. It’s me, Kim Severson.

headline: Page, Stage and Screen: How Well Do You Know This Author?
abstract: This writer’s novels found new audiences on the Broadway stage and in movie theaters. Can you guess who?
lead_paragraph: This writer’s novels found new audiences on the Broadway stage and in movie theaters. Can you guess who?

headline: They Were at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Now They’re Running for Congress.
abstract: A handful of Republicans who heeded President Donald J. Trump’s call to march to the Capitol are now vying to return to Washington, this time as lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As rioters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Derrick Van Orden, a retired Navy SEAL, had a front-row seat to the mayhem, perching on the grounds beside a tall, intricately carved, sandstone lantern pier.

headline: Against Fierce Resistance, Ukraine Makes Small Gains in the South
abstract: Stepping up an offensive in the region near Kherson, Ukraine has retaken small villages. But officials predict a brutal winter ahead.
lead_paragraph: KRYVYI RIH, Ukraine — After weeks of pounding Russian supply lines and logistical hubs, the Ukrainian military pushed forward this week with its southern counteroffensive, breaking through some frontline defenses to retake several small villages and signaling its ability to strike a larger force that has spent months preparing for such an attack.

headline: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
abstract: A bunch of movies and TV shows are leaving the streaming service for U.S. subscribers in September. These are the ones not to miss.
lead_paragraph: A sci-fi classic, an iconic cop movie, two satisfyingly silly comedies and an Oscar winner for best picture are among the movies leaving Netflix in the United States this month, along with a handful of cult-favorite TV shows and a big hit from a recently departed director. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Biden and Trump: ‘Contrasting Visions for America’
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s sharp words about Donald Trump and MAGA Republicans. Also: Iran nuclear deal; Crimea attacks; New York City skyline.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: F.B.I. Found 48 Empty Folders That Had Contained Classified Documents at Trump’s Home
abstract: A detailed inventory of items seized in the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago raised the question of whether the government had fully recovered the documents or any remained missing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida club and residence last month turned up 48 empty folders marked as containing classified information, a newly disclosed court filing shows, raising the question of whether the government had fully recovered the documents or any remain missing.

headline: Hungry for Cash, Zeldin Turns to Trump in N.Y. Governor’s Race
abstract: Representative Lee Zeldin is depending on Donald J. Trump’s stature to help him in a crucial race for cash, even though Mr. Trump is unpopular in New York.
lead_paragraph: Republicans running statewide in a Democrat-dominated state like New York often follow a predictable path toward the political center. On Sunday, though, Representative Lee Zeldin will take a different route — south to the Jersey Shore for a fund-raiser starring former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Gina McCarthy, Biden’s Top Climate Adviser, to Step Down Sept. 16
abstract: As the country’s first national climate adviser, Ms. McCarthy helped seed climate policy throughout the federal government.

headline: How to Clean Your Toaster
abstract: Don't forget the crumb tray.
lead_paragraph: Don't forget the crumb tray.

headline: Trump Embraces Conspiracy Theories He Only Winked at Before
abstract: The former president’s activity on his social network, Truth Social, openly promotes far-right and conspiratorial ideas that are usually confined to corners of the internet.
lead_paragraph: In a 24-hour period this week, former President Donald J. Trump posted to his social media platform, Truth Social, 88 times, amplifying one conspiracy theory after another.

headline: The Dreamiest Shrimp Pasta Anchors This Summery Menu
abstract: Overindulge at the market? Turn sweet peppers into a starter, toss the corn into a pasta main and finish the meal with a berry-topped lemony Prosecco slush.
lead_paragraph: There’s an eye-popping display at the farmers’ market right now. If you feel like cooking, meander the overflowing vegetable stalls, grab anything and take it home for dinner. It’s bound to be at peak ripeness, juicy and sweet, no matter what it is. Peppers, tomatoes, corn, cucumbers, fresh herbs, stone fruit, berries, melons: We are gleefully overwhelmed with choice.

headline: In Familiar Works, a Chance for Black Film and TV Actors to Shine
abstract: On Broadway this fall, it’s less about new playwrights making their debuts and more about established stars giving the stage a shot.
lead_paragraph: One of the most exciting parts of the 2021-22 Broadway season was the number of people who looked like me, both onstage and behind the scenes. We saw the Broadway debut of seven plays by Black playwrights, starring Black actors, in an art form that too often tokenizes people of color, alienates them, misrepresents them or ignores them altogether.

headline: Serena’s Game Day Hair
abstract: Serena Williams’s on-court hairstyles: 27 years of self-expression.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s on-court hairstyles: 27 years of self-expression.

headline: Romeo Santos and Justin Timberlake’s Team-Up, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Shygirl, Ava Max, Horse Lords and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness
abstract: New research shows small gestures matter even more than we may think.
lead_paragraph: In late August, Erin Alexander, 57, sat in the parking lot of a Target store in Fairfield, Calif., and wept. Her sister-in-law had recently died, and Ms. Alexander was having a hard day.

headline: Wonking Out: The Nightmare After Gorbachev
abstract: Why did Russia’s economy do so poorly?
lead_paragraph: Most articles on the death of Mikhail Gorbachev dwell on the political failure of his reform project. The Russian Federation, the main successor state to the Soviet Union, has not, to say the least, become a democratic, open society. Ukraine may finally have gotten there, but that very success is probably one major reason the country is now fighting for its life against Russian invasion.

headline: Overlooked No More: Vera Menchik, First Women’s Chess Champion
abstract: As the only woman in a tournament, she was often greeted with skepticism. She once responded by saying that she looked forward “to drinking some men’s blood.”
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Low-Cook Lifestyle
abstract: When it’s just too hot out, lean into cheesy kimchi noodles, hummus plates and flavorful chicken salads.
lead_paragraph: Hi, Five Weeknight Dishers. It’s Krysten, this newsletter’s editor, stepping in for Emily.

headline: Biden, Remaking Climate Team, Picks John Podesta to Guide Spending
abstract: Mr. Podesta, a Democratic stalwart, will oversee $370 billion in clean energy investments. Gina McCarthy, the president’s domestic climate adviser, is stepping down.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday appointed John Podesta, a veteran Washington insider who spearheaded the Obama administration’s climate strategy, to oversee the federal investment of $370 billion in clean energy under a landmark new climate law.

headline: A mother-daughter generational divide
abstract: My mom loves cars, but I despise them. Our yearslong debate is a window into the connection between our personal choices and the future of our climate.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — “Hey, why don’t you have a car?”

headline: The Sound of the Vikings, With a Heavy Metal Twist
abstract: The band Heilung performs on replica instruments to recreate the sound world of pre-Christian Europe and bring it into the modern age.
lead_paragraph: BORRE, Norway — “We have vegan potato salad in the medium cauldron,” Maria Franz announced to the 17 members of Heilung, her folk metal band, as they gathered around a campfire here recently. The band was celebrating the release of its third album, “Drif,” at Midgardsblot, a festival that takes place on a Viking burial ground and also includes seminars on Viking culture for an audience of campers, many of whom were dressed up in tunics and cloaks. Earlier that day, festivalgoers joined the band to listen to the new album while sitting on the floor of a replica Viking feast hall rigged up with a speaker system.

headline: How Did T.S. Eliot Go From Young and Wild to Old and Stodgy?
abstract: “Eliot After ‘The Waste Land,’” the second volume of Robert Crawford’s two-part biography, offers some answers — and some revelations.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly 100 years ago, T.S. Eliot published a wildly experimental, cacophonous and moving poem of despair and spiritual hunger, forged in the flames and devastation of the First World War. Together with James Joyce’s equally groundbreaking experimental novel “Ulysses,” which appeared at the same moment, “The Waste Land” seemed to epitomize the radical new brand of art and literature that would come to be known as modernism; as Eliot’s friend Ezra Pound put it, the poem felt like “the justification of our modern experiment since 1900.” Even those who disliked it recognized the poem’s enormous significance and influence — the American poet William Carlos Williams, who viewed Eliot’s poetic project as the antithesis of his own, later lamented that “The Waste Land” “wiped out our world as if an atom bomb had been dropped upon it.”

headline: Paul W.S. Anderson and Milla Jovovich: A Marriage Built on Monsters
abstract: In 20 years and several “Resident Evil” films, the couple has found their love language in action — and a lot of blood and dust.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Paul W. S. Anderson has directed Milla Jovovich in no less than four films in the apocalyptic “Resident Evil” franchise, and written two more she starred in. That’s in addition to directing her in “Monster Hunter” (2020) and a 2011 version of “The Three Musketeers.”

headline: Love Letter: What Would You Do?
abstract: Infidelity on the eve of an international move.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you slip and shatter your kneecap; you have a trying year, rehabilitating your knee while working and raising two children; your husband gets a job offer in New Zealand; he wants you to go with him; you decide to take the leap and move your life and children overseas; as you’re packing the kitchen cupboard, you discover a message on your husband’s phone: “I had a dream last night … I kissed you a lot, a lot.”

headline: What Are Your Lessons From Remote Work?
abstract: We’re looking for advice.
lead_paragraph: As we head into fall, some companies are finally recalling their employees to the office (including The New York Times).

headline: Barbara Ehrenreich, Explorer of Prosperity’s Dark Side, Dies at 81
abstract: Her book “Nickel and Dimed,” an undercover account of the indignities of being a low-wage worker in the United States, is considered a classic in social justice literature.
lead_paragraph: It was a casual meeting.

headline: Kazuo Inamori, Major Industrialist in Postwar Japan, Dies at 90
abstract: Founding two giant companies, he helped turn his country into an economic giant while encouraging employees to approach work with an almost spiritual devotion.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kazuo Inamori, one of the great Japanese industrialists of the postwar generation, who founded two multibillion-dollar companies and pulled another back from the brink of bankruptcy, died on Aug. 24 in Kyoto, Japan. He was 90.

headline: Science Is on His Dance Card
abstract: The visual artist Charles Atlas started his video career with Merce Cunningham, but his new Pioneer Works project shows how many leaps he has taken since.
lead_paragraph: On a hot day in July the pioneering film and video maker Charles Atlas seemed a little anxious about his latest sprawling piece, “The Mathematics of Consciousness,” opening Sept. 9 at Pioneer Works, the nonprofit cultural center in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Richard Roat, Seen on ‘Cheers,’ ‘Friends’ and ‘Seinfeld,’ Dies at 89
abstract: A familiar TV face for years, he appeared on many of the most popular prime-time shows of recent decades.
lead_paragraph: Richard Roat, a versatile character actor whose half-century-long career was punctuated by notable guest appearances on three of the most popular sitcoms of recent decades, “Cheers,” “Friends” and “Seinfeld,” died on Aug. 5 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Newly Published, From Lost Worlds to Whale Talk
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: CIVIL SERVICE: Poems, by Claire Schwartz. (Graywolf, paper, $16.) Schwartz’s debut collection casts a critical eye on the bureaucratic apparatus that allows injustices to thrive. If racism (or empire, or patriarchy) is structural, these poems say, here is the structure that sustains it, via ordinary workers like curators and interns and prison guards.

headline: After a Climate Catastrophe, These Birds Flocked to the Moon
abstract: “Birds of Maine,” about a colony of birds fleeing disaster, showcases Michael DeForge’s trademark blend of the enigmatic and the ridiculous.
lead_paragraph: A new release from Michael DeForge should be met with trumpet blasts across the length and breadth of the book world. With his artistry, intellect and wit, it’s a mystery why he hasn’t been dubbed the next Dan Clowes or Chris Ware by now. Not that DeForge’s style bears any resemblance to those two standard-bearers of ’90s comics — or that he hasn’t collected his share of praise (plus a smattering of awards) since he began publishing in the late 2000s. But he deserves to be known even by those who don’t necessarily follow comics.

headline: In Montauk, Big Money Moves In On a Surfers’ Paradise
abstract: The acres overlooking a prize stretch of Long Island’s East End were empty for years. Now they’ve been sold in multimillion-dollar deals. It’s been the talk of the beach all summer.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — Ditch Plains Beach is the heart of the surf scene in Montauk, a two-mile stretch of dunes and sea at the tip of Long Island’s East End with views of sand cliffs to the east and west.

headline: Iran Seizes, Then Releases Two U.S. Drones, Officials Say
abstract: The Navy called a similar incident this week “flagrant” and “unwarranted.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran seized two American maritime drones operating in the Red Sea on Thursday, three U.S. defense officials said, the latest naval incident in a string of late-summer spats between Washington and Tehran.

headline: Jane Krakowski Cherishes ‘Chorus Line’ Merch and Old Tonys Tapings
abstract: The “Schmigadoon!” actress explains the things that keep her in a Broadway state of mind: her Vespa, Lizzo’s music and French Fries.
lead_paragraph: The actress Jane Krakowski is proud that “Schmigadoon!,” the Apple TV+ musical comedy series she stars in, gave people a dose of theatricality when it premiered during Broadway’s lockdown in 2021, even with an unusual production period Covid restrictions.

headline: A Volcano Erupted Without Warning. Now, Scientists Know Why.
abstract: A new study explains how Nyiragongo, a volcano in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was relatively quiet before its eruption last year took everyone by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Last year, one of the most dangerous volcanoes in Africa erupted without warning.

headline: Venice: A Creepy ‘Call Me by Your Name’ Reunion in ‘Bones and All’
abstract: In this cannibal romance, the director Luca Guadagnino reunites Timothée Chalamet with Michael Stuhlbarg under very different circumstances.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — There is a message that social scientists and environmental watchdogs have been trying to convey in this newspaper for a while. But maybe you haven’t really been listening. Maybe it will take a different messenger to catch your attention.

headline: South African Villagers Win Suit to Halt Shell’s Oil Exploration
abstract: A judicial panel ruled the energy giant had not properly consulted local communities, possibly setting a broader precedent for challenges to offshore drilling activities.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In a case that pitted rural South African communities against the energy giant Shell Global, a judicial panel ordered a halt this week to the company’s plans to explore a pristine coastline for oil and gas, saying the residents were not properly consulted on the project.

headline: Both Parties Flood New Hampshire With Ads About the Same Senate Candidate
abstract: On the surface, both sides’ ads are about Chuck Morse, who is running in the Republican primary for U.S. Senate. But their real target, unnamed in the ads, is Don Bolduc, the hard-right front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another deluge of outside money into New Hampshire’s Republican Senate primary.

headline: Investigators, Citing Looting, Have Seized 27 Antiquities From the Met
abstract: The museum said it is cooperating with the Manhattan district attorney’s office, which has executed several search warrants at the museum since February.
lead_paragraph: Investigators in New York have seized 27 ancient artifacts valued at more than $13 million from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, asserting that the objects, acquired to showcase the glories of ancient Rome, Greece and Egypt, had all been looted.

headline: Parler Returns to Google Play Store
abstract: Google said that Parler had more robust content moderation practices than it did when it was banned in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 riot.
lead_paragraph: Parler, the social media service that attracted fans of former President Donald J. Trump, will return to Google’s Play app store on Friday, more than a year after Google suspended the app for content that incited violence.

headline: ‘This worries me a lot.’ U.N. nuclear watchdog says shelling at Ukrainian plant still poses a grave risk.
abstract: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned that increased fighting near the Russian-occupied nuclear plant could cause an accident.
lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — The gravest risk to the embattled Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant is physical damage to equipment from shelling that could lead to a release of radiation, the director of the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency said Friday after a visit to the site.

headline: This Salad Silences the Okra Critics
abstract: Filled with crisp broiled okra and served with a garlicky yogurt dressing, this summery recipe is deeply lovable.
lead_paragraph: Up against the wide-ranging appeal of sweet corn and juicy, ripe tomatoes, okra will probably never be crowned summer’s most popular vegetable. But those of us who love it do so passionately, whether it’s stewed until silky, fried until crunchy or, as this recipe showcases, broiled until the edges crisp and the center softens — and without any of the gooeyness that gives some people pause.

headline: College Football Playoff Will Expand to 12 Teams
abstract: The change could take effect as soon as the 2024 season. It is expected no later than 2026.
lead_paragraph: The College Football Playoff, already a financial gusher for the country’s most powerful conferences, will triple in size to 12 teams no later than the 2026 season as organizers seek to capitalize on the nation’s vast appetite for the sport.

headline: 29 Reasons to Make a Date With a New York Restaurant
abstract: After fits and starts, New York restaurateurs are ready to return to business as prepandemic usual, with a flurry of reboots, expansions and cuisine pivots.
lead_paragraph: New York restaurateurs offer a robust fall lineup despite reduced hours because of staff shortages caused by the pandemic. This is a season of restaurant reopenings. Down time during the pandemic permitted a number of favorites to renovate and some of the city’s major destination areas to offer new dining options. For others, unsuccessful lease negotiations forced closings, but several soon found new locations close enough to keep their loyal customers. Well-loved places are reopening in new surroundings or adding nearby satellite locations, and some familiar chefs are rebooting and broadening their repertoires. The most tempting newcomers are those that till new ground: There are enough cookie-cutter lists of tuna tartare, Caesar salad, fried calamari, grilled branzino and fillet of beef.

headline: Bueckers Says She’ll Stay in School. (That’s Where the Money Is.)
abstract: UConn guard Paige Bueckers could jump to the W.N.B.A. when she recovers from her knee injury. But experts said she may be better off financially by staying in college.
lead_paragraph: Some college basketball fans have been wondering whether Paige Bueckers, the star UConn guard who will miss the season with a knee injury, would enter the W.N.B.A. draft after this season instead of returning for her senior year with the Huskies.

headline: Archie Roach, Who Lived and Sang the Aboriginal Blues, Dies at 66
abstract: His song “Took the Children Away,” inspired by his childhood, shook Australians into confronting a grim era when their government tore apart Aboriginal families.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1970, Archie Cox’s high school English class in Melbourne, Australia, was interrupted by a voice from the intercom: “Could Archibald William Roach come to the office?”

headline: WordleBot’s Word Switch: ‘Slate’ Is Out, and ‘Crane’ Is Back In
abstract: An update on the bot’s preferred opening guess, and some small changes.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, we introduced WordleBot 2.0, an update to our (mostly) beloved and still occasionally supercilious tool that will analyze and rate your Wordle play. In that update, we noted that the new way the bot thinks about information means that the bot’s preferred opening guess may change.

headline: The Founders of a Nation Should Not Have the Last Word
abstract: Chileans are debating how to rewrite the nation’s Constitution to address their society’s most stubborn problems.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Writing a new Constitution strikes many Americans as a transgressive idea. Our Constitution is the oldest in the world, and it has come to seem immutable. The last really substantive change was a 1971 amendment lowering the voting age to 18. Instead of updating a text written more than 200 years ago, Americans have come to rely on the imaginations of nine justices who decide what they think it should say.

headline: With Midterms Looming, McConnell’s Woes Pile Up
abstract: The minority leader who takes pride in his status as the “grim reaper” of his rivals’ agenda has allowed Democrats to claim policy victories as his party’s hopes of reclaiming the Senate dim.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader, spent the summer watching Democrats score a series of legislative victories of the sort he once swore he would thwart.

headline: Proving Racists Wrong Is Not a Trivial Pursuit
abstract: Underestimation should be countered with demonstration, not indignation.
lead_paragraph: To be a “heterodox” Black thinker on race is to be often accused of claiming that racism is extinct or doesn’t matter. For example, when he reviewed my book “Woke Racism” for The Washington Post, The Nation’s Elie Mystal described it as “a pleasing bedtime story to a certain kind of white person who is always looking for a magic Black person to tell them what they want to hear.”

headline: The Prison Letters Project
abstract: Emily Bazelon knew she would receive more letters after the exoneration of Yutico Briley. With the help of a group of students at Yale Law School, their claims of innocence will be heard.
lead_paragraph: Last July, The New York Times Magazine published a cover story by Emily Bazelon about the exoneration of a prisoner named Yutico Briley. He was serving a 60-year sentence in Louisiana for an armed robbery he did not commit. The article started with a letter that Yutico sent to Bazelon from prison. As she explained in her story: “Like many journalists who write about criminal justice, I get a lot of mail from people in prison. The letters usually go on for pages, carefully handwritten on lined note paper, sometimes with sentences in smaller print crawling up the margins. The pages are dense with facts, about a conviction or an appeal. They often brim with desperation. It’s impossible for me to read all of them, and though I don’t feel good about it, many go unanswered.”

headline: California Biotech Executive Is Guilty in $77 Million Blood-Testing Scheme
abstract: Arrayit Corporation claimed to have invented a technology to test for any disease using a drop of blood, including Covid-19 and cancer.
lead_paragraph: A biotech executive in California was convicted on Thursday of orchestrating a $77 million scheme involving false and fraudulent claims for Covid-19 and allergy testing, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Jane Fonda Says She Has Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
abstract: The actress said that she had begun chemotherapy and vowed not to “let any of this interfere with my climate activism.”
lead_paragraph: The actress Jane Fonda announced on Friday that she had been diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, a treatable form of cancer of the lymph system, and that she would be undergoing chemotherapy treatments for six months.

headline: Pete Buttigieg Is Trying to Fix Air Travel With a ‘Dashboard.’ What’s on It?
abstract: The D.O.T. says its new interactive chart is compelling many U.S. airlines to publicly commit to pay for things like hotels and meals when flights are canceled or significantly delayed. But does it have teeth?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Department of Transportation unveiled its most concrete endeavor yet to fix air travel: an online dashboard featuring 10 U.S. airlines with green check marks next to the services they offer when flights are delayed or canceled for reasons within their control. The website, which is reminiscent of the sort of brand comparison charts offered up by Consumer Reports magazine, reveals, for example, that JetBlue and Hawaiian Airlines will, in some circumstances, rebook passengers on another airline when a flight is canceled, but that Southwest and Alaska will not.

headline: All Eyes Are on Serena, but What Are Venus’s Plans?
abstract: Venus Williams has not been clear about when (or if) she plans to retire from tennis.
lead_paragraph: Since Serena Williams announced in August that she plans to retire after this year’s U.S. Open, all eyes have been on her and what has turned into her farewell tour. But what’s next for Venus Williams is unclear.

headline: Barr Dismisses Trump’s Request for a Special Master
abstract: The former attorney general, who chose not to indict Mr. Trump in the Russia inquiry, said the Justice Department was justified in investigating his handling of government materials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Attorney General William P. Barr dismissed former President Donald J. Trump’s call for an independent review of materials seized from his Florida home on Friday — and said an inventory of items recovered in the search last month seemed to support the Justice Department’s claim that it was needed to safeguard national security.

headline: Resentful, Media-Savvy and Paving the Way for Trump
abstract: In “Partisans,” Nicole Hemmer zeros in on ’90s figures like Pat Buchanan as guiding forces behind the Republican Party’s hard-right, conspiracy-minded turn.
lead_paragraph: American political history is not always terribly complicated, but even its simplest lessons can be little match for our collective amnesia. How surprised should we be, really, to learn that “America First,” one of Donald Trump’s favored campaign slogans, was used by a pair of also-ran presidential candidates in 1992 — the hard-core right-wing commentator Pat Buchanan and the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke?

headline: White House Requests $47 Billion for Pandemic Response and Ukraine Aid
abstract: The request to Congress comes as lawmakers face a Sept. 30 deadline to finish annual funding bills for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Friday formally requested $47.1 billion in emergency spending from Congress, including almost $27 billion that officials say is critical to continue fighting the coronavirus pandemic and the monkeypox outbreak.

headline: This article was published in error.
abstract: This article was published in error.
lead_paragraph: This article was published in error.

headline: U.N. Inspects Zaporizhzhia
abstract: The U.N. nuclear watchdog warns of grave risk from shelling.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Hawaii Closes Its Last Coal-Fired Power Plant
abstract: A state law bans the use of coal for energy production beginning next year.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii shuttered its last remaining coal-fired power station on Thursday, a major milestone in the state’s ambitious effort to transition to 100 percent renewable energy by 2045.

headline: The gas pipeline connecting Russia to Germany remains closed.
abstract: Gazprom postponed restarting the flow of natural gas through a closely watched pipeline that connects Russia and Germany, an unexpected delay that appeared to be part of a larger struggle between Moscow and the West over energy and the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Gazprom postponed restarting the flow of natural gas through a closely watched pipeline that connects Russia and Germany, an unexpected delay that appeared to be part of a larger struggle between Moscow and the West over energy and the war in Ukraine.

headline: Pennsylvania Stakes Its Claim as Center of the Political Universe
abstract: Few states feature as many high-stakes, competitive races, each pulsing with the political currents that are shaping midterm campaigns across the country.
lead_paragraph: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — Pennsylvania, the site of crucial victories and devastating defeats for both political parties in recent elections, has emerged as the nation’s center of political gravity and its ultimate battleground as peak campaign season arrives.

headline: In Oracene Price, a ‘Hall of Fame’ Mother
