abstract: The mother of Serena and Venus Williams has always been a beacon of calm and grace on the sidelines — even now, in what may be a turning point in her daughters’ lives.
lead_paragraph: The crowd roared. People sprang from their seats in an explosion of cheers and applause. Serena Williams had taken the lead against No. 2 seed Anett Kontaveit during their second-round match at this year’s U.S. Open tournament.

headline: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
abstract: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Brittany Packnett Cunningham, 37, a racial equality activist, podcast host and a new mother, stayed up late to watch Serena Williams, the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion, play her second-round match.

headline: Argentina Reels From Assassination Attempt on Its Powerful Vice President
abstract: The man who the authorities believe tried to shoot Cristina Fernández de Kirchner showed an interest in a mix of fringe ideologies, including the far right, his social media showed.
lead_paragraph: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner has been the most prominent politician in Argentina for almost two decades. After an eight-year run as president, she is now the country’s leftist vice president, and political analysts are expecting her to make a bid to return to the top job next year.

headline: Americans Think Our Democracy Is on the Brink. So Does Biden.
abstract: We examine the president’s speech in Philadelphia with Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House reporter.

headline: Russell Wilson, Ciara among the celebrities in the stands for Williams’s match.
abstract: Also in attendance to watch Williams in Round 3 of the U.S. Open were the rapper Pusha T and the actress Heidi Gardner.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams continues to attract celebrities and politicians to her U.S. Open matches. In attendance Friday:the N.F.L. quarterback Russell Wilson and his wife, the singer Ciara; the rapper Pusha T; the actress Heidi Gardner; and the former Yankees pitcher C.C. Sabathia. Williams is facing Ajla Tomljanovic of Australia.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Coco Gauff Is Playing With a Veteran’s Confidence
abstract: The 18-year-old has advanced to the round of 16 in singles at the U.S. Open for the first time in her career. On Sunday, she will face the unseeded Shuai Zhang of China.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Coco Gauff saw a photo memory from five years ago. It had the caption “courtside seats” at Arthur Ashe Stadium as she had watched one of her idols, Venus Williams, play.

headline: More Than 14,000 Strollers Recalled After Child’s Fingertip Is Amputated
abstract: Only one case has been reported involving an UPPAbaby All-Terrain RIDGE Jogging Stroller, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: More than 14,000 UPPAbaby brand strollers were recalled on Thursday after a child’s fingertip became caught in a brake and was amputated, according to a federal agency.

headline: The Biden administration asks Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underscoring its resolve.
abstract: The Biden administration on Friday asked Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underlining its commitment to support the war-battered country in a costly conflict that shows little sign of abating.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday asked Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underlining its commitment to support the war-battered country in a costly conflict that shows little sign of abating.

headline: Parties’ Divergent Realities Challenge Biden’s Defense of Democracy
abstract: The president seeks to confront threats to American institutions, but Americans are deeply divided on who is imperiling them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The good news is that deeply divided Americans agree on at least one thing. The bad news is they share the view that their nearly two-and-a-half-century-old democracy is in danger — and disagree drastically about who is threatening it.

headline: What if You Could Give Start-Up Money to People, Not Companies?
abstract: The entrepreneurial Liberman siblings are testing out the concept — on themselves.
lead_paragraph: What if you could hitch your wagon to an entrepreneurial star? You know someone who is creative and hardworking, and you want to write a check in exchange for a piece of whatever that person produces.

headline: Nine Migrants Drown as Dozens Are Swept Down Rio Grande
abstract: A large group attempting to cross into Texas was overcome by a fast-moving current, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Nine migrants drowned and 37 others were rescued as they tried to cross the raging waters of the Rio Grande to reach the United States on Thursday, administration officials said.

headline: California wildfire burns at least 50 structures and forces thousands to flee.
abstract: The Mill fire quickly spread to more than 4,000 acres, injured civilians and forced residents in the rural Northern California region to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: WEED, Calif. — A wind-whipped fire that erupted near a defunct lumber mill in Northern California on Friday and became a fast-moving inferno has destroyed at least 50 structures, including homes, and prompted the evacuation of thousands of people in rural Siskiyou County, fire authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Yas and Jas
abstract: David Distenfeld really sells this Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David Distenfeld’s fourth daily grid for The New York Times. Like his other themeless Friday and Saturday puzzles, this one brings us bawdy, zeitgeisty debuts. (Did any of today’s wordplay make you say CAN WE NOT? OK, BOOMER.) There are many surprises, but today a flexible mind will do as well as one stuffed with trivia.

headline: Manslaughter Indictment Dismissed in 2019 Dive Boat Fire That Killed 34
abstract: Prosecutors in California say they will seek to appeal a federal judge’s ruling that the charge against the vessel’s captain needed to allege gross negligence.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Los Angeles dismissed a manslaughter indictment against the captain of a dive boat that caught fire in 2019 off the coast of Southern California, killing all 33 passengers and one of six crew members, according to an order made public on Friday.

headline: Serena Williams, Moving Toward Retirement, Ends Her Magical Run at the U.S. Open
abstract: “It’s been the most incredible ride and journey I’ve ever been on in my life,” Williams, wiping tears, said on court after the match.
lead_paragraph: As Serena Williams walked onto the court at the U.S. Open this week, the question was how the greatest player in modern tennis would handle the pressures of what she said could be her last Grand Slam tournament.

headline: Hurricane Earl Weakens as It Heads Toward Newfoundland
abstract: The storm was expected to veer east away from land and become a powerful post-tropical cyclone.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Earl was downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone Saturday but was expected to bring strong winds over Newfoundland through Sunday, along with large swells along the U.S. East Coast.

headline: Explosion Kills 7 Police Officers in Colombia
abstract: Dozens of police officers have been killed in the country so far this year, as its new president struggles to quell a wave of violence he campaigned on ending.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — An explosion on Friday afternoon killed seven police officers who were heading to a social welfare event in Colombia’s southern department of Huila, according to the authorities. An eighth officer was hospitalized with injuries.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For Wheelchair Users, Flying Includes Risks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Sept. 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “When I fly nowadays, it literally is a moment of, ‘OK, what do I have to do to get through this day without getting injured more?’”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 3, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 12 about the disc jockey Zach Sang misstates the arrangement surrounding the ownership of his content and his plans for a new studio. Sang is building a studio in conjunction with a production partner, OBB Media, not alone. OBB Media will have partial ownership of his content for a period of time; he does not retain sole ownership.

headline: ‘We Do Not Want Unknown Graves’: The Struggle to Identify Bucha’s Victims
abstract: No longer able to defer burial, Ukrainian investigators are photographing unclaimed and unidentified bodies, taking DNA samples and assigning them numbers, hoping that one day their families will claim them.
lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — It was supposed to be the bright spot in a grim day. Of a dozen unclaimed bodies set for burial recently at Bucha City Cemetery, one had just been identified. The dead man’s family was present and would be able to bury him with full ceremony. His grave would be marked with his name instead of just a number.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Ex-President Returns Home, Just Weeks After Being Ousted
abstract: Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s fall from grace had seemed to end a powerful dynasty, but his arrival in the country’s capital, Colombo, shows how deeply entrenched his family is.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Gotabaya Rajapaksa, the former Sri Lankan president who was forced to flee the island nation and relinquish power after months of protest over the economy’s being run into the ground, returned home late on Friday.

headline: Serena’s Magic Comes to an End
abstract: This composite photo shows Serena Williams’s last match at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: This composite photo shows Serena Williams’s last match at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Lawsuits Over Tragedies Can Drag On. Not in the Florida Condo Collapse.
abstract: A little over a year after the Champlain Towers South fell, the Surfside condo victims’ families are about to be compensated for their losses.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Each day, before the unusual hearings unfolded inside Judge Michael A. Hanzman’s Miami courtroom this summer, the judge’s aides would stock the judge’s bench, the lawyers’ tables and the witness stand with boxes of tissues. At some point, they knew, almost everyone would cry, and each excruciating presentation would end with Judge Hanzman offering people hugs.

headline: Why Aren’t Student Loans Simple? Because This Is America.
abstract: Instead of making higher education free, we subsidize it later through repayment plans and attempts at debt cancellation. The complexity is disrespectful.
lead_paragraph: If we want higher education to cost less, we should make it cheaper when people enroll.

headline: Britain’s Pubs Are Threatened by ‘Alarming’ Rise in Energy Bills
abstract: Businesses have fewer protections than residential users against higher electricity and gas costs, and industry groups warn of widespread closings this winter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With every day that passes, Lindsey Armstrong’s dilemma gets worse as Britain’s energy crisis closes in on her pub.

headline: Decorating an Apartment, Sight Unseen
abstract: When an interior designer decided to make a big move during the worst months of the pandemic, she planned her new rental around several key pieces.
lead_paragraph: When an interior designer decided to make a big move during the worst months of the pandemic, she planned her new rental around several key pieces.

headline: How to Decorate a New York Apartment From Los Angeles, in a Few Easy Steps
abstract: When an interior designer decided to make a big move during the worst months of the pandemic, she planned her new rental around several key pieces.
lead_paragraph: When Jackie Terrell left her life behind during the worst months of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, she migrated to the East Coast from the West — unlike most Americans, who moved in the opposite direction. And she took her nest with her.

headline: Russians Mourn Gorbachev in Silent Protest Against an Absent Putin
abstract: At the funeral of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, the size of the crowds signaled the depth of the regret about the undoing of the freedoms that his tenure initiated.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Thousands of Russians on Saturday stood for several hours in snaking lines amid a heavy police presence to pay their respects to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, who died on Tuesday.

headline: What the F.B.I. Seized From Mar-a-Lago, Illustrated
abstract: An inventory of the materials taken from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home and private club in an Aug. 8 search includes dozens of documents with classified, secret or top secret markings and thousands more without.
lead_paragraph: An inventory of the materials taken from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home and private club in an Aug. 8 search includes dozens of documents with classified, secret or top secret markings and thousands more without.

headline: In Paul Theroux’s New Novel, a Sibling Rivalry Boils Over
abstract: “The Bad Angel Brothers” comes laden with jealousy, betrayal and a mythic lust for vengeance.
lead_paragraph: Tolstoy was wrong. There are no happy families, only less unhappy ones. At least that’s one takeaway from Paul Theroux’s latest novel. Born in 1941, and best known for “The Mosquito Coast,” Theroux is nothing if not productive. “The Bad Angel Brothers” is his 33rd work of fiction and 53rd book overall. In it, the fierce rivalry between two siblings comes laden with jealousy, betrayal and an almost mythic lust for vengeance.

headline: ‘That Nurse Should Be Alive’: How Police Delays Left a Suspect at Large
abstract: The New York Police Department let a suspect in a Brooklyn rape case slip through its grasp. A month later he was arrested in connection with the murder of a nurse in Queens.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 18, 2018, a hospital in New York City summoned the police to meet a woman who said she had been raped.

headline: A Photographer Who Tours with Beyoncé and Lewis Hamilton
abstract: Timothy McGurr captures intimate moments with big stars.
lead_paragraph: Name: Timothy McGurr

headline: Is There Such a Thing as Too Big for Baseball?
abstract: Aaron Judge is in line for a massive payday when he reaches free agency this off-season. The $300 million (or more) question is whether a player his size can stay healthy as he ages.
lead_paragraph: By several measures, Aaron Judge, the superstar outfielder for the Yankees, has been the best player in Major League Baseball this season. After Friday’s loss to Tampa Bay, he had a .294 batting average with a major league-leading 51 home runs and a 1.059 on-base plus slugging percentage. The closest hitter to him in the home run race, Philadelphia’s Kyle Schwarber, had 36.

headline: How the Editor in Chief of Elle Decor Spends His Sundays
abstract: Asad Syrkett stays close to his Brooklyn home, doing Pilates, seeing friends, burning incense and reading fiction.
lead_paragraph: When Asad Syrkett became the youngest-ever editor in chief of Hearst Magazines, one of his goals at Elle Decor, the interior design glossy he would be overseeing, was to enjoy himself. Two years in, Mr. Syrkett, 33, said he’s having the most fun of his career.

headline: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
abstract: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
lead_paragraph: Now that their son is grown and their water-loving Labrador retriever has passed away, Kristen Miller and her husband, Scott Miller, have decided to fill in their San Diego swimming pool. “No one uses it, there’s a drought and we’re in our 60s,” she said. “We decided YOLO, like the kids say. We’re gonna put in a frickin’ pickleball court.”

headline: Dressing for Hot: How a Warming Planet Is Changing What We Wear
abstract: A climate reporter in Washington set out to test clothes designed for keeping cool. He found a few good (but pricey) options, along with some questionable claims.
lead_paragraph: Shirts made from the same polymer as plastic bags. Jeans infused with crushed jade. Garments constructed using computerized knitting for superior ventilation, or made with cooling technology designed for astronauts by NASA.

headline: Serena Williams Willed Her Way to a Glorious Goodbye
abstract: Her last match — at the U.S. Open and probably of her career — was a gutsy display of the power and resilience that have kept fans cheering for nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: It was match point, which Serena Williams had faced many times before. It was career point, which was startlingly new territory for one of the greatest athletes of any era.

headline: At 66, Elizabeth Strout Has Reached Maximum Productivity
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author has written five books in six years and been nominated for a Booker Prize for “Oh William!” What’s gotten into her?
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Strout didn’t bat an eyelash when I admitted, moments after meeting her, that I’d snapped the handle off the toilet in her agent’s bathroom. I almost didn’t mention it — my plumbing skills are silent and efficient — but, knowing the cast of honest-to-a-fault characters who cycle through Strout’s novels, I had a hunch she’d appreciate my candor.

headline: They Have Debt but No Degree. Could Loan Forgiveness Send Them Back to School?
abstract: Millions took on debt for college but left without graduating, making it harder to repay their loans. Will the Biden administration’s relief plan get them to try again?
lead_paragraph: A car dealership employee is hoping she can return to community college with a clean slate. An operations manager is wondering whether he might be able to afford to buy a home. And a customer service representative is facing the bitter reality that she may never escape her decades-old debt.

headline: How Fake GPS Coordinates Are Leading to Lawlessness on the High Seas
abstract: A technology enabling the transmission of fake locations to carry out murky or even illegal business operations could have profound implications for the enforcement of international law.
lead_paragraph: The scrappy oil tanker waited to load fuel at a dilapidated jetty projecting from a giant Venezuelan refinery on a December morning. A string of abandoned ships listed in the surrounding turquoise Caribbean waters, a testament to the country’s decay after years of economic hardships and U.S. sanctions.

headline: Abortion Pill Providers Experiment With Ways to Broaden Access
abstract: These new efforts, which test the legal boundaries, have sprung up since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and many states restricted abortion.
lead_paragraph: As bans and restrictions proliferate across the country, abortion pill providers are pushing the envelope of regulations and laws to meet the surging demand for medication abortion in post-Roe America.

headline: Celebrating Creators of Design
abstract: A look at the international creative talent showcased at Paris Design Week and the London Design Festival.
lead_paragraph: Two of Europe’s liveliest design celebrations return this month, each a multiday, multilayered extravaganza fusing local character with international creative talent. Paris Design Week runs from Thursday through Sept. 17, with scores of exhibitions and events weaving through museums, monuments, parks, plazas, galleries and shops. A centerpiece is the Maison et Objet design fair.

headline: You’ve Seen a Bodega Cat. How About a Barber Shop Rooster?
abstract: New York City’s beloved bodega cats are internet famous. But other animals — birds, snakes and even pigs — are also at home in neighborhood shops.
lead_paragraph: Yes, New York’s beloved bodega cats are internet famous. An Instagram account dedicated to chronicling the friendly felines who live at corner delis, serving as both exterminators and entertainers, has more than 400,000 followers. But these aren’t the only animals at home in neighborhood small businesses. There’s the pigeon turned unofficial laundromat mascot. The rescue parrots who keep everyone company in a liquor store. And the rooster who helps a barber stave off homesickness.

headline: As Britain Prepares for a New Leader, Tensions With Allies Loom
abstract: Comments from the front-runner for prime minister, Liz Truss, suggest bumpier relations with Europe and the U.S. if she wins, with Northern Ireland getting in the way of the “special relationship.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three weeks after Liz Truss became Britain’s top diplomat in 2021, she told a Conservative Party conference that her country need not compete for the affection of the United States. Britons, she said, should not worry “like some teenage girl at a party if we’re not considered to be good enough.”

headline: How Many Drinks a Week Are Safe? Canada Considers a Much Lower Limit
abstract: Research to update Canada’s drinking guideline has found that there are no health benefits, only dangers, from alcohol.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Day weekend has long been promoted by the alcohol industry as summer’s last great drinking opportunity. But a proposed set of guidelines issued earlier this week might offset some of the effects of that one-more-party-in-the-sun advertising blitz.

headline: Game On
abstract: It’s Labor Day weekend, the perfect time to try — you guessed it — pickleball.
lead_paragraph: The lesson began with a provocation. “People say pickleball is a mash-up of tennis, badminton and Ping-Pong,” our teacher said. “But it’s really a game of chess.”

headline: ‘I Was Not Surprised’: David Rubenstein on Carlyle’s Recent Leadership Shake-Up
abstract: Mr. Rubenstein, who started the Carlyle Group over 30 years ago, discusses its former chief executive’s sudden departure, the carried interest loophole and what he’s learned from the industry’s titans.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Europe says it can weather the winter as Russia postpones resuming gas flow.
abstract: The European Union economy minister said the bloc was “well prepared” to resist efforts by Moscow to disrupt its energy supply.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European officials have expressed confidence that they can endure a winter with limited Russian energy, as Moscow postponed restarting the flow of natural gas to Germany through a closely watched pipeline.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Aug. 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Women Are So Fired Up to Vote, I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It
abstract: Since Roe v. Wade was overturned, women have registered to vote in incredible numbers.
lead_paragraph: I’ve watched Americans in recent years acclimate to some very grim realities. Especially since the ascension of Donald Trump, numerous tragedies and extreme policies have been met with little political consequence: schools targeted by mass murderers, immigrants treated as subhuman and autocratic regimes around the globe affirmed as allies. While Mr. Trump failed in his re-election bid, a swing of just over 20,000 votes in the three states with the narrowest margins would have produced a win for him, and Democrats hold razor-thin majorities in the House and the Senate.

headline: How Long Can My Building Keep Scaffolding Up?
abstract: Sidewalk sheds and scaffolding are ubiquitous fixtures in the New York City landscape, but they aren’t supposed to stay up forever.
lead_paragraph: Q: My large, rent-stabilized building in New York City has been encased in scaffolding with a sidewalk shed for over four years. Many of the apartments have balconies or terraces, and there is a roof deck, but no one is allowed to use these spaces while the scaffolding is up. Repair work is done only intermittently, with no real sign of progress. Because city law requires facade inspections every five years, we were told management may leave the scaffolding up indefinitely. Homeless people now shelter beneath the sidewalk shed, which is littered with garbage. Is a building allowed to put up scaffolding and not complete work for an endless amount of time?

headline: Earnie Shavers, Hard-Punching Heavyweight, Is Dead at 78
abstract: He won 68 bouts by knockout and fought some of the biggest names in boxing. He lasted 15 rounds against Muhammad Ali. But he never won a championship.
lead_paragraph: Earnie Shavers, who was regarded as one of the hardest punchers in boxing history, but who failed in his two quests to capture a world heavyweight championship in the 1970s, died on Thursday in Virginia, a day after his 78th birthday.

headline: Republicans Are Showing Contempt for the Rules
abstract: The party is turning against a political commitment to fairness.
lead_paragraph: One of the recurring points I make in my column is that the Republican Party, from the most junior state lawmaker to senators in Washington, has turned against many of the hallmarks of a functional political system, including a commitment to fairness and following the process. There are almost always new examples of Republican politicians rejecting any result or rule that doesn’t favor their interests, and this week we have two.

headline: Pilot Lands After Threatening to Crash Small Plane Into a Walmart
abstract: The pilot took a plane from a Tupelo, Miss., airport on Saturday and flew erratically for hours, officials said. After negotiators convinced him to safely come down, another pilot talked him through landing.
lead_paragraph: A pilot who threatened to crash into a Walmart in Tupelo, Miss., on Saturday morning, and then flew erratically for several hours, was taken into custody after landing in a field, officials said.

headline: Stanley Turkel, Manager and Avid Historian of Hotels, Dies at 96
abstract: A hotelier, a history maven and a New York civic activist, he chronicled hotels in extraordinary detail both in books and on a blog.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Turkel, whose career as a hotelier, hospitality consultant and historian required him to check into more hostelries than a million-mile frequent flier, died on Aug. 12 in his own bed in Alexandria, Va. He was 96.

headline: The End-of-Summer Child Care Crunch Is Here. I’m Not Amused.
abstract: North Carolina offers a frustrating example of how hard it can be to make changes that help families.
lead_paragraph: Finding child care to last the entire summer has long been a problem for parents of young kids. In 2019, the Center for American Progress polled around 1,000 parents of children under 13 and found that three in four had “at least some difficulty” finding care, with more than half saying it was cost prohibitive, and nearly a quarter saying they couldn’t find programs to last the whole summer.

headline: What Is Owed to Pakistan, Now One-Third Underwater
abstract: The Global North can help Pakistan by taking responsibility for the losses and damage of extreme weather fueled in part by the burning of fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: We heard the story all the time, told as a warning: When man first set foot on Earth, all the winged animals flew high into the sky, and the fish dived deeper into the sea, scattering in fear because they knew the destroyer of the world had arrived.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Less Sexist and Racist. But Is It Good?
abstract: The showrunners say they’ve heard and responded to criticism of “Game of Thrones,” but some say that has made the new show boring.
lead_paragraph: In HBO’s new hit show “House of the Dragon,” the dragons are bigger, scalier and fire-breathier than they ever were in the network’s culture-changing fantasy epic, “Game of Thrones.” The casual misogyny and disturbing racial tropes of the first series have, however, been turned down a notch.

headline: The Post-Colonoscopy Male Friendship Test
abstract: What the pandemic, parenthood and nomadism took away from my life, I replaced with surprisingly intimate connections with other men.
lead_paragraph: I met Peter when I wrote him a mash note after reading one of his books. I met Andrew when I took one of his wine classes. I met Michael when I gave a reading in a bookstore managed by his mother. I met Matt when I hired him to ship a car. Alex I had met a decade before, but we hadn’t kept in touch since our initial meeting, so I’ll call it a rekindle.

headline: Militants Attack Trucks Carrying Food Relief in Somalia
abstract: The attack in central Somalia comes even as the country faces a devastating drought that has left almost half its population hungry.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The militant group Al Shabab killed 20 people and burned seven trucks carrying food supplies in central Somalia, the authorities and the state  media said on Saturday, in the latest deadly attack to rock the Horn of Africa nation gripped by catastrophic hunger and worsening drought.

headline: NASA Scrubbed Another Moon Launch. It May Not Be the Last Time.
abstract: Engineers were unable to resolve a hydrogen leak, which led the launch director to call off Saturday’s flight.
lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — Before the first launch attempt of the Artemis I mission last Monday, Wayne Hale, a former program manager of NASA’s space shuttle program, shared a note of caution on Twitter that the day could end up disappointing:

headline: Why LeBron James Is Worth $100 Million to the Lakers, Win or Lose
abstract: If all James did was win basketball games, that would be more than enough. But his value goes beyond the court.
lead_paragraph: If one believes in science, historical trends and the limits of human capabilities, there’s a high likelihood that the 37-year-old LeBron James soon will no longer play like a superstar.

headline: How Ajla Tomljanovic Faced Down Serena Williams and 24,000 Others
abstract: On the advice of her father, Tomljanovic channeled Kevin Costner to beat the six-time U.S. Open champion in front of a raucous, partisan crowd in Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: When Ajla Tomljanovic was a little girl, she asked her father about a prized photograph of him holding a big trophy on his head. Ratko Tomljanovic was a great professional handball player, winning two European Championships for Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, and was the captain of the Croatian national team; before that, he was a member of the Yugoslavian team.

headline: Chile Votes on Constitution That Would Enshrine Record Number of Rights
abstract: In a single ballot on Sunday, Chileans will decide on abortion, universal health care, rights for nature and a record expansion of constitutional rights.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Voters in Chile on Sunday could transform what has long been one of Latin America’s most conservative countries into one of the world’s most left-leaning societies.

headline: Sweltering California could see temperatures rise this weekend.
abstract: Warmer nights may offer little relief, and the worst of the heat wave could arrive in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: The heat wave that began earlier this week in California has fueled fires across the state, caused power outage concerns and prompted the governor to declare a state of emergency. But the worst may be coming this holiday weekend.

headline: Does Biden Really Believe We Are in a Crisis of Democracy?
abstract: The president’s strategy and rhetoric make more sense if he doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: Strip away the weird semi-fascist optics, the creepy crimson lighting and the Marines standing sentinel, and the speech Joe Biden gave on Thursday night outside Philadelphia’s Independence Hall could have been given by other prominent Democrats throughout the Trump era.

headline: In the California Desert, L.G.B.T.Q. Voters Could Sway a Key House Race
abstract: Representative Ken Calvert, a long-serving Republican, is facing a tough re-election race in a redrawn district that now includes Palm Springs, proclaimed to be the gayest city in America.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — Tucked away in the California desert, where windmills line the sprawling hills and rainbows adorn the crosswalks, a sizable progressive L.G.B.T.Q. community has turned a once reliably Republican stronghold into a battleground in the fight for control of Congress, giving Democrats hope for picking up a House seat that has long been beyond their reach.

headline: How a Record Cash Haul Vanished for Senate Republicans
abstract: The campaign arm of Senate Republicans had collected $181.5 million by the end of July — but spent 95 percent of it. A big investment in digital, and hyperaggressive tactics, have not paid off.
lead_paragraph: It was early 2021, and Senator Rick Scott wanted to go big. The new chairman of the Senate Republican campaign arm had a mind to modernize the place. One of his first decisions was to overhaul how the group raised money online.

headline: Thousands Mourn Mikhail Gorbachev at Funeral in Moscow
abstract: Russians stood outside the famous House of the Unions to pay their respects to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet Union leader. Citing a busy schedule, President Vladimir V. Putin did not attend the funeral.
lead_paragraph: Russians stood outside the famous House of the Unions to pay their respects to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet Union leader. Citing a busy schedule, President Vladimir V. Putin did not attend the funeral.

headline: Marilyn Loden, Who Championed a Feminist Metaphor, Dies at 76
abstract: She was asked to speak at a conference in 1978 about barriers faced by women in the workplace. She noted a barrier she called “the glass ceiling.”
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Loden was 31 and working in human resources at the New York Telephone Company when she was asked to be part of a panel at a feminist conference in Manhattan. It was 1978, and the topic was how women were thwarted in the workplace. As her fellow panelists discussed poor self-image and self-deprecating behaviors, Ms. Loden grew frustrated. It was clear to her that women were not to blame for their own stalled careers.

headline: Renewed Shelling Puts Nuclear Plant at Risk Despite U.N. Presence
abstract: The decision to keep monitors at the plant despite the obvious risks underscored what the International Atomic Energy Agency’s leader called the “unprecedented” peril of the moment.
lead_paragraph: Even as hopes were raised that a permanent presence of United Nations inspectors would help reduce the risk of disaster at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, the war once again endangered the plant’s safe operation.

headline: Charlie Finch, Caustic Chronicler of New York’s Art Scene, Dies at 69
abstract: He exposed what he saw as pretension and bad art with passion and, at times, viciousness, winning fans but offending many.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Finch, who shook up the New York art world for years with gossipy, often caustic writing about the city’s artists and art scene, died on Aug. 24 in Manhattan. He was 69.

headline: A 9-year-old boy is killed in a rocket attack in southern Ukraine.
abstract: A 9-year-old boy was killed and at least 10 people were seriously injured on Saturday when Russian rockets hit a residential area in the southern Ukrainian town of Zelenodolsk, as fighting over the Kherson region intensified, the local governor said.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old boy was killed and at least 10 people were seriously injured on Saturday when Russian rockets hit a residential area in the southern Ukrainian town of Zelenodolsk, as fighting over the Kherson region intensified, the local governor said.

headline: Ups and Downs
abstract: Tracy Gray’s Sunday puzzle doesn’t miss a step.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s constructor, Tracy Gray, lives in Hunt Valley, Md.; she and her husband have owned and operated a lawn and landscaping business for 33 years. She got the idea for this puzzle last Christmas while riding an escalator, up and down, at a mall, further evidence that ideas can come from anywhere, if you let them. This is Tracy’s 33rd puzzle, and ninth Sunday grid, for The Times. (And her first puzzle in over a year! Welcome back.)

headline: Initial Tests Showed Arsenic in Water at N.Y.C. Housing Complex
abstract: The city distributed bottled water after a preliminary test showed arsenic levels higher than federal guidelines, though subsequent tests were less clear.
lead_paragraph: City officials said Monday that additional test results were pending of the tap water at a New York City Housing Authority complex in the East Village that initially was found to contain arsenic at levels higher than the federal drinking water standard, while subsequent negative tests have called the earlier results into question.

headline: Looking Like a Title Defender, Georgia Thrashes Oregon
abstract: Before cruising, the Bulldogs built a 28-3 lead at halftime over the 11th-ranked Ducks. And Oregon didn’t score again. Yeah, it was that ugly.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In December, the last time Georgia swaggered into Atlanta’s Mercedes-Benz Stadium, the Bulldog faithful fell all but silent long before the end.

headline: Why NASA Is Not Rushing to Launch the Artemis Moon Rocket
abstract: After a pair of called-off launches, the latest caused by a large hydrogen leak, the agency is not expected to try again until later in the month or October.
lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — For the second time in a week, NASA officials on Saturday called off the test launch of a rocket that is to one day carry astronauts to the moon. It was another setback for a signature national spaceflight program, though NASA officials expressed confidence that would it be just a temporary one.

headline: W.N.B.A. Semifinals Check-In: Can’t. Stop. Candace. Parker.
abstract: Both semifinals series are tied, 1-1. The Las Vegas Aces and Seattle Storm have shown offensive power, while the Connecticut Sun and Chicago Sky dig in on defense.
lead_paragraph: As Chicago Sky guard Kahleah Copper and Connecticut Sun guard Courtney Williams tussled over the basketball in Game 1 of their W.N.B.A. semifinal series, Sky forward Candace Parker walked down the court, waving her hands in the air to ignite the Chicago crowd. The moment reflected how physical the series had been, and it was reminder of the teams’ history.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pressing Limits to Ease Delivery of Abortion Pill
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 4, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We just don’t have a road map about how to provide medication abortion post-Roe, so it’s all being created right now.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 4, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 6 about grilling in city parks misstates the type of home that Roy and Ida White’s family moved to in East Harlem in 1938. It was an apartment building, not a brownstone.

headline: China Threatens Reaction After U.S. Announces Arms Sales to Taiwan
abstract: A $1.1 billion package would “severely jeopardize” ties, Chinese officials say in demanding that Washington revoke the deal.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China threatened over the weekend to take countermeasures after the Biden administration approved the sale of more than $1.1 billion worth of arms to Taiwan.

headline: Trump Lashes Out in First Rally Since F.B.I. Search
abstract: Donald J. Trump and President Biden have both made recent appearances in Pennsylvania, one of the key states in November’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WILKES-BARRE TOWNSHIP, Pa. — In his first rally since his home was searched by the F.B.I. on Aug. 8, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday lashed out at President Biden and federal agents, calling his Democratic rival “an enemy of the state” and the F.B.I. and the Department of Justice “vicious monsters.”

headline: Serving Fresh Looks
abstract: Some of the best outfits from the U.S. Open, a Kate Hudson dinner and an Hermès party for the Hampton Classic.
lead_paragraph: It was Serena Williams’s night. Celebrities and politicians thronged the opening night of the U.S. Open on Monday, many dressed in pink — Ms. Williams’s favorite color. They cheered her on and helped raise $3 million for the United States Tennis Association Foundation, which supports underprivileged youth.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: One Spot Where All of Aaron Judge’s Home Runs Land
abstract: Benjamin Hoffman, who manages baseball coverage at The Times, came up with a fresh way to cover the Yankee outfielder’s pursuit of a longstanding record.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Judge has a tendency to interrupt Benjamin Hoffman’s life at home.At any moment — watching TV with his wife, walking his children home from summer camp — Hoffman’s smart watch may buzz, alerting him that the Yankees have scored. And if Judge, the team’s star outfielder, has hit a home run, Hoffman has to get up, grab his computer and get to work.

headline: How Russia Uses Low Tech in Its High-Tech Weapons
abstract: Investigators who examined the electronics in Russia’s newest cruise missiles and attack helicopters were surprised to find decades-old technology reused from earlier models.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Russian forces fire precision-guided weapons at military and civilian targets in Ukraine, officers in Ukraine’s security service working with private analysts have collected parts of the crashed missiles to unravel their enemy’s secrets.

headline: ‘I Became a Regular at a Coffee Shop Around the Corner’
abstract: Ordering unpredictably as a daily task, a subway intervention and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: For Transgender Young People, a Haven From the Outside World.With S’Mores.
abstract: Indigo Point was created as an oasis, one that organizers saw as all the more necessary after a barrage of conservative legislation focused on transgender young people.
lead_paragraph: MAKANDA, Ill. — The middle schoolers at Camp Indigo Point were hanging out by their cabins after swimming in the lake, practicing the ukulele and stuffing foil packets with ground beef and vegetables, which were now roasting on the fire, seven minutes on each side.

headline: India’s Electric Vehicle Push Is Riding on Mopeds and Rickshaws
abstract: The country’s success with two- and three-wheeled vehicles that sell for as little as $1,000 could be a template for other developing countries.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, luxury-car buyers are snapping up Teslas and other electric cars that cost more than $60,000, and even relatively cheap models cost more than $25,000.

headline: In South Korea, a Hit Show Brings Autism Into the Spotlight
abstract: “Extraordinary Attorney Woo” has raised awareness of autism in South Korea, where developmental disabilities are still a taboo subject for many people.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — When Yoon Wn-ho, a visiting professor at Inha University in South Korea, saw “Extraordinary Attorney Woo” for the first time, he turned the television off. The popular Korean drama’s portrayal of a young autistic lawyer bothered Mr. Yoon, who has autism himself.

headline: The Dodgers Don’t Need to Play the Percentages
abstract: Despite the team’s high payrolls, Los Angeles was known for platoons and creativity. With Freddie Freeman, Mookie Betts and Trea Turner, they embraced stability instead.
lead_paragraph: There is a phrase in modern sports lingo that make no sense to Freddie Freeman: load management. The idea of sitting out now to stay strong later simply does not add up.

headline: When the Family Business Is Crime, Some Women Thrive
abstract: In Barbie Latza Nadeau’s “The Godmother,” we meet the women who have run the mob, and the new generation poised to take over.
lead_paragraph: How could Pasquale Simonetti — Pasqualone to his pals — not fall hard for Assunta Maresca?

headline: The Quiet Cost of Family Caregiving
abstract: Many employees reduce their hours or stop working to help ailing family members. But it may be years before they fully return to the work force, studies indicate.
lead_paragraph: At first, Dana Guthrie thought she could help care for her parents, whose health had begun to decline, and still hold onto her job administering a busy dental practice in Plant City, Fla.

headline: Movie Theaters Had a Great Summer. But There’s a Plot Twist.
abstract: Hits like “Top Gun: Maverick” seemed to lead a revival, yet one chain is preparing for bankruptcy, another is awash in debt and blockbusters are in short supply.
lead_paragraph: The hits just keep on coming. But not the ones movie theaters need.

headline: Russia’s Unfounded Claims of Secret U.S. Bioweapons Linger On and On
abstract: Without providing evidence, the Kremlin is pressing allegations that the U.S. operates labs in Ukraine and beyond. This week, it has called an investigative session in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: The United States secretly manufactured biological weapons in Ukraine. It trained birds to carry pathogens into Russia. It created Covid-19. It operated laboratories in Nigeria that engineered this year’s outbreak of monkeypox.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Town After Town, Residents Are Fighting Affordable Housing in Connecticut
abstract: Local residents and elected officials are seeking to block large housing projects, warning that increased density could change the character of their towns.
lead_paragraph: In the town of Fairfield, Conn., nearly 2,400 residents have signed a petition opposing a project proposed for downtown that could bring 19 units of affordable housing.

headline: Jonathan Escoffery Has a Reality He’d Like to Share
abstract: In “If I Survive You,” Escoffery, the son of Jamaican immigrants, wrote stories that are not strictly autobiographical, but feel true to his experience.
lead_paragraph: Ackee is ripe when the fruit starts to open, revealing its black, glossy seeds. That’s how you know it’s safe to cook, the author Jonathan Escoffery explained: “If you force the ackee pod open and eat the edible parts, you’ll poison yourself.”

headline: The Final Days of New York’s ‘Wild West’ Outdoor Dining Scene
abstract: The city has removed dozens of dining sheds and is considering more regulations for those that remain.
lead_paragraph: It was 8:15 p.m. on a steamy Saturday night on the Lower East Side, and every table on Canal Street outside of Clandestino was occupied and buzzing.

headline: From Jamaican to Miamian, and All the Identities in Between
abstract: Jonathan Escoffery’s debut story collection, “If I Survive You,” follows a young man through family tensions and personal struggles.
lead_paragraph: The opening story of Jonathan Escoffery’s debut collection is a bravura overview of the themes and dynamics that will haunt the rest of the book. Titled “In Flux,” it’s a second-person chronicle (“You immediately resent this question”) of the protagonist’s early life as the younger of two brothers in a Jamaican immigrant family living in Miami. The story is Escoffery’s most direct engagement with the question of identity, as the protagonist, Trelawney, tries to figure out where he fits in a Spanish-speaking, multiethnic city that can’t figure out his parents’ Jamaican accents or his own ambiguous racial features.

headline: The Curious Hole in My Head
abstract: Born without my left temporal lobe, a brain region thought to be critical for language, I’ve been a research subject for much of my life.
lead_paragraph: I barreled into the world — a precipitous birth, the doctors called it — at a New York City hospital in the dead of night.

headline: Seven Days That Closed Out a Career
abstract: At the U.S. Open, Serena Williams laughed, rocked sparkly shoes, rang the bell at the stock exchange, beat two opponents, teared up and said goodbye. She didn’t win, but she didn’t lose.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams left the Lotte New York Palace hotel on Madison Avenue and folded herself into the back seat of a dark green Lincoln Navigator. She arrived at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center about 15 minutes later. Traffic’s bearable on Saturday mornings.

headline: Katrina Babies Are Hurting, but We Are Healing, Too
abstract: What happened to the children who lived through Hurricane Katrina?
lead_paragraph: How much does childhood trauma affect a person’s life? What about the life of an entire city? These are among the questions Edward Buckles Jr. leaves viewers to grapple with in his new documentary, “Katrina Babies,” which premiered on HBO on Aug. 24 to mark the 17th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: The Way You Get Around New York City Is About to Change
abstract: The city’s crumbling infrastructure is finally getting some upgrades.
lead_paragraph: Like an old, well-loved couch, crumbling infrastructure is a fixture of life in New York City.

headline: What You Missed at the U.S. Open While You Were Glued to Serena Williams
abstract: In case you missed it: The defending women’s singles champion, Emma Raducanu, is out, and a few players not named Serena retired, too.
lead_paragraph: The Serena Williams show has come to an end, quite likely for good in competitive tennis. Even if Williams continues to say “you never know” and her current coach Eric Hechtman and long-ago coach Rick Macci have their doubts.

headline: Office Drama
abstract: Labor Day has become a flash point for big companies who want workers to return to the office.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic upended American offices like nothing in memory. But now many big companies are again starting to require employees to work in person. To understand how that’s going, I called my colleague Emma Goldberg, who covers workplace issues.

headline: 5 Palestinians, 2 Accused of Spying for Israel, Are Executed in Gaza, Officials Say
abstract: The Gaza Interior Ministry said that three of the executions were carried out by hanging and the other two by firing squad.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Officials in Gaza announced the executions on Sunday of five Palestinians, two of whom were accused of spying for Israel.

headline: Kane Brown Didn’t Fit the Country Music Mold. So He Made His Own.
abstract: Prejudice has followed the biracial singer from his earliest days as a performer. Now a proven hitmaker in a range of styles, he’s releasing his third album, “Different Man.”
lead_paragraph: Kane Brown recently hosted a fellow country singer at his Nashville home, then paused to collect himself. “After he left,” Brown recalled, “I was like, Randy Travis really just came over and ate barbecue at my house.”

headline: New Titanic Footage Heralds Next Stage in Deep-Sea Tourism
abstract: New, high-resolution footage of the Titanic offers a glimpse into the ambitions of the deep-sea tourism industry. Tourists paid $250,000 to take a submersible to view the wreckage.
lead_paragraph: New footage of the Titanic wreckage released last week by a commercial exploration company shows the doomed ship in vivid detail and highlighted that the world for wealthy tourists not only extends to space, but also the deep sea.

headline: Scholz announces a $65 billion relief package in Germany.
abstract: Berlin aims to ease the burden on citizens facing soaring inflation and surging energy costs that have worsened with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German government announced a $65 billion relief package on Sunday to help ease the burden on citizens facing soaring inflation and surging energy costs that have worsened with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine — and have sent European leaders scrambling to prepare the continent for winter.

headline: Sterling Lord, Premier Literary Agent, Is Dead at 102
abstract: The list of well-known writers he represented is long. But his success began with an unknown named Jack Kerouac and his hard-to-sell novel “On the Road.”
lead_paragraph: About 10 years ago Sterling Lord invited four long-term clients of his for lunch at the Regency Hotel in New York. As a matter of longevity, at least, it’s pretty safe to say that no other literary agent anywhere at any time could have assembled such a group.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: A bacon, egg and cheese breakfast sandwich, Thai basil chicken, and more recipes for the coming days.
lead_paragraph: It’s exciting, that new-school-supply feeling.

headline: My Hopes and Fears for My Children as They Go Back to School
abstract: When I sent my kids back to school this year, I sent them with my prayers.
lead_paragraph: As I sent my kids back to school this year, I sent them with my prayers.

headline: Other European nations try to fight rising prices as fears of social unrest grow.
abstract: Sweden, Germany, and the Czech Republic all announced new measures, while soaring energy prices and inflation stoked protests in Prague.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Governments across Europe moved this weekend to introduce measures aimed at tackling soaring energy costs and inflation, amid growing concerns that rising prices fueled by the war in Ukraine could stoke social unrest.

headline: Logging in National Forests: A Crime or a Necessity?
abstract: Readers discuss an essay by Carole King calling for a ban on commercial logging in national forests. Also: Doppelgängers; cultural exchange with Russia; death row pardons.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Body of Abducted Memphis Teacher Is Found, Police Say
abstract: Eliza Fletcher was on an early morning jog last week when she was forced into an S.U.V., the police said. A man has been charged with her murder.
lead_paragraph: The body of a kindergarten teacher in Memphis who was abducted last week during an early morning jog has been found, the city’s police department said on Tuesday.

headline: In Street Takeovers, Young Stunt Drivers Outmaneuver the Police
abstract: Many states have passed laws cracking down on rogue stunt-driving events in the past year, but drivers have new tactics for evading law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, CALIF. — The sound of revving engines and shrieking tires reverberates across the city, disrupting the quiet of the wee hours. The cacophony comes from an intersection, taken over by young drivers and designated as “the pit,” a proving ground where they can display acrobatic yet reckless drift-driving skills. Rings of spectators gather around a vortex of cars careening around one another — often with screaming passengers hanging out of the windows.

headline: Gustavo Arnal, C.F.O. at Bed Bath & Beyond, Dies
abstract: He joined the home goods retailer in 2020 during an executive shake-up.
lead_paragraph: Gustavo Arnal, 52, the chief financial officer of the beleaguered home goods retailer Bed Bath & Beyond, died on Friday. He was brought on to help stabilize the company in 2020, as it needed to ramp up its offerings to meet shopper demand in a retail sector disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Deadly shelling in the east offers a grim reminder of a continuing battle.
abstract: Russian shelling killed four Ukrainian civilians in Donetsk Province over the weekend, offering a grim reminder of the continuous battle in the country’s east even as the war’s focus has shifted to the south.
lead_paragraph: Russian shelling killed four Ukrainian civilians in Donetsk Province over the weekend, offering a grim reminder of the continuous battle in the country’s east even as the war’s focus has shifted to the south.

headline: The Week in Business: Job Growth Is Solid but Slowing
abstract: Jobs growth is slowing but still strong. Bed Bath & Beyond gets a reprieve. A former Uber executive goes to trial.
lead_paragraph: After a surprising jobs report in July, which showed employers adding jobs at a blistering pace, August’s numbers fell more in line with expectations. The economy gained 315,000 jobs last month, well within range of the roughly 300,000 that forecasters had projected. That was a significant deceleration for the labor market — and is just what the Federal Reserve was looking for. Policymakers at the central bank have been trying to slow job growth as part of their campaign to rein in inflation and cool the economy. The Fed is likely to see this latest jobs report as a sign that its policies are working, but it well knows that its work isn’t over. The August jobs numbers still reflect a strong pace of growth, and Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, has indicated that there is little that would sway the central bank from its path of raising rates, including at its Sept. 20-21 meeting.

headline: John Sullivan, the U.S. ambassador to Russia, leaves Moscow to retire.
abstract: John Sullivan managed the U.S. embassy during its most difficult period in decades — when Moscow forced hundreds of employees to leave and after Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: John J. Sullivan, the U.S. ambassador to Russia, left Moscow on Sunday and is retiring from public service after serving under five American presidents, the State Department said.

headline: Water Crisis in Jackson Is ‘Unacceptable,’ Residents Say
abstract: Over 150,000 people are without safe and reliable drinking water in Jackson, Miss. A pregnant mother, her husband and a community activist describe the dire conditions and explain how the water crisis has affected them.
lead_paragraph: Over 150,000 people are without safe and reliable drinking water in Jackson, Miss. A pregnant mother, her husband and a community activist describe the dire conditions and explain how the water crisis has affected them.

headline: Venice: Brendan Fraser Mounts a Transformational Comeback
abstract: In Darren Aronofsky’s “The Whale,” the onetime leading hunk is earning Oscar chatter for his role as a 600-pound recluse, though the emotional actor is wary.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — For someone who became famous for playing the titular lunkheads in 1990s movies like “Encino Man” and “George of the Jungle,” Brendan Fraser speaks with a surprising delicacy.

headline: Biden Shouldn’t Apologize to Republicans
abstract: The president said that Trumpism resembles “semi-fascism.” He’s right.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are outraged — or possibly simply pretending to be outraged — that President Biden has, in recent speeches, warned that “MAGA Republicans” are a threat to democracy and, at one point, called the philosophy fueling Trumpism “semi-fascism.”

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Over Naked Baby Image on Nirvana Album Cover
abstract: Spencer Elden, who was pictured as a baby on the cover of “Nevermind,” argued in his lawsuit that the grunge rock group had engaged in “child pornography.”
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a man who, as a baby, had graced the cover of Nirvana’s seminal album, “Nevermind,” and argued 30 years later that the iconic photo of him drifting naked in a pool had been a form of sexual exploitation.

headline: Blame, Hate and License Plates in a Divided Kosovo Town
abstract: Tensions between ethnic Albanians and ethnic Serbs have flared in recent months, stoked by a bureaucratic dispute over vehicle tags, testimony to the region’s toxic identity politics.
lead_paragraph: NORTH MITROVICA, Kosovo — Hoping to ease the bad blood that flows on both sides of the river that divides their city in northern Kosovo, ethnic Serb and ethnic Albanian artists joined forces to paint cheery murals over abusive graffiti daubed on the concrete pillars of the main bridge.

headline: Diamondbacks 1, Story 0
abstract: How a bloop single in the 2001 World Series shattered an author’s long-held faith in the ancient narrative arc.
lead_paragraph: No one knows precisely when human language was invented. Spoken words leave no archaeological trace. As soon as their last echoes die away, they are gone forever. All that remains is guesswork. Scientific advances in the field of human origins have been spectacular, but scientists don’t like to guess.

headline: Wary of Cold Days and Hot Tempers, Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief
abstract: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European governments moved this weekend to soften the blow of soaring costs and a deepening energy crisis triggered by the war in Ukraine, and scrambled to prepare for the possibility of social unrest as the days grow colder.

headline: A Second Constitutional Convention? Some Republicans Want to Force One
abstract: A new book by a former Democratic senator warns of the risks of allowing states to call for a convention. Some in the G.O.P. see it as the only way to rein in the federal government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jodey Arrington, a conservative Texas Republican, believes it is well past time for something the nation has not experienced for more than two centuries: a debate over rewriting the Constitution.

headline: For Mark Spitz, Olympic Greatness Came Amid Tragedy
abstract: The former swimmer said it was “like an out-of-body experience” to win seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Games and then learn that terrorists had attacked Israelis at the Olympic Village.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — On Sept. 5, 1972, a brief editorial in The New York Times noted that “nothing that has happened in Munich so far this summer can compare with the awesome feats of Mark Spitz, swimmer extraordinary.”

headline: As Midterms Near, Election Rule Raises Dilemma for Trump Inquiries
abstract: Justice Department officials are debating how an unwritten rule should affect the criminal investigations into Jan. 6 and the former president’s handling of sensitive documents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the midterm elections near, top Justice Department officials are weighing whether to temporarily scale back work in criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump because of an unwritten rule forbidding overt actions that could improperly influence the vote, according to people briefed on the discussions.

headline: ‘We Are Here Because of Him’: The Runner Who Defied Apartheid
abstract: In the dying days of South Africa’s apartheid regime, pioneering Black runners helped transform the Comrades Marathon into the race it is today, one that reflects the country around it.
lead_paragraph: DURBAN, South Africa — On a balmy Sunday morning in late August, Kgadimonyane Hoseah Tjale stood below a stadium full of roaring fans on the finish line of the Comrades ultramarathon, clutching a small air horn.

headline: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail, the largest convoy so far.
abstract: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail from once-blockaded Ukrainian ports on Sunday, the largest convoy to depart the country since a U.N.-brokered deal meant to ease a global food crisis was reached in July, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail from once-blockaded Ukrainian ports on Sunday, the largest convoy to depart the country since a U.N.-brokered deal meant to ease a global food crisis was reached in July, officials said.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Europe’s Energy Protections
abstract: Plus Chileans vote on a new constitution and rickshaws lead India’s electric vehicle transition.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine has roiled Europe’s economy. Now, as energy costs surge, countries are scrambling to prepare for winter.

headline: Plan to Blare Propaganda Meets Resistance (and Eye Rolls) in Vietnam
abstract: The city of Hanoi may revive regular loudspeaker broadcasts, which were routine before most people had TVs or internet access. Residents are wary of bringing them back.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — For most of his life, Nguyen Lap listened to scratchy announcements from loudspeakers that were affixed to utility poles around Hanoi, draped in electrical wiring and shaded by subtropical foliage.

headline: Las Vegas Reporter Found Fatally Stabbed Outside His Home, Police Say
abstract: Jeff German was remembered by colleagues as a superb reporter who chased down stories about corruption and organized crime in the city.
lead_paragraph: A veteran investigative reporter for The Las Vegas Review-Journal was found stabbed to death outside his home on Saturday morning, prompting a search for the attacker, according to the newspaper and the authorities.

headline: Really Impresses
abstract: Et tu, Adam Simpson’s puzzle?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Adam Simpson, who is making his constructing debut in the New York Times Crossword with a fabulous Monday puzzle that really impresses. The Times’s crossword editors described it as “lively and modern” and observed that the clues are perfectly pitched for a Monday crossword, the easiest puzzle of the week.

headline: How Cesar Chavez’s Union Lost Its Way
abstract: Workers have to be persuaded that to join a union is worth the risk.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Day after day this summer, the dramatic images filled front pages and social media feeds: a sea of red flags; the trademark black eagle on homemade signs carried by weathered hands; banners with an image of Our Lady of Guadalupe and the face of Cesar Chavez. The storied United Farm Workers was on the move, re-enacting the 335-mile march to Sacramento that its founder, Chavez, led in 1966.

headline: LIV Golf Continues to Try New Ways to Be Noticed
abstract: Whether it’s the team concept or a decision to allow its golfers to play in shorts, the breakaway Saudi-backed series so far sees itself as the anti-PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: BOLTON, Mass. — The LIV Golf event outside Boston was minutes from beginning on Friday, and Greg Norman, the frontman for the insurgent Saudi-backed circuit, needed a new, showy way to make an entrance in the rancorous battle for the future of men’s golf.

headline: After a Frenzy, Las Vegas Emerges Over Seattle
abstract: The teams scored 10 points in the final 11 seconds of the fourth quarter before the Aces won. They’ll play to clinch a finals spot, while Seattle will look to extend the series, and Sue Bird’s career.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Despite the game looking like a Las Vegas Aces pummeling of Seattle in the first half, somehow Storm guard Jewell Loyd stood at the free-throw line with her team holding a 2-point lead with just over 11 seconds remaining and with a chance to steal Game 3 of the W.N.B.A. semifinals — a game that the Storm should have been out of a long time ago.

headline: Chile Says ‘No’ to Left-Leaning Constitution After 3 Years of Debate
abstract: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — For the past three years, Chileans have fought over a path forward for their country in the form of a new constitution, written entirely from scratch, that would transform their society and grant more rights than any national charter before it.

headline: Picture(s) of Excellence at the Open
abstract: Images of Serena Williams at the U.S. Open from the past 25 years.
lead_paragraph: It was hard not to watch Serena Williams. And who would want to look away? Since she played her first U.S. Open, in 1998, she played with athleticism and emotion that quickly drew in even the most casual spectator. She married sport and entertainment in a way few other athletes have. Even when she was not moving, she was far from still.

headline: Mill Fire in Northern California Has Killed at Least Two People, Officials Say
abstract: The fire, one of two whipping through the region, has destroyed at least 100 homes, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: YREKA, Calif. — Wind-whipped fires that have forced the evacuation of thousands in Northern California have killed at least two people, the authorities said Sunday.

headline: Coast Guard Ends Search for Survivors of Puget Sound Floatplane Crash
abstract: Nine adults and one child were aboard the commercial chartered seaplane when it went down in Mutiny Bay north of Seattle.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard on Monday called off its search for survivors of a floatplane that crashed with 10 passengers aboard Sunday afternoon in Puget Sound in Washington State, the authorities said.

headline: Suspects at Large After Deadly Knife Attacks in Canada
abstract: The Canadian authorities identified two suspects after killings on an Indigenous reservation and in a nearby village.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian authorities identified two suspects after killings on an Indigenous reservation and in a nearby village.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 3: Two Targaryen Hunts
abstract: Viserys sought a stag and clarity while his brother, Daemon, tried to bag a Crabfeeder. Who had the most success?
lead_paragraph: In the series premiere of “House of the Dragon,” Viserys described the Iron Throne as “the most dangerous seat in the realm.”

headline: Nick Kyrgios Upsets No. 1 Daniil Medvedev at the U.S. Open
abstract: Medvedev grew frustrated in a four-set loss that ensured neither singles draws will have a repeat winner this year. Kyrgios will play another Russian, No. 27 Karen Khachanov, in the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Nick Kyrgios’s finest season continues to get finer, and on Sunday he defeated No. 1 Daniil Medvedev, the defending U.S. Open men’s singles champion, 7-6 (11), 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, with a deeply convincing display of power and finesse to reach his first quarterfinal in New York.

headline: Deadly California Wildfire Destroys Homes and Forces Evacuations
abstract: Authorities said the Mill Fire has forced the evacuation of thousands of people in Northern California and claimed at least two lives.
lead_paragraph: Authorities said the Mill Fire has forced the evacuation of thousands of people in Northern California and claimed at least two lives.

headline: As Russia Chokes Europe’s Gas, France Enters Era of Energy ‘Sobriety’
abstract: The government is helping residents with soaring gas and electric costs, but some businesses are already shutting down amid fears of rationing and blackouts.
lead_paragraph: A factory making iconic French bistro glasses is idling its furnaces to offset soaring energy costs. Cities around France are turning off streetlamps and other outdoor lighting to curb electricity use. In Normandy, some schools will start heating classrooms by burning wood to conserve natural gas.

headline: Ukrainians in Rural Ireland Piece Together New Lives, Step by Step
abstract: With 50,000 Ukrainians now finding sanctuary in Ireland, the largest number of refugees the country has ever accepted is merging with locals in homogeneous rural villages.
lead_paragraph: ARRANMORE ISLAND, Ireland — There are two flags flying over the youth hostel on Arranmore Island, a speck of land off Ireland’s northwestern coast, visible from the ferry as it pulls into its tiny port: the Irish tricolor and the blue and yellow banner of Ukraine.

headline: The suspects are likely in the city of Regina, police chief says.
abstract: The two men sought in the stabbing attacks that began in the James Smith Cree Nation remain at large and “are likely” in Regina, the city’s police chief, Evan Bray, said in a video posted on Twitter late Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The two men sought in the stabbing attacks that began in the James Smith Cree Nation remain at large and “are likely” in Regina, the city’s police chief, Evan Bray, said in a video posted on Twitter late Sunday night.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Support for European energy costs.
lead_paragraph: European governments are racing to soften the blow of soaring costs and a deepening energy crisis triggered by the war in Ukraine. E.U. energy ministers have planned an emergency meeting this week, and three different countries announced relief measures yesterday. Europe is working to drastically reduce its purchases of Russian oil and gas.

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 5, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Claim to Fame’ and ‘American Gigolo’
abstract: ABC wraps up its new celebrity-adjacent competition show, and Showtime airs a modern TV version of the Richard Gere film.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: South Korea Braces for Typhoon Hinnamnor
abstract: The storm, expected to make landfall on Tuesday, could be the strongest in the country’s recorded history. Japan and China were also making preparations.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Just weeks after record-setting rainfall brought deadly floods to South Korea’s capital, the country was bracing on Monday for Typhoon Hinnamnor, which forecasts indicated could be the strongest storm to make landfall in its recorded history.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: My Weight Keeps Changing. What Clothes Should I Buy?
abstract: An environmentally conscious reader is looking for clothing that accommodates fluctuations in size.
lead_paragraph: Changes in weight and body shape — bits going in or out whether from illness, age, lifestyle changes, pregnancy, mental health or financial circumstances (the list goes on) — are simply a part of life. Feet and hips spread when you are carrying a baby. Poochy bits migrate over time. Sickness melts padding.

headline: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
abstract: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
lead_paragraph: YAKIMA, Wash. — The water managers of the Yakima River basin in arid Central Washington know what it’s like to fight over water, just like their counterparts along the Colorado River are fighting now. They know what it’s like to be desperate, while drought, climate change, population growth and agriculture shrink water supplies to crisis levels.

headline: Shakespeare or Bieber? This Canadian City Draws Devotees of Both
abstract: For nearly 70 years, Stratford, Ontario, has attracted legions of theater fanatics to its Shakespeare festival. About a dozen years ago, a very different type of pilgrim began arriving: Beliebers.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD, Ontario — It’s a small city that practically shouts “Shakespeare!”

headline: Liz Truss has offered tax cuts, but stayed quiet on efforts to tackle a mounting economic crisis.
abstract: Once a student activist for a smaller, centrist party, the Liberal Democrats, Ms. Truss, 47, campaigned for Britain to remain in the European Union during the 2016 Brexit referendum. But the Foreign Secretary has remade herself as a champion of Brexit causes, pursuing aggressive negotiations with the European Union over trade in Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Once a student activist for a smaller, centrist party, the Liberal Democrats, Ms. Truss, 47, campaigned for Britain to remain in the European Union during the 2016 Brexit referendum. But the Foreign Secretary has remade herself as a champion of Brexit causes, pursuing aggressive negotiations with the European Union over trade in Northern Ireland.

headline: Rishi Sunak was seen as Boris Johnson’s likely successor. Then the campaign began.
abstract: CARDIFF, Wales — Earlier this summer, Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, seemed well-placed to become Britain’s next prime minister, topping the short list of two contenders selected by Conservative Party lawmakers to replace the departing Boris Johnson.
lead_paragraph: CARDIFF, Wales — Earlier this summer, Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, seemed well-placed to become Britain’s next prime minister, topping the short list of two contenders selected by Conservative Party lawmakers to replace the departing Boris Johnson.

headline: A prolonged leadership contest has come down to two sometimes bitter rivals.
abstract: LONDON — Britain will learn the identity of its new prime minister at around 12:30 p.m. on Monday (7:30 a.m. in New York), when the Conservative Party announces the results of a hard-fought contest to replace Boris Johnson. Liz Truss, the foreign secretary, remains the heavy favorite over her opponent, Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain will learn the identity of its new prime minister at around 12:30 p.m. on Monday (7:30 a.m. in New York), when the Conservative Party announces the results of a hard-fought contest to replace Boris Johnson. Liz Truss, the foreign secretary, remains the heavy favorite over her opponent, Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer.

headline: Less than 1 percent of Britain’s people voted on the new prime minister. Here’s why.
abstract: Around 160,000 people had the final say in choosing the leader of the Conservative Party, and therefore the next prime minister.
lead_paragraph: It may come as a surprise, particularly to those less familiar with parliamentary systems of government, that the decision on Britain’s new leader has been made by just a small (and not very representative) fraction of the country’s 67 million people.

headline: A Genius Cartoonist Believes Child’s Play Is Anything But Frivolous
