abstract: “There’s such profound amnesia about what kids are actually doing,” Lynda Barry says.
lead_paragraph: “There’s such profound amnesia about what kids are actually doing,” Lynda Barry says.

headline: Student Journalists Reveal a Changing World. Let Them.
abstract: The shutdown of a high school newspaper in Nebraska is only the latest episode in efforts to censor student publications across red states.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It wasn’t exactly news when a principal in Nebraska censored a high school newspaper, canceled the school’s journalism program and abruptly disbanded its student newspaper. I mean, it’s news news, but it’s not surprising news. Red state bureaucrats and politicians have been at war with the First Amendment for a while now.

headline: Sex and Murder in Maggie O’Farrell’s Overwrought Historical Drama
abstract: “The Marriage Portrait” is the fictionalized story of the 16th-century Italian noblewoman Lucrezia di Cosimo de’Medici.
lead_paragraph: Does great sex yield great children? Norman Mailer thought so (of course), but other writers have circled this topic, too. If you have a blah night in bed when you and your partner conceive, maybe it’s a karma thing — maybe you’ll have a blah kid.

headline: Two Grieving Sisters, in Love With the Same Man
abstract: In Reine Arcache Melvin’s debut, “The Betrayed,” the Filipina-born daughters of a dead political dissident fall for the enemy.
lead_paragraph: “The only way to get to someone’s story,” Reine Arcache Melvin writes in her debut novel, “The Betrayed,” “was to circle it, again and again, to come close and pull away, to try to catch them off guard.” This line belongs to Lali, one of the main characters, but it is also indicative of Melvin’s overall technique. Throughout the nearly 500 pages, the author circles and weaves, at times delectably close to and other times frustratingly distant from the trio at its center: two politically exiled sisters and the man they both love.

headline: Even With Biden as a Pro-Labor Champion, Unionizing Is Still a Grind
abstract: A flurry of new organizing efforts is giving young people hope.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — This city is known as a capital of organized labor; a legendary 113-day auto strike here in the 1940s helped make health care coverage and pensions the gold standard for employers nationwide. But this year, a notable strike in Detroit happened in a coffee shop, not a car factory.

headline: Has Bidenomics Been Good for Workers?
abstract: Yes, creating millions of jobs is a good thing.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has presided over a huge employment boom that, according to Friday’s employment report, is still in progress. That’s simply a fact, although stating it (like pointing out that we aren’t in a recession at the moment) guarantees that I will receive a truckload of hate mail. By Biden’s second Labor Day, the U.S. economy had added substantially more jobs on his watch than it did in the Trump administration’s first 37 months — that is, before Covid-19 put the economy into a temporary coma.

headline: Javier Zamora Carried a Heavy Load. He Laid It to Rest on the Page.
abstract: Decades after traveling without his parents from El Salvador to the U.S. as a 9-year-old — a journey that almost killed him — Zamora describes the experience in a memoir.
lead_paragraph: Javier Zamora had a lot going for him in 2019: He’d won poetry prizes, an Ivy League fellowship and an “extraordinary ability” visa that finally gave him certainty about his status as an immigrant in the United States.

headline: Frances Tiafoe Downs Rafael Nadal at U.S. Open
abstract: The next generation of top American players has struggled heavily against Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer in Grand Slams. Tiafoe broke through by winning, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3.
lead_paragraph: It happens at just about every Grand Slam. One of the American men of the so-called next generation begins to look dangerous, raising hopes for a breakthrough.

headline: Baseball Traveled to Japan 150 Years Ago. By Way of Maine.
abstract: Japan is celebrating the sport’s introduction there in 1872. The living descendants of the American teacher who took the game to Tokyo only learned of his role in 2000.
lead_paragraph: GORHAM, Maine — This small town on the East Coast can make a claim of being one of baseball’s birthplaces. But Gorham, about a 30-minute drive inland from Portland, has no intention of picking a fight with Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Betty Gilpin Is a Vivid Talker
abstract: The Emmy-nominated star of “GLOW” and “The Hunt,” is also, it turns out, a pretty imaginative writer, as her new book of essays shows.
lead_paragraph: It was 2020, and like pretty much everyone else on planet Earth, the actress Betty Gilpin was having a strange year: Her first leading role in a movie, Craig Zobel’s “The Hunt,” had already stirred a manic level of controversy and drawn the ire of President Trump, before it came out on March 13.

headline: Did Friends Who Vacationed Together for 50 Years Kill Someone?
abstract: In “The Rising Tide,” old school chums who meet on an island off the Northumberland coast become murder suspects.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine once joked that the work of Ann Cleeves is the closest the crime-fiction genre comes to evoking ASMR — the euphoric, pleasant, spine-tingling sensation that’s all the rage on YouTube. The books never get too dark, never venture too far into dangerous territory, but aren’t outright cozy, either.

headline: On the Gulf Coast, a Quiet Hurricane Season (So Far!) Brings Little Relief
abstract: The season has gotten off to an unusually calm start, but the absence of storms has only ratcheted up the anxiety.
lead_paragraph: IOWA, La. — In a community still etched with the scars of past storms that charged in from the Gulf of Mexico, the congregants at St. Pius X begin each service this time of year by petitioning God with the same solemn appeal: Please, spare us.

headline: John McEnroe Gets His Revenge
abstract: While other stars fade, the notorious “Super Brat” has become a subject of fascination and a ubiquitous presence, inside tennis and outside it, too. You have a problem with that?
lead_paragraph: John McEnroe was sitting on a couch 43 stories above Manhattan, his gray curls and sleepy, crinkled eyes betraying every one of his 63 years, some of them hard ones, regaling an awe-struck podcaster with stories of his glory years. His rivalry with Bjorn Borg, his battles with chair umpires and his own demons.

headline: Abortion and Trump Are Giving Democrats a Shot
abstract: This may be a year when politics gets flipped on its head.
lead_paragraph: Forget Hot Girl Summer. We just came off Hot Primary Summer, which featured fewer tequila shots than the Megan Thee Stallion-inspired original — unless, maybe, you were partying with Dr. Oz — but still packed way more drama than you’d expect in a midterm election cycle.

headline: Shopping for Runners
abstract: Sure, you can do without a long rug in your hallway or kitchen. But a runner adds comfort and style.
lead_paragraph: Do you really need a long rug in your hallway? Not necessarily. Bare floors are fine for getting from A to B.

headline: The Hunt for Big Hail
abstract: Hailstones of record size are falling left and right, and hailstorm damage is growing. But there is surprisingly little research to explain why.
lead_paragraph: In August, a couple of days before his 68th birthday, Leslie Scott, a cattle rancher in Vivian, S.D., went to the post office, where he received some bad news. His world record had been broken, the clerk told him. That is, the hailstone Mr. Scott collected in 2010, which measured eight inches across and weighed nearly two pounds, was no longer the largest ever recorded. Some people in Canada had found a bigger one, the clerk said.

headline: With Voters From Both Parties Energized, Campaigns Begin Fall Sprint
abstract: Republicans are focusing on pocketbook issues, and Democrats are emphasizing abortion rights, as Labor Day marks the start of the midterm elections’ final stretch.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, midterm elections have served as a vehicle for voter discontent, a chance for Americans to punish the president, shake up a statehouse and express their anger with the party in power by costing them congressional seats and governor’s mansions.

headline: When George Clooney Met Julia Roberts (Don’t Believe the Reports)
abstract: For their latest big-screen partnership, they play exes who take shots at each other. It’s not such a stretch to the fond insults they sling in real life.
lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts began the interview with a question: “Is George causing problems already?”

headline: Tending to Grass, and to Grief, on a Tennis Court in Iowa
abstract: Twenty years ago, a grass court emerged from the surrounding cornfields in Charles City. Its story is colored by exacting standards, profound loss and, ultimately, rebirth.
lead_paragraph: Mark Kuhn is hunched over, one knee on the ground, pulling dandelions from an otherwise immaculate lawn. With a small, serrated blade, he carefully carves tiny leaves from the turf, extracting as much of their roots as he can reach, and places them in a plastic container beside him. Dandelions, I learn, are as prolific as they are stubborn.

headline: What You Get for $1 Million in California
abstract: A 1921 bungalow in Berkeley, a 1942 ranch house in Altadena and a midcentury-modern home in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: A 1921 bungalow in Berkeley, a 1942 ranch house in Altadena and a midcentury-modern home in San Diego.

headline: $1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1921 bungalow in Berkeley, a 1942 ranch house in Altadena and a midcentury-modern home in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: This house is in South Berkeley, a neighborhood where bungalows built in the early 20th century are plentiful. It is a few blocks from the well-known Berkeley Bowl grocery store and less than two miles from the University of California, Berkeley. San Pablo Park, which has a recreation center, tennis courts and athletic fields, is half a mile away. San Pablo Avenue, which has several tea shops, a breakfast cafe, and Thai and Vietnamese restaurants, is about a mile away. The nearest BART stop, Ashby Station, is a five-minute drive.

headline: Quotation of the Day: This Earth, This Realm, This Land of Bieber and the Bard
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s changed the museum forever, in a myriad of ways.”

headline: With Boris Johnson’s departure, Ukraine loses a friend.
abstract: If there is one place where appreciation for Mr. Johnson is undimmed, it is Ukraine, where he has been seen as a genuine friend since Russia’s invasion in February.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, where his long association with scandal forced his resignation.

headline: Trial Over 2016 Terror Attack in Nice Opens in Paris
abstract: A self-radicalized Tunisian man plowed a truck through crowds celebrating Bastille Day, killing 86. The proceedings, against eight defendants, are scheduled to last until December.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The third high-profile terrorism trial in France in two years opened on Monday in Paris, with eight defendants facing charges in a 2016 attack in the Mediterranean city of Nice that left more than 80 people dead and hundreds more injured or traumatized.

headline: As China Imposes More Covid Lockdowns, ‘Everyone Is Scared’
abstract: Nearly every province has recorded infections in recent days, leaving some 60 million residents locked down. Weariness is growing by the day as the restrictions go on seemingly without end.
lead_paragraph: In the hours before the southern Chinese city of Chengdu entered a coronavirus lockdown, Matthew Chen visited four vegetable markets in an attempt to stock up on fresh food. But seemingly the entire city had the same idea, and by the time he got to each place, most of the shelves had been stripped bare, except for hot peppers and fruit, he said.

headline: The candidates sought to channel an icon of the right: Margaret Thatcher.
abstract: LONDON — When Rishi Sunak kicked off his campaign for leader of Britain’s Conservative Party and prime minister in July, his choice of venue — a tire shop in the market town of Grantham — felt almost inevitable.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Rishi Sunak kicked off his campaign for leader of Britain’s Conservative Party and prime minister in July, his choice of venue — a tire shop in the market town of Grantham — felt almost inevitable.

headline: Northwest Georgia Hit by Severe Storms and Flash Flooding
abstract: An estimated 12 inches of rain fell in Chattooga and Floyd Counties, where the governor declared a state of emergency. A flood watch was discontinued Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: A flood watch was lifted Monday night for parts of Georgia that were inundated with a foot of rain a day earlier, as storm damage was still being assessed.

headline: Cyrus Mistry, Who Once Led India’s Biggest Company, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Mistry, who was unceremoniously removed from his job in 2016, was killed in a car accident.
lead_paragraph: An Indian-born Irish businessman who once led India’s biggest conglomerate but was unceremoniously removed from his job died in a car accident in the western Indian state of Maharashtra on Sunday. He was 54.

headline: The Fall Dining Scene
abstract: Diners are returning from their summer vacations and heading back into restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants scrapped printed menus and told diners to scan QR codes. Plexiglass partitions were installed between tables. Restaurants began selling more merchandise and even kitchen goods.

headline: Kenya’s Supreme Court Upholds Presidential Election Results
abstract: In a sweeping rejection of claims that the Aug. 9 vote had been rigged, the court confirmed Vice President William Ruto as the country’s fifth president.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Supreme Court of Kenya on Monday upheld the election of William Ruto as president, ending an acrimonious courtroom battle over disputed results from the Aug. 9 election and confirming Mr. Ruto as the fifth president of a country often seen as a beacon of democratic strength in Africa.

headline: OPEC Plus Agrees to Cut Production by 100,000 Barrels a Day
abstract: The oil producers group is worried about slipping prices, weak demand in China and a deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Officials of OPEC and its major allies agreed on Monday to modestly cut oil production by 100,000 barrels a day, rolling back the increase they approved a month ago.

headline: The Conservatives Made Everything in Britain Worse (Yes, Even the Weather)
abstract: With Liz Truss as its next prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.
lead_paragraph: So Liz Truss will be Britain’s next prime minister — the nation’s fourth in seven years. And she’s inheriting a nation falling apart at the seams.

headline: The Conservatives Made Everything in Britain Worse (Yes, Even the Weather)
abstract: With a new prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.
lead_paragraph: With a new prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.

headline: A Hawkish Diplomat Takes Control, Facing Hard Times and Johnson’s Ghost
abstract: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON —  As a passionate 19-year-old student at Oxford in 1994, Elizabeth Truss called for a referendum to abolish the British monarchy, telling an audience of fellow Liberal Democrats, “We do not believe that people should be born to rule.”

headline: A frightening economic picture awaits the new prime minister.
abstract: Consumer prices in Britain are rising at their fastest pace in decades, as the inflation rate exceeds 10 percent and is expected to keep climbing.
lead_paragraph: For the past eight weeks through the Conservative Party’s leadership contest, the severity of Britain’s economic troubles only worsened. The new prime minister, Liz Truss, will be greeted with a long list of demands for rapid and aggressive support to alleviate the pain caused by the rising cost of living.

headline: Museums in the U.S. and Europe Are in Blockbuster Mode
abstract: From Los Angeles to Antwerp, Jason Farago, our critic at large, picks a fall season laden with offerings on Cubism, modern Korean art and paintings of the Spanish Baroque.
lead_paragraph: Nothing makes sense anymore! War rages everywhere, politicians prattle; new media come at you a mile a minute; the world your parents built is collapsing, and only chaos lies ahead. Do you cower? Do you take refuge in tradition? Or do you do what they did 100 years ago: plunge into the chaos and make something new?

headline: Markets Wobble as Britain Gets a New Prime Minister and Energy Worries Grow
abstract: Liz Truss, the Conservative Party’s choice, will face a falling British pound and myriad economic troubles.
lead_paragraph: If financial markets are sending a message to Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, it’s one of concern.

headline: ‘Recipes for Love and Murder’ That Are to Die For
abstract: Set in a picturesque South African town, this series stars Maria Doyle Kennedy as a columnist who serves up mouthwatering dishes while solving murder mysteries.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — In the opening moments of “Recipes for Love and Murder,” a gentle new murder mystery series from Acorn TV, a woman emerges from a farmhouse holding a live chicken and picks up an ax: Thwack. Squawk.

headline: Under Liz Truss, Britain is expected to double down on support for Ukraine.
abstract: As foreign secretary, Ms. Truss back in March said “Putin must lose,” using language that went beyond that of the U.S. and other Western allies.
lead_paragraph: On the world stage, Britain’s incoming prime minister, Liz Truss, is best known for taking a hard line against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Suicide Attack Hits Russian Embassy in Afghanistan, Killing 2 Employees
abstract: The bombing in Kabul, which also left 4 Afghan civilians dead, was the first strike on a diplomatic mission since the Taliban regained control.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber attacked the Russian Embassy in Kabul on Monday, killing two employees and four Afghan civilians, Russian and Afghan officials said, in the first assault on a diplomatic mission in the country since the Taliban seized power last year.

headline: Venice: ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ Faces the Press, but Where Is Florence Pugh?
abstract: Though the movie’s star skipped the media session, director Olivia Wilde called rumors of their feud ‘endless tabloid gossip.’
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Even before the talent filed in for the “Don’t Worry Darling” news conference on Monday afternoon at the Venice Film Festival, the name placards on the dais told a story.

headline: Strong Earthquake Shakes Southwestern China, Killing Dozens
abstract: Government agencies said at least 65 people had died, but communications in the landslide-prone area were disrupted and the full extent of the damage was unclear.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A strong earthquake shook a mountainous, steep-sloped area in southwestern China on Monday, and local government agencies said on Tuesday morning that at least 65 people had been killed and more than 250 others were injured. At least 12 people were said to be missing.

headline: 7 Musicals Head to Broadway This Fall, but 100 More Lie in Wait
abstract: Behind every new New York season are a lot of wannabes, also-rans and hopeless cases to keep track of.
lead_paragraph: I have friends who keep a spreadsheet of every show they’ve seen, cross-indexed to their Playbill collection.

headline: Fantasy Face-Off: ‘The Rings of Power’ vs. ‘House of the Dragon’
abstract: Which has the better dragons? Which has the better swords? Now that we’ve seen a few episodes of each, here’s an early comparison.
lead_paragraph: Comparisons between HBO’s “House of the Dragon” and Amazon’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” — both new epic fantasies, both prequel series, both with huge budgets and ready-made fan bases — were probably inevitable. And indeed the internet has already been more than happy to oblige.

headline: To Mask, or Not to Mask: Theaters and Concert Halls Face a Dilemma
abstract: Some audience members are turned off by mask mandates. Others won’t attend indoor performances without them. Arts presenters are taking different approaches this season.
lead_paragraph: The new masking policy at “The Kite Runner” on Broadway was devised at the doctor’s office.

headline: In Shift, Israel Says Journalist Was Most Likely Shot by Israeli Soldier
abstract: The Israeli Army has concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American broadcaster, was probably killed by one of its own soldiers — but stopped short of accepting definitive blame.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Army on Monday acknowledged for the first time that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist killed in May in the occupied West Bank, was most likely shot by an Israeli soldier, but it stopped short of definitively accepting responsibility for her death.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Last-minute Labor Day recipes for your holiday, a charred okra salad and more.
lead_paragraph: The first Labor Day parade was in New York City in 1882. More than a decade later, Labor Day became a national holiday, the fruit of activists who wanted to underscore the social and economic achievements of the American worker.

headline: Your Final Wine School Assignment
abstract: This last class will examine Alpine white wines, but after 100 classes, the most important messages should carry through to a long and pleasing relationship with wine.
lead_paragraph: This column will be the last installment of Wine School.

headline: What’s the Deal With Riesling?
abstract: The dry white wine can’t seem to win fans. Are wine lovers generalizing from bad wines, or is riesling’s appeal profound but too narrow?
lead_paragraph: When introducing the subject of dry German rieslings last month, I wondered why so many people say they do not like the wines, whether dry or sweet. After spending the last month drinking them and reading through comments, I confess, not surprisingly, that I’ve come no closer to finding an answer.

headline: No, Turning the Tables Won’t Create Political Understanding
abstract: Readers disagree with a guest essay about investigating Democrats. Also: protecting civilians; signs of Alzheimer’s; alternative words for retirement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Katie Crutchfield and Jess Williamson Embrace Their Roots, as Plains
abstract: Both singer-songwriters came of age in the South and started out in indie-rock. Their joint project explores a spectrum of country influences and lets them reckon with their pasts.
lead_paragraph: Though they first met only five years ago, the musicians Katie Crutchfield and Jess Williamson have long walked parallel paths.

headline: Of Barbecues and Men: A Summer Storm Brews Over Virility in France
abstract: A Green politician told men to get over meat and masculinity for the sake of the planet, setting off a sizzling argument.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s “la rentrée” in France, the back-to-school, return-to-normal month after the vacations that is often marked by renewed social conflict. But nobody expected France to be up in arms over barbecues.

headline: Deadline Looms for Trump Media Merger
abstract: The company seeking to acquire the social media site needs shareholder approval to extend the time to complete the deal. The results of the vote are to be announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The cash-rich company that seeks to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company is facing a looming deadline and is asking shareholders to give it more time to complete the deal.

headline: Judge Grants Trump’s Request for Special Master to Review Mar-a-Lago Documents
abstract: The ruling also effectively barred federal prosecutors from using key pieces of evidence as they continue to investigate whether Mr. Trump illegally retained national defense documents at his estate.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge intervened on Monday in the investigation of former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of sensitive government records, ordering the appointment of an independent arbiter to review a trove of materials seized last month from Mr. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida.

headline: Horror grips a bucolic farming region after the killing spree.
abstract: Police searches and the roar of helicopters disrupt the routine in a rural stretch of Saskatchewan.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s bucolic prairie region is known for its rolling landscapes and farming industry. But on Monday, it was in the global spotlight because of one of the worst mass stabbings in Canada’s recent memory.

headline: Meta Fined $400 Million for Treatment of Children’s Data on Instagram
abstract: Irish regulators said Instagram violated European data protection rules. It was the latest move by authorities in Europe and the U.S. related to child protection online.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Meta was fined roughly $400 million for breaking European Union data privacy laws for its treatment of children’s data on Instagram, the latest in a series of steps by authorities in Europe and the United States to crack down on what information is collected and shared by companies about young people online.

headline: Moon Landrieu, 92, Dies; New Orleans Mayor Championed Integration
abstract: He rose in local politics in the 1960s and ’70s by nurturing crosscultural connections, even as many other Southern leaders of his era exploited racial division.
lead_paragraph: Moon Landrieu, who reshaped racial politics in one of the nation’s most polyglot and irrepressible cities, New Orleans, where he won the mayor’s office in 1970 with a rare coalition of white and Black supporters, died on Monday at his home in New Orleans. He was 92.

headline: At the Telluride Film Festival, ‘Women Talking’ and Other Topics of Conversation
abstract: Up in the mountains, feminism, artistic solipsism, Lady Chatterley and Cate Blanchett mingle in an expansive vision of mainstream moviemaking.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — At the Telluride Film Festival here, the “ringmasters” who introduce screenings in venues that include two school auditoriums, a hockey rink, an old opera house and a classic single-screen movie theater like to invoke the pure love of cinema as the sole organizing principle. The conceit of this annual Labor Day weekend event, which lures a few thousand travelers high into the Rockies to sit in dark rooms amid spectacular scenery, is that it rises above the hype and hustle that animate other major festivals.

headline: Celtic’s Tokyo Drift Into the Champions League
abstract: Under its well-traveled Australian coach, the Scottish champion has become a gateway to Europe for Japanese players, and a model for clubs trying to punch above their financial weight.
lead_paragraph: Ange Postecoglou did not have much time. The Australian coach was not Celtic’s first choice as manager: The Glasgow club had, instead, spent weeks last summer trying to persuade the Englishman Eddie Howe to take the post. By the time Postecoglou was hired in June 2021 — and served out his mandatory quarantine upon arrival in Scotland — he had little more than a month before his first competitive game.

headline: Nick Kyrgios Is Having a Very Good U.S. Open. Make That Summer.
abstract: The often tortured tennis player said he was “really sick of letting people down,” after beating No. 1 ranked Daniil Medvedev to advance to the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: His tennis, always sublime some of the time, has been sublime far more of the time.

headline: 50 Years After Attack at Munich Olympics, a Formal German Apology
abstract: Palestinian militants killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games in 1972. Decades later Germany asked the victims’ families for forgiveness for not keeping the delegation safe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Fifty years ago, Fürstenfeldbruck airfield was the scene of a bloody firefight. When it was over, two burned-out helicopters were neatly parked on the bullet-riddled tarmac, a symbol of German failure in the face of a terrorist attack at the Munich Olympics that left 11 athletes and one German policeman dead.

headline: Work Is Intrinsically Good. Or Maybe It’s Not?
abstract: A question to ponder on Labor Day.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Labor Day, I offer this stirring quotation from the Scottish essayist and historian Thomas Carlyle:

headline: Breaking Taboo, Germany Extends Life of 2 Nuclear Reactors
abstract: The step is intended to cushion a growing energy crisis in Europe but could upend the country’s plans to become the first industrial power to shutter its program.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany will keep two of its three remaining nuclear power plants operational as an emergency reserve for its electricity supply, its energy minister announced on Monday, delaying the country’s plans to become the first industrial power to go nuclear-free for its energy.

headline: Frank Drake, Who Led Search for Life on Other Planets, Dies at 92
abstract: He was convinced that human beings would eventually connect with extraterrestrials, and he inspired others to share that belief.
lead_paragraph: Frank Drake, who pointed a radio telescope at a pair of stars in 1960 hoping to find alien civilizations and thus kindled a continuing endeavor called the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence, or SETI, died on Friday at his home in Aptos, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Chileans Reject Left-Leaning Constitution
abstract: After three years of debate, Chileans voted against a new constitution that would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enacted more than 100 rights.
lead_paragraph: After three years of debate, Chileans voted against a new constitution that would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enacted more than 100 rights.

headline: California swelters through a Labor Day heat wave, stretching its electricity resources.
abstract: Demand was expected to outstrip energy supply on Monday evening, an official said, and Tuesday could see record demand for power.
lead_paragraph: A vast dome of high pressure has edged westward and settled over California, inflicting sweltering and record-setting temperatures across much of the state and threatening to strain the state’s power grid.

headline: All the Color and Joy of the West Indian Parade’s Comeback
abstract: Scenes from the Labor Day tradition, which returned to Brooklyn after it had been canceled for two years because of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Brooklyn bid farewell to summer with J’Ouvert, a predawn reverie with roots in the emancipation of enslaved people in the Caribbean, followed by the West Indian American Day Parade, where throngs of costumed paraders dance into the dusk.

headline: Russia sentences a prominent journalist to 22 years in prison on treason charges.
abstract: The prosecution of Ivan Safronov, a former defense reporter, sent chills through the Russian journalism community.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court on Monday sentenced a former journalist to 22 years in a high-security prison on two counts of treason, signaling a new level of repression against the free press in Russia and provoking an outcry in the journalism community.

headline: In Senegal, Riding the Train for the First Time
abstract: Our reporter takes a ride on Senegal's first regional express train.
lead_paragraph: Our reporter takes a ride on Senegal's first regional express train.

headline: The police have been criticized for their handling of crimes against Indigenous people.
abstract: After the Sunday stabbings, police treatment of Indigenous communities is under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The brutal knife assaults in Saskatchewan are likely to revive concerns in Indigenous communities about the seriousness with which the Canadian authorities treat crimes against them.

headline: Liz Truss to Replace Boris Johnson at a Time of Crisis for Britain
abstract: Ms. Truss, who prevailed over Rishi Sunak, will be greeted by an array of vexing problems, including double-digit inflation, a looming recession, labor unrest and soaring household energy bills.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A divided British Conservative Party announced on Monday that it had chosen Liz Truss to replace Prime Minister Boris Johnson, turning to a party stalwart, hawkish diplomat and free-market champion to lead a country facing the gravest economic crisis in a generation.

headline: California Governor Signs Bill to Regulate Fast-Food Industry
abstract: The measure will create a state council to establish minimum pay and regulate safety conditions on an industrywide basis.
lead_paragraph: California will enact a sweeping new approach to regulating fast-food restaurants after Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday that he had signed a bill to effectively set a minimum wage in the industry and to create new safety and anti-discrimination rules.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Liz Truss Selected to Lead Britain
abstract: And a typhoon bears down on South Korea, and more Covid lockdowns rip through China.
lead_paragraph: Liz Truss will formally assume the prime minister’s title in a meeting today with Queen Elizabeth II at Balmoral Castle in Scotland.

headline: ‘Famine Is at the Door’ in Somalia, U.N. Warns
abstract: A U.N. official stopped short of officially declaring a famine in the country. But some aid workers said that the threshold had already been reached.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations on Monday declared that “Famine is at the door” in Somalia, as nearly half the country’s population faced severe hunger and food deliveries were impeded by conflict, mass displacement and the ever-growing threat from the militant group Al Shabab.

headline: Ukraine Nuclear Plant Pulled Off Line After Shelling Kindles Blaze
abstract: A fire caused by shelling forced the staff of Europe’s largest nuclear plant to disconnect from the nation’s power grid, showing that risks remained at the plant despite the presence of U.N. experts.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A fire caused by renewed shelling near Europe’s largest nuclear power plant led to its disconnection from the national power grid on Monday, Ukrainian officials said, raising fears that despite the presence of U.N. inspectors, conditions at the Russian-occupied facility could deteriorate quickly and threaten a catastrophe.

headline: CVS Makes $8 Billion Bet on the Return of the House Call
abstract: The deal for Signify Health, which has a network of doctors who make home visits, would cement the drugstore chain’s move away from its traditional roots.
lead_paragraph: The drugstore giant CVS Health said on Monday that it would acquire Signify Health, which runs a network of doctors making house calls, for roughly $8 billion in a deal that cements the pharmacy chain’s move away from its retail roots.

headline: Map: Tracking Typhoon Hinnamnor
abstract: Map showing the expected path of Typhoon Hinnamnor.
lead_paragraph: Map showing the expected path of Typhoon Hinnamnor.

headline: In Canada’s Bucolic Prairie Region, a Mass Stabbing Shocks the Country
abstract: The body of a man being sought by the authorities was found with wounds that were not believed to be self-inflicted. The killing of 10 people stunned the country.
lead_paragraph: WELDON, Saskatchewan — The horror began at 5:40 a.m. on Sunday, when the police received a report of a stabbing on a rural Indigenous reserve in the western Canadian province of Saskatchewan. By the time the rampage was over, hours later, the police said that 10 people were dead and 18 wounded — some apparently chosen at random — in a killing spree that has shaken the country.

headline: With the Yankees on His Shoulders, Aaron Judge Stays Ahead of Maris
abstract: Judge’s go-ahead homer against the Twins has him on pace for 64 this season. He says he just wants to win. “It’s not all about me, no matter what happens.”
lead_paragraph: Sixty-one years ago, in the 135th game on the Yankees’ schedule, Roger Maris blasted his 52nd and 53rd home runs of the season. The first one came off the Detroit Tigers’ Frank Lary, who was widely known as “The Yankee Killer” for somehow mastering the best lineup of the era.

headline: ‘Deeply Problematic’: Experts Question Judge’s Intervention in Trump Inquiry
abstract: A ruling by a judge appointed by former President Donald J. Trump surprised specialists and could slow the documents investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge’s extraordinary decision on Monday to interject in the criminal investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s hoarding of sensitive government documents at his Florida residence showed unusual solicitude to him, legal specialists said.

headline: Russia Is Buying North Korean Artillery, According to U.S. Intelligence
abstract: Moscow’s purchase of millions of shells and rockets from North Korea is a sign that global sanctions have hampered the Russian military’s supply lines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is buying millions of artillery shells and rockets from North Korea, according to newly declassified American intelligence, a sign that global sanctions have severely restricted its supply chains and forced Moscow to turn to pariah states for military supplies.

headline: Doing Things the Rite Way
abstract: Trenton Charlson’s puzzle is an indication of more to come.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Tuesday, solvers! Today we have a puzzle from the constructor Trenton Charlson, who is making his 37th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. That’s a lot of crosswords, and if today’s puzzle is any indication, I suspect there will be many more to come from Mr. Charlson.

headline: Rafael Nadal Loses His Serve and His Way at the U.S. Open
abstract: His loss to Frances Tiafoe was Nadal’s earliest defeat at a major tournament in more than five years and the first time he had been beaten in any major in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal clenched his fists and roared at the U.S. Open on Monday.

headline: Typhoon Hinnamnor Drenches South Korea
abstract: Typhoon Hinnamnor made landfall in South Korea, bringing record winds and dumping as much as 24 inches of rain on some parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Hinnamnor made landfall in South Korea, bringing record winds and dumping as much as 24 inches of rain on some parts of the country.

headline: South Korean Marines in Pohang Rescue Hinnamnor Flood Victims
abstract: The Ministry of Defense said a division of the South Korean Marines in Pohang had dispatched firefighters in two amphibious assault vehicles to rescue flood victims from Typhoon Hinnamnor.
lead_paragraph: The Ministry of Defense said a division of the South Korean Marines in Pohang had dispatched firefighters in two amphibious assault vehicles to rescue flood victims from Typhoon Hinnamnor.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Challenge to French Virility Is Red Meat for Debate
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “What are we going to eat? Tofu and soy beans? Come on!”

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 6, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: The Key to Saquon Barkley’s Football Future? Playing With ‘No Fear.’
abstract: Barkley’s prolific rookie season in 2018 justified the Giants’ risk of using the No. 2 overall pick on him. A reversion to form may help convince the team’s new leadership to extend his contract.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For just a moment, during a joint practice with the Jets at the end of August, Giants running back Saquon Barkley reversed time.

headline: What to Watch For in the Massachusetts Primaries
abstract: Democrats expect to reclaim the governor’s office this fall with Maura Healey, there’s a three-way Democratic primary for lieutenant governor and Boston has a messy district attorney race.
lead_paragraph: The 2022 primaries are almost, but not quite, over: Voters in Massachusetts go to the polls on Tuesday, the second-to-last election night of the primary season.

headline: ‘Nothing Has Really Changed’: In Moscow, the Fighting Is a World Away
abstract: A detachment from the battle in Ukraine is exactly what President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is counting on as he carries out a domestic strategy of shielding his people from hardships.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On a recent evening in Red Square, a corps of elite paratroopers dressed in camouflage performed a battle-like dance with pyrotechnics. An Egyptian performer dressed as a pharaoh rode back and forth in a chariot wielding an ankh, the ancient Egyptian symbol of life, as a band played “Katyusha,” a Soviet-era patriotic war song.

headline: Will Return to Office Get Serious in September?
abstract: Bosses want employees back, but it looks like the return will be gradual and depend on the future of Covid.
lead_paragraph: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at who’s returning to the office and why the expectations are different from a year ago. We’ll also see how J’Ouvert and the West Indian American Day Parade unfolded in Brooklyn.

headline: The Void Serena Williams Left in Tennis Doesn’t Need to Be Filled
abstract: Tennis has long thrived on singular stars, no one bigger than Serena Williams. But perhaps women’s tennis doesn’t need one big name to be interesting.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams is gone from the game; at least, we think so. Given the sharp, competitive way she played at the U.S. Open last week, maybe, just maybe, she’ll end up coming back for an encore.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A special master will review Mar-a-Lago files.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday ordered the appointment of an independent arbiter, known as a special master, to review a trove of materials seized by the F.B.I. last month from Mar-a-Lago, Donald Trump’s residence in Florida. Justice Department officials have not yet said whether they will appeal the ruling.

headline: Britain’s New Prime Minister Is Still in Thrall to the Empire
abstract: Liz Truss is absorbed in imperial thinking.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Do we confront this moment with honesty,” asked Rishi Sunak, one of the two candidates running to replace Boris Johnson as prime minister of Britain, “or do we tell ourselves comforting fairy tales?”

headline: In farewell speech, Boris Johnson pledges to support Liz Truss ‘every step of the way.’
abstract: The outgoing prime minister defended his three-year tenure but appealed to his party to unite around his successor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A defiant Boris Johnson defended his three-year premiership but appealed to his party to unite around his successor, Liz Truss, in his final address as Britain’s prime minister on Tuesday morning.

headline: Watch Live: Boris Johnson Delivers Farewell Remarks
abstract: Boris Johnson is expected to deliver his final address as prime minister, kicking off a day of events that will see the political office transfer to his successor, Liz Truss.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson is expected to deliver his final address as prime minister, kicking off a day of events that will see the political office transfer to his successor, Liz Truss.

headline: Word of the Day: myriad
abstract: This word has appeared in 404 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word myriad has appeared in 404 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 29 in “How Serena Williams Won the Fashion Game” by Vanessa Friedman:

headline: Kylian Mbappé Is Coming for It All
abstract: In a rare interview, the French soccer star discussed chasing the Champions League title, supplanting his teammate Lionel Messi as world player of the year and the possibility of a move to Real Madrid.
lead_paragraph: Kylian Mbappé will eventually turn up for his interview in an oversized vehicle outfitted with tinted windows, and accompanied by his mother, two P.R. reps, two lawyers, a small documentary crew, a stylist and a friend whose role is, initially, unclear. This is how one of the world’s biggest sports stars travels these days. Kylian Mbappé doesn’t just walk through the door. He arrives.

headline: The queen will meet the new prime minister at Balmoral Castle in Scotland.
abstract: The meeting, usually performed at Buckingham Palace, was moved as the 96-year-old monarch faces health challenges.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In her 70 years on the throne, Queen Elizabeth II has formally appointed more than a dozen prime ministers at Buckingham Palace. On Tuesday, for the first time, she will hold the ceremony at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, where she is spending the summer.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Biden Administration Releases Plan for $50 Billion Investment in Chips
abstract: The Commerce Department issued guidelines for companies angling to receive federal funding aimed at bolstering the domestic semiconductor industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Commerce on Tuesday unveiled its plan for dispensing $50 billion aimed at building up the domestic semiconductor industry and countering China, in what is expected to be the biggest U.S. government effort in decades to shape a strategic industry.

headline: As Ex-Uber Executive Heads to Trial, the Security Community Reels
abstract: Joe Sullivan, Uber’s former chief of security, faces criminal charges for his handling of a 2016 security breach. His trial this week has divided the security industry.
lead_paragraph: Joe Sullivan was a rock star in the information security world. One of the first federal prosecutors to work on cybercrime cases in the late 1990s, he jumped into the corporate security world in 2002, eventually taking on high-profile roles as chief of security at Facebook and Uber.

headline: Biden Puts Defense of Democracy at Center of Agenda, at Home and Abroad
abstract: President Biden’s foreign policy priority overlaps with a main domestic drive — both made more urgent by the persistent power of China, Russia and Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is the element of President Biden’s foreign policy that overlaps most significantly with his domestic agenda: defending democracy.

headline: It Was War. Then, a Rancher’s Truce With Some Pesky Beavers Paid Off.
abstract: The ‘highly skilled environmental engineers’ can help to store precious water and rejuvenate land ravaged by climate change. Just don’t dynamite their homes.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Battling Violence and Censors, Women in China Become ‘Invisible and Absent’
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party has long promoted gender equality as a core tenet, but as cases of gender abuse make headlines, Beijing has tried to squelch dissent and control the narrative.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When a prominent woman in China’s #MeToo movement took on a powerful man in court, it was the accused, not the accuser, who was held up as the victim. When several women were savagely beaten by men after resisting unwanted advances in a restaurant, the focus of the story pivoted from gender violence to gang violence. And when a mother of eight was found chained to the wall of a doorless shack, it was her mental fitness — not her imprisonment — that became the talking point.

headline: Biden Administration Has Admitted One Million Migrants to Await Hearings
abstract: The presence of asylum seekers in the United States is both a humanitarian challenge and a political flash point in a divided country.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH PORTLAND, Maine — At a modest hotel a few miles from the ocean here, most of the rooms have been occupied this summer by families from African countries seeking asylum — 192 adults and 119 children in all.

headline: Scenes From the Aftermath of Typhoon Hinnamnor
abstract: The storm swept past South Korea’s southeastern corner, causing at least three deaths, sparking a fire at a steel plant and leaving tens of thousands without power.
lead_paragraph: One of the most powerful storms of the year made landfall in South Korea early Tuesday, sparing the country of the brunt of its destructive force yet still leaving it reeling from severe, if isolated, flooding and damage.

headline: Boris Johnson Delivers Last Address as Prime Minister
abstract: Boris Johnson pledged to support his successor, Liz Truss, in his final speech as Britain’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson pledged to support his successor, Liz Truss, in his final speech as Britain’s prime minister.

headline: What Were Your ‘Mundane Joys’ of Summer?
abstract: What ordinary moments did you enjoy during your summer vacation?
lead_paragraph: What did you do this summer? Did you work or go to camp? Commune with animals and nature? Pick up a book and laze about in the sun reading it? Or find creative ways to stay cool in the blistering heat? Maybe you tried something new or just spent time with old friends?

headline: Summer Playlist
abstract: What did you listen to over and over this summer?
lead_paragraph: How important is music to you? What did you listen to this summer? How did it capture your feelings and moods? What songs remind you of the things you did and the people you did them with?

headline: Can You Get Hooked on Melatonin?
abstract: The sleep supplement doesn’t cause physical dependence, but falling asleep without it can be tricky for some people.
lead_paragraph: Whether you reached for melatonin to ward off the “coronasomnia” that set in during the pandemic or have turned to the supplement for years, taking it can become a comforting nightly ritual — almost like an insurance policy for uneasy sleepers.

headline: Lesson Plan: The First Images From the James Webb Space Telescope
abstract: In this lesson, students will closely examine these spectacular pictures and consider their meaning and significance in understanding the universe — and ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Webb Telescope Reveals a New Vision of an Ancient Universe” by Dennis Overbye, Kenneth Chang and Joshua Sokol

headline: The Subtle Art of Appreciating ‘Difficult Beauty’
abstract: The writer Chloé Cooper Jones talks about bodies, disability and how searching for beauty can change our lives.
lead_paragraph: When is the last time you paused — truly paused the flow of life — to appreciate something beautiful? For as long as we know, humans have sought out beauty, believing deeply that beautiful things and experiences can enhance our lives. But what does beauty really do to us? How can it fundamentally alter our experience of the world?

headline: Debtors, Unite! You Have Nothing to Lose but Your Shame.
abstract: Conversations about debt are never purely about economics. They are always also conversations about power and morality.
lead_paragraph: Conversations about debt are never purely about economics. They are always, also, conversations about power, morality and shame. The debate over President Biden’s student loan relief plan is no exception.

headline: Why Gorbachev Mattered
abstract: Gorbachev’s dream of a democratic, prosperous Russia at peace with its neighbors has been dashed.
lead_paragraph: No world leader has a bigger place in the history of the late 20th century than Mikhail Gorbachev, for the pivotal role he played in the peaceful end of the Cold War. The free world will be forever grateful to him, even if many of his fellow citizens are not.

headline: The Stakes
abstract: This November, Americans will head to the polls for the first major political test since Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: “I’m worried that democracy is being eroded.”

headline: The Notorious Madame S.
abstract: The toast and terror of Belle Epoque Paris, Marguerite Steinheil was a society hostess, a woman of letters, a muse — and probably a murderer.
lead_paragraph: Although she is not universally known to Americans, Marguerite Steinheil is a household name in France, the subject of books, plays and television specials — and with some reason. As Sarah Horowitz, a professor of history and the head of the Women’s, Gender and Sexuality Studies program at Washington and Lee University, recounts, Steinheil’s salon was adorned by the great eminences of the Third Republic, and among her lovers was the French president, Félix Faure.

headline: Agatha Christie’s Latest Biographer Plumbs a Life of Mystery
abstract: In “Agatha Christie: An Elusive Woman,” Lucy Worsley revisits the weird story of one of the 20th century’s most popular and enduring authors.
lead_paragraph: Agatha Christie’s best books have crisp dialogue and high-velocity plots. The bad ones have a Mad Libs quality: feeble prose studded with blank spots into which you can picture the prolific Christie plugging a random “BODY PART” or “WEAPON.” In a 1971 study of English crime fiction, Colin Watson snickered that Christie “seems to have been well aware that intelligence and readership-potential are quite unrelated.”

headline: Signal, the Encrypted Messaging App, Appoints a President
abstract: In the newly created role, Meredith Whittaker will guide policy and strategy for the messaging app and work to expand its business.
lead_paragraph: Signal, the encrypted messaging app, has tapped Meredith Whittaker, a former adviser to the Federal Trade Commission chair and an artificial intelligence expert who protested Google’s use of the technology for military projects, as its president.

headline: Lea Michele and the Question of Second Chances
abstract: What happens when a canceled star makes a comeback?
lead_paragraph: Before she was canceled — however you choose to define that word — the actress Lea Michele had been more or less auditioning for a decade to star in “Funny Girl” on Broadway someday.

headline: Are Vasectomies Reversible?
abstract: If you are considering the procedure, but are worried about its permanence, here is what experts want you to know.
lead_paragraph: Q: Are vasectomies reversible?

headline: Distance Pains
abstract: In her follow-up to “The Outrun,” Amy Liptrot grapples with more urban demons.
lead_paragraph: Amy Liptrot’s debut, “The Outrun,” was an unflinching examination of trauma, addiction and the restorative power of the natural world: Her rendering of Orkney, in the North Isles of Scotland, acts as a counterpoint to the detailed description of her alcohol abuse, collapse and recovery. It is a wild, wind-lashed book, and you come away from reading with the taste of salt spray on your lips.

headline: Steeper Winter Heating Bills Loom, With Less Federal Aid
abstract: Energy costs are expected to rise even faster than overall inflation, but a key assistance program will lack the extra funds it got for Covid relief.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, Michael Jandro and Jillian Park could have faced heating costs that rivaled the $806 monthly mortgage payment on their Maine farmhouse.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to Uproot Your Life and Open an Inn
abstract: In early 2020, Maureen McNamara and her wife, Jennifer Stark, traded in their popular restaurant in Michigan for an inn nestled in the Catskill Mountains of New York. The inn opened just days before the pandemic was declared.
lead_paragraph: It’s Never Too Late is a series about people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.

headline: Money Can’t Buy Class. Or Can It?
abstract: In “Status and Culture,” W. David Marx sets out to unravel the grand mysteries of identity.
lead_paragraph: W. David Marx writes that he was inspired to tackle his subject because he couldn’t find “a single book that explains the Grand Mystery of Culture.”  The capitalization immediately, and knowingly, evokes grandiosity: arcane scholarly tracts, Mr. Casaubon’s doomed pursuit of “The Key to all Mythologies” — not to mention most of Malcolm Gladwell’s oeuvre.

headline: The Electrifying, Emotional Return of Yeah Yeah Yeahs
abstract: After a nearly decade-long break, the trio that helped spark New York’s early 2000s rock revival is back with “Cool It Down,” an expansive album that dares to imagine a bold, fresh future.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The Yeah Yeah Yeahs were planning to cry.

headline: Cameras, Plexiglass, Fireproofing: Election Officials Beef Up Security
abstract: With violent rhetoric from the right intensifying, some election officials are bolstering their defenses. Others are quitting.
lead_paragraph: In Wisconsin, one of the nation’s key swing states, cameras and plexiglass now fortify the reception area of a county election office in Madison, the capital, after a man wearing camouflage and a mask tried to open locked doors during an election in April.

headline: This Jellyfish Can Live Forever. Its Genes May Tell Us How.
abstract: A new study followed as a Turritopsis dohrnii rejuvenated itself, uncovering developmental patterns for further inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Fleets of tiny translucent umbrellas, each about the size of a lentil, waft through the waters of the Mediterranean Sea. These miniature jellyfish, known as Turritopsis dohrnii, wave and grasp with their pale tentacles, bringing plankton to their mouths like many other jellyfish species adrift in the glowing water.

headline: New York Is Pushed to Stop Asking Aspiring Lawyers About Long-Ago Crimes
abstract: To become a lawyer in New York, one must share details of sealed cases and juvenile records. Critics say that the requirement may be illegal, and that it harms racial diversity.
lead_paragraph: Dylan James, a second-year law student in New York, aspires to fight systemic problems in the legal system. But even if he passes the bar exam after graduation, one part of the state’s admission application to become a lawyer could limit his plans: Question No. 26.

headline: The Spanish Beach Town That Keeps Calling You Back
abstract: Sitges, just south of Barcelona, has 17 beaches and a quiet, timeless charm that draws all kinds of visitors to return year after year.
lead_paragraph: Coming out of the pretty little train station in Sitges on a sunny Sunday morning, I took a deep breath and started laughing. Ever since I first visited this Spanish seaside town a half-hour south of Barcelona by train 40 years ago, it’s a destination that’s unfailingly made me happy.

headline: A Rural Escape in Connecticut
abstract: In a “magical place in the woods,” in Roxbury, Conn., one couple built a second home where art surrounds them.
lead_paragraph: In a “magical place in the woods,” in Roxbury, Conn., one couple built a second home where art surrounds them.

headline: Mixing Children and Art? Yes, It’s Possible.
abstract: In a ‘magical place’ in the Connecticut woods, one couple built a rural escape where the most fragile artwork is just out of reach.
lead_paragraph: To get the house they wanted, Javier Morales and Alex Morris realized they would have to build it.

headline: A User’s Guide to the Midterm Elections
abstract: What happens in November won’t just be about who wins and who loses. Astead W. Herndon, the host of “The Run-Up,” explains why the stakes are so high.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the unofficial start of the campaign for the midterm elections. This year’s midterms will be the first major referendum on the Biden era of government — and a test of how much voters want to reinstall the Trump wing of the Republican Party.

headline: New Yorker Festival to Host Bono, Quinta Brunson and Jamie Raskin
abstract: The three day-festival beginning on Oct. 7 will also include conversations with stars like Ben Stiller, Chloe Bailey and Sandra Oh.
lead_paragraph: The New Yorker Festival returns for its 23rd edition, featuring conversations with Bono, Quinta Brunson, Ben Stiller, Chloe Bailey, United States Representative Jamie Raskin and more, and will run from Oct. 7-9.

headline: New prime minister or not, Larry the cat is here to stay.
abstract: The chief mouser to the Cabinet Office will remain in 10 Downing Street even after Britain welcomes Liz Truss as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Moments after Prime Minister Boris Johnson pulled out of Downing Street for the last time on Tuesday, a familiar brown-and-white tabby cat slipped out of the lacquered black door of No. 10 and perched serenely on the doorstep.

headline: A Good Issue for Democrats
abstract: Despite the large partisan gaps on many aspects of Covid, Americans give Democrats higher marks for pandemic management than Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The partisan divide in Covid attitudes has been so large that you might think Americans would be split roughly down the middle about which of the two political parties had handled the pandemic better.

headline: Bomb Kills Dozens of Civilians in Burkina Faso
abstract: At least 35 people were killed and dozens of others wounded when a roadside blast struck a convoy. The country has been devastated by growing violence driven by extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: At least 35 civilians were killed in northern Burkina Faso after a convoy of vehicles hit a roadside bomb, according to the authorities, the latest attack in the West African country that has faced hundreds from Islamist groups this year.

headline: South Korea Is Spared as Typhoon Hinnamnor Makes Swift Exit
abstract: The storm brought heavy rain and blackouts near the southern coast, but its fast pace kept the country from experiencing the severe damage caused by floods in August.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — South Korea on Tuesday was hit by heavy rain and strong winds but avoided the extensive destruction that many had feared as Typhoon Hinnamnor made its way out to sea faster than forecasters had expected.

headline: Truss takes office in time-honored British fashion.
abstract: The transfer of power from the outgoing prime minister, Boris Johnson, was accomplished in a pair of meetings with the queen.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Liz Truss became Britain’s prime minister after midday on Tuesday, when Queen Elizabeth II invited her to form a government, a day after Ms. Truss was confirmed as the new leader of the Conservative Party.

headline: ‘Fall TV’ Is Dead. But Buzz Will Always Be With Us.
abstract: Two television critics ponder what fall TV even means in the streaming era and discuss the series they’re most looking forward to this season.
lead_paragraph: Each fall brings an onslaught of new television shows, but now so does every other season of the year. As another autumn approaches, James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons, television critics at The New York Times, discussed what “fall TV” even means in the streaming era, along with the new and returning series they’re most looking forward to.

headline: Josh Groban to Star in ‘Sweeney Todd’ Revival on Broadway
abstract: Groban, playing the title character, will be joined by Annaleigh Ashford in a production scheduled to open in March at the Lunt-Fontanne.
lead_paragraph: The demon barber of Fleet Street is returning to Broadway.

headline: In India’s Tech Capital, Floods Leave Workers Riding Tractors to Work
abstract: Bengaluru, India’s Silicon Valley, joined the roster of places in South Asia inundated by torrential rains during this monsoon season.
lead_paragraph: Two days of torrential rain have flooded Bengaluru, the southern city known as India’s Silicon Valley, forcing tech workers to use boats and hitch rides on tractors to get to the office. Water supplies were disrupted and some residents struggled to evacuate as India’s tech capital joined the roster of places in South Asia inundated during this monsoon season.

headline: A New Bid to Crack the Code on Gun Violence
abstract: Amalgamated Bank and the nonprofit Guns Down America are trying a different way to use the financial system to clamp down on mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here.

headline: Our Interview With Kylian Mbappé: Audio Excerpts
abstract: After signing a reported $250 million contract to stay with Paris St.-Germain, Kylian Mbappé sat down with The New York Times to discuss his past, his present and his plans for the future.
lead_paragraph: After signing a reported $250 million contract to stay with Paris St.-Germain, Kylian Mbappé sat down with The New York Times to discuss his past, his present and his plans for the future.

headline: Is This Heat Wave Hot Enough for You, California?
abstract: Blistering temperatures shattered records over Labor Day weekend. Meteorologists say they’ll linger for the rest of the week.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures spiked to 112 degrees on Monday in Stockton and Paso Robles. In Sacramento, the mercury shimmered at 114 degrees. In Livermore and Fairfield, it was 116 degrees, shattering records. In Death Valley, it was a blinding 121 degrees.

headline: Michelin Reveals 2022 New York Area Additions
abstract: The star ratings will not be revealed until October, but the Michelin Guide offers a glimpse of the new restaurants making the list.
lead_paragraph: The star ratings and other distinctions in the Michelin Guide New York City for 2022 will be announced on Oct. 6 during a ceremony at Peak, the restaurant on the 101st floor of 30 Hudson Yards.

headline: Climate Law a ‘Game Changer’ for Highways and Bridges
abstract: Through a combination of tax credits and direct funding, the Inflation Reduction Act aims to increase the manufacturing of sustainable materials used in infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: The manufacturing of the concrete and asphalt needed to build the nation’s bridges and highways is a dirty business: Companies that make those materials produce a lot of the emissions that are heating the planet.

headline: How Abbott Kept Sick Babies From Becoming a Scandal
abstract: Abbott’s lawyers at Jones Day negotiated secret settlements and used scorched earth tactics with families whose infants fell ill after consuming powdered formula.
lead_paragraph: Early on a Saturday morning in 2013, Mark Bennett, a federal judge, walked into his chambers in the courthouse in Sioux City, Iowa. He’d been out of town for a speaking engagement and was hoping to catch up on work. A surprise awaited him as he entered his office: Cardboard boxes were stacked everywhere. His immediate thought was that another judge might be moving in.

headline: It’s a challenging time to be @Liztruss on Twitter.
abstract: The woman who has owned the account since 2009 is having fun replying to well wishers and world leaders who tag her, thinking she is Britain’s new prime minister.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Liz Truss as Britain’s prime minister has brought a flood of new attention to the Twitter account of @Liztruss.

headline: 06 moscow mood fader
abstract: 06 moscow mood fader
lead_paragraph: 06 moscow mood fader

headline: DJ Khaled’s Latest All-Star Album, ‘God Did,’ Is His Fourth No. 1
abstract: The LP, featuring Drake, Kanye West and others, had the equivalent of 107,500 sales in the United States last week. The K-pop group Twice wasn’t far behind, with 100,000 at No. 3.
lead_paragraph: Each new LP by DJ Khaled, hip-hop’s indomitable guru of positivity, is an all-star summit, chocked with A-list guest stars. “God Did,” his 13th studio album, which opens at No. 1 on Billboard’s latest chart, is no different. Its 18 tracks feature Drake, Jay-Z, Dr. Dre, Rick Ross, Travis Scott, Roddy Ricch, Eminem, Future, Kanye West, SZA, 21 Savage and three Lils — Wayne, Durk and Baby — as well as a posthumous appearance by Juice WRLD.

headline: How and Where to Vote in Massachusetts and Who’s on the Ballot
abstract: Because of a state law passed in 2019, any Massachusetts resident who has applied for state benefits or a state driver’s license since Jan. 1, 2020, is automatically registered to vote.
lead_paragraph: Massachusetts voters are going to the polls Tuesday to choose their parties’ nominees in races including governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general. Here’s what to know about voting in the state:

headline: The Artist Who Throws Newton a Curve
abstract: The Orange County Museum of Art inaugurates its new building with a tribute to Fred Eversley, an unheralded pioneer of the Light and Space movement.
lead_paragraph: COSTA MESA, Calif. — As a teenager in Brooklyn, Fred Eversley filled a pie pan with Jell-O and spun it on a turntable in his father’s basement laboratory. It was one of his many early science experiments, inspired by an article in Popular Mechanics about Isaac Newton’s contributions to modern physics involving a bucket of water and a rope.

headline: In Energy Crunch, Germany Turns Down Heat but Won’t Limit Autobahn Speeds
abstract: Putting general restrictions on the country’s storied highways is a simple step to save energy, carbon emissions and lives. But even with the Greens in power, the country is unlikely to take it.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany is trying any range of measures to combat an energy crisis that is only expected to worsen this winter. Public buildings can be heated to just 66 degrees and most private pools not at all. Starting this month, billboards and other landmarks go dark at 10 p.m. The government has even extended the lives of two of the country’s last nuclear reactors.

headline: Truss’s cabinet choices will signal the political direction of her government.
abstract: The announcements, expected later on Tuesday, are likely to reward loyalists and overlook defeated rivals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In her choice of cabinet members, Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, will give the first clues about the direction of her government, and how magnanimous she will be toward her defeated Conservative Party rivals.

headline: Ice, Ice Baby
abstract: The 1990s rapper known as Vanilla Ice is back, performing concerts, opening a museum and hawking a namesake energy drink.
lead_paragraph: “I just want to go back to the ’90s,” said Vanilla Ice, the rapper.

headline: Bed Bath & Beyond Names an Interim Finance Chief
abstract: Laura Crossen will assume the duties of Gustavo Arnal, the retailer’s chief financial officer, who died by suicide on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond, the beleaguered retailer, named Laura Crossen as interim chief financial officer on Tuesday, four days after the death of its former finance chief, Gustavo Arnal.

headline: Britain’s Pound Wavers on Reports of Relief From Energy Bills
abstract: But analysts warn that investor confidence in Britain is waning as British assets have slumped.
lead_paragraph: The British pound inched away from its two-and-a-half-year low against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday after media reports that the new prime minister, Liz Truss, would announce a major plan to freeze energy bills for households to ease the cost-of-living crisis.

headline: Scientists Have Made a Human Microbiome From Scratch
abstract: To better understand how microbes affect our health, researchers combined 119 species of bacteria naturally found in the human body.
lead_paragraph: Our bodies are home to hundreds or thousands of species of microbes — nobody is sure quite how many. That’s just one of many mysteries about the so-called human microbiome.

headline: After a Summer of Grief, It’s Back to School in Uvalde
abstract: Classes resumed on Tuesday in the South Texas community where a mass shooting in May took the lives of 19 students and two teachers.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Kimberly Rubio’s four children had been quiet about the start of the school year in Uvalde until three days ago, when she heard them talking about back-to-school outfits. Missing from the nervous anticipation was her daughter Lexi Aniyah Rubio, one of 19 students and two teachers killed when a gunman stormed her fourth-grade classroom on the last day of school.

headline: Restaurant Review: Nabila’s Takes a Homemade Approach to Lebanese Food
abstract: A longtime hit on the Washington party circuit, the food of Nabila Farah comes to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: When I found out that some of the dishes I’ve been enjoying recently at Nabila’s, an impressive new Lebanese restaurant in Brooklyn, have been staples on the Washington party circuit for years, I wasn’t angry. Disappointed, perhaps.

headline: The New Generation of Tasting Menus Won’t Test Your Patience (or Your Wallet)
abstract: With lower price points and less attitude, chefs around the country are finding fun and freedom in the once-stuffy form.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — This state’s capital city is an unusual location for a seven-course tasting-menu restaurant. So much so that Zacchaeus Golden made the news when he opened one called Southern Soigné in December. But it turns out he wasn’t such an outlier.

headline: Lady Wong and Singapura Team Up for a Singapore Tea Service
abstract: There will be a trolley with Southeast Asian sweets along with dessert wines, teas and more.
lead_paragraph: Lady Wong, an East Village pastry shop that is home base for vibrant Southeast Asian treats, has joined with Salil Mehta’s Singapura restaurant to offer early afternoon tea service, by way of Singapore. A trolley laden with choices like Lady Wong’s lychee tart, black sesame passion fruit cake, mango mousse, pandan serimuka (a custard cake) and more, circles the room. Dessert wines, spirits, cocktails and teas are poured to accompany the sweets.

headline: Take a Free Course in Rosh Hashana Foods With WoodSpoon
abstract: Alon Hadar, an Israeli chef living in Brooklyn, will demonstrate how to make his stuffed kubbeh matzo balls and more.
lead_paragraph: The company WoodSpoon, founded in 2019, sells and delivers meals prepared by chefs and home cooks, often with backgrounds from outside the United States. To bolster your repertory for Rosh Hashana, the Jewish High Holiday that starts at sundown on Sept. 25, it has scheduled a free virtual cooking class for Sept. 21 at 7 p.m. with Alon Hadar, an Israeli chef living in Brooklyn who was previously a chef at Homemade by Miriam in TriBeCa. He will demonstrate how to make his stuffed kubbeh matzo balls and his multicultural cacio e pepe Jerusalem kugel, a dish with angel hair pasta, pecorino, abundant pepper and also sweetness, from a caramelized sugar core and glaze. (He said his inspiration is also American mac and cheese.) There’s no charge, but registration is required.

headline: Severe Floods Inundate India’s Silicon Valley
abstract: Tech workers hitched rides on tractors to get to their offices and other residents struggled to evacuate after two days of torrential rain flooded streets in Bengaluru, India.
lead_paragraph: Tech workers hitched rides on tractors to get to their offices and other residents struggled to evacuate after two days of torrential rain flooded streets in Bengaluru, India.

headline: ‘Soup Broth Bread’ Takes an Irish Approach to Seasonal Cooking
abstract: Set your kitchen scale to grams for this cookbook by Rachel Allen, of the Ballymaloe Cookery School in County Cork, Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Be sure to have the kitchen scale set for grams, not ounces, to tackle “Soup Broth Bread,” a cookbook by Rachel Allen, a member of the family that runs the Ballymaloe Cookery School in County Cork, Ireland. (Metric measurements are all Ms. Allen uses.) The beautifully photographed book takes you through four seasons of soups; there’s still time to make salmorejo, a delicious pared-down gazpacho. The chowderlike Nordic salmon and dill soup can anchor a meal, and yellow lentil soup with lemon and parsley knows no seasons. Why the rib-sticking beef and sweet potato goulash soup landed in the spring chapter, alongside others like asparagus with tarragon is puzzling; maybe it says something about spring weather in Ireland. The bread side of the equation is hearty, with whole wheat, buckwheat and oat loaves, both yeast and soda-leavened.

headline: Our Place Introduces a Tagine Lid for Its Pans
abstract: The domed lid is meant to fit the company’s pans, but it can top most 11-inch skillets.
lead_paragraph: Our Place, a company that sells a line of cookware with some interchangeable lids, pans and so forth, has introduced a Moroccan tagine lid. Just the lid, no bottom dish. At a little more than 10 ½ inches in diameter, the typical slope-sided dome with a topknot is meant to fit the company’s pans, but it can top most 11-inch skillets. Using it with a cast iron pan allows you to sear chicken or other ingredients before letting them braise under the lid, something that’s harder to accomplish in the clay bottom of a typical tagine. The contour permits steaming juices to condense, keeping the ingredients moist. There’s a slit at the bottom to allow some of the steam to escape. The interior is glazed and seasoning is not required.

headline: Tune In to a Talk on a Black Caterer of Early America
abstract: Henry Orr, who was born into slavery in 1792, catered for government figures and bought his and his family’s freedom.
lead_paragraph: Henry Orr, who was born into slavery in 1792, became a caterer in antebellum Washington, providing high society and the households of government figures with necessarily stylish dinners, earning enough along the way to buy his and his family’s freedom. Leni Sorensen, who was the African American Research Historian at Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's home, has studied Orr and will discuss him in a virtual program for the Culinary Historians of New York. The title of her talk, “Beets Are Too Old-Fashioned,” derives from Orr’s supposed advice to a client about what was trendy to serve, and his refusal to include beets on the menu.

headline: Rosemary’s Expands With a Pantry for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village
abstract: This new airy store from Carlos Suarez has ample seating and sells prepared foods and ingredients.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, Carlos Suarez, whose restaurants are in and around Greenwich Village, opened an eastern outpost of his Rosemary’s at the border of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village. Adjacent to it he has now added an airy store with ample seating, selling sandwiches and other prepared food, pizza, pastries and ingredients made in-house like fresh pasta and condiments, some bearing his new label, La Bomba. “I felt it was something that the neighborhood could use, food that’s ready to take home and eat or take home and cook,” he said. Out front there’s a gelato cart for something on the spot.

headline: ‘Queen Sugar’ Ends on Its Own Terms
abstract: The series, which begins its final season on Tuesday, sought “to put a Black family in the canon of American family dramas,” said Ava DuVernay, the creator.
