headline: The Artist Sculpting a Terra-Cotta Forest
abstract: Setsuko Klossowska de Rola’s exhibit in Rome, plus a fashion designer’s collaboration with West Elm and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I use less and less as I get older, but I make sure what I do use is really great. First thing in the morning, while I’m still in bed, I spray Chantecaille rosewater all over to help myself wake up. Then I shower and use Leonor Greyl Shampooing Reviviscence — on my hair and on my body, too — then Christophe Robin’s Shade Variation Mask in Baby Blonde. I am so devoted to my colorist in New York, Sharon Dorram, so I do all I can to preserve her work. If I do a blowout at home, I’ll use Dyson’s Airwrap. After the shower, I apply our Bio Lifting Serum and Rose de Mai Cream. In the summer I follow that with our Anti-Aging Face Tint in sheer bronze, and in the winter I’ll use our Sheer Glow Rose Face Tint and Future Skin foundation in one of four tones depending on how much sun I’ve had. The tints give you a little bit of a highlight and make your skin look delicious. I use a number of eye products, including our Nano Gold Energizing Eye Serum and the Eye Cream from the same range. When it comes to makeup, one thing I have to have is a very good eye pencil — I’m partial to our Luster Glide in Earth or Olive Brocade, which is green with a little blue. And I have a myriad of lipsticks but, right now, I’m using a lip tint we launched this summer. It looks so natural and is really moisturizing. If I have been outside all day, I will sleep in our Gold Recovery Mask and, the next day, it’s like my skin has no memory of being in the sun. And if I’m going to be on television, I’ll do our Bio Lifting Mask to help with wrinkles. I’m a gardener and don’t get manicures, but my mother got me started using Dior’s Creme Abricot on my nails — that and Aesop’s Resurrection Aromatique Hand Balm. I get pedicures at Spa 27 in East Hampton and I do acupuncture in Amagansett with Sandra Foster. I love Arnican, too. If you have a bruise just use that little orange tube. Le Wild is my signature scent — it’s based on a wild gardenia found in a forest in Brazil and is really fresh but has a lot of energy. I feel that it represents my life in that all that I love is wild. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Can Architecture Build Values, Too?
abstract: With designs that strive to enhance ecology, strengthen community and affirm cultural identity, today’s innovative buildings and projects transcend style.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a harrowing ride for projects coming to fruition this fall, planned in what now seems a faraway time before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the ricocheting effects of Covid-19, and disasters fueled by climate change. Yet the best architecture can transform our ways of thinking, our work, our connections to local community. The designs presented here seek to transcend the moment’s crises.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Dumbo, Lenox Hill and Turtle Bay.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Dumbo, Lenox Hill and Turtle Bay.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Dumbo, Lenox Hill and Turtle Bay.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and a six-bedroom in Allendale, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and a six-bedroom in Allendale, N.J.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and a six-bedroom in Allendale, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: How California Officials Are Trying to Keep the Lights On
abstract: The state continues to endure a prolonged heat wave that will test the power grid through Friday.
lead_paragraph: The huge heat dome that has engulfed California for more than a week appears to be weakening, although meteorologists say triple-digit temperatures will remain with us for a couple more days. On Wednesday, residents were asked yet again to conserve power between 4 p.m. and 9 p.m., when the grid tends to get strained. Don’t be surprised if today brings yet another so-called flex alert.

headline: Jerome Powell speaks on monetary policy.
abstract: The comments from the Federal Reserve chair were his last public statements before the Fed’s policy setting committee meets later this month.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, spoke at conference hosted by the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank.

headline: U.S. Open Semifinals: The 4 Women Left
abstract: Caroline Garcia, Ons Jabeur, Aryna Sabalenka and Iga Swiatek have a title in their sights.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Garcia, Ons Jabeur, Aryna Sabalenka and Iga Swiatek have a title in their sights.

headline: Saudi-Tied Tournament Causes Push to Void Trump’s N.Y.C. Golf Contract
abstract: City Council leaders asked Mayor Eric Adams to end the Trump Organization’s contract to run a city-owned golf course in the Bronx and to cancel a tournament next month.
lead_paragraph: It sounded like the type of event that Mayor Eric Adams would want to bring to New York City to boost the economy: an elite international golf tournament that would draw visitors and their wallets.

headline: Bannon Pleads Not Guilty to New York Charges in Wall Case
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, whom former President Donald J. Trump pardoned, has been entangled in what prosecutors have said was a crowdfunding fraud scheme.
lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon, the self-professed populist adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, was accused by Manhattan prosecutors on Thursday of defrauding Americans who wanted to contribute to construction of a southern border wall, resurrecting a threat that Mr. Bannon seemed to have escaped with a 2021 presidential pardon.

headline: Jerome Powell signals interest rates will remain high to fight inflation.
abstract: The Federal Reserve chair has taken a hawkish tone in recent appearances, seeking to underscore the central bank's commitment to bringing down prices.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, signaled on Thursday that the central bank will continue raising interest rates to convince the American public that it is serious about bringing soaring price growth back to normal levels, further cementing market expectations of another aggressive rate increase this month.

headline: Philippines Rebuffs International Court Over Duterte’s War on Drugs
abstract: The Marcos government rejected a request to let prosecutors resume an inquiry into former President Rodrigo Duterte’s drive against crime, which left thousands dead.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine government on Thursday officially rejected a request by the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court to resume an investigation into former President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs, which left thousands of people dead.

headline: Investors Sue Treasury Department for Blacklisting Crypto Platform
abstract: Tornado Cash was banned last month to prevent hacking, money-laundering and other cryptocurrency crimes.
lead_paragraph: A group of cryptocurrency investors sued the Treasury Department on Thursday to block government sanctions that bar Americans from Tornado Cash, a popular crypto platform that criminals have used to launder virtual currencies.

headline: Here are the takeaways from the E.C.B.’s big move.
abstract: The European Central Bank said it expected to continue raising rates and raised its forecast for inflation.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a point on Thursday, and said that it expected to continue raising them in the future. The central bank also published a new set of economic forecasts.

headline: The Harrowing Migration Story of One 9-Year-Old Child
abstract: In his new memoir, “Solito,” the poet Javier Zamora recounts his experience traveling from El Salvador to the United States, by himself, when he was a young boy.
lead_paragraph: Javier Zamora was born in El Salvador in 1990 during the country’s civil war. His father fled to the United States first, a year after Zamora was born, and his mother followed when he was 5. For the next four years, he lived with his grandparents; then it was his turn to go north. Zamora’s memoir, “Solito,” is a chronicle of that journey, which Zamora made by himself at the age of 9, from a tiny village in El Salvador to Arizona — thousands of miles in all.

headline: ‘The Woman King’ and Intimate Moments Amid Epic Action
abstract: The director Gina Prince-Bythewood is known for her attention to character, but she made this historic saga of female warriors on another scale altogether.
lead_paragraph: From her debut feature, the rom-com classic “Love and Basketball,” to her most recent action hit, “The Old Guard,” Gina Prince-Bythewood is known for films with rich character introspection amid outward chaos. That touch is evident again this fall even as she widens her cinematic playing field with the fact-based battle epic “The Woman King.”

headline: ‘Barbarian’ Review: This Rental Is Hell
abstract: Two strangers explore the basement of their Detroit rental home in this gleefully twisty horror movie by Zach Cregger.
lead_paragraph: “Barbarian,” a gleefully twisty horror movie by the writer-director Zach Cregger, is both a product of modern times and something of a throwback.

headline: Ask Wirecutter: Dollar Store Duds?
abstract: How do I get my mom to stop buying junk?
lead_paragraph: How do I get my mom to stop buying junk?

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Serena Williams’s Record and Legacy
abstract: What makes Serena Williams’s tennis career record so extraordinary?
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams announced she is retiring from professional tennis after a 27-year career. During this time, she broke down barriers for Black tennis players and female athletes. This graph compares the ages of Williams and her opponents for all of her championship tennis matches. She went pro in 1995 at the age of 14 and she announced on Aug. 9, 2022, that she will retire this year (at the age of 40).

headline: EY, the accounting and consulting firm, will split into two businesses.
abstract: The firm, commonly known as Ernst & Young, announced a plan to separate into two companies, one that does mainly auditing work and the other consulting and advisory work.
lead_paragraph: EY, one of the world’s biggest auditing and consulting firms, is moving forward with a plan to split up its two main business practices.

headline: David Shor, a Data Guru for Democrats, Throws One Last Bash
abstract: Political operatives, techies and the nightlife crowd mix at a Burning Man-style party hosted by an influential strategist who gained new friends and enemies after a tweet.
lead_paragraph: At 7 p.m. on Saturday, the political consultant David Shor was setting up his fifth-floor apartment in Lower Manhattan for one last blowout party before the start of election season, when he expects to work between 65 and 70 hours a week crunching numbers on behalf of Democratic candidates across the country.

headline: Trump’s Post-Election Fund-Raising Comes Under Scrutiny by Justice Dept.
abstract: A federal grand jury has issued subpoenas seeking information about Save America PAC, which was formed as Donald J. Trump promoted baseless assertions about election fraud.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Washington is examining the formation of — and spending by — a fund-raising operation created by Donald J. Trump after his loss in the 2020 election as he was soliciting millions of dollars by baselessly asserting that the results had been marred by widespread voting fraud.

headline: What We're Reading This Fall
abstract: Good news, book lovers: This is a great season to be a reader. Let us help you find your next book.
lead_paragraph: Good news, book lovers: This is a great season to be a reader. Let us help you find your next book.

headline: Boy, 15, Fatally Shot in Downtown Brooklyn Park, Police Say
abstract: The child, a student at Brooklyn Laboratory Charter Schools, was approached by two boys, one of whom shot him after a fist fight, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy was shot and killed in McLaughlin Park, in Downtown Brooklyn, on Wednesday afternoon after two people approached him and started a verbal dispute that turned physical, the police said.

headline: Live by the Trump, Die by the Trump
abstract: Republicans’ amoral alliance with the former president may well be a midterms curse.
lead_paragraph: Democrats were doomed. We prediction-mad pundits felt predictable certainty about that. The recent history of midterm elections augured disaster for the party in power. Inflation would make the damage that much worse.

headline: Does Anyone Drink Hot Coffee Anymore?
abstract: Even in the dead of winter, cold drinks account for 60 percent of Starbucks beverage sales. Is the hot cup of joe on its way out?
lead_paragraph: Hannah Maute’s obsession with iced lattes, iced coffees and cold brews began during her freshman year at Temple University, where she was surrounded by students who “looked cool” bouncing from class to class with a cup in hand. Now, not a day goes by when she isn’t sipping one herself.

headline: Meet Four Theater Artists to Watch This Fall
abstract: We spoke to three actors and a playwright — Gregg Mozgala, Bonnie Milligan, Solea Pfeiffer and Noah Diaz — who are taking big shots this season.
lead_paragraph: The actor Gregg Mozgala has dark hair swooped back from his forehead and watchful, heavy-lidded eyes. His upper body is muscular, his right arm etched with two elaborate tattoos, one showing a rooster mid crow. He credits his family’s focus on athletics for the vigor of his performances.

headline: 445 Prompts for Narrative and Personal Writing
abstract: Questions that invite students to write about themselves, their lives and their beliefs.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been posting fresh writing prompts every school day for over a decade now, and every so often we create a themed collection like this one to help you find what you need all in one place.

headline: Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine Looks Like a ‘Failure,’ C.I.A. Director Says
abstract: William J. Burns said that counterattacks in the south and northeast showed that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had underestimated Ukraine’s capacity for combat.
lead_paragraph: Six months into “a very tough slog of a war,” Ukraine has begun to mount a counteroffensive and Russia’s invasion can only be seen as a failure, the director of the C.I.A., William J. Burns, said Thursday.

headline: Independent 20th Century’s Artists in a Cozy New Fair Spinoff
abstract: Just 32 booths this year, a show of artists both famous and unknown at the southern tip of Manhattan is high quality — and sometimes thrilling.
lead_paragraph: The Independent Art Fair, already curated and intimate, has gotten even cozier. In its brand-new spinoff, Independent 20th Century — some 32 galleries showing work by 20th-century artists both famous and unfamiliar — occupies a single floor of the Battery Maritime Building on South Street. (I found the building a little claustrophobic when it hosted the regular Independent last year, but for this it works perfectly.)

headline: New York City Center Taps Veteran Arts Administrator as Its Next Leader
abstract: Michael S. Rosenberg, the managing director of the McCarter Theater Center, will succeed Arlene Shuler as the City Center president and chief executive.
lead_paragraph: New York City Center, a nonprofit known for its starry short-run musical revivals as well as its contemporary dance programming, is naming a New Jersey arts administrator as its new leader.

headline: Review: A Singer’s Immense Sound Engulfs a Recital Room
abstract: Michael Spyres made an overdue New York recital debut at the Park Avenue Armory, whose intimate space could not contain his voice.
lead_paragraph: Some singers thrive in a recital room. A small space invites extremities of intimate expression; audiences can become the confidants of a lovelorn raconteur. Other voices, though, are better fit for an opera house — voluminous to the point of superhuman strength, thrilling for their athleticism as much their artistry.

headline: F.D.A. OKs Daxxify, an Anti-Wrinkle Drug and Botox Competitor
abstract: The treatment lasts for six months in half of its users, company studies showed, representing the first major advance in facial injections in decades.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new drug that reduced the appearance of facial wrinkles for about six months, spurring competition in a market that for decades has been dominated by Botox.

headline: The U.S. will send an additional $675 million in military supplies to Ukraine, Austin says.
abstract: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — Emphasizing that the United States was prepared to support Ukraine “for the long haul,” Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said Thursday that Washington will send an additional $675 million in military supplies to Ukraine, including air-launched missiles designed to destroy enemy radars.
lead_paragraph: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — Emphasizing that the United States was prepared to support Ukraine “for the long haul,” Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said Thursday that Washington will send an additional $675 million in military supplies to Ukraine, including air-launched missiles designed to destroy enemy radars.

headline: A Goodbye to Readers and a Reflection
abstract: In Shira Ovide’s last On Tech newsletter, she looks back at how the past two and a half years have shifted her thinking on technology.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had the opportunity to write the On Tech newsletter for the past two and a half years, and now that time has come to an end. This is my last edition.

headline: As Pennsylvania Senate Race Tightens, Oz Sharpens Attacks on Fetterman
abstract: Dr. Mehmet Oz is trying to revive his campaign against Lt. Gov. John Fetterman with a pair of pointed attack lines, including about his rival’s policies on felons.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Pa. — Dr. Mehmet Oz, trailing in the polls and still contending with an image as an out-of-touch, carpetbagging elitist, is seeking to reboot his Senate campaign in Pennsylvania in the final sprint to November.

headline: Mercedes and Rivian Plan to Make Vans Together in Europe
abstract: The agreement is a rare example of cooperation between a traditional carmaker and an upstart.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz and Rivian said Thursday that they would team up to build electric vans in Europe, a rare example of cooperation between a traditional carmaker and a new challenger.

headline: Bernard Shaw, CNN’s Lead Anchor for 20 Years, Dies at 82
abstract: He covered the Gulf War, anchored convention coverage and asked a revealing question of Gov. Michael Dukakis during a presidential debate in 1988.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Shaw, CNN’s lead prime-time anchor for 20 years, who was also known for his steely coverage from Tiananmen Square in Beijing during the Chinese government’s crackdown on protesters in 1989 and from Baghdad at the start of the Persian Gulf war two years later, died on Wednesday. He was 82.

headline: When There’s Nothing in the Fridge
abstract: Pasta, beans and more pantry cooking saves the day.
lead_paragraph: I got home late on Monday from a friend’s wedding in New Hampshire, dropped my bags and went straight to the fridge.

headline: Balmoral Castle has a long history as a royal retreat in the Scottish Highlands.
abstract: Her family says Queen Elizabeth is happiest at the sprawling estate, her primary summer residence.
lead_paragraph: Queen Victoria fell so in love in June 1852 with a sweeping estate in the Scottish Highlands that she later called it “this dear paradise,” and her husband, Prince Albert, bought it for her.

headline: Schaller & Weber Adds a Cocktail Bar to Its Upper East Side Realm
abstract: The latest business from the third-generation owner of the famed butcher shop is modeled on American-style cocktail bars in Vienna.
lead_paragraph: The butcher shop Schaller & Weber, a vestige of the German American culture that once flourished in the Yorkville section of the Upper East Side, plans to add a little Austrian flavor to its stretch of Second Avenue.

headline: Read the Bannon Indictment
abstract: The indictment charging Stephen K. Bannon.
lead_paragraph: The indictment charging Stephen K. Bannon.

headline: NASA Could Retry Moon Rocket Launch in Late September
abstract: After two mission scrubs for technical issues, NASA officials have tentative hopes to launch the Artemis I mission on Sept. 27.
lead_paragraph: After replacing leaky seals that halted a launch attempt of its new moon rocket last week, NASA said on Thursday that it hoped to try again later this month.

headline: Macron Aims for a National Dialogue at a Meeting, but Faces No-Shows
abstract: The inaugural meeting of a council to examine France’s most pressing problems had an issue of its own: boycotts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Seemingly humbled by the fractures in French society exposed during the election that ultimately led to his second term as France’s president, Emmanuel Macron promised to rule in a new way — fewer dictates from above and more collaborating.

headline: Mourn the Queen, Not Her Empire
abstract: She helped obscure a bloody history of decolonization whose proportions and legacies have yet to be adequately acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: “The end of an era” will become a refrain as commentators assess the record-setting reign of Queen Elizabeth II. Like all monarchs, she was both an individual and an institution. She had a different birthday for each role — the actual anniversary of her birth in April and an official one in June — and, though she retained her personal name as monarch, held different titles depending on where in her domains she stood. She was as devoid of opinions and emotions in public as her ubiquitous handbags were said to be of everyday items like a wallet, keys and phone. Of her inner life we learned little beyond her love of horses and dogs — which gave Helen Mirren, Olivia Colman and Claire Foy rapt audiences for the insights they enacted.

headline: The Legacy of Elizabeth II: The Media Queen
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II, the longest-reigning monarch in British history, died at the age of 96, leaving behind a legacy that blended the ancient and the modern with the help of mass media.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II, the longest-reigning monarch in British history, died at the age of 96, leaving behind a legacy that blended the ancient and the modern with the help of mass media.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96; Was Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
abstract: She ruled for seven decades, unshakably committed to the rituals of her role amid epic social and economic change and family scandal.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: A Life in Photos
abstract: Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, and became Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. Here are a selection of images from her life.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Born in 1926, eight years after the end of World War I, Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, in a country yet to see its first public TV broadcast and one that was in some respects more like the 19th century than the 21st.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II and the Shape of 20th-Century Power Dressing
abstract: The longest-serving British monarch let her clothes do the talking for her.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Wildfires Rage as California Endures Another Scorching Day
abstract: Two blazes, in Riverside and Placer Counties, have spread rapidly through dry, hilly terrain.
lead_paragraph: High temperatures, treacherous terrain and winds combined to fuel the spread of two large wildfires in California on Thursday, as the state endured another day under an oppressive heat wave.

headline: An Inscrutable Monarch, Endlessly Scrutinized Onstage and Onscreen
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II was portrayed in plays and highbrow films, in made-for-TV movies and broad comedies and, of course, in “The Crown.” Many sought to answer the question: What was she like?
lead_paragraph: She was the most opaque of celebrities, a silent film star somehow thriving in a TikTok world. If no one except her closest friends and family knew what Queen Elizabeth was really like, that’s exactly how she wanted it.

headline: Authorities Say D.N.A. Links Las Vegas Official to Killing of Reporter
abstract: The Las Vegas Review-Journal said its slain reporter, Jeff German, had been “pursuing a potential follow-up story” about a politician who has now been accused of killing him.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Authorities investigating the killing of a veteran Las Vegas journalist, Jeff German, said Thursday that they found D.N.A. at the crime scene that matched a public official who had been the subject of Mr. German’s recent reporting.

headline: Why Economic Populism Remains the Winning Ticket
abstract: In “The Middle Out,” Michael Tomasky contends that Joe Biden is following a smart path in a time of growing inequality and financial distress.
lead_paragraph: For those who see the Democratic Party in turmoil, poised to lose its razor-thin congressional majority in November, and then the White House in 2024, Michael Tomasky has a message for you: Calm down.

headline: Queen Elizabeth Embodied the Myth of the Good Monarch
abstract: She seemed to rise above the tawdry mess of politics.
lead_paragraph: To function in an otherwise normal democracy, a hereditary monarchy requires that the citizenry accept a bit of fiction — namely that one family, standing above politics, can represent the nation and its values.

headline: What Makes Your Brain Different From a Neanderthal’s?
abstract: Scientists have discovered a mutation that increases the production of brain cells and seems to have set our ancestors apart from other hominins.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered a glitch in our DNA that may have helped set the minds of our ancestors apart from those of Neanderthals and other extinct relatives.

headline: Failure to Slow Warming Will Set Off Climate ‘Tipping Points,’ Scientists Say
abstract: As global warming passes certain limits, dire changes will probably become irreversible, the researchers said, including the loss of polar ice sheets and the death of coral reefs.
lead_paragraph: Failure to limit global warming to the targets set by international accords will most likely set off several climate “tipping points,” a team of scientists said on Thursday, with irreversible effects including the collapse of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, abrupt thawing of Arctic permafrost and the death of coral reefs.

headline: A Storied New York Gallery Comes Home
abstract: After her building was damaged in 2018, Paula Cooper and her staff return to West 21st Street in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a story that serves as a worthy metaphor for the current state of the art world: In 2018, the construction of an imposing mixed-use real estate development on West 21st Street in New York City damaged its neighbor, Paula Cooper Gallery, a beloved exhibition space that was then forced to close and relocate to a different building a few blocks north. Shortly after, the development stalled, leaving behind a shuttered gallery and a vacant lot.

headline: Lillias White Finds Her Goddess for ‘Hadestown’
abstract: The Tony Award-winning actress will step into the role of the musical’s narrator, now known as Missus Hermes.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t do anything today!” Lillias White said as she emerged, somewhat flustered, from the elevator outside the Tricorne costume shop on the sixth floor of a Midtown Manhattan office building on a recent Tuesday morning. Her face was hidden behind white sunglasses and a navy and green star-patterned mask.

headline: ‘Dos Estaciones’ Review: A Tequila Factory’s Story, Sip by Sip
abstract: A woman tries to keep her family business running in this film that employs dreamlike rhythms and documentary-style realism.
lead_paragraph: There is a startling moment in the soulful Mexican drama “Dos Estaciones” when it shifts from the protagonist to a secondary character. Movies often take detours, yet when they pop into a supporting player’s life or nose around the story’s periphery, it’s usually to expand on the main event. Here, though, the diversion is so imbued by the secondary character’s being, so organic and leisurely, that it feels like the beginning of another movie entirely.

headline: Planning for the End of Elizabeth’s Reign Began at the Beginning
abstract: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has set in motion a meticulously choreographed process — known as Operation London Bridge — that the palace, and the nation, has spent decades planning.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The death of Queen Elizabeth II sets in motion a meticulously choreographed and coordinated procedure for which the palace, the government, the news media, the local authorities and the queen herself had long planned.

headline: Two Critics, 13 Favorite Booths at The Armory Show
abstract: Among the standouts and discoveries in new art at the Javits Center fair are a Lakota artist, an emerging Cambodian American painter and a sculptor from Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: The fall art season has arrived, with its manic harvest of exhibitions, and also The Armory Show, the major art fair in New York City that shifted its schedule and venue last year, moving to this early-September date and the Javits Center. With some 240+ galleries showing, and solid delegations from every continent, the fair is abundant and properly international again after a slimmed-down 2021 edition constrained by Covid-19 travel restrictions and hesitancy. Those are gone now — though the pandemic continues — and the scene is buzzing.

headline: 3 Browsers’ Delights Among the Art Fairs in NYC
abstract: Our guide to the smaller fairs, including Art on Paper, Spring/Break Art Show and CLIO, all in Manhattan this weekend.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, there is no shortage of art fairs. If you can’t make it to the Independent or the mammoth Armory Show — or if smaller fairs with nascent artists are more your style — there are satellite art fairs taking place across the city. Here’s a quick guide to our top three.

headline: Long an Uneasy Prince, King Charles III Takes On a Role He Was Born To
abstract: Once an awkward, self-doubting young man, he comes to the throne, at 73, as a self-assured, gray-haired eminence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Never, perhaps, has an heir been more ready for the crown.

headline: What it was like to portray the queen onscreen.
abstract: In “The Queen” and “The Crown,” actors took different approaches to get under the skin of the enigmatic monarch.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II was for most people unknowable, but there was one place where the curious could feel close to her: onscreen.

headline: Vice journalists raise concerns about potential deal with Saudi-backed firm.
abstract: The deal would involve the creation of a new brand focused on lifestyle and entertainment coverage and could be worth at least $50 million over several years.
lead_paragraph: Vice Media journalists raised concerns with executives on a call Thursday about a potential deal between the company and MBC, a media giant partially owned by the Saudi government.

headline: Conditions at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Are ‘Unsustainable,’ U.N. Watchdog Warns
abstract: Cut off from the country’s electric grid, the plant is relying on an emergency measure that it is not designed to keep up for long, while shells continue to rain down.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The head of the United Nations nuclear energy watchdog on Friday stepped up his calls for the creation of a safe zone around the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine after renewed shelling caused a widespread blackout in the town where the plant’s workers live.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Almost 30 years ago, when I was first coming up in this business, Randall Kenan was a young writer to watch: the author of an acclaimed novel, “A Visitation of Spirits,” and a story collection, “Let the Dead Bury Their Dead,” who combined folklore and magical realism and a rollicking biblical lyricism to bring his native rural North Carolina to life. I knew Kenan briefly in his New York years, when he taught a writing workshop at my school, and he seemed poised to make it as big as anyone ever does in the literary realm. But fame is fickle, and the moment passed, and so rather than a household name Kenan became that noble thing, the “writers’ writer,” continuing to produce excellent and award-nominated work for decade after decade until he died, too young, in 2020.

headline: Kay, a Post-Tropical Cyclone, Moves Up Baja California’s Western Coast
abstract: The storm’s effects were helping firefighters gain control of the Fairview Fire in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: A storm that formed off the Pacific shores of Mexico moved up the coast of the Baja California peninsula and brought heavy winds and rain into California, which has already been coping with extreme heat, wildfires and drought.

headline: The Disappearing World of Wolfgang Tillmans
abstract: His informal, generous pictures were some of the most moving art of the 1990s. Now, at MoMA, time catches up with the German photographer.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t seem like a titillating photograph: an orderly queue of Germans, waiting to enter a nondescript industrial site. It is dark. Just a single light illuminates the door. What does it look like? Like a color remake of Depression-era imagery: the factory entrance, the bread line.

headline: Yellen Embarks on Economic Victory Tour as Midterm Elections Approach
abstract: In Michigan, Janet L. Yellen, the Treasury secretary, said investments made by Democrats would reshape the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Emerging from months of inflation and recession fears, the Biden administration is pivoting to recast its stewardship of the U.S. economy as a singular achievement. In their pitch to voters, two months before midterm elections determine whether Democrats will maintain full control of Washington, Biden officials are pointing to a postpandemic resurgence of factories and “forgotten” cities.

headline: Britain’s national anthem will swap ‘king’ for ‘queen’ as Charles takes the throne.
abstract: Many small changes are expected in Britain in the coming weeks, but one will be only obvious only when it’s sung: For the first time since 1952, the anthem will go ‘God save the king.’
lead_paragraph: Numerous small changes to British daily life are expected in the coming weeks to welcome the new monarch — King Charles III, who ascended to the throne after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on Thursday.

headline: The New Royal Line of Succession
abstract: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has elevated her son Charles to the throne, with Prince William next in line.
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has elevated her son Charles to the throne, with Prince William next in line.

headline: President Biden remembers a monarch who ‘defined an era.’
abstract: Biden first met Queen Elizabeth in 1982 during a trip to Britain as a young senator. His most recent meeting came about a year ago, in Cornwall, England.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden hailed Queen Elizabeth II as “more than a monarch,” saying in a statement after her death on Thursday that the queen, who was 96, had borne witness to seven decades of “unprecedented human advancement and the forward march of human dignity.”

headline: How Dentists Keep Their Own Teeth Healthy
abstract: Two dentists share their daily dental hygiene tips.
lead_paragraph: Two dentists share their daily dental hygiene tips.

headline: A Sovereign’s Final Journey, in Photos
abstract: The death of the queen marks the loss of a revered monarch, the only one most Britons have ever known.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin began its journey on Sunday, traveling from Balmoral Castle to Edinburgh. The queen, who died on Thursday, Sept. 8, lay in rest in Edinburgh until Tuesday afternoon. Her coffin was flown to London on Tuesday evening to lie in state ahead of her funeral on Monday at Westminster Abbey.

headline: 9 Books to Read About Queen Elizabeth II
abstract: Elizabeth, famously reticent during her decades in the public eye, was a source of fascination for many. These books offer a deeper understanding of her life, family and world.
lead_paragraph: During the 70-year reign of Queen Elizabeth II, through times of turbulence and peace, celebration, controversy and scandal, the monarchy has been an object of fascination.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a darling cooking show, a juicy historical drama and an evocative orchestra performance.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Tiny Chef Show’When to watch: Friday at 11:30 a.m., on Nick.

headline: The Death of Queen Elizabeth: ‘We Shall Not Know Her Like Again’
abstract: Early reaction to the end of the 70-year monarchy. Also: Germany’s “moral failure”; women’s equality; Moosewood memories; homage to trees.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Twitter Reached $7 Million Settlement With Whistle-Blower
abstract: Lawyers for Elon Musk mentioned a $7 million payment to Peiter Zatko, Twitter’s former top security executive, in a court hearing this week.
lead_paragraph: Twitter reached a $7 million settlement with its former top security executive, Peiter Zatko, in June, after he was fired from the company and had raised concerns about its security practices.

headline: In Orange County, a House Race Is Testing What Asian Americans Want
abstract: In politically competitive Orange County, two Asian American candidates are facing off for the support of the growing Asian American electorate.
lead_paragraph: WESTMINSTER, Calif. — Dozens of Vietnamese-speaking volunteers filled a community center on a recent Wednesday to phone bank for Representative Michelle Steel, Republican of California, a Korean American lawmaker whose campaign signs and fliers in Vietnamese and English lined the walls.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the remake of "Pinocchio" on Disney+.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the remake of "Pinocchio" on Disney+.

headline: In a Surprise Visit to Ukraine, Blinken Offers Aid and Encouragement
abstract: At a “pivotal moment” as a counteroffensive makes gains, the secretary of state pledged $2.8 billion more in military aid to Ukraine and allies.
lead_paragraph: RZESZOW, POLAND — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken paid a surprise visit to Kyiv on Thursday, pledging $2.8 billion in military aid for Ukraine and other countries at risk of Russian invasion as the United States backs a Ukrainian effort to gain fresh military momentum.

headline: Justice Dept. Asks Judge to Lift Block on Trump Documents Investigation
abstract: The Justice Department asked a judge to hold off on enacting key parts of her order, including a temporary ban on its ability to use files seized from former President Donald J. Trump in its inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department asked a federal judge on Thursday to revisit her decision to temporarily stop prosecutors from gaining access to classified documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home, arguing that her ruling was hindering the government’s effort to determine whether national security had been compromised.

headline: The U.S. announces sanctions on Iranian companies involved in Russia drone sales.
abstract: The U.S. Treasury Department on Thursday announced sanctions against Iranian companies involved in the sale of drones to Russia, part of a continuing effort to pressure military supply chains and make it more difficult for Moscow to resupply its forces fighting in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Treasury Department on Thursday announced sanctions against Iranian companies involved in the sale of drones to Russia, part of a continuing effort to pressure military supply chains and make it more difficult for Moscow to resupply its forces fighting in Ukraine.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96
abstract: Plus the Solomon Islands postpones its election and tycoons leave China.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth died peacefully yesterday afternoon after more than 70 years as the British head of state. She was Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. Here is her obituary, photos from her reign and live updates.

headline: The Queen and Her Presidents
abstract: Six of the American leaders she met during her long life offer remembrances of her and their encounters.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II met 13 sitting U.S. presidents during her long life. Several of them released statements of condolences on her death on Thursday:

headline: Michigan Voters Will Decide Abortion Rights Question, Court Says
abstract: A state board had previously said the issue could not appear on the ballot because of word spacing problems on the petitions.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Supreme Court said Thursday that voters would decide in November whether to add protections for abortion rights to the State Constitution, reversing the decision of a state board that had not allowed the proposal onto the ballot because of typographical problems on petition forms.

headline: The Queen Met 13 Sitting U.S. Presidents, Who Basked in Her Global Prestige
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II was a gracious host and guest over the last seven decades, even when faced with protocol mistakes and awkward missteps.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They danced with her, rode horses together and went for a boat ride or a picnic. They took her to church or a baseball game. They hosted her or were hosted by her for gala dinners and receptions. Most of all, they basked in her global prestige and historical majesty.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Kick at the Door, a Knife in the Hand: The Saskatchewan Murders
abstract: As investigators pore over a sprawling and complex trail of crimes, a clearer picture is emerging of the stabbing rampage on an Indigenous reserve in Canada.
lead_paragraph: JAMES SMITH CREE NATION, Saskatchewan — The hunt for the killer behind the rampage that killed 10 people in Western Canada ended on Highway 11, a rural Saskatchewan roadway surrounded by dusty fields.

headline: The Queen’s Death Comes at a Moment of Great Uncertainty for Britain
abstract: There is no analogous British figure who will be mourned as deeply, or whose death will provoke a greater reckoning with the identity and future of the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II, whose seven-decade reign made her the only sovereign that most Britons had ever known, died on Thursday at her summer estate in Scotland, thrusting a bereaved country into a momentous transition at a time of political and economic upheaval.

headline: In Memphis, Renewed Attention on Violence After Shooting Rampage
abstract: The city, which had a record number of homicides last year, was already reeling from the abduction and killing of a young woman when a gunman shot seven people, four of them fatally.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Memphis had already been on edge. Just days earlier, a kindergarten teacher had been abducted on an early morning jog in the city and was later found dead.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Future College Tennis Stars Are an Unsung Draw
abstract: College coaches can be found across the U.S. Open’s outer courts during the juniors competitions, displaying their school colors while searching for the next star recruit.
lead_paragraph: On an outer court at the U.S. Open, tucked into a far corner by the perimeter fencing, Raquel Gonzalez Vilar powered shots over the net in her first-round match of the junior girls’ draw. Two men dressed in orange and black, wearing white hats emblazoned with the words “Oklahoma State,” cheered her on.

headline: In a Divided Britain, Near Unity in Admiration of the Queen
abstract: Across London, conversations reflected how deeply the loss had touched the nation — and how fundamental Elizabeth’s role had been in the national identity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Thursday evening, hours after the death of Queen Elizabeth was announced, the British capital was just starting to process its collective loss.

headline: The Tennis Umpire With the Velvet Voice Makes His Call
abstract: Kader Nouni, called the “Barry White of tennis,” used to worry that his deep baritone distracted from the job, but now he’s comfortable in the umpire chair.
lead_paragraph: Trailing 5-4 in the second set of her first-round match in this year’s U.S. Open, Venus Williams hit a forehand winner down the line to bring the game to 40-40. The chair umpire, Kader Nouni, let out a booming “deuce” that reverberated throughout Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Teddy Bears and Racial Justice: How St. Louis Became a Laboratory for Social Work
abstract: Politicians, activists and entrepreneurs are trying to solve the city’s deep racial and economic divides — and their ambitions know few boundaries.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — It’s called the Delmar Divide, named for the once-grand boulevard that bisects this city into enclaves that have long been more starkly segregated than almost anywhere else in America.

headline: The Immortal Awfulness of Open Plan Workplaces
abstract: No amount of evidence can bury this bad idea.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Wilde is said to have quipped that “God, in creating man, somewhat overestimated his ability.” Our species is capable of folly on a grand scale. Exhibit No. 4,000 in this litany of woe is the continued existence of open plan workplaces.

headline: ‘End of the Road’ Review: Thrill Ride
abstract: Queen Latifah and Chris Bridges anchor a predictable thriller that also manages to spin a charming tale of family unity.
lead_paragraph: A family of four traverses an obstacle course of Wild West crime escapades in the charming caper “End of the Road.” Queen Latifah and Chris Bridges anchor the antics as Brenda, a mother of two teenagers, and Reggie, Brenda’s layabout younger brother. Their sibling alliance forms the heart of the movie, and the pair toggle credibly between a combative dynamic and a considerate one.

headline: Wartime Economics Comes to Europe
abstract: Sometimes rationing and price controls are unavoidable.
lead_paragraph: The West isn’t exactly at war with Russia. However, it isn’t exactly not at war, either. Western weapons have helped Ukraine to stall Russia’s invasion and even to counterattack, while Western economic sanctions have clearly created serious problems for Russian industry.

headline: Trump Media Merger Gives Itself Another Month to Scramble for Shareholder Votes
abstract: Digital World Acquisition adjourned by a month an important shareholder meeting after it came up short in votes supporting a one-year extension for the deal.
lead_paragraph: The cash-rich company that seeks to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s upstart social media company is still scrambling to get enough shareholders to vote in favor of extending the deadline for getting a deal done.

headline: A Global Outpouring of Grief Mixes With Criticism of the Monarchy
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II was remembered by ordinary Britons, world leaders and other royals for her grace, humor and longevity. Others had more conflicted views on the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II has died. Follow the latest coverage.

headline: In the U.S., Queen Is Mourned by Those Who Were Never Her Subjects
abstract: Americans paid their respects to the only British monarch most can recall, the head of a royal family that continues to be a source of fascination.
lead_paragraph: The mourners began pouring in to Myers of Keswick, a small British grocery store in Manhattan, on Thursday morning even before Elizabeth II’s death, on the hunt for tea towels, royal memorabilia, Cornish pasties and other small tokens of Britishness to mark a moment in history.

headline: Yankees Injury Woes Continue as D.J. LeMahieu Is Shelved
abstract: With LeMahieu finally taking time to let his toe heel, the struggling Yankees now have 15 players on the injured list.
lead_paragraph: Thursday had a familiar feeling for the Yankees in a frustrating second half of the season: one step forward and two steps back.

headline: After a Legal Fight, Oberlin Says It Will Pay $36.59 Million to a Local Bakery
abstract: Gibson’s Bakery said the liberal arts college had falsely accused it of racism after a Black student was caught shoplifting.
lead_paragraph: Oberlin College, known as a bastion of progressive politics, said on Thursday that it would pay $36.59 million to a local bakery that said it had been defamed and falsely accused of racism after a worker caught a Black student shoplifting.

headline: Meghan and Harry’s children could now inherit royal titles.
abstract: Now that their grandfather is king — and if the royal family adheres to convention — the children of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex should become Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The queen’s death means that Prince Harry and Meghan’s children should become Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet — if the royal family sticks to convention.

headline: Tiafoe Is the Latest Hope for the Rise of Black Men in Tennis
abstract: Frances Tiafoe’s ascent has been the talk of the U.S. Open, but his path to the pros is difficult to follow for other young Black men hoping for a career in tennis.
lead_paragraph: Frances Tiafoe has everything needed to be a difference maker in tennis.

headline: When You Can’t Stand the Sound of Chewing (or Crunching, or Sniffling)
abstract: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
lead_paragraph: I’m a fairly calm person, but one thing that launches me into a fit of rage is the sound of my husband chewing. I can’t say whether his chewing differs in a demonstrable way from other people’s chewing, other than the fact that I’m subjected to it on a daily basis. But I do know that his chewing sounds are the only ones that make me want to pick up my chair and hurl it across the room.

headline: Breast Implants May Be Linked to Additional Cancers, F.D.A. Warns
abstract: On rare occasions, new cancers have been found in women with both textured and smooth implants, filled with saline or silicone, federal health officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday warned women who have breast implants or are considering getting them that certain cancers may develop in scar tissue forming around the implants.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Life and Legacy of Queen Elizabeth II
abstract: Britain’s longest-reigning monarch died on Thursday at the age of 96. Learn about her seven-decade reign, as well as what is next for the British monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Featured Video: “The Legacy of Elizabeth II: The Media Queen” by Nailah Morgan, Will Lloyd, Alan Cowell and Robin Stein

headline: Intense California Wildfire Begins Creating Its Own Weather
abstract: The blaze forced new evacuations of rural communities northeast of Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: The Mosquito fire is prompting new evacuations on Thursday and alarming firefighters and meteorologists with its rapid spread and huge plume of smoke as it burns its way through dry, hilly terrain northeast of Sacramento.

headline: Ons Jabeur Will Play Iga Swiatek for the U.S. Open Women’s Singles Title
abstract: Top-ranked Swiatek will play for her third Grand Slam title. Jabeur, who lost this year’s Wimbledon final, will get another chance to win her first major title.
lead_paragraph: There will be a new U.S. Open women’s singles champion this year, and Ons Jabeur and Iga Swiatek remained in contention in very different ways on Thursday night in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
abstract: Experts weigh in on how long immunity lasts after an infection — or vaccination.
lead_paragraph: The United States has reported more monkeypox cases than any other country in the world. As people recover from their infections, they’ll naturally want to avoid a repeat infection and repeat episodes of the pain and fear associated with the disease.

headline: ‘About Fate’ Review: Love the One You’re With?
abstract: Thomas Mann’s beguiling performance drives this Emma Roberts vehicle, but the romantic comedy creaks under the weight of its coincidences.
lead_paragraph: A few coincidences can have their charms, but the romantic comedy “About Fate,” directed by Marius Vaysberg and written by Tiffany Paulsen (“Holidate”), creaks under the weight of a pile of improbabilities.

headline: First Pass Friday: Work the Crossings, Luke
abstract: Brandon Koppy finds a place for everything.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to First Pass Friday, the occasional feature that shows readers how I worked my way through the dreaded, second-hardest puzzle of the week (the hardest is on Saturday). Please go ahead and feel superior to me before the solving begins. There will be no intermission in today’s column.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon make us feel better about watching television.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from a 2019 book by Emily Nussbaum, a Pulitzer Prize-winning television critic for The New Yorker, called “I Like to Watch: Arguing My Way Through the TV Revolution.” I’m part of the decreasing population of people who grew up before streaming and e-books, which means that I still mentally schedule viewings of shows that are available 24/7, and I still reflexively consider reading to be a worthwhile effort and television to be indulgent entertainment. Ms. Nussbaum thinks we should evolve beyond that snobbery; I agree, and it seems inevitable anyway.

headline: Connecticut Sun Complete Comeback to Reach W.N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Connecticut forced a decisive Game 5, then beat the reigning champion Sky and set up a finals matchup with the Las Vegas Aces.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Sky looked like they were on their way to their second straight appearance in the W.N.B.A. finals. They led Connecticut by 9 points with less than five minutes to go in the decisive Game 5, and had held the Sun to just 14 points since halftime. Sky guard Kahleah Copper was dominating, forcing turnovers, flexing her muscles and clapping her hands en route to a game-high 22 points.

headline: Developing a Harmony at Different Stages in Life
abstract: Matei Varga, a concert pianist, met Missi Gibbs, an arts enthusiast four decades his senior, while looking for an apartment. In time, they went from roommates to something more romantic.
lead_paragraph: As is often the case in New York, housing crises can lead to life-altering changes in direction. For Matei Varga, 41, being kicked out of an apartment led to an unexpected romance with Melissa Gibbs, 84.

headline: Two Journalists Who Cover Hate Find Love
abstract: Tess Owen and Andy Campbell met in Charlottesville, Va., while reporting on the aftermath of the “Unite the Right” rally of white nationalists.
lead_paragraph: Tess Alexandra MacVicar Owen and Andrew Blaise Campbell were in Charlottesville, Va., in August 2017 to cover the violent “Unite the Right” rally of white nationalists, or, as Ms. Owen called it, “a brazen display of hatred.”

headline: The Feelings Were There, Even When Words Were Not
abstract: After talking to Abrielle Moore for weeks, Kobina Johnson got her number and then sent a one-word message: “hey.” When he learned it upset her, he sent another (longer) note that led to a first date.
lead_paragraph: Kobina Amani Johnson and Abrielle Kiana Moore had been talking for weeks by the time Mr. Johnson asked Ms. Moore for her phone number with the intention of inviting her on a date. But Mr. Johnson waited a week before sending his first text message to Ms. Moore at around 11 p.m. on a Saturday night in December 2017. At the advice of a friend who told him not to immediately suggest a get-together, he simply said, “hey.”

headline: Hitting a High Note on and Off the Opera Stage
abstract: Soon after Jordan Rutter and Vincent Covatto met at a Halloween drag gala, the two, both members of New York City’s opera scene, found their paths crossing at the National Opera Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Leigh Rutter and Vincent Joseph Covatto both say a certain magnetism drew each to the other at Heartbeat Opera’s annual Halloween drag gala in October 2016.

headline: A Two-Week Trip That Took Them Out of the Friend Zone
abstract: Jennifer Noinaj and Perry Chu, part of the same social group for years, began to see each other in a more romantic light while competing online.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Noinaj didn’t think she would ever get married, but after a year with Andrew Perry Chu, who goes by his middle name, she changed her mind.

headline: If at First You Don’t Succeed at Love, Try an Instagram DM
abstract: When Carly Stein and Oliver Kremer matched on Hinge, they didn’t make it past the messaging stage before she ghosted. But he persisted.
lead_paragraph: When Carly Lena Sophie Stein first saw Oliver Samuel Kremer’s profile on Hinge, she almost swiped left.

headline: No Longer Running From My Emotions
abstract: At 19, I rejected his romantic gestures because they were too intense. At 27, I relished intensity.
lead_paragraph: When I bumped into him on the street in Rome last summer, we hadn’t seen each other for nearly a decade. You know how people say that you’ll fall in love when you least expect it? I am never not expecting it. On every plane, at every coffee shop, I’m always hoping for a spark with someone.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Elizabeth II, Whose 7-Decade Reign Linked Generations, Dies at 96
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Sept. 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t think people around the world realized just how brilliant she was. It’s like losing your grandmother. My wife will be in tears when I get home tonight.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 9, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the challenges the Department of Justice faces in its investigation into Donald J. Trump’s retention of highly classified documents at his home in Florida described incorrectly a judge’s order appointing a special master to examine documents taken from Mr. Trump’s residence. Her decision to allow the arbiter to review the files for any potentially shielded by executive privilege was in response to a request by Mr. Trump’s lawyers. It did not go beyond what they had argued.

headline: Frances Tiafoe vs. Carlos Alcaraz in the U.S. Open Men’s Semifinals: How to Watch
abstract: Fans will get to see what one of the next great tennis rivalries could look like on Friday at 7 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Those who have been worried about the state of men’s tennis when the likes of Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal are retired have nothing to worry about.

headline: ‘We Deserve Gold Medals’
abstract: Fifty years after a painful, and controversial, loss to the Soviet Union in the 1972 Olympics, some American men’s basketball players still hope to be declared the rightful winners.
lead_paragraph: It was after 2 a.m. on Sept. 10, 1972, when Tom McMillen and Tom Burleson made their way to the Hofbräuhaus, the famed beer hall in central Munich, so they could commiserate in the dark over German sausage and pilsners.

headline: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
abstract: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine and rising energy prices are rapidly overturning European economic orthodoxy, with barely a peep of dissent.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Nationalizations. Subsidies. Cash handouts. Price caps. Profit taxes. It’s back to 20th-century economics in Europe.

headline: Magic Mountains: Novels of Appalachia From Natalie Lloyd and David Barclay Moore
abstract: In “Hummingbird” and “Holler of the Fireflies,” a girl with brittle bones and a boy plagued by racist tensions seek healing in the hills.
lead_paragraph: The magic of flight — as depicted by creatures such as birds, butterflies and fireflies — is just one of the shared themes of two new middle grade novels, Natalie Lloyd’s “Hummingbird” and David Barclay Moore’s “Holler of the Fireflies.” Another is transformation, as experienced by the books’ protagonists, who choose to put themselves in challenging and unfamiliar circumstances that they must navigate in order to … if not exactly survive then evolve.

headline: Behind Josh Allen, Bills Take Rams in Hand
abstract: Buffalo dominated the defending Super Bowl champions on both sides of the ball in Thursday’s N.F.L. regular season opener.
lead_paragraph: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — The N.F.L.’s season opener is always a hyped affair, but the Super Bowl-champion Los Angeles Rams’ game against the Buffalo Bills, a preseason favorite of football pundits, came down to a number of quieter dramas.

headline: After Long Brawl, South Carolina Senate Approves More Abortion Restrictions
abstract: Legislators failed to advance a total ban on abortion, instead adding more restrictions to an existing law. The G.O.P. split over exceptions for rape and incest.
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina Senate voted Thursday night to tighten abortion restrictions but failed to pass a total ban after a heated debate revealed the ongoing struggle among Republicans to define a cohesive post-Roe strategy.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A special edition of the Briefing on the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s longest-serving monarch, died at 96 yesterday afternoon at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, her summer retreat. Members of the royal family rushed to be at her bedside. The family’s announcement did not specify a cause, but said she had “died peacefully.” Read our obituary.

headline: Rising energy prices amid a standoff with Russia over Ukraine are pushing Europe to spend big again.
abstract: BRUSSELS — With people across the European Union facing painful inflation driven by higher fuel costs, the bloc’s energy ministers plan to meet Friday to discuss how to remedy their distress.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With people across the European Union facing painful inflation driven by higher fuel costs, the bloc’s energy ministers plan to meet Friday to discuss how to remedy their distress.

headline: James Corden Pays Tribute to the Queen
abstract: The British host of “The Late Late Show” called Queen Elizabeth II “a guiding light.” Other hosts went a bit lighter with their commentary.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: succinct
abstract: This word has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word succinct has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 22 in “This Game Is Why the Word ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Exists” by Tania Ganguli:

headline: The U.S. and Russia clash at the U.N. over military aid.
abstract: At the United Nations Security Council on Thursday, sparring between Russia and the West centered on the supply of foreign weapons and military equipment to Ukraine on a day when the United States announced it would allocate an additional $675 million in military supplies.
lead_paragraph: At the United Nations Security Council on Thursday, sparring between Russia and the West centered on the supply of foreign weapons and military equipment to Ukraine on a day when the United States announced it would allocate an additional $675 million in military supplies.

headline: Charles addresses Britain on his first full day as monarch.
abstract: LONDON — King Charles III, in his first address to the nation as sovereign, made clear his intention to carry on his mother’s legacy while honoring her service, telling the nation in a televised speech, “Our values have remained and must remain constant.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III, in his first address to the nation as sovereign, made clear his intention to carry on his mother’s legacy while honoring her service, telling the nation in a televised speech, “Our values have remained and must remain constant.”

headline: Distance
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: The One Constant in an Inconstant World
abstract: From fading empire to the Cold War to 1970s turmoil to Brexit to Covid, “she was always there.” What will Britain, and the world, do without her?
lead_paragraph: She did not complain. She did not call in sick. She did not descend into self-pity. She did not deviate from tradition, at least not if she could help it. She did not show her emotions in public. When her beloved husband, Prince Philip, died during the dark days of Covid, she adhered to government guidelines by sitting apart from everyone else at his funeral, the picture of stiff-upper-lip stoicism and rectitude in black mourning clothes and two face masks.

headline: North Korea Adopts New Law Hardening Its Nuclear Doctrine
abstract: The law authorizes a nuclear strike if an enemy tries to remove Kim Jong-un from power, the North’s state media reported.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea has adopted a new law that says the country will launch a nuclear attack if the United States or South Korea tries to remove its leader, Kim Jong-un, from power, state media reported on Friday.

headline: 5 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's roundup includes titles by Lauren Groff, Louise Erdrich and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's roundup includes titles by Lauren Groff, Louise Erdrich and more.

headline: Should More Parents Play Video Games With Their Kids?
abstract: Some parents who grew up playing video games are introducing the popular pastime to their children. Should more parents embrace the joys of gaming with their kids?
lead_paragraph: Do you ever play video games with the grown-ups in your life? Or do they think video games are bad for kids?

headline: Traveling This Fall? Expect Cheaper Prices, ‘Seasonal Drift’ and, Yes, Chaos
abstract: After a haywire summer of flight cancellations and delays, travelers remain eager to roam, returning to familiar hot spots like New York, Europe and the Caribbean. Here’s what they can expect this season.
lead_paragraph: After a haywire summer of flight cancellations and delays, travelers remain eager to roam, returning to familiar hot spots like New York, Europe and the Caribbean. Here’s what they can expect this season.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 9, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: As Wildfires Grow, Millions of Homes Are Being Built in Harm’s Way
abstract: The number of homes in fire-prone parts of the West soared from 10 million in 1990 to 16 million today, a big reason wildfires are causing more destruction.
lead_paragraph: The number of homes in fire-prone parts of the West soared from 10 million in 1990 to 16 million today, a big reason wildfires are causing more destruction.

headline: The Treasure America Scavenges From the Poor
abstract: The world’s blood banks are filled with “donations” collected in the United States.
lead_paragraph: I first sold plasma in 2009 after years of avoiding it. It was a temporary solution to a continuous state of financial instability.

headline: Ling Ma’s Surreal Subversions
abstract: The stories in “Bliss Montage” see women — insouciant, detached, mostly Chinese American — making questionable choices.
lead_paragraph: In her 1993 book “A Woman’s View,” the film historian Jeanine Basinger observed a peculiar phenomenon in early Hollywood movies about women: They almost always included a sequence depicting “the protagonist in her marginal territory of joy.” Sound-tracked by a swelling score, the elegantly dressed leading lady would, in the company of a lover, throw her head back in laughter, beam over dinner, stroll contentedly in the park or dance into dawn.

headline: Elizabeth Bailey, Who Helped Deregulate Airlines, Dies at 83
abstract: In a career full of firsts, she was the first woman to serve on the Civil Aeronautics Board as well as a distinguished economist and academic.
lead_paragraph: In March 1979, on an Eastern Airlines flight to Tallahassee, Fla., from Atlanta, a flight attendant got into a disagreement with a late-boarding passenger who insisted that the airline was obligated to place her in a nonsmoking section, rather than in the back of the plane among the puffers. When the attendant welcomed passengers over the plane’s intercom several minutes later, she was still miffed.

headline: A Premature Victory Lap for Black Lives Matter
abstract: While compellingly readable, Peniel E. Joseph’s “The Third Reconstruction” overstates the impact of the recent reckoning over racial justice.
lead_paragraph: If racial progress in America tends to arrive in waves, much of it has come in the form of two crashing breakers: the First Reconstruction, which ended slavery after the Civil War, and the Second, which ended Jim Crow segregation a century later. The historian Peniel E. Joseph believes we have just witnessed a third such moment, bracketed by Barack Obama’s election in 2008 and the wake of George Floyd’s murder in 2020.

headline: I.R.S. to Refund Late-Filing Penalties for 2019 and 2020 Returns
abstract: But to be eligible for the relief, taxpayers have to file the returns by Sept. 30. The agency says the average refund will be $750.
lead_paragraph: About 1.6 million taxpayers who missed deadlines for filing their 2019 and 2020 federal income tax returns will get automatic refunds of late-filing penalties under a new Internal Revenue Service pandemic relief program.

headline: The Cost of Driving in Manhattan
abstract: Everyone agrees there are too many cars in Midtown. No one agrees on how to limit them.
lead_paragraph: This summer, after a near quarter-century of anxious procrastination, I got a driver’s license, a minor triumph followed by a commitment to getting in the car and traveling in increasingly longer increments. This mission in exposure therapy brought a personal best over Labor Day weekend. On a cloudless afternoon with little traffic, I drove my son to visit a friend in Duxbury, Mass., a trip of about 60 miles from our starting point in Rhode Island and one that, even though made under the least imaginably stressful conditions, still left me with the vague sense that I was undertaking a risk along the lines of going heli-skiing in Kashmir.

headline: The Plane’s a Filthy Mess. Who’s to Blame?
abstract: Recent social media posts suggest that the days of clean flights may be going the way of masks. And they’ve ignited a debate about who bears responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The camera pans across the floor below two rows of passenger seats. The carpet is littered with so many potato chip crumbs it appears as if there was a recent in-flight snowfall.

headline: Two Barbers, a YouTube Channel and the Truth About Race at the Racetrack
abstract: Two entrepreneurial barbers with video cameras are documenting the overlooked characters of thoroughbred racing, with an emphasis on Black grooms and trainers.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Rasi Harper and Maurice Davis arrived in Louisville a couple of days before the Kentucky Derby in May, carrying their video cameras and searching, as always, for true stories of life at the racetrack.

headline: Biden Is Telling You That Trump Is a Threat, and the Proof Is Everywhere
abstract: Trump is the chosen candidate of reactionary billionaires and fanatical opponents of racial and gender equality for a reason.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is right. The so-called MAGA movement, led by Donald Trump, is a direct threat to democratic self-government in the United States.

headline: Downsizing in Retirement: Expenses They Didn’t Expect
abstract: On the way to spending less, people often have to shell out more, at least temporarily — especially when selling a home. Here’s what to consider.
lead_paragraph: Louise Angel Kiss and her husband, Charles, lived in their four-bedroom, split-level house in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue, Wash., for 40 years. Their two daughters had moved away long ago, and the couple decided they’d had enough of the stairs and the hassles and costs of upkeep. Like many older homeowners, they decided to downsize.

headline: Alex G and the Art of Interesting Choices
abstract: The 29-year-old musician has recorded with Frank Ocean, released a film score and made oodles of outré indie rock. One thing has guided his unusual career: gut decisions.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On a blustery Thursday in June, the 29-year-old musician Alex Giannascoli sat on a bench in tranquil Penn Treaty Park, overlooking the Delaware River, the breeze occasionally shaking loose acorns from an overhead tree. Giannascoli, who is known professionally as Alex G, has dark, shaggy hair and a disheveled handsomeness that makes him look a bit like a softer, more approachable Andrew W.K. He clutched a large Dunkin’ Donuts coffee cup and, whenever he felt like he’d gone on a tangent, blamed the caffeine.

headline: China’s Public Puts on a Show of Zero Covid for an Audience of One
abstract: Because of Xi Jinping’s unrelenting policy, the Chinese people put up with a precarious existence filled with lockdowns, quarantines and mass testing.
lead_paragraph: As fire was raging in the mountains surrounding the southwestern Chinese metropolis of Chongqing, 10 million residents stood in 100-plus-degree heat to get Covid tests. Two cases were detected that day in August.

headline: What My Family and I Saw When We Were Trapped in China’s Heat Wave
abstract: On a trip through the epicenter, ravaged landscapes, paralyzed cities and populations pushed to extremes.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Last month, I traveled with my wife and 5-year-old daughter from our home here to southwestern China for a family camping trip.

headline: How Silicon Chips Rule the World
abstract: Maintaining the flow of oil is still crucial for the world economy. But now the supply of semiconductors is also critical for commerce, and war and peace.
lead_paragraph: When I first arrived in Taiwan as a college student in the summer of 1973, there was no ambiguity whatsoever about the American role on the island.

headline: To Grandmothers’ House We Go. Next Door.
abstract: In-laws typically have one of the most fraught family dynamics. What about two sets of in-laws living together down a hall from their children and grandchildren?
lead_paragraph: In a city with no shortage of unusual real estate stories, Adele Geffen Eil and Judith Seligson have created one of the more unexpected living arrangements in New York.

headline: What This War Correspondent Wants You to Know About America and Fear
abstract: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
lead_paragraph: Luke Mogelson is a journalist for The New Yorker who has reported from some of the world’s most harrowing and unlucky places, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria and Liberia. Before he returned to the United States in 2020 to cover our political convulsions, he hadn’t spent more than a few consecutive months in his native country in almost a decade.

headline: 16 Easy Recipes for Hungry, Busy People
abstract: Or just hungry people who like easy recipes.
lead_paragraph: We’ve shaken the sand from our shoes and tucked away our swimsuits until next summer, and the busyness of fall has begun: The calendar is filling up with to-dos and appointments, and if you can believe it, holiday plans. The days can sometimes feel like they’re slipping by, but stopping to make a simple meal and enjoy it can help you slow down and smell the proverbial roses. These recipes are blessedly easy, the kind you can cook once or twice, then cook from memory. Put them together while chatting with your loved ones about their days or booking your plane tickets home for Thanksgiving.

headline: How Do Japanese Show They Care? By Sending a Telegram.
abstract: Millions of the messages still crisscross Japan each year, offering congratulations or condolences in a way that more modern communications cannot.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When he got married this summer, Hiroshi Kanno, who works at a security services firm in Tokyo, wanted to make a big statement that would impress his future in-laws.

headline: With Drought, ‘Spanish Stonehenge’ Emerges Once Again
abstract: The Dolmen of Guadalperal, a Bronze Age stone monument newly exposed by plummeting water levels in Europe, is now imperiled by tourists.
lead_paragraph: Like the skeleton of an extinct sea monster, the Dolmen of Guadalperal has resurfaced from the depths of the Valdecañas reservoir in western Spain, where Europe’s persistent drought has caused water levels to plummet and submerged monuments to come to light. The remnants of this Bronze Age sepulcher, nicknamed the Spanish Stonehenge, are now fully exposed for only the fifth time since the area was deliberately flooded in 1963 as part of a rural development project.

headline: Gods of 125th Street
abstract: A new book traces the arc of hip-hop jewelry from the 1980s to today.
