lead_paragraph: In 1976, Ricky “Slick Rick” Walters’s Jamaican British family moved from South London to the Bronx, where he would go on to become one of the most influential rappers of early New York hip-hop. But as he puts it in ICE COLD: A HIP-HOP JEWELRY HISTORY (Taschen, $100), “I’ve been telling stories through my attire and adornments for as long as I’ve been telling them with beats and rhymes.”

headline: Some Like It Not: Are Men in Dresses Still Funny?
abstract: As “Some Like It Hot” and “Ain’t No Mo’” head to Broadway, following runs of “Tootsie” and “Mrs. Doubtfire,” 10 artists reflect on an enduring trope and how it works, or doesn’t, today.
lead_paragraph: Men in dresses are in vogue on Broadway. Just before the pandemic, there was “Tootsie,” and just after the shutdown, “Mrs. Doubtfire.” Now comes “Some Like It Hot,” a musical adaptation of the classic caper comedy about two men who dress as women to escape the mob.

headline: Bill de Blasio Knows New York Is Tired of Him. He’s at Peace With It.
abstract: On the eve of the former mayor’s return to his New England home, a frank exit interview about his time in New York.
lead_paragraph: For decades, as Bill de Blasio climbed the political ladder, he resolutely insisted he was a New Yorker. This insistence came even though he was raised primarily in Boston — well, nearby in Cambridge, technically — and kept his childhood fealty to the Red Sox.

headline: The Queen in New York, From a Ferryboat to Bloomingdale’s
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II made three visits to New York City during her 70-year reign.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at Queen Elizabeth II and New York, a city she visited three times in her long reign. We’ll also hear former Mayor Bill de Blasio’s reflections on a subject he has had time to reflect on: former Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: A California County Braces for Fire, Floods and Mudslides, All at Once
abstract: A storm threatens to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the state’s largest wildfire, creating a recipe for a compound disaster in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: Riverside County, already facing a growing wildfire, was placed under multiple extreme weather advisories on Friday as a tropical storm threatened to bring high winds, lightning, flooding and mudslides to the area in Southern California.

headline: How Queen Elizabeth II Preserved the Monarchy
abstract: A look back at the life of Britain’s longest-reigning monarch, who led her country and the royal family through moments of enormous upheaval.
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday brought to an end a remarkable reign that spanned seven decades, 15 prime ministers and 14 American presidents.

headline: Premier League Soccer Games Postponed After Queen’s Death
abstract: The league was one of many sports organizations in Britain to alter its schedule after the death of Queen Elizabeth II. Others will play on this weekend.
lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — A swath of sporting events across Britain, including the entire professional soccer schedule, were canceled in the hours after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, with most likely to remain on hiatus through the weekend as a mark of respect.

headline: For Australians, Too, It’s the End of an Era
abstract: “I don’t think we’ll ever have the security again that we had with her,” said one Australian about the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s longest-reigning monarch, has reverberated around the world. Amid the outpouring of grief on social media and in news coverage, her passing inevitably renewed questions about the monarchy’s role, including in Commonwealth countries, like Australia, where she was the head of state.

headline: Buckingham Palace provides details about tributes to the queen.
abstract: The palace released the protocol for floral tributes, the closing of royal residences and a period of mourning to mark the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: Buckingham Palace released details on Friday morning about protocol for floral tributes, the closing of royal residences and a period of mourning to mark the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: An Era Ends
abstract: After 70 years, the reign of Queen Elizabeth II is over.
lead_paragraph: She became queen when Britain was only seven years removed from World War II, and she went on to have the longest recorded reign of any monarch in world history other than Louis XIV.

headline: Austrian Takes Over as Top U.N. Human Rights Official
abstract: One of Volker Türk’s toughest challenges will be determining what to do about a highly critical report on China that his predecessor, Michelle Bachelet, released just before departing.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A week after Michelle Bachelet stepped down as the United Nations’ high commissioner for human rights, the U.N. has approved Volker Türk, an Austrian who is a trusted adviser to the secretary general, to take on the notoriously challenging job.

headline: Thousands of Angry Indonesians Gather to Protest Rising Fuel Prices
abstract: Labor activists, workers and students are demanding a reversal of an economic policy that the government says is necessary but remains deeply unpopular.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Thousands of protesters rallied across Indonesia this week calling for the government to reverse its first price hike on subsidized fuel in eight years, and vowing to continue demonstrations until President Joko Widodo meets their demands.

headline: 2 Years After Deadly Fistfights, India and China Pull Back From Border
abstract: The two sides, after 16 rounds of talks, made an announcement a week before their leaders will meet in Uzbekistan.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — Their soldiers have fought with fists, rocks and wooden clubs along a disputed frontier high in the Himalayas. Both India and China have said they don’t want a war, but the brawls led them to move thousands of soldiers to inhospitable terrain.

headline: The queen’s death draws a more muted response in India, the largest of Britain’s former colonies.
abstract: India declared a day of mourning, but the British colonial era evokes uncomfortable memories.
lead_paragraph: In India, the government declared a day of mourning on Sunday, with flags flying at half-staff to honor the late Queen Elizabeth II. But her death provoked a muted reaction across much of the country, the largest in the Commonwealth of Nations, an association of mostly former British colonies.

headline: Remember ‘Avatar’? Neither Do We. Catch Up Before the Sequel Arrives.
abstract: After 13 years, James Cameron’s sequel, “Avatar: The Way of Water,” is finally opening in December. Here’s everything you need to know.
lead_paragraph: What can be accomplished in 13 years? Given that much time, J.K. Rowling published all seven of the Harry Potter books — and helped turn the first six of them into movies. Taylor Swift cranked out eight studio albums — and rerecorded two of them. The Yankees won the World Series eight times.

headline: Navalny, a jailed Putin critic, says Russia has revoked his attorney-client privilege.
abstract: Mr. Navalny said on Twitter that the prison administration had accused him of committing unspecified crimes by communicating with “accomplices through lawyers.”
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, said on Thursday that the prison authorities had deprived him of his attorney-client privilege, which has been his main line of communication with the outside world and has allowed him to remain active in Russian political life.

headline: Dissecting the Royal Family’s Wealth
abstract: The Windsors benefit from a complex array of holdings, which face the same economic challenges as Britain as a whole.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Britain mourned the death of Queen Elizabeth II and welcomed the ascension of her son as King Charles III. Much attention will be paid to the formal procedures of royal mourning and the crowning of a new monarch — but it’s also worth examining the state of a multibillion-dollar fortune that will change hands as well.

headline: Artists discuss how they turned the queen into an icon.
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain was one of the world’s most photographed and painted people. Three artists explain how they made portraits of the monarch that stood out from the crowd.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Chris Levine, a Canadian artist, was commissioned to make a holographic portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, who died in Scotland on Thursday, he took an unusual approach to getting her to relax.

headline: How Readers Are Reducing Their Carbon Footprint
abstract: Whether biking around town or adopting a meatless diet, Californians describe how they are reducing their impact.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, the temperature in Los Angeles typically reached 90 degrees 56 days a year. By 2072, climate models suggest there could be 87 days annually when the temperature hits that mark.

headline: Harry leaves Balmoral Castle, with uncertain plans ahead.
abstract: The Duke of Sussex was among the members of the royal family who traveled to the estate in Scotland where Queen Elizabeth II died.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry was seen leaving Balmoral Castle in Scotland on Friday morning, having spent the night there after the death of his grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 1, Episode 3: Island Time
abstract: New characters, new realms and the same old prejudices (onscreen and off). Here are five takeaways from the third episode of Amazon’s “Lord of the Rings” prequel.
lead_paragraph: The audience reactions to last week’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” premiere ran the gamut from a warm reception to the show’s expensive-looking special effects and old-fashioned adventure-fantasy sprawl to a dispiriting campaign of social media bile, aimed in part at the diverse casting and the balance of male and female heroes. What is especially vexing about the race- and gender-focused gripes is that the story this series is telling — similar to the one J.R.R. Tolkien told in his books — is largely concerned with how different groups overcome their biases and superstitions for a higher cause. In other words: The various ways these multihued creatures look and act is kind of the point.

headline: U.S. Open Semifinals: The 4 Men Left
abstract: Men’s tennis will have a first-time Grand Slam winner by Sunday: Frances Tiafoe, Carlos Alcaraz, Karen Khachanov or Casper Ruud.
lead_paragraph: Men’s tennis will have a first-time Grand Slam winner by Sunday: Frances Tiafoe, Carlos Alcaraz, Karen Khachanov or Casper Ruud.

headline: In a Power Crisis, South Africans Adjust to Life in the Dark
abstract: Blackouts are no longer merely a problem in South Africa. They have become a crisis that affects nearly every facet of life.
lead_paragraph: Blackouts are no longer merely a problem in South Africa. They have become a crisis that affects nearly every facet of life.

headline: Amid Crypto Downturn, Two Big Names Cut Deal
abstract: The billionaire investor behind the cryptocurrency exchange FTX has bought a 30 percent stake in the hedge fund SkyBridge Capital.
lead_paragraph: The venture arm of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, helmed by the billionaire investor Sam Bankman-Fried, announced on Friday that it had taken a 30 percent stake in SkyBridge Capital, the hedge fund founded by Anthony Scaramucci, for an undisclosed sum. SkyBridge will use $40 million from the proceeds to buy cryptocurrencies to strengthen its long-term balance sheet.

headline: Siddhartha Mukherjee Weaves History and Biology to Tell the Story of Us
abstract: His forthcoming book, “The Song of the Cell,” part of what he says will be a quartet, is “fundamentally about understanding the units that organize our life.”
lead_paragraph: Books, Siddhartha Mukherjee says, just tumble out of him, like fluffy towels and clean socks cascade out of a dryer at the end of the cycle. And it’s a good thing, because it’s not as if the man has a lot of idle time to spare.

headline: ‘Three Divas, What Could Be Better?’ Making ‘The Hours’ Operatic
abstract: Renée Fleming, Kelli O’Hara and Joyce DiDonato discuss their preparations for the staged premiere of Kevin Puts’s work at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s opera event of the fall — an adaptation of “The Hours” having its staged premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in November — started with a pitch from Renée Fleming.

headline: Did You Recently Buy an Electric Vehicle? We Want to Hear About It.
abstract: Sales of electric cars are surging as more people become interested in the technology and grow concerned about climate change.
lead_paragraph: People are buying electric vehicles at a record pace, snapping up battery-powered cars and trucks as quickly as automakers can make them. In just a few years, electric vehicles have gone from expensive novelties for the superrich to a must-have product for many people.

headline: Issy Wood Met Power Players in Art and Music. She Went Her Own Way.
abstract: The painter and budding electronic-pop musician has a new show of figurative paintings in New York, and quietly released the LP “My Body Your Choice” last month.
lead_paragraph: For the last three years, through art fairs, auctions, a global pandemic and an album release, the British painter and musician Issy Wood has been perfecting the craft of being pursued professionally.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Inside New York’s private pools. Also in this edition: Christine Baranski’s throwback flair, and an interview with the soccer star Kylian Mbappé.
lead_paragraph: Inside New York’s private pools. Also in this edition: Christine Baranski’s throwback flair, and an interview with the soccer star Kylian Mbappé.

headline: S.E.C. Chair Doubles Down on the Need to Regulate Cryptocurrencies
abstract: Gary Gensler, the S.E.C. chair, said he would work with Congress to create new legislation.
lead_paragraph: The chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gary Gensler, has repeatedly warned that cryptocurrencies must be regulated to protect investors. On Thursday he took a big step toward that goal, saying he will work with Congress to help create legislation that would increase crypto oversight.

headline: What You Get for $5 Million in California
abstract: A 2017 residence near Manhattan Beach Pier, a rustic beach house in Bolinas and a four-bedroom condominium in an Edwardian building in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: A 2017 residence near Manhattan Beach Pier, a rustic beach house in Bolinas and a four-bedroom condominium in an Edwardian building in San Francisco.

headline: The Burn Test
abstract: Can controlled fires protect forests? California is about to find out.
lead_paragraph: My summer break is over. This summer of flames is not.

headline: Claw Clips Claw Their Way Back
abstract: A ’90s hair accessory makes a triumphant return on the heads of models, influencers and, well, everybody else.
lead_paragraph: Bethany Simko didn’t mean for claw clips to become her TikTok claim to fame. If it weren’t for one forgetful moment earlier this summer, they might never have been.

headline: A Back-to-School Book List for the Ages
abstract: Karina Yan Glaser, author of the Vanderbeekers series, recommends picture books, chapter books and novels for preschool to middle grade readers.
lead_paragraph: There is a unique and palpable energy around back-to-school season. For some, it’s the beginning of something brand-new and unexplored; for others, it’s a time for reinvention and much anticipated milestones. No matter what the emotions surrounding a new school year, one thing is for sure: No kid is alone in how he or she is feeling.

headline: Camilla Becomes Queen Consort, Capping Years of Image Restoration
abstract: Upon Queen Elizabeth’s death, there was no question that as her son became King Charles III, Camilla would become queen consort. Elizabeth put the issue of Camilla’s role to rest earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Earlier this year, Queen Elizabeth issued a letter that was seen as a major moment of recognition for a long beleaguered member of the royal family, intended to smooth the path for her ascent when the inevitable finally came.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Sam Sifton’s back at the wheel with recipes for banana pancakes, simple risotto and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You miss me? Here’s what I did on my summer vacation: made a lot of pizzas, 63 percent hydration in my dough. Took a lot of long walks through browned and crusty fields. Caught striped bass in the foaming rips between boulders on the shoreline. Read some terrific fiction — Rebecca Rukeyser, Ling Ma, Sebastian Barry. Drove great distances. Ate very well.

headline: How Well Do You Know These Novels Set in California?
abstract: America’s Golden State has long been a place for storytelling in many forms. Can you name the California locations where these books take place?
lead_paragraph: America’s Golden State has long been a place for storytelling in many forms. Can you name the California locations where these books take place?

headline: Kurt Gottfried, Physicist and Foe of Nuclear Weapons, Dies at 93
abstract: As a founder of the Union of Concerned Scientists, he defended Soviet dissidents and advocated higher standards in government research.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Gottfried, a theoretical physicist who barely escaped the brutal reality of one world war and devoted his career to preventing another as a co-founder of the influential Union of Concerned Scientists, died on Aug. 25 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Was Biden’s Democracy Speech Too Harsh?
abstract: Readers discuss Bret Stephens and Ross Douthat’s criticism of the Philadelphia speech. Also: Reasons for the teacher shortage; the reusable bag glut.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Africa, the queen’s death renews a debate about the legacy of the British Empire.
abstract: While some in Africa paid tribute to the deceased monarch, others stressed Britain’s violent colonial history on the continent.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Though Queen Elizabeth II was revered by many in Africa, her death also reignited a different sort of conversation — one that touched on the legacy of the British Empire and the brutality the monarchy meted out to people in its former colonies.

headline: How Ivo van Hove Turns a Novel Into a Play
abstract: We followed the theater director in and around Amsterdam and through rehearsals as he developed a new work, adapted from a book by Édouard Louis.
lead_paragraph: We followed the theater director in and around Amsterdam and through rehearsals as he developed a new work, adapted from a book by Édouard Louis.

headline: Hate Doing the Dishes? Try These 3 One-Pot, One-Pan Recipes.
abstract: Melissa Clark is obsessed with maximum flavor and minimal cleanup, and these sheet-pan brussels sprouts, full English breakfast and lemony chickpea stew show just that.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing that makes me appreciate the streamlined ease of a one-pan meal more than watching a professional chef at work.

headline: Arsenic in N.Y.C. Water Sample Came From a Testing Error, Lab Says
abstract: In a reversal, New York City officials said that tap water at the Jacob Riis Houses never contained elevated levels of arsenic, but they are still testing for dangerous bacteria.
lead_paragraph: Days after New York City officials said they had found potentially dangerous levels of arsenic in the tap water at a Manhattan public housing development, they delivered a stunning turnabout on Friday, saying arsenic had been added to the sample during a laboratory test and there had never been elevated levels in the water.

headline: Björk Insists on Connection, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Blood Orange, Madison Cunningham, Yeat and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Los Angeles County Investigates Death of Person With Monkeypox
abstract: Officials said they were conducting an autopsy to see if a monkeypox infection contributed to the death of a Los Angeles County resident.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County officials said this week that they were investigating the death of a person who had been diagnosed with monkeypox to see if the illness was a contributing cause of death.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include an Indian thriller, a Japanese teen assassin movie and an intense, character-driven Kenyan heist flick.
lead_paragraph: This sprawling and incisive action thriller from the Indian director Anubhav Sinha offers a distinctive glimpse into the divergent political and cultural identities found in India’s northeast.

headline: A Filmmaker Explores David Bowie’s Life and Finds Clarity About His Own
abstract: With the epic “Moonage Daydream,” Brett Morgen contended with a chameleonic star whose approach to living helped him refocus after a heart attack.
lead_paragraph: When the documentary filmmaker Brett Morgen hit his eighth month of writer’s block on an epic project about David Bowie, he decided it was time to hit the road. With just a few hours’ notice, he left his home in Los Angeles one morning and grabbed the first flight to Albuquerque, where Bowie had filmed “The Man Who Fell to Earth” (1976). When Morgen arrived, he took a cab to the train station and hopped aboard an Amtrak, heading west.

headline: Trump Media Gets Aggressive With Regulators Over Delayed Merger
abstract: The former president’s social media company said “improper political considerations” by regulators have caused “unnecessary financial harm,” as it scrambles to keep a money-raising merger deal alive.
lead_paragraph: The upstart social media company backed by former President Donald J. Trump appears to be taking a more aggressive approach with regulators as it seeks approval for its delayed merger with a cash-rich shell company.

headline: What will happen to the queen’s royal pack of corgis?
abstract: Wherever the dogs end up, they may need to become accustomed to a home that is less luxurious than a royal castle.
lead_paragraph: Among the many transitions that Queen Elizabeth II’s death has set in motion for Britain will be one that affects the smallest, and perhaps cutest, members of the royal family: the monarch’s pack of four royal dogs. These include two corgis, a corgi-dachshund cross (known as a dorgi) and a cocker spaniel.

headline: King Charles III is formally proclaimed to his new role.
abstract: The ceremony was televised for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, her son Charles’s new role as British monarch was officially proclaimed on Saturday in a ceremony at St. James’s Palace in London.

headline: In London, Mourning, Remembrance and Tributes. And Some Shrugs.
abstract: Though mourning and grief were visible in Britain’s capital on Friday, some young Britons were more muted in their reaction to an institution that many called increasingly irrelevant.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gertrude Dudley remembers sitting on her grandfather’s shoulders in 1953 at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, a monarch she came to know as “the fabric of Britain.”

headline: He Stole Another Man’s Name to Rejoin the Army. He Got Caught Decades Later.
abstract: The life a Black man made for himself far from the violence of 1980s St. Louis was upended when the man whose name he used discovered the ruse.
lead_paragraph: Joel Sanders served in the United States Army from 1985 to 1988. Originally from St. Louis, Mr. Sanders was stationed in Berlin, and after being medically discharged, he stayed in Germany and made a life for himself, having six children and founding a security business.

headline: Joseph Hazelwood, Captain of the Exxon Valdez, Is Dead at 75
abstract: The tanker spilled millions of gallons of oil when it ran aground, causing one of the nation’s worst environmental disasters. He accepted responsibility but was demonized.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Hazelwood, the captain of the tanker Exxon Valdez, which ran aground on a reef in the icy waters of Alaska’s Prince William Sound in March 1989, dumping at least 10.8 million gallons of crude oil in one of America’s worst environmental disasters, has died. He was 75.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: After a summer full of breaks, the late-night hosts returned just in time to talk about the documents the F.B.I. found at Mar-a-Lago. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: After a summer full of breaks, the late-night hosts returned just in time to talk about the documents the F.B.I. found at Mar-a-Lago. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Balmoral, a Cherished Royal Getaway in Scotland, Becomes a Place of Pilgrimage
abstract: ‘If she had to go, this was the place,’ one visitor said. ‘She loved it.’
lead_paragraph: BALMORAL CASTLE, Scotland — By 7:30 on Wednesday morning, the flowers already lined the walls outside Balmoral Castle, the beautiful and remote Scottish country estate much loved by Queen Elizabeth II, and where her life and seven-decade reign ended on Thursday.

headline: This Fish Has a Smart Shortcut
abstract: Kay Chun uses peanut butter to create a simple, savory glaze.
lead_paragraph: Hello, everyone. I missed writing to you when I was out on my summer vacation, though I didn't miss trying to come up with different ways to say “delicious.” (“Toothsome!”)

headline: Wonking Out: The Mysteries of the Almighty Dollar
abstract: Why is our currency so often the rest of the world’s problem?
lead_paragraph: In 1971, John Connally, Richard Nixon’s Treasury secretary, told his counterparts from other major economies that “the dollar is our currency, but it’s your problem.” The context — the lingering demise of the Bretton Woods currency system — is ancient history. But his statement, remarkably, still rings true after all these years.

headline: Mr. Mayor, Who Are You Wearing?
abstract: “I love clothing,” said Eric Adams, kicking off New York Fashion Week with a cocktail party — alongside Anna Wintour, his “angel that wears Prada.”
lead_paragraph: The mayor of New York City is not a labels guy.

headline: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
abstract: Changing minds can be powerful, but history shows that changing societies takes more.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There is a certain story about women’s progress that goes something like this: For too long, women have been held back by the personal prejudices of misguided individuals, and by society’s failure to imagine their potential for dazzling achievement. But if one extraordinary woman could cut her way through, proving the doubters wrong, others would be able to follow in her footsteps. And if women can lead, equality will follow.

headline: ‘American Gigolo’ Review: Can You Take the Escort Out of the ’80s?
abstract: A Showtime series remakes an era-defining film for the current age of victimization.
lead_paragraph: Whatever else you thought of Paul Schrader’s 1980 Southern California noir, “American Gigolo,” you couldn’t deny that it nailed its post-disco, pre-Reagan moment: the blurry, enervated style, like a music video on quaaludes; the tragic-young-man story of a high-class hooker brought low by his hubris and refusal to play by the rules; the clinical fascination with the luxury goods he used to armor himself. (And the casting of those ultimate luxury goods Richard Gere and Lauren Hutton.)

headline: When Crisis Is a Constant
abstract: Change at Chelsea. A loss at Liverpool. Chaos is part and parcel of the Premier League story line. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea managed to cycle through it all in nine hours, give or take. First, bright and early on Wednesday, came the announcement that the club’s owners had decided to dispense with the services of Manager Thomas Tuchel, after a reign encompassing a mere 19 months and one measly Champions League title.

headline: Tina Ramirez, Founder of a Leading Hispanic Dance Troupe, Dies at 92
abstract: Her company, Ballet Hispánico, performed for audiences across the United States and beyond. It also trained countless dancers.

headline: Hochul Declares Polio State of Emergency for New York
abstract: The virus has now been detected in a Nassau County wastewater sample, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York declared a state of emergency on Friday over the growing polio outbreak, in an effort to better equip health care providers with tools to curb the spread of the sometimes disabling virus before it takes further hold in the state.

headline: M.L.B. Bans the Shift and Adds a Pitch Clock for 2023
abstract: The league’s competition committee chose to take immediate action on the issues despite the players voting against the changes.
lead_paragraph: Radical defensive shifts are headed the way of flannel uniforms, train travel and organ music as Major League Baseball, a sport searching for its identity, moved Friday to institute some significant rules changes for 2023.

headline: Here is the transcript of King Charles III’s inaugural address.
abstract: King Charles III honored his mother in his first speech to the nation as sovereign.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III delivered his first address as sovereign Friday, after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as released by the palace.

headline: Love Letter: Yes, I’m Intense
abstract: After a deep depression, a woman embraces her emotions.
lead_paragraph: “For a long time, I focused on what the intensity of my emotions has taken from me. But my feelings also have given me the ability to imagine vivid possibilities.”

headline: Buy American? It Gets Complicated.
abstract: Consider the pros and cons of the Jones Act.
lead_paragraph: For all their differences, President Joe Biden resembles former President Donald Trump in one way: Both are huge believers in the “Buy American” cause. Just five days after his inauguration, Biden issued an executive order toughening requirements for the federal government to purchase from domestic sources where possible. A White House document said this would “ensure that our future is made in all of America by all of America’s workers.”

headline: The U.S. Must Invest in the People Who Care for Children’s Mental Health
abstract: Ways to make the work more sustainable for new and experienced therapists.
lead_paragraph: My stomach lurched when I answered the phone at my therapy practice. On the line was the latest worried and exasperated parent hoping to schedule a psychotherapy appointment with me for a child or teenager. I’m one of the few child and adolescent therapists in my area, and I dreaded telling this mother that my schedule is full. I listened to her, provided a couple of referrals and suggested some self-help or online resources the family can use while they wait for a therapy opening with someone else.

headline: Inside Trondheim, One of Europe’s Northernmost Creative Hubs
abstract: From Michelin chefs to fashion plates, the Nordic city comes into its own.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: B.Y.U. Says It Found No Evidence of Racial Slurs at Volleyball Match
abstract: The school apologized to a spectator it had banned from its sporting events and said it could not corroborate a Duke player’s accusations of racial heckling. Duke said it stood by its players, “especially when their character is called into question.”
lead_paragraph: Brigham Young University said Friday that it had completed its investigation into accusations of racial heckling and slurs at a volleyball match against Duke University last month and found no evidence to confirm that the behavior took place.

headline: A Great Podcast, a Worthy Memoir and a Curdled Take on Clarence Thomas
abstract: A fall syllabus.
lead_paragraph: I spent the summer away from New York City and this week am back into the swing of my real life. Already, I’ve been gobsmacked by things relating to the three topics I cover here the most.

headline: In New Hampshire, a MAGA Rivalry Is Splitting House Republicans
abstract: Two young conservatives are battling for the mantle of Trumpism in a congressional primary in a competitive district in New Hampshire that could help decide the House majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He calls her “fake MAGA Karoline” from “the swamp.” She calls him a “Fauci foot soldier” and a “pharma bro.”

headline: In Ohio, Biden Says Democrats Have Started a Manufacturing Revival
abstract: President Biden attended the groundbreaking for an Intel computer chip factory in a heavily Republican part of Ohio, an effort to focus voter attention on parts of the economy that are improving.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden attended the groundbreaking for a $20 billion computer chip factory on Friday in a heavily Republican part of Ohio, testing the power of his election-year message that Democrats have helped start a manufacturing revival with record amounts of government spending.

headline: Galileo Forgery’s Trail Leads to Web of Mistresses and Manuscripts
abstract: The unmasking of a fake Galileo manuscript this summer brought renewed attention to a colorful, prolific early-20th-century forger named Tobia Nicotra.
lead_paragraph: When the University of Michigan Library announced last month that one of its most prized possessions, a manuscript said to have been written by Galileo around 1610, was in fact a 20th-century fake, it brought renewed attention to the checkered, colorful career of the man named as the likely culprit: Tobia Nicotra, a notorious forger from Milan.

headline: Credit Card Sales at Gun Stores Would Be Flagged Under New Code
abstract: The move was approved by a group that sets standards for business transactions, but it was unclear how companies and banks would carry it out.
lead_paragraph: An organization that sets standards for business transactions has voted to create a special code for gun stores to use when processing credit and debit card transactions, a move long sought by gun safety advocates who say it will help law enforcement officials spot suspicious purchases.

headline: Why King Charles’s profile may face left on British coins, and why it matters.
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II faced right on British coins. Her son and successor might face the other way.
lead_paragraph: There are 29 billion British coins in circulation with Queen Elizabeth II’s face on them. Since she first appeared on the coins, a year after her ascension in 1952, the Royal Mint has used five different portraits. And on all of them, she faces to the right.

headline: Biden Administration Outlines Scope of Asian Economic Pact
abstract: Officials from 14 countries met in Los Angeles this week to discuss a potential economic agreement covering digital trade, secure supply chains, decarbonization and other issues.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday concluded its first round of in-person negotiations for a proposed trade pact with more than a dozen Asian nations, the initial steps toward an agreement that officials said would reassert American influence in the Pacific and counter China’s dominance of the region.

headline: The Royal Grief You Will Not See
abstract: To mourn in public is to feel judged but supported, too.
lead_paragraph: Death holds up a mirror to everything — moments of love, stretches of strife, memories that punish and exalt. This is true if your family is far removed from the public eye, and it’s true if your family is ensconced in the world’s spotlight.

headline: Thomas Carney, Crusty Bartender at Elaine’s, Dies at 82
abstract: Cracking wise, keeping tabs and keeping order, the head barman of New York’s famous saloon was a supporting character in one of the city’s longest-running shows.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Carney, who served stiff drinks, hard-boiled humor and rough justice for three decades as the bartender in chief of Elaine’s, a saloon that furnished an improbable gathering place for New York’s writers, actors, athletes, models, power brokers, journalists, police officers, gangsters, playboys, go-getters and countless wannabes, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Palm City, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Charles, in First Speech as King, Pledges a Reign of Service to Britain
abstract: On a day of mourning in Britain after the death of Queen Elizabeth, Charles’s ascent to the throne was a symbol of the continuity of the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Swiftly taking on the mantle of Britain’s monarch, King Charles III returned to London from Scotland on Friday, a day after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, to pledge that he would serve the British people “with loyalty, respect and love, as I have throughout my life.”

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Understood the Weight of the Crown
abstract: Without the queen, how will anyone know how to be British anymore?
lead_paragraph: She died in her happy place. It was a photograph of herself and Prince Philip at Balmoral, wrapped in a tartan picnic blanket beside the hills of her beloved Loch Muick, that she chose to release on the eve of his funeral last year. Balmoral is where it is said he proposed to her and where, throughout her life, she spent contented summer months unassailed, except by her own family.

headline: Ukraine Claims Major Gains in Kharkiv
abstract: A rapid advance by Ukrainian troops appears to have caught Russian forces by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: ‘Burbank’ Review: When Disney’s Animators Went on Strike
abstract: Cameron Darwin Bossert’s smart new play fictionalizes a 1941 labor dispute to explore the tension between passions and paychecks.
lead_paragraph: On the lawn outside Walt Disney’s snazzy new animation studio in Burbank, Calif., a young woman is out cold. The apple that was going to be her meager lunch has slipped from her grasp and rolled away.

headline: Russia Holds First Elections Since Ukraine Invasion, but Opposition Is Mostly Absent
abstract: Voters are choosing local and regional governments, but the ranks of opposition candidates have been severely depleted by jail and exile.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russians began voting on Friday in the first nationwide elections since the invasion of Ukraine in a climate of wartime censorship and repression, with the Kremlin trying to assure the public that it was business as usual.

headline: People Are Weight Training Barefoot. Is There Any Upside?
abstract: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, Claire Haeuptle, a physical therapist based in San Diego, was interested in strengthening the muscles and ligaments of her feet. Dr. Haeuptle, who played four years of collegiate basketball, has a history of knee injuries, including five surgeries.

headline: William and Catherine are now Prince and Princess of Wales.
abstract: In a palace statement, they indicated they would honor William’s late mother while still forging their own path.
lead_paragraph: The titles King Charles III granted Friday upon his oldest son, William, and William’s wife, Catherine, bridged two distinct eras of the royal family.

headline: Ukraine Attacks Russia Along Northern Front, Swiftly Making Gains
abstract: Sweeping south from positions in the Kharkiv region in Ukraine’s northeast, Ukrainian forces have made their largest gains since routing Russia from Kyiv in April.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces have scored the most significant battlefield gains since they routed Russia from the area around Kyiv in April by reclaiming territory in the northeast, according to Ukrainian officials, Western analysts and battlefield imagery.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Lars Vogt, Acclaimed Pianist and Conductor, Is Dead at 51
abstract: Piano technique for Mr. Vogt was a means to expression, not an end in itself. He avoided repertoire that called for mere virtuosity.
lead_paragraph: Lars Vogt, a sensitive, communicative pianist whose warmth as a collaborator made him an outstanding chamber musician and a conductor of growing stature, died on Monday at a clinic in Erlangen, Germany. He was 51.

headline: Sheila Tobias, Who Defined ‘Math Anxiety,’ Dies at 86
abstract: Feeling jittery about math — and altogether avoiding it — “is a serious handicap” that often affected women, she wrote in Ms. magazine in 1976, followed by a book on the subject.
lead_paragraph: When Sheila Tobias finished her freshman year at Radcliffe College in 1954, her professor in a natural sciences course congratulated her on her performance. But for many years she was troubled that he had not encouraged her to take more science classes. When she finally asked him, he said that her limited science background had already made her ineligible for a science career.

headline: The American Guided Rockets Helping Ukraine Destroy Russian Forces
abstract: The Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System can hit targets 50 miles away with 200 pounds of explosives.
lead_paragraph: Out of the billions of dollars in weapons the White House has shipped to Ukraine since the Russian invasion, perhaps none have attracted as much attention as the M142 HIMARS, an advanced rocket launcher that Ukrainian troops have used to devastating effect.

headline: Navy Orders High-Level Outside Investigation of SEAL Course
abstract: The punishing selection course for the Navy’s most elite force has come under new scrutiny after a sailor’s death exposed illicit drug use and other problems.
lead_paragraph: The Navy has started an independent investigation of the brutal selection course for its elite SEALs after a sailor’s death this year revealed a tangle of physical abuse, poor medical oversight and use of performance-enhancing drugs in the course.

headline: Marc Lewitinn, Covid Patient, Dies at 76 After 850 Days on a Ventilator
abstract: While no definitive statistics exist, doctors say Mr. Lewitinn, a retired Manhattan store owner, likely remained on the device longer than any other Covid patient.
lead_paragraph: As the Covid-19 pandemic swept across the country in March 2020, the family of Marc Lewitinn, their 74-year-old patriarch, urged him to stay indoors. He had survived lung cancer and a stroke that left him unable to speak, and doctors were already warning that older people with his sort of medical history were especially vulnerable to the virus.

headline: First Kansas, Next Michigan and Beyond as Abortion Ballot Measures Spread
abstract: Democrats are hoping ballot measures on abortion rights will drive up voter turnout. They’re looking to Michigan as a test run.
lead_paragraph: The inclusion of an abortion-rights referendum on Michigan’s November ballot has given Democrats hope for a wave of enthusiastic voter turnout on Election Day as the movement to allow voters to decide the issue directly sweeps outward from the first state that did so, Kansas.

headline: Two Top Trump Political Aides Among Those Subpoenaed in Jan. 6 Case
abstract: Stephen Miller, a senior policy adviser, and Brian Jack, who served as White House political director, are among those who received requests for information this week from a federal grand jury.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has subpoenaed two former top White House political advisers under President Donald J. Trump as part of a widening investigation related to Mr. Trump’s post-election fund-raising and plans for so-called fake electors, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Mentors Named for Next Class in Rolex Arts Initiative
abstract: El Anatsui, Bernardine Evaristo and Dianne Reeves are among those pairing up for the program.
lead_paragraph: The Ghanaian-born visual artist El Anatsui, the British writer Bernardine Evaristo, the Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhangke, the French architect Anne Lacaton and the American jazz singer Dianne Reeves are the new mentors in the Rolex Mentor and Protégé Arts Initiative, a program started by Rolex in 2002 to foster new generations of outstanding talent.

headline: Californians Unsure if Tropical Storm Will Be Friend or Foe
abstract: After enduring a historic heat wave and deadly wildfires, the rare storm could bring welcome relief — unless it causes floods or mudslides.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a week of record-shattering heat and explosive wildfires, weary Californians were buffeted on Friday by Tropical Storm Kay, which delivered both the possibility of destruction and the promise of sweet relief.

headline: M.L.B. Will Voluntarily Recognize Minor League Union
abstract: The statement from Commissioner Rob Manfred indicated that the process of having minor leaguers represented by the M.L.B.P.A. would be fast tracked.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball will voluntarily recognize the M.L.B. Players Association as the formal union representative of minor league players, Commissioner Rob Manfred said on Friday. At a news conference regarding upcoming on-field rules changes in the major leagues, Manfred announced the notable development in the rapidly progressing unionization efforts by minor league players.

headline: Yeshiva University Can Bar L.G.B.T. Club for Now, Justice Rules
abstract: Sonia Sotomayor’s ruling will be in place pending a decision by the Supreme Court to take up the case.
lead_paragraph: Justice Sonia Sotomayor said on Friday that Yeshiva University in Manhattan can for now disregard a state court ruling that ordered it to recognize an L.G.B.T. student club — a case she said could be considered by the full Supreme Court.

headline: To Play an Anti-Gay Parent, Gabrielle Union Dug Deep for ‘The Inspection’
abstract: At the Toronto premiere, she spoke of playing a homophobic mother as “the challenge of a lifetime” because it represents everything she stands against in reality.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 30 years of working in Hollywood, Gabrielle Union is used to facing slings and arrows. Still, when she opens up Twitter and sees people attacking her trans daughter, Zaya Wade, it hits differently.

headline: Writer’s Block?
abstract: Kameron Austin Collins gets us all unstuck.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Something neat about this solve today: If you felt at all cocky about getting through a Saturday grid from Kameron Austin Collins without feeling as if you just scaled the world’s third- or fourth-tallest mountain, that might be because this construction has been laid on its side: Its Across entries are distinctly shorter and more doable than its downs.

headline: Justice Dept. and Trump Legal Team Clash Over Special Master Candidates
abstract: The two sides had sharply diverging views of who could serve as a special master and what that person would do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department and lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump failed to agree on Friday on who could serve as an independent arbiter to sift through documents the F.B.I. seized from Mr. Trump’s Florida club and residence last month.

headline: What makes Casper Ruud a worthy opponent in the final.
abstract: Ruud, the No. 5 seed, has already played in one Grand Slam final this year.
lead_paragraph: In the men’s final of the U.S. Open, Casper Ruud will put up a fight.

headline: Carlos Alcaraz Outlasts Frances Tiafoe to Reach the U.S. Open Final
abstract: The 19-year-old from Spain ended the talented American’s deep run in New York in five sets and will play Casper Ruud of Norway for the men’s singles title.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every year now, it seems, the U.S. Open becomes a life-changing event.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 10, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about King Charles III’s elevation to the throne upon the death of Queen Elizabeth II misstated the age of Camilla, the queen consort. She is 75, not 74.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Heating Aid For the Poor Will Be Less
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Sept. 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I pray — a lot. Because some things and situations are just beyond your control.”

headline: Ons Jabeur and Iga Swiatek Face Mental Test in U.S. Open Final
abstract: Swiatek will look to affirm her place as the top-ranked player, while Jabeur could become the first African woman to win the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the two women’s finalists in the U.S. Open, it can be easy to forget that tennis is a sport that involves strength, speed, athletic skill and some strategy.

headline: W.N.B.A. Finals Preview: The Aces and Sun Fight for Their First Title
abstract: Stars from both teams have been to the finals recently, but neither franchise has ever won a championship. A’ja Wilson of Las Vegas said the “vibe” is different this time.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three years ago, Becky Hammon and Curt Miller helped lead Colorado State to the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. Division 1 women’s basketball tournament. Miller was an assistant coach, and Hammon was one of the best players in the country. On Sunday, they’ll match up in the W.N.B.A. finals as opposing coaches, hoping to win their first titles as Hammon’s Las Vegas Aces take on Miller’s Connecticut Sun.

headline: For Ukraine, the Fight Is Often a Game of Bridges
abstract: The southern counteroffensive has been a painstaking battle of river crossings, with pontoon bridges as prime targets for both sides. But so far, it is Ukraine that has advanced.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON REGION, Ukraine — The pontoon bridge had been in place for barely a day. The Ukrainian Army rushed to move troops and equipment across. Then the soldiers watched on a drone video feed as the Russians blew up their bridge, yet again.

headline: For Florida A&M, Getting on the Field Is Just One of Many Problems
abstract: The university’s football players nearly skipped their opening game in protest of their mismanaged athletic department. Recent history shows far more dysfunction within the university’s sports program.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Here’s what comes with being a football player at Florida A&M: getting booted from the dorms during training camp and sleeping in your car. Bad or uncertain advice from an overwhelmed staff about what classes to sign up for. Monthslong waits for the scholarship check that covers your meals and rent.

headline: How a Marathon Win 50 Years Ago Kick-Started the ‘Running Boom’
abstract: Frank Shorter couldn’t have imagined the impact his 1972 Olympic marathon victory would have on the sport. “I was just a piece in the puzzle,” he said.
lead_paragraph: For people who favor clean and simple marks for the start of something new, America’s “running boom” began 50 years ago today, on Sept. 10, 1972, when Frank Shorter, a Yale graduate and law student at the University of Florida, won the marathon at the Munich Olympics.

headline: Mosquito Fire near Sacramento is at a ‘tipping point,’ fire officials say.
abstract: Firefighters said that conditions had improved and there was an opportunity to get control of the explosive blaze.
lead_paragraph: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — The Mosquito fire, a 30,000-acre blaze raging through the Sierra Nevada foothills northeast of Sacramento, has calmed slightly Friday after explosive growth a day earlier, fire officials said.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Clover Lawns Are Blooming in Front Yards, and on TikTok
abstract: Amid droughts and extreme heat, people are welcoming clover into their lawns, an alternative to the purely grass lawn, helping them save water and money.
lead_paragraph: Edwina von Gal thinks that grass lawns can become like cigarettes: something that was once in vogue and backed by a massive industry that can be rebranded as an unhealthy and costly symbol of American corporatism.

headline: Looking for More Frances Tiafoes
abstract: Frances Tiafoe’s rise to the top echelon of tennis is an inspiration, but tennis officials are trying to build a U.S. system that relies less on kismet to produce a Black champion.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to quantify how many young Black girls have signed up for tennis lessons since the late 1990s when Serena and Venus Williams burst onto the scene under the guidance of their father, Richard Williams, or how many parents of athletic Black girls living in America, tried to follow his blueprint and repeat the Williams’s success.

headline: Guaranteed Income Programs Spread, City by City
abstract: Since 2020, four dozen pilot programs have started, with Los Angeles running one of the largest to provide cash assistance.
lead_paragraph: Early in the pandemic, Alondra Barajas had a temporary job for the Census Bureau, doing phone work from the two-bedroom apartment she shared with her mother and four younger siblings. When that job ended in late 2020, she struggled to find employment.

headline: These maps show how Ukraine is rapidly advancing around Izium.
abstract: Ukraine’s military made significant advances in recent days near the northeastern city of Izium, a key Russian stronghold, according to military analysts and geolocated photos and videos. The breakthrough — possibly some 50 kilometers in just a few days — threatened to encircle Russian forces, which appeared to be caught by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military made significant advances in recent days near the northeastern city of Izium, a key Russian stronghold, according to military analysts and geolocated photos and videos. The breakthrough — possibly some 50 kilometers in just a few days — threatened to encircle Russian forces, which appeared to be caught by surprise.

headline: ‘Do No Harm’: OB-GYNs Weigh the Legal Impact of Abortion Bans
abstract: As anti-abortion laws take effect across the country, doctors treating patients with high-risk pregnancies are facing difficult decisions — and legal risks — over their standards of care.
lead_paragraph: As anti-abortion laws take effect across the country, doctors treating patients with high-risk pregnancies are facing difficult decisions — and legal risks — over their standards of care.

headline: How Do I Make My Landlord Improve Fire Safety?
abstract: In a building evacuation, the stairs are a resident’s lifeline. New York is specific with its rules about their placement, dimensions and lighting.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am concerned about evacuation safety in my 14-story Midtown rental building. The building has two passenger elevators and one service elevator. Recently, staff began locking the service elevator at night, leaving two working elevators for about 150 apartments. I worry that we we’ll need all the elevators in an emergency evacuation, because the stairwells are not a reliable alternative for older residents — they’re often dark because the light bulbs burn out, and the treads are narrow and slippery from high-gloss paint. Does management have a responsibility to keep our means of egress safe and navigable, and to keep all our elevators working regularly?

headline: A Global History of Gender, in All Its Varieties
abstract: Kit Heyam’s “Before We Were Trans” spans continents and millenniums to prove that where there is humanity, there is nonconformity.
lead_paragraph: In “Before We Were Trans,” the nonbinary British academic Kit Heyam undertakes an inherently impossible task: to encompass the story of a planet in a single book. But this impossibility proves the value of the effort: As they demonstrate in this astute, self-aware and riveting study, the history of gender nonconformity around the world is so vast that no book can begin to contain its reaches.

headline: The Broncos Will Be Good Because Russell Wilson Said So
abstract: With a picture-perfect family, a Super Bowl-caliber team and Michael Jordan’s trainer at his side, the star quarterback is back to spreading football intensity — with a smile.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Russell Wilson does not believe in balance. That word suggests that he in any way conserves energy, parceling it out among football and family, his fans and his business ventures, instead of investing every neuron of his being into whatever he is doing in the moment.

headline: 6 Y.A. Love Stories to Add to Your Reading List
abstract: Nicola Yoon, the author of “Everything, Everything,” “The Sun Is Also a Star” and “Instructions for Dancing,” recommends a few of her favorite Y.A. love stories.
lead_paragraph: My favorite love stories are philosophical talkies. The ones where the characters are witty, opinionated and deeply curious about the world around them. These characters don’t so much fall in love but rather open themselves to love and to the possibility that the world is wilder, bigger and different than they’d previously known.

headline: How the CUNY Chancellor Spends His Sundays
abstract: An avid city cyclist, Félix V. Matos Rodríguez also manages to fit in some work, a lunch outing, a movie and a call to his mother.
lead_paragraph: Félix Matos Rodríguez oversees the largest urban public university system in the United States.

headline: Medical Impact of Roe Reversal Goes Well Beyond Abortion Clinics, Doctors Say
abstract: State abortion bans carry narrow but sometimes vague exceptions, and years of prison time. That’s forcing doctors to think like lawyers, and hospitals to create new protocols.
lead_paragraph: In Wisconsin, a group of doctors and lawyers is trying to come up with guidelines on how to comply with a newly revived 173-year-old law that prohibits abortion except to save the life of a pregnant woman. They face the daunting task of defining all the emergencies and conditions that might result in a pregnant woman’s death, and the fact that doctors could be punished with six years in prison if a prosecutor disagrees that abortion was necessary.

headline: The Olive Oil Capital of the World, Parched
abstract: Spain’s Jaén Province, home to one fifth of the world’s supply of “green gold,” copes with climate change and threats to its way of life.
lead_paragraph: The branch, plucked from one of thousands of trees in this densely packed olive grove, has browning leaves and a few tiny, desiccated buds that are bunched near the end. To Agustín Bautista, the branch tells a story and the story is about a harvest that is doomed.

headline: With Tears and Steel, Kenya’s ‘Hustler’ President Vanquishes His Foes
abstract: William Ruto built a career on beating the odds. In his greatest triumph, he is expected to be inaugurated as Kenya’s fifth president on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — William Ruto wept when he won, falling to his knees in prayer after Kenya’s Supreme Court confirmed his presidential win last week, the climax of a bruising courtroom battle over the results of a hard-fought election.

headline: The Wedding Photographer Favored by High Society and Fashion Royalty
abstract: At rarefied weddings, including those of British Vogue’s top editor, Princess Diana’s niece and Paris Hilton, German Larkin has become a fixture.
lead_paragraph: German Larkin had never photographed a wedding when he booked his first job, at the Palace of Versailles in May 2017.

headline: Jann Wenner Wants to Reveal It All
abstract: The Rolling Stone founder talks about LSD, not reading the magazine anymore and how the Stones now look like “Lord of the Rings” characters onstage.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — Rock may be dead, but Jann Wenner is still rolling.

headline: A Proud Nuclear Town Grapples With How to Remember the Bomb
abstract: The A high school in Richland, Wash., is emblazoned with a mushroom cloud. But some are asking for better ways to recognize the city’s history-altering past.
lead_paragraph: RICHLAND, Wash. — In the arid shrublands of southeastern Washington state, a small agricultural outpost underwent a covert transformation during World War II. Thousands of workers converged next to the Columbia River, rushing to produce the material needed for the ultimate weapon.

headline: In an ancient ceremony with a modern twist, King Charles III is formally proclaimed sovereign.
abstract: While Charles became the new monarch automatically upon the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on Thursday, his new role was officially proclaimed on Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For more than 300 years, Britain’s kings and queens have been proclaimed sovereign in a ceremony laced with history. But on Saturday morning, for the first time, the public was able to see the process in action as the proclamation of King Charles III was broadcast live, weaving just a bit of modernity into a centuries-old tradition.

headline: Hong Kong Sentences 5 to 19 Months for Children’s Books Deemed ‘Seditious’
abstract: Tales about a sheep village resisting a wolf pack prompted the charges against leaders of a speech therapists’ union, extending a government crackdown on dissent.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Five speech therapists in Hong Kong were sentenced to 19 months in prison on Saturday after they published a series of children’s books that the court said instilled a hatred of the government in young readers.

headline: A Time of Horror in a Place of Family and Beauty
abstract: The mass murder in the James Smith Cree Nation is not the first killing that many members of the community link to crystal meth.
lead_paragraph: Only 48 hours or so had passed since two brothers had gone on a stabbing rampage, mostly on the James Smith Cree Nation in Saskatchewan, that had left 10 people dead and 18 injured and resulted in the end of both men’s lives. But when Amber Bracken, a photographer from Edmonton on assignment for The Times, and I pulled into a horse ranch on the reserve for an arranged meeting with Ivor Wayne Burns and his family, one of the brothers was still alive — and we were met with unexpected chaos.

headline: Read King Charles III’s declaration to the Accession Council.
abstract: In the address, the king mourned the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, and said, “I am deeply aware of this great inheritance and of the duties and heavy responsibilities of sovereignty which have now passed to me.”
lead_paragraph: After he was officially proclaimed Britain’s new sovereign on Saturday, King Charles III delivered a declaration to the Accession Council.

headline: TV’s Prequel-Mania
abstract: This fall, if you feel like you’ve seen that new series somewhere before, you’re probably right.
lead_paragraph: “The past is with us all, whether we like it or not.” So says Arondir (Ismael Cruz Córdova), an elf soldier in Amazon Prime Video’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.”

headline: What John Donne Knew About Death Can Teach Us a Lot About Life
abstract: He thought humans a disaster, the most spectacular disaster there has ever been.
lead_paragraph: The power of John Donne’s words nearly killed a man.

headline: Strong Women, Madwomen, Mob Women
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Redefining What Nerd Culture Looks Like
abstract: Dragon Con has transformed from a niche science fiction convention into a diverse celebration of fandom.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Wall Street’s Favorite Sport Is a Failing Business
abstract: Tennis may appear to be on a roll, with exciting young players and record ratings. But if it were a company, activist shareholders would have already called for a restructuring.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: After Decades of Silence, Art About Abortion (Cautiously) Enters the Establishment
abstract: An art taboo is falling, from the Whitney Museum to the Armory Show to blue-chip galleries. Yet artists acknowledge self-censorship on the topic.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, a fashion for painting the human figure has preoccupied the art world, with an emphasis on race, gender and other urgent social issues. Yet another pressing topic in America has been curiously absent from art: abortion, which became all the more timely when the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.

headline: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
abstract: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.
lead_paragraph: For the next few months, we’re sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcast’s archives. This week’s segments first appeared in 2010 and 2020, respectively.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Sept. 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Charles in Charge
abstract: No more women reign over the new king.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His whole life, King Charles has been in the shadow of women with more star power.

headline: ‘Glorious’ Hero or ‘Deplorable’ Traitor? Pétain’s Legacy Haunts French Island
abstract: Philippe Pétain, who led France to victory in World War I and then collaborated with the Nazis, is buried on a small island, where his grave is the site of bitter debates over his legacy.
lead_paragraph: ÎLE D’YEU, France — On a recent afternoon, three French friends, still groggy from a long night of partying on a tiny island south of Brittany, stopped by a cemetery to snap a photograph of a grave they had heard so much about.

headline: Gun Violence Epidemic Looms Large Over a Swedish Election
abstract: The far right has made strides by tying the longstanding issue of crime to immigration, while Sweden’s center-left party is blaming failed integration, resulting in an exceptionally tight race.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — The best years were still ahead for Susanna Yakes and her 12-year-old daughter, Adriana. The two danced to music around the house and screamed together on roller coasters — still ahead were more adult milestones like travel and love.

headline: For Trump’s Lawyers, Legal Exposure Comes With the Job
abstract: The many lawyers who have helped the former president avoid removal from office and indictment have drawn legal problems of their own.
lead_paragraph: A dark joke has begun circulating among lawyers following the many legal travails of former President Donald J. Trump: MAGA actually stands for “making attorneys get attorneys.”

headline: Mourners leave sunflowers outside Windsor Castle in tribute to the queen.
abstract: “She was a ray of sunshine to so many people,” said Natalie Prince, a Windsor florist who said she had sold 8,000 sunflowers on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, England — Thousands of people paid their respects to Queen Elizabeth II outside Windsor Castle on Saturday, placing bouquets of flowers, many of them sunflowers, at the gates to the castle where the queen had spent much of her time.

headline: Marsha Hunt, Actress Turned Activist, Is Dead at 104
abstract: She seemed well on her way to stardom until her career was derailed by the Hollywood blacklist. She then turned her attention to social causes.
lead_paragraph: Marsha Hunt, who appeared in more than 50 movies between 1935 and 1949 and seemed well on her way to stardom until her career was damaged by the Hollywood blacklist, and who, for the rest of her career, was as much an activist as she was an actress, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 104.

headline: Queen’s Death Leaves U.K. Grappling With Its Sense of National Identity
abstract: A figure who embodied Britain, Elizabeth cast long shadow. She leaves behind a country unsettled by domestic crises and anxiety over its place in the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — No sooner had the long-anticipated news broken — Queen Elizabeth II was dead — than Britain activated Operation London Bridge, the painstakingly choreographed funeral plan that guides the country through the rituals of tribute and mourning that culminate with her burial 10 days later.

headline: Want to Regain Parents’ Trust, Public Health Institutions? Be Humble.
abstract: Definitive statements on open questions isn’t the way.
lead_paragraph: This week, my colleague Dana Goldstein reported that Head Start preschools and child care centers are still requiring teachers and children as young as 2 to wear masks. As she explains, this is out of sync with the latest guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “The vast majority of schools and day care centers have made masks optional, even in the most virus-cautious regions of the country,” Goldstein writes.

headline: Censorship Is the Refuge of the Weak
abstract: Republicans across the country are trying to use the power of the state to restrict speech.
lead_paragraph: Fights about free speech can feel rhetorical until they are not. Here’s what censorship looks like in practice: A student newspaper and journalism program in Nebraska shuttered for writing about pride month. The state of Oklahoma seeking to revoke the teaching certificate of an English teacher who shared a QR code that directed students to the Brooklyn Public Library’s online collection of banned books. A newly elected district attorney in Tennessee musing openly about jailing teachers and librarians.

headline: Rudy Giuliani Is Alone
abstract: 9/11 was his triumph, then it became his undoing.
lead_paragraph: It has been 21 years since Rudy Giuliani led a terrified city through the deadliest attack in its history. As a reporter covering him from a few feet away that morning, I ran with him from the hurricane of ash and debris following the collapse of the World Trade Center’s North Tower, trekked a mile up a Manhattan avenue as he and his aides searched for safe harbor and watched his security detail break into a firehouse with a crowbar.

headline: Linda Evangelista, the It Bag and ‘Sex and the City’
abstract: Fashion week kicked off with a bang at the Hammerstein Ballroom, where Fendi celebrated 25 years of the Baguette bag (with the help of Marc Jacobs).
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week began in earnest with a time-space collapse Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom in midtown Manhattan.

headline: Democrats Didn’t Conjure Up the Demand for MAGA Candidates
abstract: The Republican base has shown us what it wants, repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I tackled some of the major objections to President Biden’s Philadelphia speech on MAGA Republicans and the threat they pose to democracy, including the view that it was too divisive.

headline: Teenagers Are in Distress. Which Treatments Are Best?
abstract: Readers discuss an article about a girl who was prescribed 10 medications in high school.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Queen Elizabeth’s funeral will be held on Sept. 19 at Westminster Abbey.
abstract: On Sunday, Elizabeth’s coffin will be carried from Balmoral Castle, in the Scottish Highlands, on a roundabout six-hour journey to Edinburgh, via Aberdeen.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will be held at 11 a.m. Monday, Sept. 19, at Westminster Abbey, Buckingham Palace announced on Saturday. The queen, who died on Thursday at Balmoral Castle, her summer retreat in the Scottish Highlands, now lies in the castle’s ballroom, her oak coffin draped in the royal standard of Scotland, officials said in a briefing about the funeral arrangements.

headline: Does Casper Ruud Stand a Chance Against the Tireless Carlos Alcaraz?
abstract: Sunday’s match is not only a battle for the U.S. Open men’s singles title. It will also determine the next world No. 1, and whoever wins will rise to the top spot for the first time.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly 2 a.m. at the U.S. Open (of course it was), and Carlos Alcaraz was cheerfully giving a news conference after his latest five-set thriller.

headline: The Joke’s on Fashion Week
abstract: Chloe Fineman, Sarah Sherman and other comedians host an unusual fashion show at the Comedy Cellar.
lead_paragraph: Is it appropriate to tell a joke about body fluids while wearing Chanel?

headline: How Ukraine Gained Momentum Against Russia and Took a Critical Hub
abstract: For months, Russia used the city of Izium as a way station to resupply and reinforce its troops in their campaign to seize the eastern Donbas region. With a northern offensive, Ukraine has retaken the city.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In a war that has for months been defined by grinding battles between two armies along largely static front lines ranging 1,500 miles, the stunning speed of Ukraine’s advance in the country’s northeast has reshaped the conflict in a matter of days.

headline: Billy McFarland Is Out of Jail and Ready for His Next Move
abstract: Five years after the Fyre Festival, the convicted fraudster is planning a comeback.
lead_paragraph: “Is this technically Dumbo?” Billy McFarland asked, walking toward the East River shoreline. “It’s super cool. Are the rents here crazy too?

headline: King Charles III Is Formally Proclaimed to His New Role
abstract: Charles will spend much of the first 10 days of his reign leading his country in mourning the queen, whose state funeral will be held on Sept. 19 in Westminster Abbey.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — While Prince Charles became Britain’s new king automatically on the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on Thursday, his role was officially proclaimed on Saturday morning in a ceremony laden with pomp and procedure at St. James’s Palace, a Tudor royal residence near Buckingham Palace.

headline: The Ukraine War’s Decisive Season
abstract: We will soon see if European resolve holds up.
lead_paragraph: The summer of war in Ukraine, while brutal for soldiers and civilians on the front lines, has been experienced from afar as a stalemate, depressing enough in its grinding sameness to slip out of American headlines for a time.

headline: As Russians Retreat, Putin Is Criticized by Hawks Who Trumpeted His War
abstract: Russian bloggers reporting from the front line provide a uniquely less-censored view of the war. But as Russia’s military flails, these once vocal supporters are exposing its flaws, lies and all.
lead_paragraph: As Russian forces hastily retreated in northeastern Ukraine on Saturday in one of their most embarrassing setbacks of the war, President Vladimir V. Putin was at a park in Moscow, presiding over the grand opening of a Ferris wheel.

headline: Cooler, Wetter Weather Brings California a Moment of Relief
abstract: Wildfires remain an issue, but the remnants of Tropical Storm Kay helped firefighters on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For more than a week, Californians endured a heat wave that smashed records, pushed the state’s energy grid to the brink and parched the landscape, creating conditions ripe for catastrophic wildfires. Several new blazes ignited and quickly burned through bone-dry vegetation, sending thousands fleeing from their homes.

headline: ‘All the Beauty and the Bloodshed’ Wins Best Film at Venice Film Festival
abstract: The director, Laura Poitras, praised Nan Goldin, the photographer and subject of her film, in her acceptance speech.
lead_paragraph: “All the Beauty and the Bloodshed,” directed by Laura Poitras, was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 79th Venice International Film Festival on Saturday by a competition jury led by Julianne Moore. The film, about the photographer Nan Goldin, was the rare documentary to win the Golden Lion and won over strong competitors.

headline: After an Arsenic Scare, City Says a Housing Complex’s Water Is Safe
abstract: A report of arsenic in the tap water at the Jacob Riis Houses in Manhattan was a false alarm, city officials said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Residents at a public housing complex in Manhattan spent a week without tap water following a report that it had elevated levels of arsenic. But on Saturday, New York City officials said that new tests confirmed that the water at the development had never been dangerous.

headline: Mosquito Fire Rages in Northern California
abstract: Firefighters said conditions had improved, and there was an opportunity to control the blaze after it had quickly spread through the Sierra Nevada foothills northeast of Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters said conditions had improved, and there was an opportunity to control the blaze after it had quickly spread through the Sierra Nevada foothills northeast of Sacramento.

headline: Sons of King Charles III Make Rare Joint Appearance Outside Windsor Castle
abstract: Prince William, Princess Catherine, Prince Harry and Meghan all visited crowds gathered to remember the queen.
lead_paragraph: The sons of King Charles III and their wives made a rare joint appearance on Saturday outside Windsor Castle, greeting crowds that had gathered to leave flowers and messages remembering Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Mable John, Soul Singer With a Star-Studded Résumé, Dies at 91
abstract: She was one of the first female acts signed to Motown, and her career later intersected with Isaac Hayes and Ray Charles. But she eventually heeded a higher calling.
lead_paragraph: Beyond her many other accomplishments — collaborating on a hit single with Isaac Hayes, singing backup for Ray Charles — Mable John earned a place in the music pantheon as one of the first female artists signed to the Motown Records empire, which altered the face of pop music in the 1960s.

headline: Harvest Moon Lights Up Skies and Marks Start of Festivals Worldwide
abstract: The harvest moon, which will appear full for about three nights from Thursday night to Sunday morning, is the full moon closest to the autumnal equinox.
lead_paragraph: If you’re someone who rejoices at every sign of fall, you may want to look out at the moon this weekend.

headline: James Stewart Polshek, Quiet Giant of Modern Architecture, Dies at 92
abstract: He took a sensitive, socially conscious approach to projects including the Clinton library and the renovated entrance to the Brooklyn Museum.
