It’s built from the earthly remains of Racines NY, a clubhouse for wine nerds that ran on Chambers Street in TriBeCa for about seven years before closing in 2021. Several faces are the same, the floor plan has barely changed and wine is still the point of the place.

headline: Bezos’ Rocket Crashes; No People Were Aboard
abstract: The capsule carrying experiments escaped damage. The F.A.A. is investigating the mishap.
lead_paragraph: An uncrewed New Shepard rocket launched by Blue Origin — the company started by Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon — malfunctioned on Monday, causing the rocket booster to crash. An emergency escape system took the capsule, which carried three dozen experiments, to safety.

headline: A Dozen Reasons to Drink Beaujolais
abstract: A number of terrific wines from the region are available now. They range from the simple thirst-quenchers of old to the surprisingly complex.
lead_paragraph: Nothing is trendy about Beaujolais. Yet for a lot of younger wine drinkers reared on a diet of either mass-market bottles or orange wines and natural wines, discovering it can be a nurturing next step.

headline: Which People Would You Like to Thank?
abstract: Many of us have received help during the pandemic. Tell us about someone you’d like to thank.
lead_paragraph: During the pandemic, many of us have faced challenges that have often felt insurmountable.

headline: There’s a New Cop on the Banking Beat: Chief Climate Risk Officer
abstract: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees big banks, hired a chemical engineer to review the risks climate change poses to banks.
lead_paragraph: The federal agency overseeing the country’s largest banks has hired its first climate cop.

headline: The Exhibit ‘Food in New York’ Comes to New York
abstract: It first opened in the Victoria & Albert Museum in London and covers issues like sustainability, labor, access to food and more.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit about New York food that first opened in the Victoria & Albert Museum in London has been transported and revised to make its debut this week at the Museum of the City of New York, a co-presenter of the show. The emphasis is on issues like sustainability, labor, access to food and the food chain and covers three major themes: production, trade and what’s on the plate. The themes are illustrated with creative works by more than 20 artists and designers. Several special programs requiring registration are also scheduled, some with a fee.

headline: Tom Colicchio’s New Pasta Sauces Look to Regional Italy
abstract: The sauce line is made in collaboration with Jersey Tomato Co. and includes options representing Piedmont, Calabria and more.
lead_paragraph: Jarred or canned tomato sauces usually stick to classic preparations like marinara and tomato-basil. The chef Tom Colicchio, a New Jersey native, has a new sauce line produced in collaboration with the Jersey Tomato Co., which uses only New Jersey tomatoes. It looks to Italy’s regions for a collection of six distinctive sauces. All with chunky textures, they represent Piedmont with rich Barolo wine and sage begging for short ribs; Sicily with white wine, orange and black olives; Calabria with eggplant, zucchini and chiles for a bit of a kick; Trentino with earthy wild mushrooms, rosemary and Parmesan; Liguria with lemon, white wine and herbs; and Abruzzo with saffron and fennel pollen. Liguria and Abruzzo are excellent with seafood.

headline: Gun Shoot Will Conclude Former Trump Aide’s House Primary Race
abstract: Karoline Leavitt, who turned her New Hampshire primary into an argument over which candidate carried the mantle of Trumpism, is closing her campaign at a fish and game club.
lead_paragraph: A heated New Hampshire primary in the state’s First Congressional District is going out with a literal bang.

headline: Get the Exact Dashi You Need in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
abstract: Dashi Okume will open on Friday and offer packaged dashi mixes as well as a counter to order personalized dashi bases.
lead_paragraph: The low-slung industrial building at 50 Norman Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, formerly housed an auto repair shop. Now a Japanese company specializing in the umami-rich broth dashi, among other things, will open a store on the premises on Friday. It will sell packaged dashi ingredient mixtures, $19 to $45 for 10, 15 or 30 bags, as well as other Japanese cooking products, and costumers will be able to order personalized dashi bases at a counter. There will also be a bar and a few tables for simple fare like grilled fish with rice. Also in the complex is Cibone, also opening Friday, a shop selling art and artisanal goods by Japanese artists; House, an eight-seat French-Japanese restaurant, will open in October.

headline: What to expect as Britain mourns the queen.
abstract: Her funeral is scheduled for Sept. 19. Before that, there are processions, vigils and four days of lying in state in London.
lead_paragraph: The queen’s funeral has been set for Sept. 19, but Britain is spending this week remembering and mourning the country’s longest reigning monarch. On Monday, the queen’s coffin was driven down the Royal Mile, a grand route through Edinburgh’s Old Town, to St. Giles Cathedral for a prayer service and vigil.

headline: Sèchey Offers Tastes of Nonalcoholic Beverages in the West Village
abstract: Emily Heintz opened the original location in Charleston. S.C., to help customers assess the options for nonalcoholic wine and more.
lead_paragraph: If picking a wine can be challenging, try the nonalcoholic versions. The usual benchmarks, like grape variety or region, are often not given or do not strongly influence the end result. Emily Heintz, a retail entrepreneur, opened Sèchey in 2021 in Charleston, S.C., a nonalcoholic beverage store with a tasting counter, to help customers assess the options. Her New York branch, a well-stocked shop with canned and bottled drinks and accessories, a couple of counters, and seating inside and out, makes its debut on Wednesday. “It’s about learning and discovery,” Ms. Heintz said of the nonalcoholic options, which she believes are steadily improving. Some samples are offered for tasting, and flights of three are $10. Eventually she hopes to hire a bartender to show how nonalcoholic spirits can be used.

headline: Add a Bit of Art to Your Breakfast Platter
abstract: The new Takashi Murakami pancake pans leave the artist’s signature flower patterns on 5-inch griddle cakes.
lead_paragraph: Decorate your breakfast plate with the results from new Takashi Murakami pancake pans bearing the artist’s signature flower patterns. The frolicking flowers decorate his artworks and many commercial products like this one. They leave their imprint on 5-inch griddle cakes; add berries and whipped cream and call it dessert. The stainless steel pans have resin handles, also decorated with flower designs.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Advance Continues
abstract: Plus former British colonies weigh their relationship with the monarchy and Lebanon faces blackouts.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine reclaimed more ground yesterday and redoubled its calls for Russia to surrender in the south. In the northeast, Moscow acknowledged the loss of almost all of the Kharkiv region. Here’s a map of Russian losses.

headline: Reversal of Fortune
abstract: A Ukrainian blitz routs Russian troops from northeast and reshapes the war.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Justice Dept. Issues 40 Subpoenas in a Week, Expanding Its Jan. 6 Inquiry
abstract: It also seized the phones of two top Trump advisers, a sign of an escalating investigation two months before the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Department officials have seized the phones of two top advisers to former President Donald J. Trump and blanketed his aides with about 40 subpoenas in a substantial escalation of the investigation into his efforts to subvert the 2020 election, people familiar with the inquiry said on Monday.

headline: Russia invaded Ukraine more than 200 days ago. Here is one key development from every month of the war.
abstract: Here is one key battlefield development from every month of the war.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces began their invasion of Ukraine more than six months ago. Since then, tens of thousands of people have been killed, millions of Ukrainians have fled and the country has sustained tens of billions of dollars worth of damage.

headline: Biden Announces His Pick to Lead New Biomedical Research Agency
abstract: President Biden said he had selected Dr. Renee Wegrzyn, a biotech executive with government experience, to be the director of a new federal agency aimed at driving biomedical innovation.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said he had selected Dr. Renee Wegrzyn, a biotech executive with government experience, to be the director of a new federal agency aimed at driving biomedical innovation.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Javier Marías, to Many the Greatest Living Spanish Novelist, Dies at 70
abstract: A regular nominee for the Nobel, his books were as popular as they were lauded, filled with themes of mystery, betrayal and the moral weight of the past.
lead_paragraph: Javier Marías, a Spanish novelist whose elegant style and intricate plots centered on espionage, murder and betrayal won him comparisons to Marcel Proust and Ian Fleming, died on Sunday at his home in Madrid. He was 70.

headline: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
abstract: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
lead_paragraph: DNIPROPETRIVSK REGION, Ukraine — After Ukraine’s stunning offensive in its northeast drove Russian forces into a chaotic retreat and reshaped the battlefield by hundreds of miles, Ukrainian leaders on Monday were weighing critical gambles that could determine the near-term course of the war.

headline: Timing Is Everything for Carlos Alcaraz
abstract: Alcaraz, the 19-year-old winner of the men’s U.S. Open, said he “worked really hard so that things like this could happen.”
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open victory party at Carlos Alcaraz’s Manhattan hotel wrapped up before 3 a.m. on Monday, which was early by his standards at this round-the-clock Grand Slam event.

headline: Strike Threat on Freight Railroads Is New Supply Chain Worry
abstract: Administration officials are pushing for a settlement to head off a walkout by tens of thousands of workers on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials are racing to prevent a strike by tens of thousands of freight railroad workers that could further disrupt an already strained supply chain and cause billions of dollars in economic damage.

headline: Emmys 2022: Red Carpet Photos From TV’s Biggest Night
abstract: A look at the big swings and major hits on the 74th Emmy Awards red carpet.
lead_paragraph: A look at the big swings and major hits on the 74th Emmy Awards red carpet.

headline: Uber Agrees to Pay N.J. $100 Million in Dispute Over Drivers’ Employment Status
abstract: New Jersey demanded back taxes from the ride-hailing company, claiming it misclassified drivers as independent contractors.
lead_paragraph: Uber has agreed to pay New Jersey $100 million in back taxes after the state said the ride-hailing company had misclassified its drivers as independent contractors.

headline: U.S. Returns Rare Coin Minted by Jews During Rebellion From Rome
abstract: The silver quarter shekel, estimated to be worth as much as $1 million, was minted in the first century by Jews who created it as a statement of sovereignty during the uprising known as The Great Revolt.
lead_paragraph: American investigators returned a rare silver coin to Israel on Monday that they say was minted as a marker of independence during the Great Revolt against Roman oppression of A.D. 66-73 and centuries later was looted from an archaeological site in the Valley of Elah.

headline: New York Lawmakers Call for More Oversight of Hasidic Schools
abstract: After a New York Times investigation found that many of the private religious schools denied students a basic education, top officials voiced serious concerns.
lead_paragraph: Top New York officials voiced grave concerns about the quality of education in Hasidic Jewish private schools on Monday, a day after The New York Times revealed that many of the schools taught only rudimentary English and math and virtually no science or history.

headline: Inside a Republican Superlawyer’s Break With Donald Trump’s G.O.P.
abstract: An exclusive excerpt from a new book by David Enrich on powerful corporate law firms and how the Trump era changed and challenged one in particular.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ginsberg’s office at the international law firm Jones Day was like a shrine to the old Republican Party.

headline: Ukraine Deflates MAGA Macho Myths
abstract: Sometimes tough guys finish last. Can the right handle it?
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 29 Tucker Carlson of Fox News attacked President Biden’s policy on Ukraine, asserting among other things: “By any actual reality-based measure, Vladimir Putin is not losing the war in Ukraine. He is winning the war in Ukraine.” Carlson went on, by the way, to assert that Biden is supporting Ukraine only because he wants to destroy the West.

headline: As Russian Losses Mount in Ukraine, So Does Criticism Back Home
abstract: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 local elected officials across Russia signed a two-sentence petition on Monday that ended with: “We demand the resignation of Vladimir Putin from the post of president of the Russian Federation!”

headline: 2 Peloton Founders Are Leaving the Company
abstract: The departures are part of an executive shake-up after the exercise equipment company announced a $1.2 billion quarterly loss last month.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of Peloton announced their resignations on Monday, part of an executive reshuffle at the maker of connected bikes and fitness equipment that was a pandemic winner but whose stock price has lost more than two-thirds of its value this year.

headline: Inside Telfar’s Rainbow Bag Drop
abstract: A pop-up event at a Rainbow store in Brooklyn drew hundreds of shoppers who lined up to buy a highly sought-after Telfar Shopping Bag.
lead_paragraph: As influencers and celebrities descend on New York City in their black cars and limousines to bask in the glamour and exclusivity of fashion week, dancers in head-to-toe Morphsuits vogued in Brooklyn on Sunday.

headline: Man Gets Life in Prison for Selling Fentanyl That Killed 11
abstract: Aaron Broussard, 31, obtained the fentanyl from suppliers based in China and conspired with them to smuggle the deadly drug into the United States, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Minnesota man was sentenced to life in prison on Monday for selling fentanyl that caused the deaths of 11 people who had bought it believing it was a less dangerous drug, the Justice Department said.

headline: Ramsey Lewis, Jazz Pianist Who Became a Pop Star, Dies at 87
abstract: His 1965 recording of “The ‘In’ Crowd” brought him to a place few jazz musicians reached in that era: the Top 10.
lead_paragraph: Ramsey Lewis, a jazz pianist who unexpectedly became a pop star when his recording of “The ‘In’ Crowd” reached the Top 10 in 1965 — and who remained musically active for more than a half century after that — died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 87.

headline: Senate to Investigate Charge That Trump Meddled in Prosecutor’s Office
abstract: The allegations of political motivation are in a new book by the former U.S. attorney in Manhattan, Geoffrey S. Berman.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee will investigate allegations that the Justice Department under President Donald J. Trump sought to use the U.S. attorney’s office in Manhattan to support Mr. Trump politically and pursue his critics, the committee’s chairman said on Monday.

headline: Sheryl Lee Ralph sings her thanks for her first Emmy.
abstract: Ralph was full of emotion as she won for best supporting actress in a comedy, for “Abbott Elementary.”
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Lee Ralph won her first Emmy on Monday night, opening her acceptance speech by belting “Endangered Species,” a song by Dianne Reeves.

headline: Justice Dept. Says It’s Open to Trump Pick for Special Master
abstract: Prosecutors said they would not object if Judge Raymond J. Dearie of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn is appointed to review the sensitive documents seized from Mar-a-Lago.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Monday that it was open to accepting one of former President Donald J. Trump’s proposed candidates for the job of an independent arbiter to review thousands of documents seized last month by the F.B.I. from Mr. Trump’s residence in Florida.

headline: Unsolemnly Swear
abstract: Adam Wagner’s puzzle features a surprising twist.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Tuesday, solvers! Today we have a puzzle from the constructor Adam Wagner, who is making his 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Wagner has gained something of a reputation over the past year for his fiendishly tricky Thursday puzzles — they’re the kind that make new solvers unsolemnly swear and shake their fists at the sky — so it’s a welcome surprise to see his byline on a relatively tame Tuesday puzzle.

headline: ‘The White Lotus’ cleans up in the limited and anthology series category.
abstract: Created by Mike White, the HBO series struck a chord with its timely and incisive satire of privilege and liberal hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: “The White Lotus,” the hit HBO anthology series that, during a season of pandemic travel restrictions, skewered the entitled behavior of wealthy vacationers, scooped up five Primetime Emmys on Monday, including the award for best TV movie, limited or anthology series.

headline: ‘Squid Game’ and Lee Jung-jae make Emmys history.
abstract: The hit Korean drama won for directing, and Lee won the top dramatic acting prize, becoming the first person from a foreign-language show to win the category.
lead_paragraph: “Squid Game,” the dystopian Netflix drama that exploded into an international smash hit, made history on Monday, picking up multiple drama awards.

headline: Review: The Emmys Keep it Light and Forgettable
abstract: While there were some memorable acceptance speeches, most of the telecast, which ran on NBC and Peacock, seemed bland and indifferently produced.
lead_paragraph: Kenan Thompson, in his opening remarks at the 74th Primetime Emmy Awards on Monday, joked about people making television so that all of us could “watch at home on television.” But were we? I was watching on Peacock instead of NBC. I imagine it was a pretty similar experience, except that instead of ignoring commercials, I was ignoring floating circular graphics set to elevator music.

headline: ‘Succession’ Wins Best Drama at Emmys as HBO Triumphs Again
abstract: It was the sixth time in eight years that HBO has taken the television industry’s biggest prize for a recurring series. “Ted Lasso” won best comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Succession,” HBO’s portrait of a dysfunctional media dynasty, won best drama at the 74th Emmy Awards on Monday night, the second time the series has taken the prize.

headline: What to Watch in Tuesday’s (Final!) Primary Night
abstract: Republicans are fighting over who will take on Senator Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire. Rhode Island and Delaware are also voting. It’s the last primary night before November.
lead_paragraph: Outside money has poured into New Hampshire heading into Tuesday’s primary as Republicans eye three opportunities to pick up Democratic-held seats, above all that of Senator Maggie Hassan, one of her party’s most vulnerable incumbents.

headline: King Charles Inherits Untold Riches, and Passes Off His Own Empire
abstract: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III built his own empire long before he inherited his mother’s.

headline: In Russell Wilson’s Seattle Return, Seahawks Have the Last Word
abstract: Wilson connected on big passing plays in his return to the city he led to a Super Bowl title, but a missed field-goal attempt in the final minute denied his Denver Broncos a victory.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It didn’t take long for the Seattle Seahawks and their fans to move on from the Russell Wilson era. Never mind that he had led the team through a decade of winning. Never mind that he had helped secure the team’s only Super Bowl title.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ukraine’s Battlefield Wins May Bolster E.U. Support
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 13, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Ukraine is demolishing the myth of the Russian Army and weakening Putin’s imperial project.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 13, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 13, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sept. 6 about the Biden administration’s handling of asylum seekers incorrectly described Maine’s role in a plan to house asylum seekers. The state has agreed to pay up to two years of rent for families in 175 units; it is not paying for the construction of 200 units.

headline: Is America in a Recession? Here’s What 16 Biden and Trump Supporters Think.
abstract: 16 Americans discuss inflation, the prospect of a recession and student loan debt cancellation.
lead_paragraph: 16 Americans discuss inflation, the prospect of a recession and student loan debt cancellation.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: More Ukrainian advances.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said yesterday that it had reclaimed more ground in the war with Russia, and it redoubled its calls for Moscow to surrender in the south. Ukraine’s next steps could determine the near-term course of the war. A false move could squander the opportunities available, but waiting too long could allow the front lines to freeze as winter sets in. Here’s a map of Russian losses.

headline: Columbia Loses A-Plus Status in U.S. News Rankings
abstract: The university plunged from No. 2 to No. 18 in the popular list, which many experts call into question.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at why Columbia University tumbled to No. 18 in the U.S. News & World Report’s college rankings. We’ll also look at what a congestion pricing plan in Manhattan could mean for air quality in the Bronx.

headline: After Bitter Election, Crowds and Confetti Greet Kenya’s New President
abstract: As he took the reins of power, William Ruto promised to alleviate rising prices and strengthen the judiciary. But his team limited local television access, raising concern about press freedoms.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — William Ruto was sworn in as Kenya’s fifth president on Tuesday in a ceremony attended by dozens of global leaders and diplomats — a peaceful handover of power following a bitter election campaign that underscored the entrenched if troubled place of democracy in East Africa’s largest economy.

headline: Word of the Day: precipice
abstract: This word has appeared in 115 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word precipice has appeared in 115 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 31 in “Naomi Osaka, Serena Williams and One Last Shared U.S. Open” by Matthew Futterman:

headline: At Soccer’s Best Talent Factory, the Future Is Always Now
abstract: Ajax sold the bulk of its Champions League-ready squad over the summer and never looked back. It can’t afford to.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands — As a rule, Arco Gnocchi regards himself as too old to buy a replica jersey with his favorite Ajax player’s name emblazoned across the back. Such displays of hero worship, he feels, are not entirely becoming of a person ticking through their early 40s. “Generally,” he said, “it’s for kids.”

headline: Football Season
abstract: Will you be watching or playing this fall?
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s 2022 season kicked off this past week with a contest between the Los Angeles Rams, the reigning Super Bowl champions, and the Buffalo Bills. The Bills won handily, 31-10.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: To Search for a Near-Extinct Snail, Tread Lightly
abstract: Monitoring the last wild Chittenango ovate amber snails, scientists tiptoe through a waterfall spray zone the size of a living room.
lead_paragraph: The Chittenango Creek, which runs north for about 30 twisting miles in central New York, has few distinguishing markers: The stream is generally only a couple of feet deep, and the towns it passes through are similarly small and overlooked.

headline: Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above Its Weight’
abstract: Before the pandemic, the long-sought ruins of Sak Tz’i’, a small but influential Mesoamerican kingdom, were discovered on a cattle ranch in Mexico. This summer archaeologists returned to excavate it.
lead_paragraph: CHIAPAS, Mexico — On a bright, buggy morning in early summer, Charles Golden, an anthropologist at Brandeis University, slashed through the knee-high grass of a cattle ranch deep in the Valle de Santo Domingo, a sparsely populated region of thick brush and almost impenetrable jungle. Only the raucous half-roar, half-bark of howler monkeys pierced the ceaseless mating call of cicadas. “We’re coming to what’s left of the Sak Tz’i’ dynasty,” Dr. Golden said.

headline: In a Final Homecoming, the Queen’s Coffin Arrives in London
abstract: Despite a rainy evening, crowds lined the streets of London as the hearse carrying the queen’s coffin made its way to Buckingham Palace.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Lesson Plan: How an Eighth-Grade Civics Class Helped Reverse the Last Conviction in the Salem Witch Trials
abstract: Students will learn about the power of civic action to achieve justice — even 329 years later. Then, they will propose their own plan to rectify a wrong in their own community.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Last Conviction in Salem Witch Trials Is Cleared 329 Years Later” by Vimal Patel

headline: The Best Chef in The World
abstract: Sally Schmitt sold her successful Napa Valley establishment, the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
lead_paragraph: Sally Schmitt sold her successful Napa Valley establishment, the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”

headline: Stock Trades Reported by Nearly a Fifth of Congress Show Possible Conflicts
abstract: A New York Times analysis found that 97 lawmakers or their family members bought or sold financial assets over a three-year span in industries that could be affected by their legislative committee work.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times analysis found that 97 lawmakers or their family members bought or sold financial assets over a three-year span in industries that could be affected by their legislative committee work.

headline: Should the Government Cancel Student Debt?
abstract: President Biden announced on Aug. 24 that the federal government would cancel up to $20,000 of student loan debt for tens of millions of Americans. Is debt forgiveness the right approach?
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, 45 million people owe $1.6 trillion for federal loans taken out for college — more than they owe on car loans, credit cards or any consumer debt other than mortgages.

headline: These 97 Members of Congress Reported Trades in Companies Influenced by Their Committees
abstract: See the stocks the lawmakers reported buying and selling and how their trades potentially conflicted with the committees they sat on.
lead_paragraph: See the stocks the lawmakers reported buying and selling and how their trades potentially conflicted with the committees they sat on.

headline: The Football Players Who Fought and Died in World War II
abstract: In “The Mosquito Bowl,” Buzz Bissinger examines the Pacific theater through the lives of several athletes who served.
lead_paragraph: I serve on the board of directors of a small company in south Arkansas with a man named John Gaughan Jr. At our annual meeting, Johnny is always cheerful and self-deprecating and admittedly, at 97, a little hard of hearing. He has lived in Camden, Ark. (population 11,000), his whole life, and once caused a stir when he made a hole in one at the Camden Country Club — at the age of 91. (“I hope this thing dies out,” he told a reporter, tiring of all the attention. “It’s getting out of hand.”) The only significant time he has spent away from his hometown was during World War II, when he flew some 50 missions in a P-38 for the Army Air Forces and earned the Distinguished Flying Cross.

headline: How Music Loops Help Me Feel More Present
abstract: Loops open a dimension where, although time is ticking forward at its usual pace, I’m moving at my own speed, appreciating my body and the world around me.
lead_paragraph: There once was a basement club in Minneapolis called Honey. I would go solo, taking the bus across the river and, descending the basement stairs, hear the music get louder with each step. I was mostly there on weeknights, when the club hosted touring D.J.s who were in between gigs in larger cities. I was nervous to go up to anyone, so instead I made myself comfortable by a column in the middle of the room. Being alone didn’t matter much once I closed my eyes. I would dance softly as techno or house tracks blared through the room. The music, much of it composed of looping, recurrent elements, went on for hours. Eventually, I opened my eyes and figured it was time to go home.

headline: Before Thomas Keller, It Was Her French Laundry
abstract: Sally Schmitt sold the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
lead_paragraph: When my father died, he held disappointment in his heart. He was 66 and had only just retired from a life of 80-hour workweeks as a successful lawyer, and this next chapter promised everything he had skimped on since deciding to go to law school: family time, creative pursuits, fun.

headline: There’s a Better Way to Reclaim Your Time Than ‘Quiet Quitting’
abstract: As counterintuitive as it seems, adding energizing activities to your schedule just might make life feel more doable.
lead_paragraph: This summer, there was much discussion of the concept of “quiet quitting” — meaning, essentially, doing the bare minimum at work. And perhaps that’s not surprising: After more than two years of pandemic uncertainty, employee stress levels are at all-time highs, and people are still languishing. When you’re exhausted and overwhelmed, it feels like something needs to give — and for many, that seems to be the pursuit of excellence at work.

headline: Is Ron DeSantis the Future of the Republican Party?
abstract: For years, Democrats have worried about the prospect of a more disciplined heir to Trump. In Florida’s pugilistic governor, that candidate may have arrived.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last year, Ron DeSantis would not indulge the speculation. Yes, he made clear to donors, he might seek the presidency. But pressed with the obvious follow-up — would he still run in 2024 if Donald Trump does? — DeSantis, the governor of Florida, begged off. “He’ll be completely, completely open about whatever, but then the Trump stuff — he suddenly starts to act like he’s being recorded,” Dan Eberhart, a prominent Republican donor and a DeSantis ally, told me in March.

headline: We Build Civilizations on Status. But We Barely Understand It.
abstract: The sociologist Cecilia Ridgeway explains how status shapes our world — and our lives.
lead_paragraph: “We see status virtually everywhere in social life, if we think to look for it,” writes Cecilia Ridgeway. “It suffuses everyday possessions, the cars we drive, the clothes we wear, the food brands we prefer, and the music we listen to.” And that’s only a partial list. Status influences the neighborhood we live in, the occupation we pursue, the friends we choose. It attaches itself to our race, gender, class and age. It shapes our interpersonal interactions. And, most of the time, it does all of this without us even realizing what’s happening.

headline: My Roommate Is Neglecting His Dog. What Should I Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist on speaking up for a member of the household — when it’s a pet.
lead_paragraph: My roommate and I have lived together for some years. We are not close but get along well. He mainly keeps to himself, sleeping most of the day and staying up at night. He is very well off and enjoys many luxuries but has long struggled with depression.

headline: From Nigeria to the United States — and to the Future
abstract: Omolola Ijeoma Ogunyemi’s novel in stories unfolds across centuries, continents, political parties and a tight group of friends.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly 20 years since I first learned of Aristotle’s belief that the best story endings are “surprising, yet inevitable,” I have rarely been as blindsided — in the best possible way — by the final moments of a book as I was while reading Omolola Ijeoma Ogunyemi’s “Jollof Rice and Other Revolutions: A Novel in Interlocking Stories.”

headline: We’ve Waited Our Whole Lives to Help Our Father, David Milch, Tell This Story
abstract: We’d always been listening.
lead_paragraph: We’ve heard the story of our dad shooting out streetlamps while on acid more times than we can count. Sometimes he does it with a shotgun, sometimes the New Haven cops know him by name (he’d been arrested before), but it always ends with him saying, “I refuse to speak to you until your badge stops melting.” It’s a good line.

headline: Can We Escape Our Parents or Are We Fated to Become Them?
abstract: Gwendoline Riley’s novels “My Phantoms” and “First Love” consider the sway and scourge of family ties.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of “My Phantoms,” Gwendoline Riley’s seventh book — and her richest and most devastating novel so far — comes an image that catches in the mind. Bridget, the middle-aged narrator, who’s sitting in her London flat while her psychoanalyst boyfriend prepares a meal, observes her mother, Hen, watching for the arrival of a dinner guest: “Like a plant straining towards the light, as close to the glass as a person could get, and with her head turned up as far as her position would allow her to look up, my mother stood at our living room window, waiting for Dave.”

headline: The Power of Poop
abstract: A comprehensive study of human waste explores the possibilities for global health, inside every flush.
lead_paragraph: Human waste may trigger automatic disgust, but fun facts about turds are another matter. Who wouldn’t be intrigued to learn that those produced in low-income countries weigh fully twice as much, on average, as those produced in wealthier nations? (The short explanation: fiber.) That’s the kind of tidbit that Bryn Nelson, a writer with a Ph.D. in microbiology, seamlessly weaves into his wide-ranging, science-based explorations of the surprisingly complicated world of waste.

headline: What a Young Philosopher Discovered More Than 200 Years Ago About Nature
abstract: Friedrich Schelling’s ideas might provide a foundation on which to anchor the fight for our climate and our survival.
lead_paragraph: As darkness settled over the small German town of Jena in the late winter of 1798, large groups of young men rushed to the town university’s biggest auditorium to listen to their new philosophy professor. They jostled for seats, took out ink and quills and waited. At the lectern, a young man lit two candles and the students saw him bathed in light.

headline: A New Book Tracks the Rise of Right-Wing Extremism in the U.S.
abstract: At a time of social turmoil, Luke Mogelson’s “The Storm Is Here” explores how we got to this point.
lead_paragraph: To get a feel for Luke Mogelson’s new book, you might watch a bit of the footage he captured during the Jan. 6 Capitol siege. You’ll hear “traitors to the guillotine” and “kill Mike Pence” bizarrely juxtaposed with “protect the Constitution” and “Christ is king.” At one point, protesters smash video equipment taken from news crews, pile it up and set it on fire. “There you go,” someone shouts, addressing journalists trying to report the event. “Now you can’t!”

headline: Why Things May Really Be Different for This Midterm Election
abstract: This cycle, the arguments for Democratic strength cut against the conventional wisdom that the party in power struggles in midterms.
lead_paragraph: Just about every election cycle, there’s an argument for why, this time, things might be different — different from expectations based on historical trends and key factors like the state of the economy or the president’s approval rating.

headline: For a Modern Master, the Short Story Is Both Form and Subject
abstract: In his new collection, “Two Nurses, Smoking,” David Means derives power from revealing the workings of his craft.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the title story of his dazzling new collection, “Two Nurses, Smoking,” David Means suddenly reverses course on the tale you’ve been reading, about two soul-weary health care workers embarking on a tentative romance.

headline: My Favorite Murder, Roaring Twenties-Style
abstract: In “Blood & Ink,” Joe Pompeo explores the gory Hall-Mills case and the tabloid nation it spawned.
lead_paragraph: The newspaper publisher Joseph Medill Patterson is alleged to have ranked the subjects most popular with his 1920s readers: “(1) Love or Sex, (2) Money, (3) Murder.” The best stories — the kind that propelled his upstart New York tabloid the Daily News from local rag to the most circulated newspaper in America — involved all three.

headline: Republicans Deploy Surprising Weapon in N.Y. Governor’s Race: Eric Adams
abstract: Lee Zeldin and other Republicans are trying to attract swing voters by aligning themselves with Mayor Adams, a Democrat, over his law-and-order platform.
lead_paragraph: In his uphill battle to become New York’s next governor, Representative Lee M. Zeldin, the Trump-supporting conservative Republican from Long Island, has turned to an unlikely weapon: Eric Adams, the mayor of New York City.

headline: It Is a Well-Known Truth That Opponents of Democracy Don’t Want You to Have Nice Things
abstract: What makes a democracy robust?
lead_paragraph: As a nation, the United States is committed to a creed of free market capitalism. But this belies a heritage of egalitarianism and economic equality in American political thought. Among the oldest and most potent strains of American thinking about democracy is the belief that free government cannot exist in tandem with mass immiseration and gross disparities of wealth and status.

headline: Nina Totenberg Opens Up About Her Friend Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: In her memoir, “Dinners With Ruth,” the NPR journalist writes about their parallel ascents in fields that were not friendly to women.
lead_paragraph: In “Dinners With Ruth,” Nina Totenberg, the legendary NPR journalist who was close to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, writes about the nature of friendship — and it’s easy to see why she might feel she has expertise in the subject.

headline: Who Wears the Skirts in the Family?
abstract: Three designers showing at New York Men’s Day prove that men’s wear influences can come from anywhere. Think Lizzo, dhotis and Flavor Flav.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing against dating apps, but I think in a lot of ways digital culture is actually keeping people from connecting,” the designer Aaron Potts said on Friday. He meant in a soulful rather than a physical sense.

headline: Girl Hunter or Girl Hunted?
abstract: In her Y.A. thriller “I’m the Girl,” Courtney Summers uses a murder mystery to explore pressing questions about female empowerment.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Summers’s books are not for the faint of heart. Even when fighting off zombies or dismantling cults, the teen girl protagonists of her novels shoulder immense personal trauma, facing abusive peers, absent or dead parents and — overwhelmingly — sexual violence. Georgia Avis, the 16-year-old lesbian heroine of Summers’s newest novel, “I’m the Girl,” is an exception. At least, she thinks she is.

headline: A $100 Million Bet on Finding the Next ‘Mr. Beast’
abstract: Reed Duchscher, the manager of the YouTube megastar “Mr. Beast,” is teaming up with the investment firm TCG to bankroll businesses led by online creators.
lead_paragraph: When Kevin Espiritu quit his job at a book subscription service in 2016, his big idea was to grow food in other people’s yards while working on his blog, “Epic Gardening.” At the time, the blog generated about $600 a month.

headline: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
abstract: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have a hard time remembering things and often feel exhausted, like I can’t clear my head at all. Is this brain fog, and is there anything I can do to fix it?

headline: The Endless Torment of the ‘Recipe?’ Guy
abstract: A rampant internet comment that just won’t die shows how recipes, and the people who develop them, are undervalued.
lead_paragraph: Picture him, scrolling Instagram. He slows down for a flash-lit image of pasta on someone’s crowded, linen-draped dining table. For a sunlit reel of chickpeas and olive oil breaking down into a golden pulp. For a bubbling pot of oxtail.

headline: Lake Superior Is Cold, Sparsely Settled and Known for Bad Weather. Perfect for Cruising, Some Say.
abstract: As cruising picks up, one small Wisconsin port weighs the pros and cons of more ships and their impact on the town and the environment.
lead_paragraph: It’s an August morning in northern Wisconsin, the kind that residents of the small town of Bayfield dream about in the darkest months of winter. The sun glistens on Lake Superior, a gentle north breeze cools the 70-degree air, and the City Dock, lined by sailboats and yachts, is quiet save for a small circle of drummers from the nearby Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa stationed in front of the town’s Lakeside Pavilion. They beat their drums in tune to dancers dressed in intricately beaded formal regalia. Behind the drummers, a few hundred yards into the bay, sits the Viking Octantis, the largest cruise ship the town of 466 year-round residents has ever seen.

headline: The Critical Moment Behind Ukraine’s Rapid Advance
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky wanted to make a dramatic move in the war against Russia. U.S. and Ukrainian officials came up with a plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The strategy behind Ukraine’s rapid military gains in recent days began to take shape months ago during a series of intense conversations between Ukrainian and U.S. officials about the way forward in the war against Russia, according to American officials.

headline: Ian McEwan Returns With a Tale of Adolescent Lust and Adult Lassitude
abstract: In “Lessons,” the hero is seduced by his piano teacher when he’s 14, then abandoned by his wife while he passively watches history unfold. Are these events connected?
lead_paragraph: Nobody is better at writing about entropy, indignity and ejaculation — among other topics — than Ian McEwan. He specializes in the mental life of one particular, culturally endemic type: the contemporary middle-class British male. His characters are occasionally lecherous, often bitter and always secularly human.

headline: Why You Should Decorate Your Hallway (and How to Get Started)
abstract: When you’re furnishing your home, it’s easy to focus on larger rooms and overlook the hall. Here’s why that’s a mistake.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to obsess about the design details in your kitchen, bathroom or living room. But what about your hallways? Many of us forget to decorate them — and it’s a missed opportunity.

headline: This Might Not Be a Cold War, but It Feels Like One
abstract: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
lead_paragraph: During a trip to China more than a decade ago as vice president, Joe Biden gave a speech celebrating the United States as the wealthiest country ever. The United States, he said, was two and a half times as rich as his host nation.

headline: His Pulitzer-Winning Comedy Broke the Rules. He’s at It Again.
abstract: Andrew Sean Greer was elated, if a little confounded, when his 2017 novel “Less” received the award. Now he’s following it with a sequel, which he knows might raise some eyebrows. So what if it’s unseemly?
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2022 Emmys
abstract: The show returned to a pre-Covid format, with the usual array of leaden gags, shameless commercialism and genuinely poignant moments.
lead_paragraph: After two consecutive ceremonies shaped by the pandemic, the Primetime Emmys returned to what felt more or less like a pre-Covid format on Monday night. The awards were handed out in the celebrity-stuffed Microsoft Theater in Los Angeles, and the corny bits were about TV clichés, not masks and social distancing.

headline: Markets Plunge as Inflation Data Undercuts Wall Street’s Optimism
abstract: Stocks plunged, government bond yields soared and the dollar bounced after investors were wrong-footed by a report showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
lead_paragraph: Stocks plummeted and government bond yields soared on Tuesday, as investors were once again caught off guard by the persistence of inflation in the United States and quickly shifted their views on what the Federal Reserve may need to do to combat rising prices.

headline: Inflation Remained Stubbornly High in August, Rattling Consumers and Investors
abstract: Overall inflation moderated less than anticipated, and a closely watched measure of price pressures jumped, bad news for the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Price increases remained uncomfortably rapid in August as a broad array of goods and services became more expensive even as gas prices fell, evidence that the sustainable inflation slowdown the Federal Reserve and White House have been hoping for remains elusive.

headline: Inflation Explained: The Good, the Bad and the Uncertain
abstract: Amid hopeful signs that U.S. inflation was about to cool off, Tuesday’s Consumer Price Index report underlined the risks that it could remain high.
lead_paragraph: Inflation in the United States has been cooling on an annual basis over recent months as a result of falling gasoline prices, but economists are looking for more evidence that the slowdown in price increases will become widespread and pronounced.

headline: U.S. Gas Prices Have Fallen for 91 Straight Days, a Relief for Consumers
abstract: The steady decline is also a welcome development for policymakers trying to cool off the economy.
lead_paragraph: The price of gasoline continues to fall steadily, easing pressure on American consumers as the cost of filling a tank continued to tumble from record levels reached earlier in the summer.

headline: Overnight Storm in New York City Causes Flash Flooding, but No Tornado
abstract: There were no reports of tornado sightings, despite a warning issued for parts of the city early Tuesday morning. But heavy rainfall led to flash flooding and subway delays.
lead_paragraph: Though a tornado in Brooklyn and Queens that had been feared failed to materialize, thunderstorms early Tuesday morning brought heavy rainfall to New York City and the surrounding areas, leading to some areas of flash flooding and subway delays during the busy morning hours.

headline: Film Club: ‘I Have Face Blindness. This Is How I Recognize You.’
abstract: How do people cope and thrive with their disabilities? How can we better understand and respond to the needs of those with disabilities?
lead_paragraph: “I Have Face Blindness. This Is How I Recognize You.” is an eight-minute film from the Times’s “Adapt-Ability” Opinion Video series inviting audiences to confront discomfort with disability.  It profiles Paul Kram, who has a condition called prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, a neurological disorder that inhibits the recognition of faces. In the video, the filmmaker James Robinson shows us how Mr. Kram experiences social interactions, his techniques for managing prosopagnosia and the ways the rest of society can better respond to the needs of those who have the condition.

headline: Jean-Luc Godard, 91, Is Dead; Bold Director Shaped French New Wave
abstract: The Franco-Swiss filmmaker and provocateur radically rethought motion pictures and left a lasting influence on the medium.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Luc Godard, the daringly innovative director and provocateur whose unconventional camera work, disjointed narrative style and penchant for radical politics changed the course of filmmaking in the 1960s, leaving a lasting influence on it, died on Tuesday at his home in Rolle, Switzerland. He was 91.

headline: The Greatest Threat to Democracy Is a Feature of Democracy
abstract: Democratic society is uniquely vulnerable to the consequences of communication.
lead_paragraph: It’s been over a month since Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence was searched by the F.B.I. The response to that event from political actors across the ideological spectrum has been predictable — and an example, for better or worse, of what democracy looks like in action.

headline: Schumer to Push $15 Million Into Democratic Fight to Hold Senate
abstract: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, is said to be planning to transfer part of his war chest to key Democratic candidates as well as to the party’s Senate campaign arm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, plans to transfer $15 million from his campaign account to the Democratic Senate campaign effort as well as to several of the party’s key candidates, according to a Democrat with knowledge of his plans.

headline: Is Ukraine Turning the Tide in the War?
abstract: What the country’s biggest victory since the beginning of the war means for the future of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Ukraine’s military stunned the world. After months of a kind of stalemate, its military took hundreds of miles of territory back from Russia — its biggest victory since the start of the war.

headline: Woman Sues San Francisco Over Arrest Based on DNA From Her Rape Kit
abstract: The woman had provided her DNA to police after being sexually assaulted in 2016, her lawyer said. About five years later, officers used it to charge her with retail theft.
lead_paragraph: A woman whose DNA from a rape kit was used by the police to arrest her in connection with an unrelated property crime last year filed a federal lawsuit against the city of San Francisco on Monday, saying that the Police Department had engaged in an “unconstitutional invasion of privacy.”

headline: Ukraine on the March
abstract: It’s not just one region. Ukraine is making progress in multiple places.
lead_paragraph: Could Ukraine actually win its war against Russia? Ukraine’s surprising recent breakthrough in the northeast has caused more military analysts to start asking that question.

headline: Clashes Erupt Between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Raising Fears of Another War
abstract: The simmering conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region last flared in 2020, when Russia brokered a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: Fighting erupted Tuesday between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the latest flare-up in their decades-long armed standoff over the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh in the South Caucasus. The clashes raised the prospect of Russia becoming embroiled in another war near its borders.

headline: In Sri Lanka, Triumphs in Cricket and Netball Bring Joy to a Nation in Crisis
abstract: The men’s cricket team won the Asia Cup in the T20 format, hours after Sri Lanka won the equivalent championship in women’s netball. Both teams were feted with a parade on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The streets of Sri Lanka’s capital have been jammed with crowds in recent months, as rage over an economic meltdown led to protests that dethroned a long-ruling political dynasty.

headline: In Rome, a 13th-Century Home Imbued With a Youthful Spirit
abstract: The architect Pietro Cicognani conjures Italian glamour — and his own enchanted childhood — in his townhouse apartment.
lead_paragraph: IN 1972, FOR Pietro Cicognani’s 18th birthday, his mother gave him a small apartment on Vicolo della Palomba, a narrow medieval street near Rome’s bustling Piazza Navona. Occupying the top two floors of a 13th-century townhouse with a weathered stucco facade and a rear spiral stairway of stone and steel, the multilevel flat was both a bohemian teen’s fantasy and an excellent investment: intimate, atmospheric and in the middle of the action.

headline: Fatal Kangaroo Attack Is Said to Be First in Australia in 86 Years
abstract: The police said they believed that the man had been keeping the wild animal as a pet.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A 77-year-old Australian man was killed this weekend by a kangaroo in what is believed to be the country’s first fatal kangaroo attack in over 80 years.

headline: ‘New History in K-Drama’: South Korea Hails Emmy Success for ‘Squid Game’
abstract: After the dystopian Netflix drama picked up multiple wins, Koreans celebrated the awards as the latest example of their country’s rise as a cultural powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — First it was the movie “Parasite.” Then Yuh-Jung Youn, the star of “Minari.” Now, “Squid Game.”

headline: Challenges for Russia and China Test a ‘No-Limits’ Friendship
abstract: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are set to meet later this week. Russia’s battlefield losses and China’s slowdown could complicate their relationship.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The summit this week between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Xi Jinping of China is a show of force by two autocratic leaders united against what they consider American hegemony. It is also a moment of mutual weakness as Russia suffers losses in Ukraine and China endures an economic slowdown.

headline: The Corsage Finds a Fresh Way to Make a Statement
abstract: Once considered fusty and unfashionable, boutonnieres and other floral adornments are enjoying a renaissance.
lead_paragraph: In periods of peace and war, for ceremony or pleasure, the art of adorning ourselves with flowers and plants — be it with wreaths, bracelets or ornamental blooms — dates to ancient times. Egyptian women wore garlands of narcotic lotuses, a sacred symbol of protection and rebirth, while, according to Greek legend, Achilles used wild yarrow, a medicinal herb that could stanch bleeding, to help heal his fellow soldiers’ wounds.

headline: Twitter Whistle-blower Is Set to Testify in Washington
abstract: Elon Musk’s legal team will follow closely the testimony of Twitter’s former head of security, Peiter Zatko, before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: Peiter Zatko, Twitter’s former head of security, is scheduled to testify this morning before the Senate Judiciary Committee about his explosive whistle-blower report claiming that the social network fails to protect user data and is vulnerable to hackers. Zatko, who is known as Mudge, has taken center stage in Elon Musk’s legal fight to get out of the Twitter deal since he went public last month — and both sides will be watching the hearing as they gear up for the October trial. In a fun twist, the shareholder vote on Twitter’s sale to Musk is also today. Expect it to be approved.

headline: A Book of Recipes and Testimony From Auschwitz-Birkenau Survivors
abstract: This affecting new cookbook includes mostly Eastern European dishes as well as first-person accounts of suffering and survival.
lead_paragraph: Preparing the dishes in this substantial new cookbook feels like paying homage to resilient survivors. The elegance of this new volume, “Honey Cake & Latkes: Recipes from the Old World by the Auschwitz-Birkenau Survivors,” assembled and copublished by the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial Foundation led by Ronald S. Lauder, almost camouflages the horrors until you read the first-person accounts. That starving people think about food and summon rich memories is not surprising, as the book, not the first to cover this topic, explains. The mostly Eastern European recipes, like a simple butter cake, a plum torte, green beans in dill sauce, chicken paprikash and Elie Wiesel’s latkes, are often excellently rendered. Some give copious quantities to serve what were once large, extended families, and might require adjustment. Proceeds from the sales of the book will benefit the Foundation.

headline: Cuomo Files Ethics Complaint Against Letitia James
abstract: Ms. James, the New York attorney general, was accused by Mr. Cuomo of violating conduct rules in her investigation of sexual harassment accusations against him.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo filed a lengthy state ethics complaint on Tuesday against Letitia James, the New York State attorney general, accusing her of deliberately mishandling the investigation that found he sexually harassed multiple former and current government employees.

headline: Boston Marathon Adds Option for Nonbinary Runners Next Year
abstract: Nonbinary runners will not be required to register in either the men’s or women’s division for the 2023 Boston Marathon, the organizers of the race said.
lead_paragraph: Nonbinary athletes will be able to compete in next year’s Boston Marathon, one of the most popular running events in the world, without having to register in the men’s or women’s division, race organizers announced on Monday.

headline: How to Live in California in a Disaster Era
abstract: The state’s longtime emergency services director offers advice and his outlook after an unprecedented decade.
lead_paragraph: Three times in the last four years, Mark Ghilarducci has tried to retire from his decade-long job as the head of emergency services in California, only to postpone because of some, well, emergency.

headline: Rivers Cuomo’s Very Complicated, Highly Organized Life
abstract: Preparing to release a new EP in Weezer’s “Sznz” series, the band’s leader explained how he keeps himself on track — and how he learned to say “Are you ready to rock?” in any language.
lead_paragraph: The Weezer frontman Rivers Cuomo knows how people think about Weezer. The veteran rock band has dedicated much of 2022 to promoting “Sznz,” a four-part series of EPs that ostensibly correspond to the different seasons, but also stand in for eras in the band’s history. “‘Spring’ was the easy-breezy side of Weezer, nobody’s really going to object to that,” he said. “‘Summer’ was more like ’90s alt-rock Weezer, which lots of people will be relieved to hear.”

headline: The Artist Making Sculptures From Scraps
abstract: Plus: the stateside rise of fermented tofu and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: Though a staple of Chinese and Taiwanese home cooking, fermented tofu, or furu, has never had the stateside appeal of other preserved soybean products, such as miso and gochujang. Made by soaking soybean curds in a brine of rice wine, water, salt and spices, furu (also romanized to “fuyu” and “doufuru”) is now being embraced by Asian American chefs who are finding clever ways to capitalize on its specific tang, mild sweetness and intense umami. At Bonnie’s, Calvin Eng’s Williamsburg palace of Cantonese American food, and Wenwen, Eric Sze’s playful Greenpoint Taiwanese spot — two of Brooklyn’s most popular new restaurants — menu showstoppers include, respectively, furu cacio e pepe mein and so-called B.D.S.M. (brined, deboned, soy milk) fried chicken with a furu-infused baste. At the original Junzi Kitchen location in New Haven, Conn., the Hong Kong-born chef Lucas Sin highlights the ingredient in the furu sesame sauce that comes with his noodle and salad bowls. And at San Francisco’s Michelin-starred Mister Jiu’s, Brandon Jew offers a dish of tendrils, greens and stems with Meyer lemon, sea urchin and fermented tofu. “Furu adds a ton of funk that you can’t get from anything else,” says Eng. — Hetty McKinnon

headline: ‘The Future of Hospitals’: Flexible Space for the Next Pandemic
abstract: After struggling to respond to a crushing Covid caseload, many hospitals are remodeling so that when the next crisis comes, they’ll be better able to meet it.
lead_paragraph: Officials at Rady Children’s Hospital in San Diego had already begun work on a $1.2 billion transformation of its campus when the pandemic hit, forcing them to switch gears. As hospitals nationwide struggled to deal with surging cases, it became clear that the facility’s new design would need to evolve.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Music Man’ Revival Will End Run on Jan. 1
abstract: The show’s producers have decided not to recast after stars Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster finish runs of slightly more than a year in the show.
lead_paragraph: An enormously popular Broadway revival of “The Music Man” will end its run on Jan. 1, reflecting a decision by the producers not to recast after the departure of the show’s stars, Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster.

headline: Pink and Polarizing: The New Tennis Shirt
abstract: Frances Tiafoe and others at the U.S. Open wore a Nike outfit that spurred a colorful conversation online.
lead_paragraph: Frances Tiafoe sweats a lot. The 24-year-old American tennis player had a breakout performance at this year’s U.S. Open, beating Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 and making it all the way to the semifinals. During each match, he repeatedly changed his shirt.

headline: Archives Is Unsure Whether Trump Surrendered All Records, Panel Says
abstract: In a letter, the chairwoman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee said the National Archives told her staff it was still not certain whether all presidential records had been returned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Archives has informed congressional aides that it is still unsure whether former President Donald J. Trump has surrendered all the presidential records he removed from the White House, even after months of negotiations, a subpoena and a search of his Florida property, according to the House Oversight Committee.

headline: 9 Great Godard Films to Stream Now
abstract: From the youthful New Wave excitement of “Breathless” to the experimental works of his old age, Godard changed cinema.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Luc Godard has died at 91. One of the pioneers of the French New Wave, Godard and his movie-mad contemporaries rebelled against the square cinematic conventions of the 1950s. They redefined the canon to include then-disreputable American genre pictures, created characters who articulated their own passions and opinions, and illustrated that the tried-and-true techniques of professional filmmaking were stifling and unnecessary.

headline: New Hampshire Primary: How to Vote and Who’s on the Ballot
abstract: Republicans in the Granite State are selecting their choices to challenge Senator Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, and two Democratic members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in the Granite State are selecting their choices to challenge Senator Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, and two Democratic members of Congress. Here’s what to know about voting in the state:

headline: Rhode Island Primary: How to Vote and Who’s on the Ballot
abstract: Rhode Island voters are heading to the polls to pick candidates for governor and an open House seat.
lead_paragraph: Rhode Island voters are heading to the polls to pick candidates for governor and an open House seat. Here’s what to know about voting in the state:

headline: 6 TV Recap Podcasts for Better Binge Viewing
abstract: These shows will help you go deeper on your favorite small-screen series, whether cult classics or current staples.
lead_paragraph: TV recap shows are among the oldest of podcast genres, and they’ve become even more plentiful during a Golden Age of television.

headline: Pandemic Aid Cut U.S. Poverty to New Low in 2021, Census Bureau Reports
abstract: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies also showed a reduction of almost half in the number of children below the poverty level.
lead_paragraph: A second year of emergency pandemic aid from the federal government drove poverty to the lowest level on record in 2021 and cut the number of poor children by nearly half, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday.

headline: How Is the Economy Doing?
abstract: Most of the economy appears to be doing well, but slowing down — all while the latest trends don’t look like recessions of the past.
lead_paragraph: Most of the economy appears to be doing well, but slowing down — all while the latest trends don’t look like recessions of the past.

headline: Delaware Primary: How to Vote and Who’s on the Ballot
abstract: Tuesday will be the first test of big changes to voting in Delaware, and the state’s one contested primary for a statewide office involves a convicted incumbent.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday will be the first test of several major changes to how Delaware administers its elections. Because of a bill signed into law this July, voters in the state can now vote by mail without an excuse, vote early in person and register any time until the end of Election Day. Here’s what else to know about voting in the state:

headline: Mike Trout Was in ‘Good Company’ With Seven-Game Homer Streak
abstract: Trout’s epic run finished one game short of tying the major league record, which is shared by three players.
lead_paragraph: In a season that already included the longest hitless streak of his career, and the revelation of a chronic back injury, Mike Trout of the Los Angeles Angels got to enjoy one of the best stretches of his life.

headline: Big Tech Is Co-Parenting Our Children. Yes, Be Afraid.
abstract: In “Who’s Raising the Kids?” Susan Linn’s searing indictment of corporate greed, tech companies targeting children are rivaled only by the lawmakers who let them get away with it.
lead_paragraph: A recurring motif in fairy tales is the parental figure who pretends to care, but in fact sees children as a nuisance, a meal ticket or a meal. Think Hansel and Gretel’s witch, scores of wicked stepmothers or the bonneted wolf in Little Red Riding Hood.

headline: How Time Softened the Judgment of Camilla and the Fury Over Diana’s Death
abstract: A quarter-century ago Princess Diana’s shocking death provoked outrage at the royal family. Queen Elizabeth’s passing, in contrast, has been draped in civility and respect.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The noise rippled through the crowd gathered near Buckingham Palace to mark Queen Elizabeth’s death — a rustling of phones, a sudden cheering, a burst of applause. “I just saw her!” a woman exclaimed excitedly as a dark car sped past, possibly containing some royal, or royal-adjacent, passengers.

headline: Whistle-Blower Says Twitter ‘Chose to Mislead’ on Security Flaws
abstract: At a Senate hearing, Peiter Zatko, Twitter’s former head of security, told lawmakers that the company lied about its data practices.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s former top security official told lawmakers at a hearing on Tuesday that executives had so heavily prioritized the company’s business that they disregarded concerns about foreign governments infiltrating its operations and misled regulators about its privacy practices.

headline: A new draft in Russia ‘is not being discussed,’ the Kremlin says.
abstract: Russian commentators have been calling on President Vladimir V. Putin to bolster the army with recruits and to target Ukrainian infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin rebuffed talk on Tuesday of a nationwide military draft in Russia, a politically risky proposal that has gained prominence in public discussion in the wake of Russian forces’ rapid reversals in northeastern Ukraine.

headline: A Honey Cake With a Long History and Many Layers
abstract: Adapted from a Hungarian Jewish family’s recipe, this honey cake tastes like an icebox cake with a gingerbread crust.
lead_paragraph: Honey cake, a springy loaf called lekach in Yiddish and traditionally served at Rosh Hashana, is not my favorite holiday dessert. So I was thrilled when, in the 1990s, Charles Fenyvesi, a colleague of mine at The Washington Post, shared a tantalizing family recipe for a Hungarian honey cake with thin, biscuit-like gingerbread layers.

headline: When the Queen Died, Someone Had to Tell the Bees
abstract: A report that the royal beekeeper had informed Queen Elizabeth II’s bees of her death received some mockery, but it has been a tradition for centuries.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: The Porch, Featuring Smokehouse Favorites, Opens in Sugar Hill
abstract: A new restaurant from a Bâtard and Augustine alumnus, Manhatta reopens, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Jazz made Sugar Hill, in the heart of Harlem, sizzle in its heyday 100 or so years ago. Now, with Paul Schermerhorn, who has a background in fine dining, as a partner, Mark Miller, a musician, Sugar Hill resident and the owner of the neighborhood’s new jazz venue and barbecue joint, hopes to reheat the beat. The neighborhood can expect smokehouse favorites like baby back ribs, brisket, pork butt and barbecue chicken from the executive chef Matt Fisher, a former pitmaster at Fletcher’s Brooklyn Barbecue and the nearby Dinosaur Barbecue. At his side is Hassan Salim, the chef de cuisine, who is smoking local bluefish and cod. They are also introducing some Cajun dishes like shrimp beignets, roast beef po boy with debris, and peanut slaw. For now, there’s beer and wine, with cocktails to come. Live music, frequently from local performers, starts at 9 p.m. Thursdays through Sundays with a modest cover charge. The restaurant has an open kitchen, seating indoors and out, and décor enlivened with vintage finds.

headline: The Chess World Isn’t Ready for a Cheating Scandal
abstract: Magnus Carlsen, the World Chess Championship winner, withdrew from the Sinquefield Cup after losing to Hans Niemann.
lead_paragraph: When Hans Niemann beat Magnus Carlsen, the world chess champion, in the Sinquefield Cup on Sept. 4, he ended Carlsen’s 53-game unbeaten streak in classical over the board tournaments, and set into motion a debacle that has turned into one of the biggest chess scandals in years.

headline: A Look at Trump’s Endorsement Record as the Primaries End
abstract: As the midterm primary season ends, candidates whom former President Donald J. Trump endorsed have racked up many wins and a handful of prominent losses.
lead_paragraph: As the midterm primary season comes to an end, candidates endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump have continued to rack up wins, but with a handful of prominent losses.

headline: Graham Proposes 15-Week Abortion Ban, Splitting Republicans
abstract: The South Carolina senator’s bill was an effort to find a politically palatable position for his party before the midterm elections, in which abortion rights are expected to be a potent issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina introduced legislation on Tuesday that would institute a federal ban on abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, reigniting debate on an issue that Republicans have worked to confront before midterm elections in which abortion rights have become a potent issue.

headline: The crown and climate
abstract: Britain has been one of the main contributors to global warming. We look at the new king’s environmental credentials.
lead_paragraph: The new king of Britain, Charles III, has long been outspoken on conservation and climate change. So I want to use today’s newsletter to fill in some context about Charles, the institution he represents, and his country’s efforts to tackle global warming.

headline: N.B.A. Fines and Suspends Phoenix Suns Owner for Misconduct
abstract: An investigation found that the owner, Robert Sarver, had used racial slurs and treated female employees inequitably. The N.B.A. fined Sarver $10 million.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is suspending Robert Sarver, the majority owner of the Phoenix Suns, for one year and fining him $10 million after an investigation determined that he had engaged in misconduct, including using racial slurs, yelling at employees and treating female employees unfairly.

headline: Is Food Sensitivity Testing a Scam?
abstract: These assessments, which tell you which foods to avoid, are becoming increasingly popular. Here’s what the experts want you to know.
lead_paragraph: Food is one of life’s pleasures, but it can also be a source of pain — especially if you’re among the tens of millions of Americans who regularly experience digestive issues like heartburn, abdominal pain, bloating or diarrhea. When those symptoms strike, you may wonder: Are certain foods to blame?

headline: Celsius Network Plots a Comeback After a Crypto Crash
abstract: The chief executive of the experimental crypto bank Celsius has told employees about an audacious plan to revive the firm, which filed for bankruptcy in July.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of the experimental cryptocurrency bank Celsius Network was one of the main drivers of this spring’s crypto crash, which erased nearly $1 trillion from the market and ruined thousands of investors.

headline: Misery Takes a Holiday
abstract: Surprise! Good news on inflation.
lead_paragraph: Back when inflation was first taking off in the late 1960s and early 1970s, Arthur Okun — an economist who served John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson — suggested a quick-and-dirty measure of the state of the economy. His Economic Discomfort Index — which Ronald Reagan later renamed the Misery Index — was just the sum of the unemployment rate and the inflation rate.

headline: Rapper PnB Rock Is Killed in Robbery in South Los Angeles
abstract: Atlantic Records described the killing of the Philadelphia rapper, whose name was Rakim Allen, as a “senseless loss.”
lead_paragraph: PnB Rock, a Philadelphia rapper known for his melodic style and songs like “Fleek” and “Selfish,” was killed on Monday afternoon in what the police said they believed was a robbery that took place after the artist was tagged on social media at a restaurant in South Los Angeles.

headline: Susan L. Solomon, Crusader for Stem Cell Research, Dies at 71
abstract: Vexed by lags in producing cures for diabetes and cancer, she helped raise $400 million to start a foundation that has made medical breakthroughs.
lead_paragraph: Susan L. Solomon, whose frustration over lags in finding a cure for her teenage son’s Type 1 diabetes prompted her to establish what became a leading independent stem cell research laboratory, died on Sept. 8 at her home in Amagansett, N.Y. She was 71.

headline: It Was Hard to Find Sheet Music by Women Jazz Artists. So She Fixed It.
abstract: The jazz drummer and educator Terri Lyne Carrington’s latest project is “New Standards: 101 Lead Sheets by Women Composers,” a book due Friday, and an album featuring 11 of its selections.
lead_paragraph: The inexhaustible drummer, producer and composer Terri Lyne Carrington’s latest multidisciplinary project was born out of a revelation.

headline: A Utopian Space for Black Artists, Reimagined at MoMA
abstract: Just Above Midtown, an incubator of some of the most important Black avant-garde art of the 1970s and ’80s, is the subject of a new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Some of David Hammons’s most important early shows took place here. So did the first appearance of Lorraine O’Grady’s celebrated performance piece, “Mlle Bourgeoise Noire.” It was where Senga Nengudi debuted her sculptures of stretched-out pantyhose weighted with sand, and where Howardena Pindell first showed her abstract “dot” paintings, composed of paper chads. Musicians like Greg Tate, Lawrence (Butch) Morris and Vernon Reid jammed here. Stevie Wonder showed up at the opening. And Miles Davis, whose tailor was also in the building, would pop in from time to time.

headline: ‘Aggressive’ Northern California Wildfire Damages More Buildings
abstract: The Mosquito fire in the Sierra Nevada foothills neared Foresthill on Tuesday after cautious optimism that firefighters were gaining control.
lead_paragraph: The Mosquito fire roaring through the dry Sierra Nevada foothills northeast of Sacramento made an unexpected surge on Tuesday afternoon, hours after firefighters expressed cautious optimism that they were gaining control over the blaze.

headline: Videos Track Ukraine’s Stunning Kharkiv Offensive
abstract: Videos on social media reveal how a lightning advance by Ukrainian forces recaptured significant territory in the northern region of Kharkiv, in what is viewed as Ukraine’s biggest victory since the war started in February.
lead_paragraph: Videos on social media reveal how a lightning advance by Ukrainian forces recaptured significant territory in the northern region of Kharkiv, in what is viewed as Ukraine’s biggest victory since the war started in February.

headline: What Music to Expect at Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral
abstract: For centuries, the format of British royal funerals has largely stayed the same, with a history that tells the story of both the monarchy and music.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: New State Rules Offer Road Map for Regulating Private Hasidic Schools
abstract: The State Board of Regents on Tuesday enacted regulations aimed at holding New York private schools to minimum academic standards.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday voted for the first time to require private schools to prove they are teaching English, math and other basic subjects or risk losing government funding.

headline: The U.S. Touts Big Investments for Mexico, Testing Its Nationalist Policies
abstract: U.S. officials are looking south for a strategic partner to create a regional manufacturing hub that can rival China. But there are still doubts over Mexico’s willingness to cater to foreign industry.
