lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Biden administration officials on Monday touted the benefits that a coming wave of investment in American manufacturing could have for Mexico, saying that new factories making semiconductors, clean cars and other products in the United States could look to Mexico for raw materials and assembly.

headline: How The Times handles and confirms breaking crime news.
abstract: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
lead_paragraph: The Times often relies on the reports given by law enforcement officials in control of a crime scene during a breaking news event. These initial reports can be valuable to readers, but they also can be incomplete and even inaccurate. We let readers know what we can’t confirm, what we can and where and how we got the information. Then we work aggressively to gather a wider range of perspectives on what happened and to verify the information through public records and interviews with witnesses and victims. We also search for video recordings of the incident and verify those before publishing.

headline: New Musical From ‘Strange Loop’ Writer to Run Off Broadway
abstract: “White Girl in Danger,” a soap opera satire by Michael R. Jackson, will be staged in New York next spring by Second Stage and Vineyard theaters.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Michael R. Jackson would religiously watch soap operas with his great-aunt. “Days of Our Lives.” “Another World.” “Santa Barbara.” “The Young and the Restless.”

headline: Delaware’s Auditor Is Running for Re-election Despite a Criminal Conviction
abstract: After Kathleen K. McGuiness, the incumbent auditor, was convicted of misdemeanors, Lydia York received the state Democratic Party’s endorsement in the primary race.
lead_paragraph: Delaware has just one contested primary for a statewide office on the ballot on Tuesday: the Democratic race for auditor of accounts, an unheralded position whose holder is responsible for supervising the state’s use of taxpayer money. But the campaign is not lacking in drama.

headline: Markets plunge on higher-than-expected inflation numbers.
abstract: Stocks plummeted and government bond yields jumped higher as investors were wrong-footed by data showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
lead_paragraph: Stocks plummeted, U.S. government bond yields rocketed higher, and the dollar bounced, after fresh inflation data undermined investors’ bets over the slowing pace of inflation in August.

headline: When Schools Don’t Educate Their Students
abstract: Readers discuss an investigation into the lack of secular education at New York’s yeshivas. Also: Outdoor dining; climate-crisis deniers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Godard Taught Me How to Watch Cinema, Even as He Kept Reinventing It
abstract: Jean-Luc Godard was a prophet of film’s future as an art form, layering images and sound that the body could sink into and the mind could puzzle through.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t prepared for Jean-Luc Godard; I doubt that anyone ever was. And now that he’s gone it feels impossible to articulate the immensity of his impact on cinema, an art that he changed more than most. His influence was profound, so much so that even after his work fell out of favor and was reflexively dismissed by the lazy, and even as he himself faded (he died by assisted suicide on Tuesday at age 91), vestiges of this vexing giant, the cool guy with the dark sunglasses and cigar, remained. He was a phantom of cinema long before his death, and he will haunt us.

headline: ‘Gameboys: The Movie’ Review: An Online Relationship Gets Real
abstract: This spinoff film from a web series deals with how a young couple handles the highs and lows of a relationship during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In “Gameboys: The Movie,” the consequences and uncertainties of the pandemic are the star of the show.

headline: To Save Whales, Don’t Eat Lobster, Watchdog Group Says
abstract: The group says that the shellfish, long considered a more responsible choice, cannot be considered a guilt-free meal anymore.
lead_paragraph: American lobster may be a beloved and delicious splurge, but it is no longer a sustainable seafood choice and consumers should avoid eating it, according to Seafood Watch, a group that monitors how fish and other seafood are harvested from the world’s oceans.

headline: Bill Gates: ‘We’re in a Worse Place Than I Expected’
abstract: The philanthropist on how the pandemic and the effects of the war in Ukraine are setting back progress.
lead_paragraph: There are not many more contested abstractions in the contemporary world than progress. Are things getting better? Fast enough? For whom?

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Irritated by the Drama of Her Effort’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are both teachers. On our 10th anniversary, I suggested that we review our vows and give grades for how well we had achieved our commitments. Going line by line, we gave our ratings on vows like, “I promise to share life’s joys and to comfort you in its sorrows,” and “I promise to listen to you when I do not understand; and to trust you when I am in doubt.” David kept giving out As and A+s. “Wow,” I said, “do you really think I rated that high?” David replied, “I thought I was grading myself!” — Camille Napier Bernstein

headline: Streetwear Lands on Savile Row
abstract: Clothsurgeon, which makes bespoke streetwear for Riz Ahmed and ASAP Rocky, is a first for the fabled street.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Savile Row tends to be quiet in late August, as the financiers, oligarchs and occasional rock stars who patronize the street’s bespoke tailors are on vacation. But there was plenty of commotion at No. 40, where sartorial traditions were being gently upended and new ones were being forged.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery Faces More Rounds of Layoffs
abstract: Executives signaled that job cuts would be coming after WarnerMedia and Discovery merged in April.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Warner Bros. Discovery had a big night at the Emmy Awards. The company’s premium cable network, HBO, had the strongest night of any television outfit, claiming prizes in both the best drama (“Succession”) and limited series (“The White Lotus”) categories. And “Ted Lasso,” the Apple TV+ series produced by the Warner Bros. television studio, won for best comedy.

headline: Israel Can Do More to Prevent Civilian Casualties
abstract: An army that operates as an occupying force has a special obligation to combat the callousness that comes with controlling a hostile population over many years.
lead_paragraph: Almost four months after the popular Palestinian journalist Shireen Abu Akleh, an American citizen, was killed during an early-morning Israeli raid in Jenin, the Israel Defense Forces finally acknowledged that she was most likely shot, accidentally, by Israeli gunfire. The State Department, which had put pressure on Israel to investigate the shooting, said, “We welcome Israel’s review of this tragic incident.”

headline: Could This Political Marriage Be Saved? Biden and Obama Found a Way.
abstract: In “The Long Alliance,” Gabriel Debenedetti traces how political leaders of different generations and contrasting temperaments helped each other succeed.
lead_paragraph: In “The Long Alliance,” Gabriel Debenedetti writes that Barack Obama and Joe Biden’s nearly two-decade-long relationship “has a claim to being the most consequential of any in 21st-century politics.” That claim would seem to be a strong one. What other political relationship of this century boasts two members who have occupied the White House for nearly half of it?

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Show with Cecilia Ridgeway
abstract: A conversation with the sociologist Cecilia Ridgeway.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by Rogé Karma, with Cecilia Ridgeway. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Did Hurricanes Sandy and Ida Damage Your House or Apartment?
abstract: We want to hear the stories of people in the New York City metro area who were affected by both storms.
lead_paragraph: As the 10-year anniversary of Hurricane Sandy approaches, we are looking to speak with people who live in New York City, New Jersey, Westchester, Connecticut or Long Island about their experiences during Hurricane Sandy in 2012 and Hurricane Ida in 2021.

headline: A Life-Changing Clam Pizza
abstract: The most important pizza goings-on across New York City.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the president must deliver a State of the Union address to Congress, and by extension the American people. The New York City food equivalent might just be the State of Pizza — it’s our pastime, our passion, our favorite thing to debate after borough superiority.

headline: The Queen’s Journey Home
abstract: The state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will take place at Westminster Abbey at 11 a.m. local time on Monday. Here is a look at how the next six days will unfold.
lead_paragraph: The state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will take place at Westminster Abbey at 11 a.m. local time on Monday. Here is a look at how the next six days will unfold.

headline: How the New Climate Law Can Save You Thousands of Dollars
abstract: Rebates and tax credits can lower the cost of solar panels, energy-efficient appliances and electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The Inflation Reduction Act signed into law by President Biden in August includes about $370 billion to fight climate change, some of it in the form of tax credits and rebates to help consumers save thousands of dollars on energy-efficient appliances, plug-in vehicles and renewable electricity for their homes.

headline: At PEN America, a Complicated Centennial for Free Speech
abstract: Literary luminaries gathered in Manhattan to celebrate the organization at a moment when many see support for free speech eroding across the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: At a sold-out event on Monday in Manhattan celebrating the centenary of the free expression group PEN America, there were as many literary luminaries in the audience as there were onstage.

headline: Dawn Staley Is Still Coaching A’ja Wilson
abstract: Staley and Wilson won a college championship at South Carolina. Now the coach is a “second mother” who harps on Wilson’s game as she stars for the Las Vegas Aces in the W.N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The day still haunts A’ja Wilson.

headline: In Northern Ireland, Mourning, Yes, but Symbolism, Too
abstract: King Charles III visited Belfast and met with members of Sinn Fein, the Irish nationalist party, now the largest in the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a national tour of sorrow, King Charles III has heard many expressions of condolence for the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. But few were as tinged with symbolism as the one delivered on Tuesday by the speaker of the Northern Ireland Assembly, Alex Maskey, at a royal castle outside Belfast.

headline: Live Primary Results: Tonight’s Key Races
abstract: We’re watching the top races in tonight’s primary elections in New Hampshire, Rhode Island, and Delaware.
lead_paragraph: We’re watching the top races in tonight’s primary elections in New Hampshire, Rhode Island, and Delaware.

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash Raises Fears of Broader Conflict
abstract: The long-simmering conflict last flared in 2020, when Moscow brokered a cease-fire. Now some wonder what Russia might do next.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Fighting erupted Tuesday between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the latest flare-up in their decades-long confrontation in the South Caucasus, killing as many as 100 service members and raising the prospect of fallout from the war in Ukraine spreading instability across a wider region.

headline: Emmys Viewership Drops to a New Low
abstract: About 5.9 million people tuned in to watch the ceremony, according to Nielsen.
lead_paragraph: The Oscars, Grammys and Tonys all had viewership gains this year, reversing recent declines.

headline: Ken Starr, Independent Counsel in Clinton Investigation, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Starr’s investigation into President Clinton’s affair with a former White House intern propelled issues of sex and morality to the center of American life for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ken Starr, the independent counsel whose investigation uncovered a White House sex scandal that riveted the nation and led to President Bill Clinton’s impeachment for lying under oath and obstructing justice, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Houston. He was 76.

headline: Russia Secretly Gave $300 Million to Political Parties and Officials Worldwide, U.S. Says
abstract: A U.S. intelligence review found that Russian agencies and figures aimed to exert political influence abroad and sway elections on behalf of the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has covertly given at least $300 million to political parties, officials and politicians in more than two dozen countries since 2014, and plans to transfer hundreds of millions more, with the goal of exerting political influence and swaying elections, according to a State Department summary of a recent U.S. intelligence review.

headline: How a Proposed 15-Week Abortion Ban Compares With State Laws
abstract: A proposed federal ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would stop short of some states’ limits on the procedure but would upend the longtime standard in most others.
lead_paragraph: A proposed federal ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would stop short of some states’ limits on the procedure but would upend the longtime standard in most others.

headline: Patching With Olivier Theyskens
abstract: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: A Bollywood Favorite Is Remade for the Stage, Raising Eyebrows
abstract: Some have taken issue with the reframing of the musical, which now focuses on the love story of an Indian American woman and a white American man.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — It is one of the most successful Bollywood movies of all time. Though released in 1995, it still plays daily at a movie theater in Mumbai. Its songs are a mainstay at weddings. Its lead actors became Bollywood superstars. And now “Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge,” or “DDLJ,” has hit the stage.

headline: Trafficked Teenager Who Killed One of Her Abusers Ordered to Pay Restitution
abstract: Pieper Lewis was 15 years old when, according to court documents, the man sheltering her forced her to have sex with other men for money. She stabbed one abuser 30 times.
lead_paragraph: Pieper Lewis was a 15-year-old repeat runaway in Des Moines in 2020 when, her lawyers say, she was taken in by a man who trafficked her for sex. She stabbed one of her abusers 30 times, killing him.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin and Xi Prepare to Meet
abstract: Plus a kangaroo killed a man in Australia and “Squid Game” made history at the Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin, the president of Russia, is preparing to meet with Xi Jinping, the leader of China, at an in-person summit in Uzbekistan later this week. The conversation comes at a time of weakness for both autocratic leaders as Russia suffers losses in Ukraine and China endures an economic slowdown.

headline: When Will We Know Who Won in Delaware, New Hampshire and Rhode Island?
abstract: Votes have historically been counted quickly in all three states that are holding primaries on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The last votes of the midterm primary season will be cast on Tuesday in Delaware, New Hampshire and Rhode Island, and we have good news for those of you who like sleep: All three states have a track record of counting votes quickly, and while nothing is ever guaranteed in close races, chances are high we’ll know who won on election night.

headline: Biden Celebrates Inflation Reduction Act as Price Pressures Remain High
abstract: The Consumer Price Index report for August showed inflation had not cooled as the administration had hoped and Americans had lost buying power over the last year as prices rose faster than wages.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index report for August showed inflation had not cooled as the administration had hoped and Americans had lost buying power over the last year as prices rose faster than wages.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.S. Rebukes Russia for Claims of Secret Bioweapons in Ukraine
abstract: Russia used a formal meeting in Geneva to air its unsupported accusations but faced considerable diplomatic pushback.
lead_paragraph: The State Department strongly criticized Russia on Tuesday for making what it called “spurious allegations” that the United States operated clandestine biological weapons laboratories in Ukraine.

headline: Starbucks Shares Shift in Strategy, to Automation and Expansion
abstract: The coffee giant intends to speed up drink-making and open thousands of additional locations in China over the next three years.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks provided a window into its much-anticipated “reinvention” strategy on Tuesday, highlighting automations it plans to begin using over the next three years that will get food and drink orders to customers faster while cutting down on the work done by employees. It also pointed to high-growth markets like China, where it intends to open thousands of additional stores.

headline: Do You Know Someone Who Has Died of Covid Recently? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: New York Times reporters are looking for people who will share the stories and experiences of loved ones who have recently died.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 400 Americans are still dying from Covid-19 each day — a number that federal health officials say is unacceptable, on top of more than one million previous deaths from the virus. At the same time, a new and updated coronavirus vaccine has just become available, and the Biden administration is embarking on another campaign to persuade Americans to get their Covid shots.

headline: Sobering Inflation Report Dampens Biden’s Claims of Economic Progress
abstract: The president is trying once again to accentuate the positives in the recovery from recession, but stubbornly high prices are complicating the message.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden gathered with top Democrats at the White House on Tuesday to celebrate their inflation fight at an inopportune moment, as a sobering new report showed just how far the economy still has to go to bring soaring consumer prices under control.

headline: Woman Gets 4 Months After Shoving Flight Attendant, Spitting on a Passenger
abstract: Kelly Pichardo, 32, will also have to pay more than $9,000 to American Airlines for the altercation, which came as incidents involving unruly passengers unnerved airline workers and the public.
lead_paragraph: A New York woman was sentenced to four months in federal prison after spitting on a passenger, then shoving a flight attendant on an American Airlines flight in February 2021, a year that saw a record number of incidents of unruly and violent behavior on airplanes.

headline: Montana Restricts Changes to Birth Certificates for Transgender People
abstract: A new rule made it “virtually impossible” for transgender people born in Montana to amend the gender listed on their birth certificates, according to the American Civil Liberties Union of Montana.
lead_paragraph: Transgender people born in Montana will no longer be able to change the sex listed on their birth certificate to accurately reflect their identity under a new state rule that is among the most restrictive in the country, according to transgender rights groups.

headline: Vogue Builds a World
abstract: In the former meatpacking district, Anna Wintour staged a commercial extravaganza with one eye on global domination.
lead_paragraph: The ornery, enduring truth about New York City is that it’s all always right here — the talent, the beauty, the energy, the vitality, the smarts, the grit and the peerless cinematic backdrop of what the director Milos Forman once called “the only city which in reality looks better than on the postcards.” All that’s needed to bring it together is a focus and a frame.

headline: Rhode Island Secretary of State Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Rhode Island primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Rhode Island primary elections.

headline: Rhode Island Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Rhode Island primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Rhode Island primary elections.

headline: West Virginia Passes Strict Abortion Ban
abstract: The bill, which has some exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the mother, will go into effect immediately if the governor signs it.
lead_paragraph: West Virginia on Tuesday became the latest state to pass a near-total ban on abortion, with the two chambers of the Legislature reaching a compromise after deadlocking on the terms earlier this summer.

headline: America’s Dueling Realities on a Key Question: Is the Economy Good or Bad?
abstract: Ben Casselman, an economics correspondent for The New York Times, unpacks the numbers.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing Democrats and Republicans absolutely cannot and never will agree on as the November midterms approach, it’s whether the U.S. economy is good or bad right now.

headline: Ukraine’s Achievement Is Biden’s, Too
abstract: As Russian troops flee their positions, now is the time to press the military advantage.
lead_paragraph: This column is rarely short of criticism of the Biden administration. So let me loudly cheer the fact that the staggering gains Ukrainian forces have made against Russia are a victory for Joe Biden, too.

headline: Tiny Memoir Contest for Students: Write a 100-Word Personal Narrative
abstract: We invite teenagers to tell a true story about a meaningful life experience in just 100 words. Contest dates: Sept. 14 to Oct. 12.
lead_paragraph: As we have since 2019, we’re inviting students to write a short, powerful story about a meaningful experience from their lives, but this year there’s a twist: They must do it in 100 words or fewer.

headline: What a High-Risk Pregnancy Looks Like After Dobbs
abstract: The photographer Stephanie Sinclair captured the newly unsettled world inside the Cleveland Clinic, where Ohio’s abortion laws have drastically changed maternal care.
lead_paragraph: Pregnancy can be dangerous — occasionally fatal — for both women and the fetuses they hope to deliver. Fetal conditions, like a nonviable twin that threatens the health of its sibling, can also imperil the mother. So can disorders like cancer, heart disease, kidney dysfunction, diabetes and lupus. Even something as straightforward as age — becoming pregnant when younger than 17 or older than 35 — or carrying twins or having a history of multiple miscarriages can put women and pregnancies in jeopardy. That’s why so many obstetricians regard the ability to terminate a pregnancy as essential: Doctors need access to abortion procedures to be able to provide care and save lives.

headline: Putin Will Make People Choose Between Heating and Eating This Winter
abstract: To defeat petro-Putinism in Europe, U.S. energy policy has to be the arsenal of democracy.
lead_paragraph: While some Russian soldiers in Ukraine are voting with their feet against Vladimir Putin’s shameful war, their hasty retreat doesn’t mean that Putin is surrendering. Last week, in fact, he opened a whole new front — on energy. Putin thinks he’s found a cold war that he can win. He’s going to try to literally freeze the European Union this winter by choking off supplies of Russian gas and oil to pressure the E.U. into abandoning Ukraine.

headline: What Story From Your Life Can You Tell in 100 Words?
abstract: To accompany our 100-Word Narrative Contest, we’re inviting you to experiment here. What small, meaningful moment can you share?
lead_paragraph: What small moments from your childhood will you always remember?

headline: In Reclaimed Towns, Ukrainians Recount a Frantic Russian Retreat
abstract: Residents of towns recently retaken by Ukraine described a chaotic flight by disorganized Russian troops, suggesting morale and inexperience remain major problems for Russia.
lead_paragraph: BALAKLIYA, Ukraine — The signs of desperation were everywhere. Abandoned military vehicles. Cans of food and dishes left on tables. Mail scattered on office floors. Clothes left hanging on lines.

headline: A Day of Firsts for Peltola in Congress Starts a Sprint to Another Election
abstract: Representative Mary Peltola was sworn in as the first Alaska Native and first woman to represent her state in the House. She has eight weeks before she faces voters again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She picked up the new office keys and the special lapel pin that grants her unfettered access in the Capitol. In between meetings and interviews, she navigated coronavirus protocols to attend her first event at the White House.

headline: How to Write a 100-Word Narrative: A Guide for Our Tiny Memoir Contest
abstract: Step-by-step directions for telling a meaningful, interesting and short true story from your life — with 25 mentor texts to help.
lead_paragraph: Can you tell a meaningful and interesting true story from your life in just 100 words? That’s the challenge we’ve posed to teenagers this fall with our 100-Word Personal Narrative Contest, and in this guide we’ll not only prove that you can, but we’ll walk you through steps that can help make your submission sing.

headline: Philadelphia Prosecutor Is Found in Contempt by State Representatives
abstract: Larry Krasner, a liberal district attorney under fire for the city’s rising crime rate, has refused to comply with subpoenas from a committee investigating his possible impeachment.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to hold Philadelphia’s liberal chief prosecutor, Larry Krasner, in contempt for refusing to cooperate with a legislative committee investigating his possible impeachment.

headline: Republicans Struggle to Unite Party Around National Abortion Restrictions
abstract: A new proposal was intended to align Republicans on abortion policy before the midterm elections. It only exposed divisions.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, anti-abortion activists and their Republican allies have been quietly seeking to rally their party around a single platform on abortion, hoping to settle divisions and blunt political damage from an issue with growing potency in the midterm elections.

headline: New York City Denied Dozens of Men Shelter Beds, Legal Aid Says
abstract: The arrival of thousands of migrants this summer has stretched the shelter system to the breaking point.
lead_paragraph: New York City failed its obligation to house the homeless on Monday night when at least 60 men, many of them migrant asylum seekers, were denied beds at shelters, the Legal Aid Society said.

headline: Deaths of 3 Children on Coney Island Ruled Homicides by Drowning
abstract: Police officials, who had questioned their mother, said no one had been charged in the deaths Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of three children who were discovered unconscious along the Brooklyn shoreline this week have been ruled homicides, the medical examiner’s office in New York City said on Tuesday.

headline: After a Wave of Subpoenas, Notes of Caution About the Jan. 6 Investigation
abstract: The criminal inquiry into Donald Trump’s efforts to reverse the outcome of the 2020 election appears to be accelerating, but prosecutors are said to be a long way from making any decisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From outside the walls of the Justice Department, the sprawling investigation into efforts to reverse the outcome of the 2020 election seems only to be accelerating, with prosecutors last week subpoenaing about 40 associates of former President Donald J. Trump and seizing phones from at least two of his aides.

headline: Mary Peltola Is Sworn In as a Congresswoman
abstract: Representative Mary Peltola, a Democrat, became the first Alaska Native to serve in Congress and the first woman to represent her state in the House.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mary Peltola, a Democrat, became the first Alaska Native to serve in Congress and the first woman to represent her state in the House.

headline: Starbucks Union Leader Says Company Forced Her Out
abstract: Jaz Brisack said her employer had refused to accommodate her scheduling requests. Starbucks said it sought to balance requests against business needs.
lead_paragraph: A Starbucks employee in Buffalo who has helped lead the union campaign at the coffee chain over the past year has accused the company of forcing her out in retaliation for her organizing efforts.

headline: N.Y. Elections Commissioner Charged in Absentee Ballot Scheme
abstract: Jason Schofield, a Republican in Rensselaer County, was accused of unlawfully requesting absentee ballots in the 2021 local election.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — A Rensselaer County elections official was arraigned on Tuesday, accused by federal authorities of fraudulently obtaining absentee ballots last year, using personal information of voters without their consent.

headline: Biden Flies Home to Wilmington to Vote in Delaware Primary
abstract: The president and the first lady arrived in Delaware shortly before polls closed to cast their votes in Tuesday’s primary election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday evening, President Biden voted. The process involved a hasty announcement to the press, multiple motorcades and two jet flights.

headline: New Hampshire Governor Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the New Hampshire primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the New Hampshire primary elections.

abstract: See full results and maps from the New Hampshire primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the New Hampshire primary elections.

abstract: See full results and maps from the Delaware primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Delaware primary elections.

headline: Delaware Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Delaware primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Delaware primary elections.

headline: Seth Magaziner, the Rhode Island treasurer, wins a Democratic House primary in the state.
abstract: In November, Mr. Magaziner will face Allan Fung, the former mayor of Cranston, R.I., in what could be one of the most competitive House races in New England.
lead_paragraph: Seth Magaziner, the general treasurer of Rhode Island, won a crowded Democratic congressional primary in the state on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, and is now headed into what could be one of the most competitive general elections on New England’s House map.

headline: Victim’s Sister Recalls the Pain of Alex Jones’s Sandy Hook Lies
abstract: The Infowars fabulist and his followers intensified their fear and trauma, Sandy Hook survivors say on the first day of a critical trial.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the trial of Alex Jones.

headline: Package Explodes at Northeastern U. in Boston, Injuring an Employee
abstract: A second package was rendered safe by the bomb squad, and the 45-year-old victim was taken to an area hospital with a minor hand injury, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A package exploded inside a campus building at Northeastern University on Tuesday night, injuring an employee and spreading fear among Boston’s many college campuses, the police said.

headline: Punster
abstract: Take a pleasant journey through Michael Dewey’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Wednesday, solvers! Today’s puzzle is brought to us by the constructor Michael Dewey, who is making his first appearance in the New York Times Crossword since 2016 (and his 7th appearance since his debut in 2012).

headline: McKee, Rhode Island’s Governor, Wins Democratic Nomination
abstract: Gov. Daniel McKee, a Democrat who took over for Gina Raimondo last year, overcame four challengers in a hard-fought primary with a focus on his pandemic leadership.
lead_paragraph: Daniel McKee, the governor of Rhode Island, has secured the Democratic nomination to run for his first full term in office, according to The Associated Press. Mr. McKee, 71, overcame four challengers in a hard-fought primary with a focus on his leadership through the Covid-19 pandemic and the economic recovery.

headline: Leavitt Upsets Mowers, Winning New Hampshire House G.O.P. Primary
abstract: Karoline Leavitt, a 25-year-old hard-right Republican, prevailed over the presumed front-runner after a race that devolved into a slugfest over the MAGA mantle.
lead_paragraph: Karoline Leavitt, a 25-year-old hard-right Republican who served as an assistant in President Donald J. Trump’s White House press office, won her party’s nomination on Tuesday for New Hampshire’s First Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘He’s Pretty Serious About Being Funny’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Sept. 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “My agent was like, ‘You can’t write a sequel to a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, that’s just not seemly.’”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 14, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the struggles of the city of Yining, China, during a monthlong lockdown to control the coronavirus misstated the daily Covid case numbers for the Ili region. The correct figures for the pertinent days are two, nine and 28, not four, 20 and 67.

headline: Shorting the Receiver Market, the Packers and Cowboys Bet Wrong
abstract: Aaron Rodgers isn’t the only quarterback who is missing his former wideouts. Just the angriest.
lead_paragraph: For want of a reliable wide receiver, the Dallas Cowboys’ season was lost.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Falling Russian morale.
lead_paragraph: As the Ukrainian army closed in, the Russian army fled the town of Balakliya in northeastern Ukraine, leaving a trail of desperation and disarray in its wake. Ukraine’s lightning assault has allowed its military to recapture hundreds of square miles of territory, strategic towns and abandoned weapons.

headline: Federal Investigation Into Colorado Clerk Reaches MyPillow’s Mike Lindell
abstract: The prominent promoter of 2020 election conspiracy theories said the F.B.I. had seized his cellphone and asked him about his ties to an indicted county clerk.
lead_paragraph: When federal agents seized the cellphone of Mike Lindell, the founder of MyPillow, in the drive-though line of a fast-food restaurant in Minnesota on Tuesday, it was a clear indication that the Justice Department had intensified its interest in a state case against a Colorado county clerk accused of tampering with voting machines.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Studies Trump’s Golfless Golf Course Gathering
abstract: “Yeah, Trump was smart. He was like, ‘How about nine of us meet on the green with no clubs, so it doesn’t look suspicious?’” Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: inimical
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word inimical has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 13 in “The Man Who Finally Made a ‘Dune’ That Fans Will Love” by Helen Macdonald:

headline: Britain’s Inflation Rate Slows Slightly to 9.9 Percent
abstract: But prices are still rising at about the fastest pace in 40 years, and an increase in core inflation will keep the pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Consumer prices in Britain rose 9.9 percent in August from a year earlier, a slight easing of the inflation rate and the first decline in nearly a year, signaling that inflation may have reached its peak, or be very near it.

headline: Who Won and Lost in New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Delaware
abstract: Here is a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses.
lead_paragraph: The primary season ended on Tuesday with elections in New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Delaware.

headline: Annoying Noises
abstract: What sounds do you hate?
lead_paragraph: Chewing, slurping, knuckle-cracking, pen-tapping — are there any sounds that you just can’t stand? Describe them in detail, and as best you can in words.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: From the Amazon to Patagonia: One Bureau Chief’s Terrain
abstract: The Times correspondent Jack Nicas covers Latin America’s largest nation and four of its neighbors. Sometimes, several countries call for his attention at once.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of a nine-day reporting trip in Chile, three days before voters there would reject a proposed new constitution in a national plebiscite, Jack Nicas learned that there had been an assassination attempt on the most prominent politician in Argentina, Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner. So he spent a day and a half reporting on the fallout in Argentina from Santiago, the Chilean capital, before returning to the plebiscite in Chile. After voters rejected the new charter on Sept. 4, Mr. Nicas flew to Rio de Janeiro and resumed reporting on next month’s closely watched presidential election in Brazil.

headline: An Oily Challenge: Evict Stinky Old Furnaces in Favor of Heat Pumps
abstract: Building by building, New York and other cities are trying to stop the age-old use of fossil fuels to heat homes and buildings. In the U.S., new climate laws aim to speed things up.
lead_paragraph: For years, Tami Nelson struggled with what she called the “temperamental old man” in the basement. He was inefficient. He was smelly. Plus, he took way too much of her money.

headline: How Fierce Primaries, Abortion and Inflation Transformed the 2022 Map
abstract: Democrats enter the final sprint to November more optimistic than expected, especially in the race for the Senate. But Republicans remain bullish that they can sweep into a House majority.
lead_paragraph: A grueling primary season riven by Republican infighting and the interventions of former President Donald J. Trump finally ended on Tuesday with a slate of G.O.P. candidates that has raised Democratic hopes of preserving Senate control and a political atmosphere that has changed strikingly over the past six months.

headline: For the Very Rich, $3,200 a Night is a ‘Prototypical’ New York Experience
abstract: Life in a hotel for the $30,000-a-day crowd. Also, ex-Gov. Cuomo continues his campaign against harassment charges.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll get a glimpse of a $3,200-a-night hotel room. We’ll also look at the ethics complaint that former Gov. Andrew Cuomo filed against the state attorney general, Letitia James.

headline: China’s Leader Emerges From Covid Bubble for First Foreign Trip Since 2020
abstract: Xi Jinping, who is expected to meet with Vladimir Putin, will seek to project confidence as a global statesman at a time of grave challenges at home.
lead_paragraph: After spending all of the pandemic hunkered down in China, Xi Jinping, the country’s leader, finally stepped outside its borders on Wednesday for the first time in more than two years, making a short visit to Central Asia to project himself as a global statesman and engage in the sort of diplomacy that can’t be done by video call.

headline: Painting the Town Blood-Red
abstract: In “The Village Idiot,” Steve Stern resurrects Chaim Soutine and the sordid eccentricities of his milieu.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, Chaim Soutine did not like to bathe. The painter lived in protest of “all the vain hygienic practices favored by our century,” according to his gallerist Paul Guillaume. “It is an article of faith to him that ablution is a heresy.”

headline: China Is Running Covert Operations That Could Seriously Overwhelm Us
abstract: The West isn’t nearly prepared enough for the scale and complexity of China’s all-of-nation covert offensive.
lead_paragraph: In my three-decade career with Britain’s Secret Intelligence Service, China was never seen as a major threat.

headline: These Romantics Celebrated the Self, to a Fault
abstract: “Magnificent Rebels,” by Andrea Wulf, paints a vivid portrait of the 18th-century German Romantics: brilliant intellectuals and poets who could also be petty, thin-skinned and self-involved.
lead_paragraph: The grand title of Andrea Wulf’s new book is wonderfully sneaky — at least that’s how I chose to read it, considering that “Magnificent Rebels” happens to recount plenty of unmagnificent squabbling among a coterie of extremely fallible humans.

headline: Why Can’t I Stop Watching This Cute Video About Animal Motherhood?
abstract: I know I shouldn’t be taken in. But then again, the way that sloth hugs her baby …
lead_paragraph: One thing I like best about marriage is that I always have someone to trade memes with. For me, that person is my husband. The memes he sends are accompanied by words that these days are devoid of meaning. “Incredible,” he’ll type. “IMPORTANT.” “Would.” Sometimes I don’t even click through. Last week, when he sent me a 34-second video of a mother sloth being reunited with her baby in Costa Rica, he wrote, “Unfortunately I liked this.” I get it: Every time I watch this video, I experience what I’m embarrassed to admit is a physical ache. The way the mom sloth looks over her shoulder is viscerally, painfully poignant (though it might just be because she’s moving so slowly). When the baby catches her eyes, she looks taken aback with recognition. “Oh, it’s you,” she seems to say, and you can hear the baby chirping as it is helped aloft by a disembodied human hand. Then, as the viewer’s breath is inevitably caught in his or her chest, the hand reaches up with the palm-size three-fingered sloth, and the mother sloth reaches out with her unwieldy claws to gather the baby to herself, safe at last with its arms around her neck.

headline: How to Make the Best Miso Soup of Your Life
abstract: Secrets from a chef who has a lifetime of experience with the dish.
lead_paragraph: Seiji Ando never had to learn how to make miso soup. In Japan, it was the kind of thing they taught in elementary school. But as far as he can remember, he never really had to learn because he just always knew. His father and his grandfather were chefs who owned a sushi restaurant in Osaka, so he was around miso soup often growing up. At home, it was breakfast every morning; at his father’s restaurant, it was an after-school snack.

headline: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
abstract: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the story of the American feminist movement seemed like a progression of hard-won gains: Title IX, Roe v. Wade, the Violence Against Women Act, #MeToo. But in a post-“lean in” and post-Roe America, the momentum seems to have reversed, leaving some feminists to wonder: What are we fighting for? And who is in that fight?

headline: A 10-Year-Old Refugee Has Met a Million People. How Will New York Welcome Her?
abstract: She invites us to remember the big idea on which the city was built. And what the city still aspires to.
lead_paragraph: Little Amal, a 10-year-old Syrian girl, left the Syrian-Turkish border in July 2021. She journeyed throughout Europe and met a million people on her quest to find safety and a better life. She was unaccompanied, like so many other refugee children who have lost their parents. She is also a 12-foot-tall puppet.

headline: Why Aren’t You Voting in Your Financial Self-Interest?
abstract: The conflict between elites and populists may not be what it seems.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of Americans on both the right and the left ignore their own economic self-interest when they choose which political party to support?

headline: How Yiyun Li Became a Beacon for Readers in Mourning
abstract: The novelist Yiyun Li, known for her powerful distillations of personal grief, makes art from subverted expectations.
lead_paragraph: As a teenager growing up in Communist China, the expatriate novelist Yiyun Li discovered her gift for writing propaganda. She would channel language through the rhetorical modes of the great patriotic writers she had studied in school, spooling out long, moving passages embroidered with beautiful clichés about boats returning to the motherland. “There were moments in life when I would be performing those public speeches, knowing that I did not trust anything I said,” she told me as we sat in the cool shadow of a library at Princeton University, where Li teaches creative writing. She remembers gazing out at her audience after giving a patriotic speech and witnessing, with some horror, the tears on their faces: She couldn’t believe how deeply they believed her.

headline: ‘Disaster Mode’: Emergency Rooms Across Canada Close Amid Crisis
abstract: A nationwide shortage of nurses has caused dozens of emergency rooms across Canada to close temporarily and forced some patients to wait days for a bed.
lead_paragraph: One night in March, an understaffed hospital in Red Lake, a tiny town in northwestern Ontario, took the drastic step of shutting down its emergency department. Road signs bearing the ‘H’ symbol to guide drivers along the 60-mile route toward the hospital were covered up. The next hospital was more than two hours away.

headline: In New York City, Pandemic Job Losses Linger
abstract: Even as the country as a whole has recovered all of the jobs it lost during the pandemic, the city is still missing 176,000 — the slowest recovery of any major metropolitan area.
lead_paragraph: The darkest days of the pandemic are far behind New York City. Masks are coming off, Times Square is packed with tourists and Midtown Manhattan lunch spots have growing lines of workers in business suits. Walking around the city, it often feels like 2019 again.

headline: Read Your Way Through Helsinki
abstract: Pajtim Statovci shares his love of Finnish literature and the books that helped him, a child of immigrants, to find his voice and grow from reader to award-winning writer.
lead_paragraph: Finns love to read: It’s their favorite thing to do in their time off. The country is a little smaller than Montana, but its library network is extensive, with hundreds of central libraries, branch libraries and mobile libraries.

headline: Social Security’s Cost-of-Living Increase Will Be Largest in Four Decades, an Estimate Says
abstract: Retirees will learn the amount of the increase for 2023 in October, and the current estimate is that it will be 8.7%.
lead_paragraph: More than 70 million Americans who receive Social Security benefits can expect an inflation adjustment to their monthly checks next year that will be the largest in four decades.

headline: Hermès Bags and Millions in Cash: The Fall of Malaysia’s Najib Razak
abstract: The former prime minister and his wife were once seen as untouchable. Now, both have been found guilty in connection with the 1MDB financial scandal.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia —The former prime minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, arrived in a black sport utility vehicle and was taken into the courthouse through a back door. Dozens of prison guards and police officers, some heavily armed, escorted him into a fifth-floor courtroom this month for his second trial on corruption charges.

headline: Little Dresses for Big Nights
abstract: Giorgia Tordini and Gilda Ambrosio, the founders of the Attico, tread the line between sexy, campy and chic.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to out-dress a room decked in leopard-print carpeting, leopard-print walls and red velvet banquets. But on Thursday night the crowd managed to upstage the décor at the Nines, the piano bar and supper club in the NoHo neighborhood of Manhattan that is named for its address — 9 Great Jones Street — and its to-the-nines attitude.

headline: Text Messaging Is Cool. But Where Are Its Boundaries?
abstract: Apple and Google have added useful features to texting apps, yet the apps still lack a major component: an effective way to set limits.
lead_paragraph: The text-messaging app has always been the most-used app on my phone. It’s fun and efficient, and it’s often a quicker way to get a response than sending an email or making a phone call.

headline: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
abstract: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
lead_paragraph: In addition to granting new political hope to Democrats, the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade has clarified the ground of public argument about abortion. As abortion-rights supporters have pressed their sudden political momentum, three pro-choice arguments have loomed particularly large: an argument about abortion in life-threatening circumstances; an argument about the unique physical costs of pregnancy in general; and an argument for the virtues of the Roe-era cultural status quo.

headline: Durham Inquiry Appears to Wind Down as Grand Jury Expires
abstract: The special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to examine the Russia investigation seems to be wrapping up its work with no further charges in store.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When John H. Durham was assigned by the Justice Department in 2019 to examine the origins of the investigation into the 2016 Trump campaign’s ties to Russia, President Donald J. Trump and his supporters expressed a belief that the inquiry would prove that a “deep state” conspiracy including top Obama-era officials had worked to sabotage him.

headline: A Uyghur Author and Translator Were Detained. Now, Their Novel Speaks For Them.
abstract: Writing and translating “The Backstreets,” a book about the oppressive environment faced by Uyghurs in China, was a danger to those involved.
lead_paragraph: Perhat Tursun was eager for his novel, “The Backstreets,” to come out in the United States. It would be the first Uyghur novel to appear in English, and he considered the grim tale of one man’s struggle within an oppressive environment one of his most consequential works.

headline: The Essential Judy Blume
abstract: For 50 years, her books have educated, entertained and connected young readers. Whether you want to revisit a classic or inspire a new fan, here’s what to read.
lead_paragraph: In the library of my elementary school, there were orange-carpeted steps where you could lounge in your OshKosh B’Gosh overalls while consulting the World Book Encyclopedia for your report on Warren G. Harding. Once you had amassed enough index cards to complete an outline, you’d stroll over to the fiction section. There, beneath coat-hanger mobiles spinning lazily from track lighting, you’d run your finger along a cool metal shelf — no need to consult the card catalog, this was familiar territory — until you came upon an oft-revisited, much-handled paperback of “Forever,” by Judy Blume.

headline: Six Lyrics That Show Why ‘Hamilton’ Is Tough to Translate
abstract: A direct transfer of words was never going to work for such a complex show. So the team involved got creative.
lead_paragraph: How does one translate “Hamilton” into another language? That was the challenge facing Sera Finale, a rapper-turned-songwriter, and Kevin Schroeder, a seasoned musical theater translator, when they were asked to collaborate on a German version of the show — the first in a language other than English.

headline: Braving the Winds on a Greek Isle
abstract: ‘We had been expecting Tinos’s famous Meltemi, the seasonal and often fierce northern winds that blow through the islands in the summer, to cool us down after a suffocating Roman heat wave. But not this.’
lead_paragraph: We arrived in Tinos at night and the wind hit us full blast. It was hard to breathe, like when you’re a kid and you stick your head out the back window of a speeding car. The rows of broom grass shrubs on the rental property pointed at us, horizontal. Airborne grains of sand and dirt stung our shins.

headline: Gravel Biking Is Picking Up Speed
abstract: A faster bicycle design with thicker tires is allowing cyclists to explore America’s 2.2 million miles of Here’s what you need to know about this new sport.
lead_paragraph: Early in the pandemic, Shequaya Bailey bought a gravel bike. She’d been an avid road cyclist for years, and was even the president of the Pittsburgh Major Taylor Cycling Club, but she wanted to try something new.

headline: Living In ... Dutch Kills, Queens
abstract: Sandwiched between Astoria and Long Island City — and often overlooked because of it — this formerly sleepy industrial area is looking at big changes.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiched between Astoria and Long Island City — and often overlooked because of it — this formerly sleepy industrial area is looking at big changes.

headline: The Mystery Behind the Crime Wave at 312 Riverside Drive
abstract: For years, the police have received thousands of 911 calls reporting fights, murders, bombs and hostage situations at the same address. But officers never find victims or make arrests. Why?
lead_paragraph: “New York City 911,” the emergency dispatcher answered. “Do you need police, fire or medical?”

headline: Dutch Kills, Queens: Low-Key and Low-Slung, but Not for Much Longer
abstract: Sandwiched between Astoria and Long Island City — and often overlooked because of it — this formerly sleepy industrial area is looking at big changes.
lead_paragraph: During the height of the pandemic, when city sidewalks seemed especially dirty, residents of Dutch Kills, a neighborhood in northwestern Queens, awoke one day to an unusual sight: Hanging on fences around fallow construction sites and on the sides of hotels that had seen better days were more than two dozen bright-yellow brooms. Some had signs urging, “Let’s come together to clean.”

headline: How Nonbinary Runners are Winning Inclusion in Major Marathons
abstract: Five of the six largest marathons in the world will soon allow runners to compete without registering as men or women. The London Marathon changed its policy on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As the oldest annually contested marathon in the world, the Boston Marathon often sets standards in the world of running. So when the Boston Athletic Association, the race’s organizer, announced this week that it would invite nonbinary athletes to compete next year without having to register in the men’s or women’s divisions, it sent a signal to runners like Cal Calamia.

headline: They Translated ‘Hamilton’ Into German. Was It Easy? Nein.
abstract: For the musical’s Hamburg premiere, a team wrestled with language and cultural differences to bring the story alive for a new audience.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — “Hamilton” is a mouthful, even in English. Forty-seven songs; more than 20,000 words; fast-paced lyrics, abundant wordplay, complex rhyming patterns, plus allusions not only to hip-hop and musical theater but also to arcane aspects of early American history.

headline: Where the New Climate Law Means More Drilling, Not Less
abstract: A compromise built into the law ensures oil and gas leasing in the Gulf of Mexico for the next decade. Activists say the region has been “sacrificed” to fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: HOUMA, La. — Justin Solet planted his foot on the edge of his camouflage green boat in Bayou Chauvin and pointed to a natural gas rig protruding from the waters ahead. A web of pipelines and rusted storage tanks jutted up from the marsh behind him as a shrimp boat floated past and markers for crab traps bobbed on the water’s surface.

headline: How a Spreader of Voter Fraud Conspiracy Theories Became a Star
abstract: For more than a decade, Catherine Engelbrecht, a Texas mom turned election-fraud crusader, has sown doubts about ballots and voting. Her patience has paid off.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Catherine Engelbrecht appeared at a Tea Party Patriots convention in Phoenix to deliver a dire warning.

headline: Ben Sinclair Gets Spiritual
abstract: The actor and writer examined — and smelled — himself with a community of seekers in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Ben Sinclair was on a houseboat in the Rockaways section of Queens shooting an episode of “High Maintenance” — the HBO show he starred in and helped create — when he found a copy of “Be Here Now,” the 1971 book that sold millions of copies and helped introduce Eastern spiritual ideas to the American counterculture.

headline: An Old Finca With New Life on Ibiza
abstract: This updated six-bedroom country home in the center of Ibiza, one of the Balearic Islands of Spain, is on the market for $4.65 million.
lead_paragraph: This updated six-bedroom country home in the center of Ibiza, one of the Balearic Islands of Spain, is on the market for $4.65 million.

headline: House Hunting in Spain: An Updated Finca With Guesthouse on Ibiza
abstract: The Balearic Islands archipelago was Spain’s most-visited province last year, with international buyers arriving to compete for a range of homes.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom country home sits on more than 12 forested acres on a dirt road in the center of Ibiza, one of the Balearic Islands of Spain in the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: What It Took for Stella Levi to Talk About the Holocaust
abstract: How a chance meeting with one of the last Jews of Rhodes changed me.
lead_paragraph: There is something unique about the way cataclysms are preserved in oral histories. In his 1936 essay “The Storyteller,” Walter Benjamin draws a distinction between the printed novel and the oral tale, where experience is “passed from one mouth to the next.” The direct line of transmission is significant: The story you hear from a living witness embeds itself into the mechanisms of memory, as I’ve learned firsthand, like no other. And yet such a transmission poses certain challenging considerations. Is a human being defined by the worst, most tragic thing that happens in her life? Should it carry more importance than the periods that bracket it? What does it mean to be the person who shares this particular heirloom?

headline: Was Elizabeth the Queen of America? This Week It Seemed Like It.
abstract: More than two centuries after Americans fought for freedom from the British crown, their descendants are absorbed by the latest chapter in the royal family’s drama.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Biden will be there; Putin won’t: The funeral guest list is coming together.
abstract: President Biden plans to be there, as do many leaders from the Commonwealth.
lead_paragraph: Presidents, princes and prime ministers from across the globe are expected to travel to London over the coming days to pay their respects to Queen Elizabeth II, history’s second-longest-reigning monarch.

headline: Irene Papas, Actress in ‘Zorba,’ ‘Z’ and Greek Tragedies, Is Dead at 96
abstract: She was best known for commanding movie roles in the 1960s but received the greatest plaudits for playing heroines of the ancient stage.
lead_paragraph: Irene Papas, a Greek actress who starred in films like “Z,” “Zorba the Greek” and “The Guns of Navarone” but who won the greatest acclaim of her career playing the heroines of Greek tragedy, died on Wednesday. She was 96.

headline: The College Pricing Game
abstract: In the wake of student debt relief, an exploration of how higher education costs became such a complex issue.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden canceled college debt last month, he left untouched the problem that created that debt: the soaring price of college.

headline: E.U. Scores Major Legal Victory Against Google
abstract: A court rejected Google’s appeal of a record-setting antitrust fine related to Android and online search.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Global efforts to crimp the power of the world’s largest technology companies scored an important legal victory on Wednesday when a European Union court gave its blessing to a record multibillion-dollar fine issued against Google in 2018.

headline: Poverty, Plunging
abstract: Child poverty in the U.S. has fallen by more than half since the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: When President Bill Clinton signed a bipartisan bill tightening the rules around welfare eligibility in 1996 — and making many benefits conditional on work — critics on the political left predicted terrible effects.

headline: A Danish royal who mourns her friend ‘Lilibet’ is now the reigning queen in Europe.
abstract: Though they ruled from capitals hundreds of miles apart, Queen Elizabeth and Queen Margrethe found time now and again to meet and spill the tea about family, children and other matters.
lead_paragraph: One monarch was nicknamed Lilibet; the other, Daisy. One was the longest-reigning royal in Britain, skilled at disarming world leaders with humor. The other was educated at Cambridge, is often seen with a cigarette dangling from her lips and hopped a roller coaster in May to mark her Golden Jubilee.

headline: Plum Finds Her Way as Aces Move One Win From W.N.B.A. Title
abstract: A scorer shakes off her struggles after a scolding, and helps Las Vegas take a 2-0 lead in the finals.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — A’ja Wilson approached her teammate Kelsey Plum with a simple message after their Las Vegas Aces narrowly won Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals: To win the series, Wilson made clear in a hail of shouts and expletives, the Aces need Plum to play better.

headline: Why Are We Obsessed With Jiggling Foods?
abstract: For more than a thousand years, dishes that wiggle and wobble have bounced to the fore during precarious eras.
lead_paragraph: IN A VIDEO clip posted to Instagram, a jelly shimmies. With fluted curves like a Bundt cake, it suggests a ball gown skirt gone rogue, the dancer within turned ghost or banished from the scene. Elsewhere online lurk ornate jellies, from 18th-century British molds, with high, gooey spires that dip wildly from side to side, to cheesecakes, ostensibly solid yet vibrating, as if in thrall to some erratic internal pulse. (These are Japanese cotton cheesecakes, so called because of their confounding lightness, achieved by folding in egg whites whipped into peaks and then baking the cakes in a hot-water bath.) Sometimes the oscillations are slowed down to a tidal ripple. Sometimes a human hand enters the frame, spanking a cheesecake to make it bounce or, in a curious trend that started in 2019, wielding a spoon to smack the bottom of a little gelatinous pig or bunny — reminding us that the food in question cannot move of its own power; that it is not, in fact, alive.

headline: Europe Plans to Ban Goods Made With Forced Labor
abstract: While it does not explicitly mention Xinjiang, the western Chinese region where Uyghurs are believed to be pressed to work in camps, the proposal is widely seen as being aimed at Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union said on Wednesday that it aimed to ban all goods that were the product of forced labor, a move that analysts predicted could hit exports from Xinjiang, the Chinese region where Beijing is believed to be forcing ethnic Uyghurs to work in camps.

headline: The E.U.’s top official lays out plans for lasting support of Ukraine.
abstract: Ursula von der Leyen’s State of the Union message asserted that the European Union would stick together against Russia despite the economic costs.
lead_paragraph: In an hourlong address replete with symbolism, Ursula von der Leyen, the top European Union official, emphasized the bloc’s unwavering support of Ukraine and detailed plans to manage the domestic costs of its confrontation with Russia.

headline: Decoding the Surprise Inflation Report
abstract: A stubbornly high inflation reading has divided experts on what the Fed should do when it weighs another interest rate hike next week.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday’s surprise of an inflation report, which showed consumer prices rose last month rather than fell, as many had predicted, continues to buffet the markets. Stocks in Asia and Europe sank this morning as fears grow that to cool off inflation, central banks, led by the Fed, will need to quash consumer demand through more aggressive interest-rate increases. Economists at Nomura and Larry Summers, the former Treasury secretary, are among those arguing that the Fed should raise its benchmark rate by a full percentage point next week. The S&P 500 tumbled more than 4 percent yesterday, the biggest one-day drop since June 2020, on interest-rate jitters.

headline: The queen’s coffin will leave Buckingham Palace at exactly 2:22 p.m.
abstract: The procession will last 38 minutes and will “arrive at Westminster Hall at 3 p.m. on the dot.”
lead_paragraph: On any other Wednesday, the walk from the gates of Buckingham Palace — along London’s leafy Mall bordering St. James’s Park and past bastions of power like Downing Street — would be full of tourists taking in London’s premier sights.

headline: Bolduc Wins New Hampshire Senate Primary, Realizing G.O.P. Fears
abstract: Mainstream Republicans are worried that Don Bolduc, a 2020 election denier, is too right-wing to beat Senator Maggie Hassan in the general election.
lead_paragraph: Don Bolduc, a retired Army general and 2020 election denier, has captured the Republican nomination for Senate in New Hampshire, according to The Associated Press.

headline: U.S. to Move Forward on Military Aid to Egypt Despite Lawmakers’ Concerns
abstract: Senior Democratic lawmakers said the United States should not give $300 million in aid to Egypt until it improves its human rights record, in the latest instance of tensions over Middle East policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State Department officials said Wednesday that they would give Egypt most of an allocated $300 million in conditional military aid despite pressure from senior Democratic lawmakers to withhold the full amount until the country improves its human rights record.

headline: Where the ‘Rust Belt’ Meets the Runway
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, a big metal bag made in the Midwest helped represent “female hysteria.”
lead_paragraph: During fashion week, we will be spotlighting the small details we saw on the runways that surprised or delighted us. Bring on the sculptural shoes and antique fork jewelry.

headline: Los Angeles to Memorialize 1871 Massacre of Chinese Residents
abstract: The city wants to ensure that the killings of at least 18 people are not forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Their lives were taken swiftly and with indifference. At least 18 Chinese people, including a teenage boy, forging their way in a Los Angeles that was as rough as it was full of promise — all shot or hanged. The slayings snuffed out a significant swath of a tiny Chinese community.

headline: Why Won’t My Husband Change His Will to Protect Our Baby and Me?
abstract: A reader wonders how to negotiate the sensitive subject of her husband’s outdated will, which she worries could leave her and her child without a place to live.
lead_paragraph: My husband is a fair bit older than I am. Before we met, he didn’t expect to get married, so he made a will leaving his house and his entire estate to his sister. The house is now our home, and I am happy to report that things are going swimmingly. We had a baby last year! I never worried about his will before our daughter was born, but now I’m afraid if something happens to my husband, my daughter and I will be left homeless. I’ve raised the subject with him a few times. He agrees that his will should be updated, but it never seems to happen. Obviously, this is a sensitive issue. Any advice?

headline: Classic Tailoring Gets a New Twist
abstract: The stage is set for men’s wear’s exuberant return to form.

headline: A New Look at a Diane Arbus Exhibition, 50 Years Later
abstract: David Zwirner Gallery in New York is restaging the photographer’s 1972 retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Diane Arbus exhibited her work only once during her lifetime, as part of a two-room photography show in 1967 with Lee Friedlander and Garry Winogrand called “New Documents” at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Arbus had a room all to herself and showed 32 photographs. One was of a smiling elderly couple, fully naked, at a New Jersey nudist camp. Another captured a boy in Central Park, vamping for the camera with a toy hand grenade. Arbus received scattered critical praise for the show — she was “a one-woman revolution,” per Newsweek — but it was not well-attended and confounded a lot of reviewers. “Sometimes, it must be added, the picture borders close to poor taste,” said a New York Times review with the title “People Seen as Curiosity.” Friedlander has called it, “The most influential photography exhibition no one ever saw.”

headline: Where’s the Next Party?
abstract: The best party outfits from New York Fashion Week, including events for Saks, Bergdorf, Marc Jacobs, Givenchy and Opening Ceremony.
lead_paragraph: The city’s nightlife went into overdrive last Thursday as New York Fashion Week returned with a torrent of private dinners, fancy cocktails and packed parties.

headline: Ostracized by the West, Russia Finds a Partner in Saudi Arabia
abstract: The two oil-producing countries have extended their partnership even as the United States and Europe have sought to punish and isolate Russia for invading Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As Russia massed troops on its border with Ukraine and invaded the country at the start of the year, Saudi Arabia’s Kingdom Holding Company quietly invested more than $600 million in Russia’s three dominant energy companies.

headline: Alan Cumming Uses Dance to Get at the Truth of Robert Burns
abstract: “Burn” is an unlikely hybrid: A movement-focused show performed by a famous actor with no dance training, about a man whose medium was words.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Rain pours down, thunder growls, lightning flickers. Fragments of melancholy melody emerge from the tumult, and a lone, silhouetted figure appears onstage, moving his upper body in sinuous circles, entwining his arms and gesturing with slow deliberation. Then he walks forward, opens his arms and smiles impishly. “Here am I,” he announces.

headline: Top European Court Condemns France Over Refusal to Bring Home ISIS Families
abstract: Fighters’ families have been held in Kurdish-run camps in Syria for years. The court ruled that France had violated their right to return home when rejecting their requests for repatriation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Europe’s top human rights court condemned the French government on Wednesday over its refusal to bring home the families of two Islamic State fighters, a landmark ruling that may push France and other European countries to speed up the repatriation of nationals held for years in squalid detention camps in northeastern Syria.

headline: Retreat in Ukraine’s Northeast Leaves Other Russian Territory Vulnerable
abstract: Ukraine’s success in the northeast raised the possibility that it would seek to reclaim territory in the eastern Donbas region, where Russia has supported separatist uprisings since 2014.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s retreat from northeastern Ukraine is a setback for Moscow, but it opens the door to the possibility of an even greater one: that Ukrainian forces, galvanized by their success, will sweep south to try to reclaim territory in the eastern Donbas region that has been one of the Kremlin’s main objectives in the war.

headline: Recipes to Make on Autopilot
abstract: On your busiest days, savory miso soup and ginger-dill salmon will feed with minimum fuss.
lead_paragraph: We’re halfway through September, and I’m already starting to feel the stress and hectic whoosh of fall. Unfinished tasks are piling up like fallen leaves — and let’s not even talk about my inbox; it’s a terrifying place (current unread email total: 2,429). There’s a kid to send off to school, lunches to pack, and jackets and sweaters and closed-toe shoes to excavate from storage. In moments like these, it can be hard to think beyond takeout for dinner.

headline: What School Anxiety Dreams Teach Us About Ourselves
abstract: Why we keep having school anxiety dreams, and what they may mean.
lead_paragraph: Right before my children went back to school this month, I had one of my most frequently recurring stress dreams. As usual, it was this version of a partially true experience: I am a few credits away from graduating from college, and I realize I have a Russian history test that I have not studied for at all. My books are stuck in a locker outside an unfamiliar classroom, and when I try to open it I can’t remember the combination.

headline: ‘Do Revenge’: Paying Homage to Teen Classics by Way of Hitchcock
abstract: Though Gen Z is the subject, the director Jennifer Kaytin Robinson wanted to honor and critique high school movies of the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: “You’re probably going, ‘Is this like a Noxzema commercial or what?’” Cher Horowitz mused in the opening montage of “Clueless,” laughing with friends in her Jeep Wrangler and splurging at Tiffany’s on Rodeo Drive. That scene, set to the Muffs’ pop-punk cover of “Kids in America,” painted a heady portrait of ’90s youth and excess.

headline: Florentina Holzinger Makes Everyone Uncomfortable
abstract: The Austrian choreographer’s shows blend dance, stunts and sideshow-inspired acts to explore lofty ideas about gender and art. She pushes performers to extremes — and audiences, too.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In a rehearsal hall on the city’s outskirts, Xana Novais was hanging by her teeth. On a recent evening, the tattooed 27-year-old performer was suspended a few inches above the ground, biting down on a piece of leather hanging from a rope, perfecting a new skill called the “iron jaw.” It did not look easy.

headline: Robert Burns, Right-Wing Republican, Wins House Primary in New Hampshire
abstract: Mr. Burns, who is aligned with former President Donald J. Trump and benefited from spending by a Democratic group, will face Representative Ann McLane Kuster in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Robert Burns, a right-wing candidate aligned with former President Donald J. Trump, won Tuesday’s Republican primary in New Hampshire’s Second Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.

headline: U.S. Establishes Trust With $3.5 Billion in Frozen Afghan Central Bank Funds
abstract: The Afghan Fund, which will be based in Switzerland, is meant to help stabilize Afghanistan’s economy and pay for imports like electricity — without benefiting the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration moved on Wednesday to establish a foundation to begin spending $3.5 billion to benefit Afghans, using funds that President Biden had frozen and seized from Afghanistan’s central bank after the Taliban took over the country last year.

headline: Clothes That Meet the Moment
abstract: Gabriela Hearst, Tory Burch and Peter Do solve some problems.
lead_paragraph: Three thick gold lines were splashed on the floor of a cavernous warehouse in the Brooklyn Navy Yards where the Gabriela Hearst show was to take place. The two on the outside were slightly curved, to enclose the inner one.

headline: In Pakistan’s Record Floods, Villages Are Now Desperate Islands
abstract: The flooding has displaced more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
lead_paragraph: DADU, Pakistan — The view from Muhammad Jaffar’s small, mud brick home in southern Pakistan used to bring him a sense of relief. Rolling fields of green cotton shrubs had started just steps from his door, their white blooms offering the promise of enough income for his family to survive the year.

headline: Charlotte Bennett Sues Cuomo Over Sexual Harassment Accusations
abstract: Ms. Bennett is one of multiple women who had accused former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of sexual harassment, leading to his resignation.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Bennett, a onetime executive assistant to former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo who was among the first women to lodge sexual harassment accusations against him, filed a lawsuit in federal court against the former New York governor on Wednesday.

headline: Rommy Hunt Revson, Creator of the Scrunchie, Dies at 78
abstract: A former nightclub singer, she developed the simple ornamental hair tie that quickly became a ubiquitous accessory.
lead_paragraph: Rommy Hunt Revson was renting a house in Southampton, N.Y., in 1986, stressed from her recent divorce from a Revlon heir, John Revson, when she conceived of a hair band to hold a ponytail without damaging the hair.

headline: 46 Years After His Death, the Producer Charles Stepney Shines Again
abstract: The Chicago musician made his mark with Minnie Riperton and Earth, Wind & Fire at Chess Records. A new collection explores his previously unreleased solo work.
lead_paragraph: Earth, Wind & Fire’s “Gratitude.” Terry Callier’s “Occasional Rain.” Minnie Riperton’s “Come to My Garden.” All three albums featured ornate sounds that fused elements of classical, psychedelic music and soul. All three nudged their creators in fresh creative directions. All three bore the hallmarks of a vibraphonist who turned into one of the most underappreciated producers of his era: Charles Stepney.

headline: Don’t Be Shy: The Benefits of Talking to Strangers
abstract: Readers react to a column by David Brooks about how we should be more social. Also: Diplomacy for Ukraine; a slain journalist; Mikhail Gorbachev.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The queen’s funeral will be paid for by British taxpayers.
abstract: The state will cover the huge price tag at a time when many in Britain are struggling to pay their bills and are bracing for a difficult winter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government has not yet disclosed how much Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral on Monday will cost, saying only that it would provide details “in due course.”

headline: Little Amal Arrives in New York, With a Message of Hope and Humanity
abstract: The 12-foot-tall Syrian refugee puppet traveled from Turkey to Britain last year. Now, she will spend nearly three weeks in the five boroughs taking part in numerous events.
