abstract: The 1970s, ’80s and ’90s came together on the last day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week ended, much as it had begun, with a blinding dose of déjà vu.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Tree Rings and Climate
abstract: What does this graph tell us about climate change in the Southwest United States?
lead_paragraph: The graph above shows how the climate has changed in the Southwest over the past 500 years. The soil moisture percentiles are derived from tree ring widths, with wider rings indicating more rain which brings more soil moisture.

headline: ‘I Used to Be Famous’ Review: Hold On to That Feeling
abstract: A boy band veteran teams up with an autistic teenager in this film about friendship and music.
lead_paragraph: The title of this movie is a bit of misdirection. Yes, one of the main characters, Vince, was famous. He’s a boy band veteran who is 20 years past his peak popularity when the story picks up in the present day. But this is less a first person singular tale than one of a team effort.

headline: Justice Department seeks to entice companies to be better corporate citizens.
abstract: The agency is trying to motivate more people to come forward, through the promise of leniency or other benefits, to identify wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is announcing a major update to its criminal enforcement policy on Thursday that will take into account a big question when it considers charging a corporate executive or business: Is the company a good actor that cooperates with the authorities and turns in wrongdoers?

headline: Coming Soon to New York: More Trees
abstract: New York continues its expansion of planting trees throughout the boroughs.
lead_paragraph: New York continues its expansion of planting trees throughout the boroughs.

headline: Republican Efforts to Ban or Restrict Abortions
abstract: Readers react to an article about divisions within the G.O.P. over abortion. Also: Lawmakers’ stock trades; the monarchy’s role; the Juul settlement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dance Theater of Harlem Names a New Artistic Director
abstract: The choreographer Robert Garland will take over next year, succeeding Virginia Johnson, who was appointed by Arthur Mitchell, the company’s co-founder.
lead_paragraph: Dance Theater of Harlem announced Thursday that its longtime artistic director, Virginia Johnson, who revived the organization’s defunct professional company after years of hiatus, would retire from that role next year. Robert Garland, the company’s resident choreographer and director of its school, has been named her successor.

headline: Man Tells of Losing His Arm to an Alligator, Followed by Days Lost in a Swamp
abstract: Eric Merda meant to go exploring, but ended up in what he described as a nightmare survival story.
lead_paragraph: Eric Merda didn’t usually have much free time between his irrigation service calls, but on July 17, he had a far more generous schedule and was looking to fill a couple of hours.

headline: Herschel Walker Tests the Importance of ‘Candidate Quality’
abstract: If he babbles his way to a win, we all lose.
lead_paragraph: Mehmet Oz could prevail over John Fetterman in Pennsylvania’s Senate election and, well, I’m not sure what that would mean. The carnival (and crudités) of that contest precludes tidy lessons. And it’s impossible to know what voters will or won’t make of Fetterman’s stroke earlier this year.

headline: Here’s What to Know About EuroBasket
abstract: The championship of Europe for men’s national basketball teams is being played for the first time since 2017. It is down to the last four teams.
lead_paragraph: We answer your questions about the EuroBasket tournament, which concludes this weekend in Berlin.

headline: ‘Drifting Home’ Review: A Sinking Development
abstract: Two friends visit their old apartment building and make haunting discoveries in this animated film from Hiroyasu Ishida.
lead_paragraph: You never know what you’re getting with real estate: a building could have water damage from sailing through the ocean; could have structural damage from colliding, Titantic-style, with other drifting domiciles; or it could have a spirit-child squatter. This makes for a terrible appraisal but might make for a great fantasy drama.

headline: The Overnight Wait to See the Queen
abstract: At 2 a.m. on Thursday, I joined the end of one of the longest lines I’ve ever seen, known as The Queue.
lead_paragraph: At 2 a.m. on Thursday, I joined the end of one of the longest lines I’ve ever seen, known as The Queue.

headline: ‘Moonage Daydream’ Review: David Bowie’s Sound and Vision
abstract: Brett Morgen’s new documentary about the singer uses archival material, not talking heads. But the film is more séance than biography.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Firefighters Battle California’s Largest Blaze of the Year
abstract: The Mosquito fire has moved northeast of Sacramento and has torn through the Sierra Nevada foothills, damaging some buildings since forming on Sept. 6.
lead_paragraph: The Mosquito fire has moved northeast of Sacramento and has torn through the Sierra Nevada foothills, damaging some buildings since forming on Sept. 6.

headline: 16 Soups Our Food Staff Cooks on Repeat
abstract: Cozy season is here. Greet it with a bowl of French onion, vegetable, chicken noodle or potato soup.
lead_paragraph: Soup season is here. If you’re more than ready to swap out a few of those quick summer salads for some brothy goodness, but don’t know where to start, the New York Times Food staff is happy to help. Whether it’s an undisputed classic or something new and quick to add to your lunch or dinner lineup, here are 16 of our go-to soups for the days when a bowl of cozy is in order.

headline: Workers Say Railroads’ Efficiency Push Became Too Much
abstract: Employees say the inflexibility of scheduling upended their personal lives. The companies say they maintained service while using fewer resources.
lead_paragraph: To defuse a labor dispute that brought the nation to the brink of a potentially catastrophic railroad strike, negotiators had to resolve a key issue: schedules that workers say were punishing, upending their personal lives and driving colleagues from the industry.

headline: Germany Offers One of the Largest Holocaust Reparations Packages, and a Special Fund for Ukrainians
abstract: The country will pay $1.2 billion, including emergency aid for Holocaust survivors in Ukraine and, for the first time, remembrance education.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany agreed to one of its largest financial reparations packages ever for the world’s remaining Jewish Holocaust survivors on Thursday — including a 12 million euro ($12 million) emergency fund for 8,500 survivors who remain in war-torn Ukraine.

headline: ‘A Perfect Party’ That Celebrates All Its Guests
abstract: Trusty Sidekick Theater Company has created an outdoor adventure for young people on the autism spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Like many festive occasions, “A Perfect Party for Trees” involves giving and receiving presents: a pine cone, a jar of found objects, a song, even a badger and a bird (both are inventively portrayed by puppets). But perhaps the greatest gift this new play offers its audience is intangible: the freedom to be themselves.

headline: Right After Primary Win, Bolduc Reverses Support for Election Lies
abstract: Don Bolduc, the Republican Senate nominee in New Hampshire, pivoted to the general election, saying he had concluded that the 2020 presidential election “was not stolen.”
lead_paragraph: Like a driver making a screeching U-turn, Don Bolduc, the Republican Senate nominee in New Hampshire, pivoted on Thursday from his primary race to the general election, saying he had “come to the conclusion” that the 2020 presidential election “was not stolen,” after he had spent more than a year claiming it was.

headline: With an Israeli Superhero, Marvel Wades Into an Intractable Conflict
abstract: The studio has angered many Palestinians and their supporters by casting the actress Shira Haas to play Sabra, a mutant Mossad agent, in a “Captain America” movie.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was the latest addition to a fantasy world populated by an ever-growing cast of superheroes and villains: Marvel Studios announced this past week that it had cast the Israeli actress Shira Haas to play Sabra, a mutant Israeli police officer-turned-Mossad agent, in the next installment of the “Captain America” franchise.

headline: Vegetarian Recipes for Cozy Days
abstract: Soups, stews and comforting, feel-good foods for after a storm.
lead_paragraph: There was a storm here over the weekend — rumbles of thunder and thick, gray skies, a soaking wet garden in the morning. It’s cooled down a little too, and all I want now is soft and cozy food. You know, stews packed with beans and greens, dumplings and noodles in hot broths, all kinds of mellow vegetable soups and long, wine-scented braises that I can leave simmering while I work.

headline: Misty Copeland Creates Program to Bring More Diversity to Ballet
abstract: The American Ballet Theater dancer announced an extracurricular initiative that Copeland hopes will bring more Black and Latino children to dance.
lead_paragraph: The dance superstar Misty Copeland has often spoken about the impact of enrolling in a free ballet class when she was 13, on the basketball court of a Boys and Girls Club in San Pedro, Calif., where she grew up. The class set in motion Copeland’s remarkable career, which included in 2015 becoming the first Black woman to be promoted to principal dancer at American Ballet Theater.

headline: For the Gloriously Over-the-Top Rina Sawayama, Less Is Less
abstract: The pop singer and songwriter’s first album was a master class in maximalism. Its follow-up, “Hold the Girl,” still carries weighty subjects, but largely without its chaotic edge.
lead_paragraph: The British-Japanese musician Rina Sawayama’s kaleidoscopically eclectic debut, “Sawayama,” ranks among the best and most imaginative pop albums of this still-young decade. Gloriously excessive but intimately personal, “Sawayama” sounded like an internet browser with too many open tabs blasting away — perhaps a vintage Christina Aguilera hit, a black metal song and an episode of “RuPaul’s Drag Race” — that somehow overlapped in synergistic, mashed-up harmony.

headline: Eleri Ward Captures the Longing at the Heart of Sondheim’s Work
abstract: On her new album, the singer fuses Stephen Sondheim’s emo register with a familiar coffeehouse folk sound.
lead_paragraph: The so-called “I want” song is a convention — if not a rule — of musical theater scores. From “I’ll Know” in “Guys and Dolls” to “My Shot” in “Hamilton,” these thesis statements by leading characters typically come early in a show, hitching the plot’s momentum to their ambitions or dreams.

headline: The Eyes Have It in Hew Locke’s Power-Challenging Show
abstract: Over the entrance to the Met are medallion portraits of white, male art heroes. Enter Hew Locke with a timely and pointed message about “Gilt” (or “Guilt”).
lead_paragraph: My introduction to the work of the Guyanese British artist Hew Locke, whose cranky, bling-gold, power-pricking sculptures are currently embedded in the Metropolitan Museum’s facade, came in 2007 in a group show of contemporary Caribbean art at the Brooklyn Museum. Locke’s contribution there was a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, the most — maybe only — interesting one I’ve encountered.

headline: Map: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Fiona
abstract: A map showing the storm’s path as it moved across parts of eastern Canada.
lead_paragraph: A map showing the storm’s path as it moved across parts of eastern Canada.

headline: Review: Outshining a Premiere, a Group Announces Its Arrival
abstract: The ensemble Orlando Furioso was the highlight of a concert featuring Kate Soper’s new but brief work “HEX.”
lead_paragraph: Kate Soper’s work, like that of so many other artists, was disrupted by the pandemic. But she weathered the moment with the same creative ingenuity she has brought to her music and dramatic projects in the past.

headline: Understanding the Migrant Busing Crisis
abstract: A tactic by Southern governors to shift the problems of border crossings onto Northern states escalated this week.
lead_paragraph: A tactic by Southern governors to shift the problems of border crossings onto Northern states escalated this week.

headline: U.K. Health Ministry Wants No Oxford Commas. Period.
abstract: The directive discourages the use of the contentious grammatical device, and also encourages employees to be “positive” and to avoid “jargon.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The government department that oversees Britain’s state-run health care system is confronting a number of urgent problems: too many unfilled positions for doctors and nurses, too many patients waiting for treatment, too many aging hospitals — and, according to a new directive, too many commas.

headline: Mexico Arrests Army General Linked to Disappearance of 43 Students
abstract: A top military officer suspected of ordering the killing of at least six of the students who disappeared in 2014 has been arrested, the latest in a string of high-profile arrests.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexican authorities arrested a general for his alleged involvement in the disappearance of 43 students in 2014, the authorities said on Thursday, the latest in a recent string of developments in a high-profile case that has become a deep wound in the national psyche.

headline: ‘Pearl’ Review: A Farmer’s Daughter Moves Up the Food Chain
abstract: A horror-movie killer gets a surprising origin story in Ti West’s prequel to “X.”
lead_paragraph: If you have seen “X,” Ti West’s ingenious and heartfelt pastiche of ’70s horror and hard-core pornography, you know that Mia Goth plays two roles. (If you haven’t seen it, there are spoilers ahead.) She is Maxine, an aspiring movie star and the designated survivor of a rural killing spree. Disguised by prosthetic makeup, she is also a horny and homicidal farmer’s wife named Pearl, and does a lot of killing.

headline: Record Summer Weather
abstract: Both Europe and North America experienced their warmest August in NOAA’s 143-year record.
lead_paragraph: Both Europe and North America experienced their warmest August in NOAA’s 143-year record.

headline: ‘The Woman King’ Review: She Slays
abstract: Viola Davis leads a strong cast into battle in an epic from Gina Prince-Bythewood, inspired by real women warriors.
lead_paragraph: The kinetic action adventure “The Woman King” is a sweeping entertainment, but it’s also a story of unwavering resistance in front of and behind the camera. The ascendancy of women filmmakers over the past decade is one of the great chapters in movie history, and as women have fought their way back into the field, they have also taken up space — on screens and in minds — long denied them. Their canvases are again as expansive as their desires.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Their ‘Mundane Joys’ of Summer
abstract: Our weekly Current Events Conversation is back. We start the school year with a roundup of teenage comments on the ordinary moments they enjoyed this summer.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first edition of our Current Events Conversation for the 2022-23 school year. If you’re new here, every Thursday, editors at The Learning Network round up some of the best teenage comments posted to our recent writing prompts, both to honor students and their schools and to offer a snapshot of what young people are thinking about issues in the news.

headline: A Man Tried to Kill the Vice President. Then Came the Conspiracy Theories.
abstract: An assassination attempt against Argentina’s vice president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, failed. Now many Argentines believe the entire event was a hoax.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — This month, a man squeezed through a crowd toward Argentina’s vice president, pointed a gun inches from her face and pulled the trigger. The gun did not go off.

headline: European Union Signals a Move Away from Wood Energy
abstract: Wood was supposed to help the E.U. reach its renewable energy goals. But it has contributed to increased emissions and a loss of Europe’s protected woodlands.
lead_paragraph: European lawmakers voted this week to phase out some wood-energy subsidies, a recognition that more than a decade of government incentives has contributed to deforestation without curbing greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Paul T. Kwami, Fisk Jubilee Singers’ Longtime Director, Dies at 70
abstract: He took the storied Black musical group to new heights, including its first Grammy win and a National Medal of Arts.
lead_paragraph: Paul T. Kwami, the longtime director of the Fisk Jubilee Singers, who cemented the ensemble’s reputation as one of the country’s premier interpreters of African American spiritual music, died on Sept.  10 in Nashville. He was 70.

headline: Cardi B Pleads Guilty to Two Misdemeanors in 2018 Strip Club Attacks
abstract: Four years after being charged, the Bronx rapper, 29, was sentenced to 15 days of community service for her role in two fights at a Queens club.
lead_paragraph: Four years after being charged with felony assault stemming from a pair of strip club brawls, Cardi B, the Bronx rapper and pop star born Belcalis Almanzar, pleaded guilty on Thursday in a Queens court to two misdemeanors.

headline: ‘The Silent Twins’ Review: Keeping the World at Bay
abstract: A beguiling look at the complicated story of the real-life twins June and Jennifer Gibbons, who lived in a mental institution for over a decade.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the sisters June and Jennifer Gibbons were part of the only Black family in their small Welsh town. They experienced racism at school, and were eventually institutionalized for 11 years at a notorious psychiatric hospital in Britain.

headline: Federer in Photos: A Career of Major Successes
abstract: For more than two decades, tennis fans admired Roger Federer’s every move as he won 20 Grand Slam singles titles.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Here’s something for the “everything old is new again” files: For the first time in more than two years, I’m writing this note from my desk at the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue. It’s a good feeling, and a weird one, this fitful return to the office, and maybe you’ve experienced something like it yourself: the cafeteria lunches, the soft hum of climate control, the familiar rhythms of commuting all the same as they were in March 2020. (Riding a train, it turns out, is a lot like riding a bike: You don’t forget.)

headline: Two Stroke Survivors, Talking Politics
abstract: As a stroke survivor myself, I felt I had a unique vantage point on a candidate's recovery.
lead_paragraph: As a stroke survivor myself, I felt I had a unique vantage point on a candidate's recovery.

headline: Fred Franzia, 79, Dies; Upended Wine Industry With Two-Buck Chuck
abstract: An unorthodox businessman, he took on the wine industry and its high markups, selling wine at prices many families could afford every day.
lead_paragraph: Fred Franzia, the iconoclastic businessman who turned the wine industry on its head with his inexpensive Charles Shaw label, better known as Two-Buck Chuck, died on Tuesday at his home in Denair, Calif. He was 79.

headline: The Shots That Made Roger Federer
abstract: His one-handed backhand, inside-out forehand and powerful serve helped fuel his championships.
lead_paragraph: His one-handed backhand, inside-out forehand and powerful serve helped fuel his championships.

headline: California Governor Signs Sweeping Children’s Online Safety Bill
abstract: The bill could require many social media sites, games and other online services used by children to install protections for minors.
lead_paragraph: California will adopt a broad new approach to protecting children online after Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill on Thursday that could transform how many social networks, games and other services treat minors.

headline: Is This the Least Cringe Option to Get People to Your Party?
abstract: Partiful wants to be the go-to option for sending online invitations. Facebook events, we hardly knew ye.
lead_paragraph: “Dramatic” and “absurd” were the words Natasha Hunt Lee, a 25-year-old musician in Los Angeles, had in mind while booking three D.J.s, a tattoo artist and a Disney princess bouncy castle for her album-release party this month.

headline: Extreme Religious Liberty Is Undermining Public Health
abstract: Recent rulings are empowering the moral judgments of a small but politically powerful group.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled last week that requiring employers to cover PrEP, a medication that helps people at high risk for H.I.V. avoid infection, violates religious liberty because these employers perceive the drug to encourage gay and extramarital sex by making it safer. The ruling suggested extreme skepticism ‌toward‌ the benefits of health care regulation.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 15, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the looming food crisis Pakistan faces in the aftermath of devastating floods miscalculated the currency exchange for the amount that Rahimullah Khan borrowed for fertilizer. It was 135,000 Pakistani rupees, the equivalent of $570, not $1,700.

headline: With Faraway Migrant Drop-Offs, G.O.P. Governors Are Doubling Down
abstract: Decisions to bus migrants to the vice president’s residence and to fly others to Martha’s Vineyard were the latest attempts to provoke outrage over record arrivals at the border.
lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Immigration lawyers rushed onto ferries to reach a quaint red church turned shelter. Students from a high school Spanish class sought to help translate. Impromptu volunteers scoured a dollar store for clothing to donate.

headline: Democrats Delay Senate Vote to Protect Gay Marriage as G.O.P. Balks
abstract: The chief negotiators were short of the 10 Republican votes that would be needed to win passage, but hoped to draw more support after the November elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats decided on Thursday to postpone a planned vote on legislation to provide federal protections for same-sex marriage until after the midterm elections in November, amid dimming hopes of drawing enough Republican support to ensure its passage with tight races on the line.

headline: Busloads of Migrants Arrive Outside the Vice President Harris’s Home
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas sent two busloads of people to Vice President Kamala Harris’s residence to protest the large numbers of immigrants being allowed into the country at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas sent two busloads of people to Vice President Kamala Harris’s residence to protest the large numbers of immigrants being allowed into the country at the southern border.

headline: A Detailed Rundown of Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Day
abstract: On Monday, dignitaries from across the globe will bid farewell to the queen at a service in Westminster Abbey.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The processions, mourning and commemorations that have followed the death of Queen Elizabeth II will culminate on Monday with the queen’s funeral at 11 a.m. (London time) at Westminster Abbey, an event that will draw dignitaries from across the globe and a massive worldwide audience watching online and on television.

headline: ‘God’s Country’ Review: A Solitary Woman Isn’t Left Alone for Long
abstract: In this simmering thriller, Thandiwe Newton plays a professor in rural Montana who confronts two hunters who say they’re just passing through.
lead_paragraph: A woman alone is seldom left alone, especially if she’s young and pretty and content in her solitude. The world presses in no matter how she resists its intrusions; strangers demand her attention, her smiles and time. The sexual connotations are unmistakable and complicated, and they’re intensified when race enters the picture, as it does in the simmering thriller “God’s Country,” a story about a woman who wants to be left in peace and isn’t.

headline: Rise of Far-Right Party in Sweden Was Both Expected and Shocking
abstract: The Sweden Democrats, with roots in neo-Nazism, came in second in national elections and will have a powerful influence on a new center-right government.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — The rise of the far-right Sweden Democrats to become the country’s second-largest party, with a claim to government, has been a slow-moving earthquake over the past decade. But even as their success in Sunday’s election seemed inevitable, it still had the ability to shock.

headline: Earl J. Silbert, Lead Prosecutor of Watergate Break-In, Dies at 86
abstract: He worked to secure several convictions, making early inroads in the investigation of a scandal that would bring down a president.
lead_paragraph: Earl J. Silbert, who led the federal prosecution of the botched Watergate burglary, which secured the convictions of all five burglars and two of the break-in’s planners, E. Howard Hunt and G. Gordon Liddy, died on Sept. 6 in Keene, N.H. He was 86.

headline: Related Companies and Wynn to Bid for New Casino in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: The companies want to put the casino on the western half of  Hudson Yards, which remains undeveloped.
lead_paragraph: One of New York City’s most prolific developers on Thursday announced that it was teaming up with a Las Vegas gambling giant to bid on a casino in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Aperture Foundation Lands a New Headquarters
abstract: The nonprofit photography organization will relocate in 2024, to offices across from the American Museum of Natural History, with greater visibility.
lead_paragraph: The Aperture Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded in 1952 by a group of prominent photographers, announced Thursday that it has purchased a new headquarters for $8.95 million. The group will occupy the lower two floors of a Romanesque Revival building at 380 Columbus Avenue on the Upper West Side, across the street from the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: UConn Agrees to Pay Former Coach Kevin Ollie $3.9 Million
abstract: Ollie, who led the men’s basketball team to the national title in 2014, was fired in 2018 during an investigation into recruiting violations.
lead_paragraph: The University of Connecticut agreed on Thursday to pay Kevin Ollie $3.9 million to settle a lengthy legal fight that began almost the moment the school fired Ollie, its one-time favorite son, as men’s basketball coach in 2018.

headline: Prosecutors in Colorado Investigating Fatal Shooting of Man Who Called 911
abstract: Christian Glass, 22, was killed by a sheriff’s deputy in June in Clear Creek County. His family said he had geology tools. The sheriff’s office said he had tried to stab an officer.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Colorado said this week that they were investigating a fatal shooting in June by a sheriff’s deputy of a disturbed 22-year-old Boulder man who had called 911 when his S.U.V. became stuck on a mountain road at night.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a sweet new farm show for children, a silly-spooky show for grown-ups and a terrific stand-up special.
lead_paragraph: ‘Lovely Little Farm’When to watch: Now, on Apple TV+.

headline: The Eight Film Festival Movies That Got the Biggest Awards Boost
abstract: “Women Talking,” women fighting, a pair of Brendans and more: After Toronto, Venice and Telluride, here are the titles and performances in the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Who are the front-runners, the dark horses and the long shots? After major film festivals in Venice, Telluride and Toronto, where most of the year’s remaining prestige films have screened, the awards season has finally begun to come into focus.

headline: House Passes Bill to Insulate Federal Workers, Addressing a Trump Threat
abstract: The legislation would prevent a president from gutting the civil service, a move that former President Donald J. Trump attempted and has threatened to revive should he win another term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed legislation on Thursday aimed at curbing a president’s authority to hire and fire tens of thousands of federal workers, moving to bolster the job security of civil servants targeted by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies as disloyal “deep state” operatives.

headline: Princess Anne’s Influence, and Workload, Rises in a Slimmed-Down Royal Family
abstract: Often appearing at more than 400 events a year, Anne is likely to become even more central as a trusted adviser to her brother, the king.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: In a First Study of Pakistan’s Floods, Scientists See Climate Change at Work
abstract: A growing field called attribution science is helping researchers rapidly assess the links between global warming and weather disasters.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan began receiving abnormally heavy rain in mid-June, and, by late August, drenching downpours were declared a national emergency. The southern part of the Indus River, which traverses the length of the country, became a vast lake. Villages have become islands, surrounded by putrid water that stretches to the horizon. More than 1,500 people have died. Floodwaters could take months to recede.

headline: A mass grave site with 440 bodies was found in Izium, a police official said.
abstract: A mass burial ground with about 440 individual graves has been found in Izium in the days since the city, in Ukraine’s northeast, was reclaimed from Russian forces in a lightning offensive last week, a senior Ukrainian police official told Sky News on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A mass burial ground with about 440 individual graves has been found in Izium in the days since the city, in Ukraine’s northeast, was reclaimed from Russian forces in a lightning offensive last week, a senior Ukrainian police official told Sky News on Thursday.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Monkeypox Scars, Lymphatic Drainage and Food Sensitivity
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Hip-Hop Mogul and Gap Officially End Their Partnership
abstract: The Yeezy Gap apparel line deal, announced with much fanfare in 2020, was supposed to last 10 years and generate $1 billion in annual sales.
lead_paragraph: The experiment in corporate disruption that was the partnership between Kanye West and Gap is officially over.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: The Putin-Xi Summit
abstract: Plus Europe’s tilt to the right continues, and Roger Federer is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Beijing’s support for Moscow’s war in Ukraine looks shakier after Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met with Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, at an in-person summit in Uzbekistan yesterday.

headline: Biden to Meet With Families of Griner and Whelan, Who Are Imprisoned in Russia
abstract: The fates of both Americans have been complicated by the deteriorating diplomatic relationship between the United States and Russia over President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will meet with the families of Brittney Griner and Paul N. Whelan at the White House on Friday, making good on a longstanding request from the relatives of the two Americans being held prisoner in Russia.

headline: Color, Sparkles and Style Return to New York
abstract: Nothing but vibes.
lead_paragraph: With many pandemic restrictions a distant memory, New York Fashion Week returned this month at full force. For many international participants, it was their first time returning to the United States since Covid, adding a jolt of energy to the pomp. Throughout the week, there was no shortage of creative looks — some the inventions of brands, others of individuals — worn by guests and spectators alike who seemed to evince a renewed appreciation for dressing up. Everyone was vibrant, the shows both inside and out were buzzing and it was the best September weather the city has had in years. Perhaps the best word to describe the general mood and sartorial aesthetic? “Happy.”

headline: Roger Federer Came Along When Tennis Desperately Needed Him
abstract: Tennis had lost its cachet in the early 2000s before Federer made the classic sport modern and the modern sport classier.
lead_paragraph: Live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: Biden Praises Deal Between Railroad Unions and Companies
abstract: President Biden’s administration helped broker the tentative agreement between freight rail companies and unions, avoiding what would have been an economically damaging strike.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s administration helped broker the tentative agreement between freight rail companies and unions, avoiding what would have been an economically damaging strike.

headline: The Big Three Are Now Just Two. Who Will Lead Tennis’s Next Generation?
abstract: Roger Federer’s retirement will augur opportunities for a new generation of players not named Rafael Nadal or Novak Djokovic.
lead_paragraph: Live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: Life on Mars? This Could Be the Place NASA’s Rover Helps Us Find It.
abstract: Rocks collected by Perseverance are filled with organic molecules, and they formed in a lake that would have been habitable a few billion years ago.
lead_paragraph: Exploring an ancient river delta in a crater on Mars, NASA’s Perseverance rover has collected samples of two rocks that are chock-full of carbon-based molecules that could be remnants of ancient life.

headline: Progressive Network Will Spend $10 Million on Asian American Turnout
abstract: The Asian American Power Network will focus on engaging Asian American voters on progressive issues and candidates in seven battleground states.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Asian American voters played a pivotal role in the presidential election, a coalition focused on building Asian American political power and engagement is launching a new $10 million midterm mobilization effort in critical battleground states.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Migrant Crisis Puts N.Y. ‘Right to Shelter’ Law to the Test
abstract: The city’s obligation to provide a bed to anyone who asks is unique and has added urgency to its efforts to welcome more than 11,000 migrants.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Mayor Eric Adams showed off a new welcome center for the thousands of migrants who are being bused from the border to New York, as evidence of how the city is going above and beyond to “meet its obligation” to house the newcomers.

headline: Pope Francis Says Arming Ukraine Can Be ‘Morally Acceptable.’
abstract: The pontiff said that it is acceptable for countries to provide weapons to Ukraine so that the country can defend itself, but stressed that communication channels with Russia should remain open.
lead_paragraph: ROME — After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Pope Francis initially appeared to uphold the Vatican’s longstanding policy of not taking sides, before eventually changing tack and saying explicitly that Russia was the aggressor in the war.

headline: The E.U.’s top official meets with Zelensky.
abstract: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Union’s top official, reassured President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a wide-ranging meeting Thursday in Kyiv that his country is still progressing toward membership in the bloc.
lead_paragraph: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Union’s top official, reassured President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a wide-ranging meeting Thursday in Kyiv that his country is still progressing toward membership in the bloc.

headline: Peter Davison, Orwell Scholar on a Monumental Scale, Dies at 95
abstract: A “super scholarly sleuth,” he devoted 35 years to editing 30 volumes of the author’s books, essays, letters, diaries and manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: Peter Davison, an indefatigable literary sleuth who, beginning in his mid-50s, devoted 35 years to revealing the unvarnished George Orwell, including curating, editing and annotating 20 volumes of the author’s complete works, died on Aug. 16 in Swindon, England. He was 95.

headline: Putin’s admission of Chinese concerns about Ukraine isn’t a sign of a weakening bond, U.S. officials said.
abstract: China’s quiet ambivalence about aspects of Russia’s war in Ukraine has long been understood by Moscow, but ties between the two countries remain strong — even if it was notable that President Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged Beijing’s concerns publicly, American officials said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: China’s quiet ambivalence about aspects of Russia’s war in Ukraine has long been understood by Moscow, but ties between the two countries remain strong — even if it was notable that President Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged Beijing’s concerns publicly, American officials said Thursday.

headline: In ‘Cancer Alley,’ Judge Blocks Huge Petrochemical Plant
abstract: The company, an affiliate of Formosa Plastics, said it intended to move forward with the $9.4 billion complex in St. James Parish despite the ruling.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana activists battling to block an enormous plastics plant in a corridor so dense with industrial refineries it is known as Cancer Alley won a legal victory this week when a judge canceled the company’s air permits.

headline: ‘Evil Will Not Win’: Biden Denounces White Supremacy and Takes a Swipe at Trump
abstract: President Biden convened a summit at the White House and called on Americans to speak out against prejudice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden convened a summit meeting at the White House on Thursday to denounce white supremacy and other forms of bias, calling on Americans to speak out against prejudice and taking a veiled swipe at former President Donald J. Trump for in his view countenancing hate-fueled violence.

headline: The Political Calculations Behind DeSantis’s Migrant Flights North
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida sent migrants to Massachusetts. He aimed to make a point about President Biden, but immigration issues are nothing new.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis, the Republican governor of Florida, one-upped his Texas counterpart, Greg Abbott, this week by sending two planeloads of migrants to Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts — the cherry on top of a monthslong campaign to essentially troll liberal cities and states by transferring many asylum seekers to those communities.

headline: Why Is There Still No Strategy to Defeat Donald Trump?
abstract: Trump-bashing makes us feel good; it doesn’t turn the tide.
lead_paragraph: One of the stunning facts of the age is the continued prominence of Donald Trump. His candidates did well in the G.O.P. primaries this year. He won more votes in 2020 than he did in 2016. His favorability ratings within his party have been high and basically unchanged since late 2016. In a range of polls, some have actually shown Trump leading President Biden in a race for re-election in 2024.

headline: Who’s Afraid of the Consumer Price Index?
abstract: There wasn’t really much news in that inflation report.
lead_paragraph: Three important reports on inflation were released this week. On Monday the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released its latest survey on inflation expectations, which was very encouraging. On Wednesday the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its latest report on producer prices, which was fairly reassuring. But the report in between — Tuesday’s bad report on consumer prices — has gotten almost all the attention.

headline: Putin Nods to Xi’s ‘Concerns,’ and the Limits of Their Cooperation
abstract: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged on Thursday that China had “questions and concerns” about Russia’s war in Ukraine, a notable, if cryptic, admission that Moscow lacks the full backing of its biggest, most powerful partner on the world stage.

headline: Biden Denounces White Supremacy at ‘United We Stand’ Summit
abstract: President Biden convened the meeting at the White House to denounce white supremacy and other forms of bias, calling on Americans to speak out against prejudice.
lead_paragraph: President Biden convened the meeting at the White House to denounce white supremacy and other forms of bias, calling on Americans to speak out against prejudice.

headline: FedEx Slashes Earnings Forecast, Citing Slowdowns in Asia and Europe
abstract: The shipping giant warned of a $500 million revenue shortfall ahead of its quarterly financial results next week, hitting its stock price hard.
lead_paragraph: FedEx said in a statement on Thursday that it expected to report that its profit shrank in the latest quarter, a decrease the shipping giant attributed to a broader slowdown of the global economy, sending the company’s stock price sharply lower.

headline: New Trial Is Ordered for Water Polo Coach Convicted in ‘Varsity Blues’ Scandal
abstract: Jovan Vavic, who was convicted on bribery and fraud, won a striking victory after a string of guilty verdicts and guilty pleas by parents, coaches and others embroiled in the scandal.
lead_paragraph: Jovan Vavic, a former water polo coach at the University of Southern California who was convicted of bribery as part of the far-reaching Operation Varsity Blues college admissions scandal, was granted a new trial on Thursday by a federal judge in Boston.

headline: ‘I Ended Up on This Little Island’: Migrants Land in Political Drama
abstract: After long, perilous journeys, Venezuelans unexpectedly found themselves on Martha’s Vineyard, wondering what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Ardenis Nazareth, newly arrived from Venezuela, was standing in a McDonald’s parking lot across the street from a San Antonio shelter a few days ago contemplating his next steps.

headline: Judge Keeps Block on Inquiry Into Mar-a-Lago Files and Names Special Master
abstract: The Justice Department is planning to appeal, but the decision is likely to significantly delay its investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of government records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday rejected the Justice Department’s request to resume a key part of its inquiry into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of sensitive government records and appointed an outside arbiter to review thousands of documents seized last month from his Florida residence.

headline: Flu Season Is Coming. Here’s How to Prepare.
abstract: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
lead_paragraph: With the recent headlines about Covid-19, polio and monkeypox, I have been in denial about the fact that yet another virus — influenza — will soon be upon us. Flu activity tends to ramp up starting in October, although the virus has already been circulating this month in Texas, New Mexico, Delaware and Georgia.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Transfer Migrants to Faraway States
abstract: The Republican governors of Florida and Texas sent roughly 150 migrants to Washington, D.C., and Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts to protest the high number of arrivals at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: The Republican governors of Florida and Texas sent roughly 150 migrants to Washington, D.C., and Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts to protest the high number of arrivals at the southern border.

headline: ‘Do Revenge’ Review: Strangers on a Text Chain
abstract: Two high school girls with grudges form a bond to get back at those who wronged them.
lead_paragraph: “Do Revenge,” directed by Jennifer Kaytin Robinson, is a playful, sharp-fanged satire that feels like the ’90s teen comedy hammered into modern emojis: crown, knife, fire, winky face. Drea Torres (Camila Mendes) is the Machiavellian queen of her pastel plaid-clad prep school. But the day after the ambitious scholarship student is coronated as one of Teen Vogue’s ideal teens — an extravagant bash that slaps her face on balloons, cupcakes and topiaries — Drea is dethroned when her nude video is posted online.

headline: ‘Remember This’ Review: Finding Strength Amid Moral Failure
abstract: David Strathairn is remarkable in a solo show about Jan Karski, who was profoundly changed by what he witnessed during World War II.
lead_paragraph: There are catastrophes so terrible that the mind struggles to comprehend them. Here is Jan Karski’s description of his visit in 1942 to a Jewish ghetto in Warsaw, during which he saw dead bodies lining the streets and starving women nursing their babies from sunken breasts: “This is not a world,” he observed. “It is not humanity.” But this was humanity. And Karski, an agent of the Polish government in exile during World War II, was tasked with reporting it.

headline: Jan. 6 Rioter Wearing ‘Camp Auschwitz’ Sweatshirt Gets 75 Days in Prison
abstract: Robert Keith Packer, 57, of Newport News, Va., was also ordered to pay $500 in restitution in connection with the riot at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia man who wore a sweatshirt with the words “Camp Auschwitz” across his chest as he breached the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Thursday to 75 days in prison, officials said.

headline: Uber Investigating Breach of Its Computer Systems
abstract: The company said on Thursday that it was looking into the scope of the apparent hack.
lead_paragraph: Uber discovered its computer network had been breached on Thursday, leading the company to take several of its internal communications and engineering systems offline as it investigated the extent of the hack.

headline: Sandy Alderson Will Step Down as Mets Team President
abstract: Alderson, the team president, will move into a special adviser role for owners Steve and Alex Cohen when a successor has been found.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Alderson, the longtime Mets executive, will step down from his position as team president when his successor is found, the club said on Thursday night. When the search is complete, Alderson, 74, will hand over the day-to-day oversight of the Mets and transition into a special adviser role for the team’s leadership group and owners Steve and Alex Cohen.

headline: The U.S. will send $600 million in additional military supplies to Ukraine.
abstract: The new shipment continues the Pentagon’s recent trend of sending ammunition that Ukraine needs to carry out heavy fighting in the country’s south, east and northeast.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after Russia’s humiliating rout in northeastern Ukraine, the Biden administration said on Thursday that it would send an additional $600 million in military supplies to Ukraine, including more artillery ammunition.

headline: Monterey Runner
abstract: Juliana Tringali Golden opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is Juliana Tringali Golden’s second New York Times Crossword, and her first themeless one.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop presents an extravaganza of uncertainties.
lead_paragraph: SPLIT DECISIONS — I am getting objectively worse at this variety puzzle. Perhaps you’ll be kind and agree that today’s is a toughie, but I didn’t even know where to start.

headline: Ex-Police Detective Suspected of Preying on Black Women Faces U.S. Charges
abstract: The former officer, Roger Golubski, 69, was indicted on charges that he sexually assaulted two women while on duty from 1998 to 2002, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: A former police detective in Kansas who had long been suspected of raping and terrorizing Black women as he patrolled the streets of Kansas City has been indicted on federal charges that he repeatedly sexually assaulted two women over several years while on duty, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Is This the End of the People’s Beach?
abstract: For decades, the shoreline in the shelter of a derelict hospital at Riis Beach has been a queer haven. Soon, the buildings will be demolished.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the shoreline in the shelter of a derelict hospital at Riis Beach has been a queer haven. Soon, the buildings will be demolished.

headline: YouTube Opens More Pathways for Creators to Make Money on the Platform
abstract: The video platform will let more creators earn payments and place ads in Shorts, its TikTok competitor, according to audio from an internal meeting.
lead_paragraph: YouTube is expected to announce more opportunities for content creators to earn money on its video service, hoping to guard its role as a home to popular personalities and gain an edge against rival TikTok.

headline: Without Knowing It, Opening the Door to Romance
abstract: Jobina Fortson and Bradley Evans met when he knocked on her dorm-room door at Howard University looking to use her printer. Eleven years later, they married.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Akil Evans didn’t exactly make the best impression on Jobina Nancee Fortson when the two first met at their Howard University dormitory 11 years ago.

headline: A Relationship With Biblical Origins
abstract: Cecelia Thornton-Alson and Terence Lee met at a wedding, where they read from the ‘Song of Songs,’ and soon began a bicoastal relationship.
lead_paragraph: “Hello, my dove,” Terence Lee said as he was introduced to Cecelia Claire Thornton-Alson at the wedding rehearsal dinner for their mutual friends, in October 2017.

headline: Dog Lovers Become Almost Instant Companions
abstract: Weeks after Kachet Jackson-Henderson and Brandon Bell met on Hinge, where the profiles of both featured photos of their dogs, she ended up in the hospital and he rushed to her side.
lead_paragraph: Days after Kachet Jackson-Henderson and Brandon James Bell had a first date, in September 2021, she noticed unusual bruising all over her body.

headline: Please Let Me Do More Laundry and Vacuuming!
abstract: For decades, I avoided domestic tasks. My failing vision has made me cherish them.
lead_paragraph: I found my wife, Anna, at her desk, working at her computer.

headline: After a Fire, Rebuilding What Matters
abstract: Months before their wedding, Emily Thompson and Stefan Kienle lost most of their possessions in the Marshall fire that destroyed their home and many others in Louisville, Colo.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 23, 2021, Emily Thompson handed her grandmother’s solitaire diamond to a jeweler to have it incorporated into her wedding band. She and her fiancé, Stefan Kienle, had planned to marry in eight months.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Homes Built in Harm’s Way, Even as Wildfires Grow Larger
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Sept. 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a beautiful place to live. But as a society, we really have to wrap our heads around what living so close to nature really entails.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 16, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about religious satire movies misidentified the production of “A Strange Loop” that was shown. It is the Playwrights Horizons production, not the Broadway production.

headline: What Price Is Right? Why Capping Russian Oil Is Complicated.
abstract: Officials from the Group of 7 are striving to strike a delicate balance that encourages Russia to keep pumping oil but to sell it at a discount.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States and its Western counterparts race to finalize the mechanics of an oil price cap intended to starve Russia of revenue and stabilize global energy markets, a crucial question remains unresolved: How should the price be set?

headline: Britain’s Spending and Tax Cut Plans Worry Investors in Its Debt
abstract: Simultaneous declines in bonds, stocks and the pound could set the stage for rising borrowing costs and persistent inflation.
lead_paragraph: Much of the outward business of government in Britain is grinding to a halt during 10 days of national mourning until the state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II, when schools, doctors offices and many shops will close.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A meeting between Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: As he met with the Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Uzbekistan yesterday, Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, acknowledged China’s “questions and concerns” about Russia’s war in Ukraine, suggesting that Moscow lacks the full backing of its biggest, most powerful partner on the world stage.

headline: A Fantasy Novel About a Harsh Reality: Childhood Depression
abstract: “Moonflower,” inspired by the author Kacen Callender’s own struggles, is about helping young people to heal.
lead_paragraph: Kacen Callender is a special kind of writer. The kind of writer who pairs careful craft with unbridled creativity. The kind of writer who pushes narrative boundaries. Which makes their latest novel, “Moonflower,” fresh, exciting and hard to pin down.

headline: This Novel Surprised Our Reviewer: It Didn’t Make Him Cry
abstract: Dan Gemeinhart’s latest book, “The Midnight Children,” is light compared with “The Remarkable Journey of Coyote Sunrise,” but weighty nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: Dan Gemeinhart is a creator of vividly believable worlds animated by whimsy and all the stuff of childhood fantasy, by kids and teenagers untethered from adult rules who make surprisingly grown-up decisions. He is also unusually obsessed with grief and loss.

headline: A Quarterback Showdown Is Decided by a Rookie Cornerback
abstract: Thursday’s matchup between Patrick Mahomes and Justin Herbert went to Kansas City thanks to an interception by cornerback Jaylen Watson.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Three years ago, Jaylen Watson was working for his mother at a Wendy’s in Augusta, Ga. He was making $7.50 an hour and getting his grades in order. On Thursday, he was the most important player on the field for Kansas City, though one that few had heard of.

headline: The World Now Has a Vision of Ukrainian Victory
abstract: After a successful counteroffensive, Ukrainians are cherishing a moment of happiness.
lead_paragraph: KYIV — Three months ago I met Vyacheslav Zadorenko, a community leader from the Kharkiv region. From the relative safety of Derhachi, he told me about how his village, a settlement on the Russian border, had been occupied in the first days of Russia’s invasion. His mother didn’t manage to escape. “My personal victory,” he said, “would be when I can return to my family house.” In midsummer, as Russia consolidated its gains and slowly secured more, that seemed a sad, impossible dream.

headline: Cultural Cringe and ‘The Lost City of Melbourne’
abstract: A new documentary goes some way to explaining why the city looks the way it does.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to New York often remark that it feels like stepping into a film set. To walk through Central Park is to trace the footsteps of Harry and Sally, Spider-Man or various Muppets. Momentary glimpses of the Chrysler Building or the New York Public Library work almost as an establishing shot: This is New York City, baby.

headline: Re-enactors Worry About Bringing Their Muskets to ‘Wars’
abstract: A new state law banning guns in certain public places concerns those who like to commemorate famous battles of the past.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at confusion among re-enactors after a new gun law took effect at the beginning of the month. We’ll also look at a classroom with no walls or windows, but a lovely view and a teacher who says that teaching there helped him get jobs in more conventional settings.

headline: Word of the Day: reprimand
abstract: This word has appeared in 98 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word reprimand has appeared in 98 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 29 in “Air France Under Scrutiny Over Safety Incidents” by Constant Méheut:

headline: Ron DeSantis’s Migrant Stunt Gets Poor Reviews From Late Night
abstract: The Florida governor claimed credit for sending migrants to Martha’s Vineyard. Trevor Noah accused him of trolling on the taxpayers’ dime.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: September 2022 Times/Siena Poll: Cross-Tabs for All Respondents
abstract: Responses from a survey of registered voters conducted by The New York Times and Siena College Sept. 6 to 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Responses from a survey of registered voters conducted by The New York Times and Siena College Sept. 6 to 14, 2022.

headline: Message Bubbles
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: What Shiva Taught Me About Covering Tragedy
abstract: I had never covered a mass shooting before. Calling the families of victims was tough, but a familiar ritual helped me.
lead_paragraph: The day after a mass shooting in Sacramento, one of the worst in the city’s history, its downtown streets were quiet. I stopped in a corner market, steps away from where the shooting had taken place, and I saw the cashier watching footage of the night’s mayhem on his phone. The regular customers, coming in for their cigarettes or sodas, bent over the counter to watch with him, and the shop filled with the sound of screams made tinny through the phone’s speakers.

headline: Democrats Buoyed by Abortion and Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
abstract: President Biden’s approval rating has climbed to 42 percent, and the number of Americans who believe the country is on the right track has doubled but remains low.
lead_paragraph: Even as they struggle to persuade voters that they should be trusted on the economy, Democrats remain unexpectedly competitive in the battle for Congress as the sprint to November’s midterm election begins, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found.

headline: 31 Bridges, 2 Cities, 6 Towns: Greenway Is New Jersey’s High Line
abstract: New Jersey plans to convert a defunct train line into a 9-mile park, connecting the state’s densest cities to some of its wealthiest suburbs.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — For years, the project has been little more than a dearly held dream of environmentalists and safe-streets advocates: a nine-mile hiking and biking trail built along a defunct New Jersey rail line that slices through one of the country’s most densely populated regions.

headline: The Afterlife of Willem de Kooning
abstract: The artist’s ghost lingers in his studio, as an auction of three of his paintings tests the vitality of his commercial reputation.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Two rocking chairs still stand duty about 30 feet from the easel, as if waiting for Willem de Kooning, the Abstract Expressionist luminary, to sit down and scrutinize his wet painting in process. Although the artist died in 1997, his studio and living quarters here on Long Island have been so well preserved by the family that his presence hovers ghostlike in the building he designed.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Mississippi Water Crisis and What It Means for the Rest of the Nation
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how more than 150,000 people were without safe, reliable drinking water for weeks and how climate change has emerged as a growing threat to water systems across the country.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Mississippi Crisis Highlights Climate Threat to Drinking Water Nationwide” by Christopher Flavelle, Rick Rojas, Jim Tankersley and Jack Healy

headline: A mass grave site is found in recently reclaimed Izium.
abstract: IZIUM, Ukraine — A mass grave site uncovered in the city of Izium in northeastern Ukraine could hold the bodies of more than 400 people who died during the six months of Russian occupation, Ukrainian officials say.
lead_paragraph: IZIUM, Ukraine — A mass grave site uncovered in the city of Izium in northeastern Ukraine could hold the bodies of more than 400 people who died during the six months of Russian occupation, Ukrainian officials say.

headline: ‘At the Breaking Point’: Tibetans, Under Lockdown, Make Rare Cries for Help
abstract: China’s ever-tightening Covid rules have prompted public complaints from residents of areas usually intimidated into keeping quiet.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Infected patients quarantined alongside those who tested negative. No food for hours, despite repeated requests. Lines of buses, loaded with people, waiting late into the night to drop them off at makeshift isolation centers.

headline: Ukrainian prosecutors work to document evidence of war crimes in Kharkiv.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian prosecutors working in the northeast of the country to document evidence of war crimes and other atrocities face a monumental task in coming weeks as they treat hundreds of villages and towns spread across thousands of square miles as a crime scene.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian prosecutors working in the northeast of the country to document evidence of war crimes and other atrocities face a monumental task in coming weeks as they treat hundreds of villages and towns spread across thousands of square miles as a crime scene.

headline: Fire and Fear in South Ukraine
abstract: The perilous life of a city under Russian attack, and the firefighters who save it
lead_paragraph: The perilous life of a city under Russian attack, and the firefighters who save it

headline: Are A.I.-Generated Pictures Art?
abstract: A man won an art competition with an image he created using an artificial intelligence program. Was it “cheating”?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever created A.I.-generated art? If so, what did you make, and what was the experience like?

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "The Woman King."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "The Woman King."

headline: What Happens When Ex-Spouses Quarantine Together?
abstract: In “Lucy by the Sea,” Elizabeth Strout relocates a formerly married couple from Manhattan to Maine at the peak of the Covid pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When global events erupt like earthquakes, writers rush to record the aftershocks. In the 21st century, we’ve already seen waves of reportage and fiction in the aftermaths of 9/11, tsunamis, Brexit and Trumpism. Now the literature of Covid has landed, pretty much on schedule, informed by the sensibilities of the well-off. As recounted in their respective books, “Last Best Hope” and “Intimations,” George Packer and Zadie Smith had the means to flee New York when the city locked down in March 2020. So did Gary Shteyngart, whose novel, “Our Country Friends,” chronicles members of the chattering classes displaced to a bungalow colony, away from the ceaseless sirens and spiking fatalities. (A New York Times article featured a photograph of a quarantined Shteyngart, cocktail in hand, at his second house in Dutchess County, where he’d decamped.)

headline: Alan Alda on ‘M*A*S*H’: ‘Everybody Had Something Taken From Them’
abstract: As the acclaimed “situation tragedy” turns 50, the star reflects on its innovations: “The crazy behavior wasn’t just to be funny. It was a way of separating yourself for a moment from the nastiness.”
lead_paragraph: When we think of the default mode of much of contemporary television — mingling the tragic and the offhand, broad comedy and pinpoint sentiment — we are thinking of a precise mixture of styles, emotions and textures first alchemized by “M*A*S*H.”

headline: There’s No Instruction Manual for Parenthood. Books Can Help.
abstract: The kids are back in their classrooms — but are they OK? These new titles can provide reassurance, advice and solidarity.
lead_paragraph: All across America, parents are prancing around the house naked. That’s because our children are in school — and (for the most part) we are saying goodbye to the maddening on-again-off-again online learning of the past two years. But at the same time the cost of these years on physical and mental health has been staggering. The latest crop of parenting books tries to reckon with this reality.

headline: Now All Biden Has to Do Is Build It
abstract: Felicia Wong on the hard road ahead to make the president’s plans a lived reality.
lead_paragraph: In the past few months, Joe Biden’s agenda has gone from a failed promise to real legislation.

headline: The Reliable, Graceful and Fallible Roger Federer
abstract: Federer’s moves made even blowout matches worthy of watching. And the moments in which he fell short made his legacy even more intriguing.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: How to Nurse an Oversharing Hangover
abstract: That thing you shared last night? It’s probably just fine.
lead_paragraph: In early August, at a tiki bar in Washington, D.C., Erin Pedati told a group of friends that she’d been struggling with depression. They were good friends, and they responded with empathy and compassion, but the next day Ms. Pedati, 40, felt weird.

headline: Willy Chavarria Takes It to Church
abstract: Classicism, class consciousness and design chops converged at the Latinx designer’s latest presentation.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is no place for people without a stomach for contradiction. Consider the gorgeous, if occasionally lugubrious, Willy Chavarria show on Wednesday in Manhattan at Marble Collegiate Church, home pulpit of President Richard M. Nixon’s favorite clergyman, Norman Vincent Peale, the self-help pundit who wrote “The Power of Positive Thinking.” Exalting and hokey, exhortatory as a sermon and yet subtly persuasive, the show was also so late in starting that guests started fidgeting in the pews.

headline: Nuclear Power Still Doesn’t Make Much Sense
abstract: There’s a lot of new enthusiasm around nuclear power. It isn’t warranted.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I write about the plummeting costs and growing capabilities of wind power, solar power and batteries, I’m usually met with a barrage of radioactive responses from the internet’s overheated nuclear reactors — social-media-savvy environmental activists who insist that nuclear power should play a leading role in the world’s transition away from fossil fuels.

headline: Good News for Weary Travelers: Online Passport Renewal Is Coming Your Way
abstract: The shift will eliminate the need for piles of paperwork and hours waiting in lines. But it will still take some time to actually get your hands on your passport.
lead_paragraph: Following the success of a limited pilot program for online passport renewal this summer, the U.S. State Department says it plans to fully launch an online passport renewal option for the general public in early 2023.

headline: ‘M*A*S*H’ at 50: War Is Hell(arious)
abstract: Five decades ago, “M*A*S*H” anticipated today’s TV dramedies, showing that a great comedy could be more than just funny.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: As Driverless Cars Falter, Are ‘Driver Assistance’ Systems in Closer Reach?
abstract: With investigations and lawsuits over accidents adding skepticism toward fully driverless technology, car companies are betting on systems that take some, but not all, control.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our series on the Future of Transportation, which is exploring innovations and challenges that affect how we move about the world.

headline: Privilege Is in Crisis. Look at Our Elite Private Schools.
abstract: The past few years have witnessed a lot of upheaval in the name of political reckoning. Is the pendulum swinging back to tradition?
lead_paragraph: As we have seen over and over in recent years, privilege is in crisis. Undone by guilt, jittery about an authority it is not eager to relinquish, lost in internal conflicts and contradictions, privilege has earnestly worked to rebrand itself, at times alienated its longstanding constituents, backtracked, corrected, wrung its hands.

headline: Was Kanye Right?
abstract: A civil rights advocate investigates.
lead_paragraph: In her debut essay collection, “Black Skinhead,” Brandi Collins-Dexter, a former senior campaign director for the civil rights nonprofit Color of Change, takes on a task I don’t envy even slightly: trying to make sense of Kanye West. The rapper, producer and fashion designer, who now goes by Ye, has been the architect of some of our era’s most enduring popular music, as well as some of the most head-scratching cultural controversies. Collins-Dexter spends the most time unpacking the ordeal that may have alienated the largest portion of his fan base: when Ye, in May 2018, having already endorsed Donald Trump for the presidency a few years prior, went on TMZ Live and said that slavery was a choice.

headline: She’s Come Undone (on Purpose)
abstract: The jeans of the young and stylish are unzipped, unbuttoned and unbothered. Why?
lead_paragraph: If you see a young person strolling down the street, pants undone, it’s probably not an “examine your zipper” situation.

headline: At Old Coal Mines, the American Chestnut Tries for a Comeback
abstract: Across Appalachia, scientists and foresters are trying to reintroduce a hybrid version, helping to revive damaged land while also bringing back a beloved tree.
lead_paragraph: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ohio — Michael French trudged through a thicket of prickly bramble, unfazed by the branches he had to swat away on occasion in order to arrive at a quiet spot of hilly land that was once mined for coal. Now, however, it is patched with flowering goldenrods and long yellow-green grasses and dotted with tree saplings.

headline: The Story Behind the Averted Rail Strike Is About Employers and Exploitation
abstract: The single best thing President Biden and the Democratic Party could do for workers is to give them the tools and support to build power for themselves.
lead_paragraph: The short story behind the now-averted railroad strike is this: The largest freight railroad carriers in the country were willing to cripple the transportation infrastructure of the United States rather than allow their workers to take the occasional day off to see a doctor or attend to their families.

headline: Humans Have a Long History of Making ‘Very Bad Decisions’ to Save Animals
abstract: As scientists push the frontiers of conservation technology, some of their initiatives raise ethical questions.
lead_paragraph: The third-to-last male northern white rhinoceros on Earth was in his late 20s — middle-aged by rhino standards — when a team of scientists carefully anesthetized him, inserted a probe into his rectum, and administered a mild electric shock to nerves near the prostate, causing the rhino to ejaculate in his sleep. The sperm was then separated out and frozen.

headline: TikTok’s C.E.O. Navigates the Limits of His Power
abstract: Shou Zi Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, is balancing how to be an autonomous leader while juggling the demands of the app’s Chinese parent company.
lead_paragraph: TikTok recently tried to tamp down concerns from U.S. lawmakers that it poses a national security threat because it is owned by the Chinese internet company ByteDance. The viral video app insisted it had an arm’s-length relationship with ByteDance and that its own executive was in charge.

headline: At Millions Per Detainee, Guantánamo Prison Stuck in a Cycle of Costly Delays
abstract: The mission has relied on short-term fixes for things like housing and medical care for two decades. With 36 detainees left, the prison will soon receive its 21st commander.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Fungus was growing in a new $10 million tiny-house village being assembled at Camp Justice, the military court compound at Guantánamo Bay that has been troubled by mold for years. So plans to house lawyers assigned to the Sept. 11 case there have been postponed until late next year.

headline: For Gen Z, TikTok Is the New Search Engine
abstract: Need to find a restaurant or figure out how to do something? Young people are turning to TikTok to search for answers. Google has noticed.
lead_paragraph: When Ja’Kobi Moore decided to apply this year to a private high school in her hometown of New Orleans, she learned that she needed at least one letter of recommendation from a teacher. She had never asked for one, so she sought help.

headline: ‘A Kitchen for the Kitchen’
abstract: The back kitchen, in essence a pantry on overdrive, has become increasingly popular among wealthier homeowners in recent years, according to architects, designers and homebuilders.
lead_paragraph: In May, about 30 eighth graders gathered around the large island in an Indianapolis kitchen to belt out “The sun’ll come out tomorrow” to celebrate a successful school production of “Annie.” About 60 parents cheered them on, spilling out onto the patio.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 16, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: What’s So Frightening About Identical Twins?
abstract: “The Silent Twins,” a new film starring Letitia Wright and Tamara Lawrance, sets out to show the complexity of twinship onscreen.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in England and Wales in the 1970s, the identical twins June and Jennifer Gibbons spoke to each other all the time. They chattered and laughed, and whispered. They were prolific readers and wrote stories that showed great creative promise. They had ambitions to become famous authors.

headline: In the ‘Great Game’ of Central Asia, China’s Leader Seeks the Advantage
abstract: Xi Jinping’s visit to Central Asia this week sheds a light on his country’s efforts to increase its sway in the vast, resource-rich region once considered Russia’s domain.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As Xi Jinping, China’s leader, visited Central Asian countries this week, he stepped off planes to rousing performances by rows of dancers, musicians and ceremonial guards. Uzbekistan’s leader called him “the greatest statesman,” Chinese state media declared, while the leader of Turkmenistan praised his “wise leadership.” They draped him in medals.

headline: Promise and Peril at the Bottom of the Sea
abstract: How a mining company and a regulator are balancing billions of dollars in profits against the future of the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: The adoption of electric cars has been hailed as an important step in curbing the use of fossil fuels and fighting climate change. There is a snag, however: such vehicles require around six times as many metals as their gasoline-powered counterparts.

headline: Profiting in Congress
abstract: Dozens of lawmakers trade stocks related to their work, and it’s harming trust in the government.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress have access to information that ordinary Americans don’t. They meet with chief executives, read classified intelligence reports and help set the rules by which the economy works.

headline: Intense Rainstorms and Flash Floods in Central Italy Leave at Least 9 Dead
abstract: The downpour was the latest in a summer of extreme weather events. Streets were turned into rivers, bridges and highways were blocked and thousands were left without power.
lead_paragraph: ROME — At least nine people died and four others were missing after a rainstorm on Thursday night dumped more than a foot of water on a coastal area of central Italy, officials said on Friday, turning streets into rivers, blocking bridges and highways, and leaving thousands without electricity or gas.

headline: The Future of San Francisco’s Fog and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: French Women’s Player Charged in Attack on Teammate
abstract: Aminata Diallo was detained and then released last year after her Paris St.-Germain teammate was beaten by masked men. On Friday, the police charged her with aggravated assault.
lead_paragraph: A former Paris St.-Germain women’s soccer player was charged with aggravated assault on Friday as part of the investigation into a violent attack on one of her teammates last year by masked men wielding a metal bar.

headline: The Martha’s Vineyard Migrant Stunt Is Making One Truth About This Country Clear
abstract: America’s immigration system has long been overburdened and outdated.
lead_paragraph: Since April, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has bused over 7,900 migrants from the state to Washington, D.C. In August, he began sending migrants to New York. Now, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is getting in on the act, sending two planeloads of migrants to Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. To hear Mr. Abbott tell it, he’s calling the bluff of blue-state mayors who claim to welcome undocumented immigrants. It’s also part of a not-so-secret Republican plan to whip up anger against Democrats ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: After Temporary Break, Line to View Queen’s Coffin Is Reopened
abstract: Would-be mourners in line to pay their respects — known as the Queue — will probably have to wait 24 hours, the British government said, after it reached capacity on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Behind the Scenes of T Magazine’s Cover Shoot
abstract: For T’s fall Men’s Fashion issue, two dozen artists — all Black, queer and under 40 — gathered in homage to the groundbreaking film “Tongues Untied.”
lead_paragraph: On a hot day in early August, 24 people gathered in a studio space in Red Hook, Brooklyn. They all had something in common: All of them were artists.
