They were also all Black, queer and 40 or younger. Four of T’s editors were on set, and they later reported what we would hear from the participants themselves — that the mood was electric; that the camaraderie was genuine. Not all of them had met before, and yet there was a sense of reunion anyway, the feeling that they recognized one another; an actual previous encounter was a mere technicality.

headline: What’s Tea?
abstract: The subjects of T Magazine’s fall Men’s Fashion cover shoot discuss what it means to be young, Black and queer in this film inspired by Marlon Riggs’s “Tongues Untied.”
lead_paragraph: The subjects of T Magazine’s fall Men’s Fashion cover shoot discuss what it means to be young, Black and queer in this film inspired by Marlon Riggs’s “Tongues Untied.”

headline: What Does It Mean to Be a Young, Black Queer Artist Right Now?
abstract: ‘A project like this is almost a double-edged sword’: A conversation with the creatives who are making the culture — and questioning it, too.
lead_paragraph: “Black men loving Black men is the revolutionary act,” says the filmmaker Marlon Riggs in his 1989 documentary, “Tongues Untied.” For Riggs, who would die of complications from AIDS five years later, the film — made during the darkest days of the epidemic — had “a singular imperative: to shatter America’s brutalizing silence around matters of sexual and racial difference.”

headline: Germany Takes Over Russian Oil Subsidiary, Securing a Key Refinery
abstract: Berlin placed the German subsidiary of Russia’s Rosneft in a trust, a step aimed at maintaining energy supplies.
lead_paragraph: The German government has taken over the Russian oil giant Rosneft’s subsidiary in Germany, an action aimed at securing critical energy supplies as Europe moves toward a ban on imports of Russian crude later this year, the economy ministry said on Friday.

headline: Philanthropy, the Billionaires’ Way
abstract: Patagonia founder Yvon Chouinard’s decision to give away billions to fight climate change was made possible by an increasingly popular tax maneuver.
lead_paragraph: The move by the Chouinard family to give away Patagonia, the $3 billion outdoor apparel company founded in the 1970s by Yvon Chouinard, to a special trust and a nonprofit grabbed headlines because it felt like a very un-billionaire-like way to fight climate change.

headline: Western Alaska Lashed by Strongest Storm in Years
abstract: Remnants of Typhoon Merbok caused widespread coastal flooding in the Bering Strait region. Dangerous conditions were expected to continue through the weekend.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm slammed western parts of Alaska on Saturday as a dangerous weather system brought winds of around 90 miles per hour and heavy rain, causing significant coastal flooding.

headline: Laceless Sneakers With a Touch of Class
abstract: An elevated twist on the classic trainer.

headline: Hundreds of Flights in France Canceled as Air Traffic Control Workers Strike
abstract: More than 400 flights departing from or arriving to Paris Charles de Gaulle and Paris Orly airports had been canceled, and about 200 had been delayed, by midday on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Airlines canceled flights across France on Friday as air traffic controllers went on a one-day strike to demand higher wages.

headline: The Sun Get Physical to Stay Alive Against Las Vegas
abstract: On the brink of elimination, Connecticut locked down Chelsea Gray and got superb performances from Jonquel Jones and Alyssa Thomas.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — The Las Vegas Aces were leading the W.N.B.A. finals heading into Thursday largely because of explosive first quarters. They had outscored the Connecticut Sun, 58-32, in the opening period of the first two games, a number that Sun Coach Curt Miller was well aware of. Before Thursday’s Game 3, Miller said he would “love” for the Sun to have an explosive start and force the Aces to take a timeout.

headline: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Rates Again, Citing Weak Consumer Demand
abstract: The bank reduced its key rate by half of a percentage point, to 7.5 percent. Last spring, the rate was 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Russian central bank cut its interest rate again on Friday, continuing to move in the opposite direction to most of the world’s major central banks, as policymakers try to buttress the economy against the impact of international sanctions.

headline: California’s Largest 2022 Wildfire Puts U.C. Research to the Test
abstract: University of California scientists previously conducted controlled burns on 250 acres where the Mosquito fire recently traveled.
lead_paragraph: The Mosquito fire is now the state’s biggest wildfire of the year at more than 64,000 acres. Crews are working to keep the blaze from ripping through towns in the Sierra Nevada northeast of Sacramento.

headline: Attempts to Ban Books Are Accelerating and Becoming More Divisive
abstract: To mark Banned Books Week, the American Library Association released a report on the rise in censorship efforts: In 2022, there have been attempts to restrict access to 1,651 titles.
lead_paragraph: Attempts to ban books are accelerating across the country at a rate never seen since tracking began more than 20 years ago, according to a new report from the American Library Association.

headline: Deadlines for Using Up Flexible Spending Accounts Return
abstract: Relaxed rules during the pandemic let workers carry over more of the pretax money, which must be spent on health costs or forfeited, but they’re expiring.
lead_paragraph: It’s especially important this year to check the balance in your flexible spending account and know the deadline for using it on health costs because the elastic rules adopted in the pandemic are expiring.

headline: Need Your Money Now? The Markets Aren’t Helping.
abstract: The rout in the stock and bond markets has been especially rough on people paying for college, retirement or a new home. Our columnist has some advice.
lead_paragraph: The stock market has been painful if you have been looking at it closely.

headline: How to Change Minds? A Study Makes the Case for Talking It Out.
abstract: Researchers found that meaty conversations among several people can align beliefs and brain patterns — so long as the group is free of blowhards.
lead_paragraph: Co-workers stuck on a Zoom call, deliberating a new strategy for a crucial project. Roommates at the kitchen table, arguing about how to split utility bills fairly. Neighbors at a city meeting, debating how to pay for street repairs.

headline: ‘The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power’ Season 1, Episode 4: Strange Magic
abstract: Prophetic visions, soft power and elf privilege. Here are five takeaways from the fourth episode of Amazon’s “Lord of the Rings” prequel.
lead_paragraph: The title of this week’s “The Rings of Power” refers to a prophetic vision, haunting the Númenor Queen-Regent Míriel’s dreams in the opening scene. As she welcomes an assortment of what look to be elven mothers and their newborn babies, Míriel hears and feels a low rumble, which grows more intense until she looks outside and sees an enormous wave, crashing over the city of Armenelos. Though she wakes up safe (and dry), she fears this will be Númenor’s ultimate end: reclaimed by the Sundering Sea in an act of divine fury. And she feels she needs to do something about it.

headline: What Parents Should Know About the Latest Enterovirus Spike
abstract: The C.D.C. has issued an alert about enterovirus D68, which has been linked to rare, polio-like paralysis.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued an advisory to health care providers about a recent uptick in severe respiratory illness requiring hospitalization in children, urging them to consider a type of enterovirus as a possible cause.

headline: Chile Loses Appeal Seeking Ecuador’s Place in World Cup
abstract: A FIFA panel reaffirmed an earlier decision dismissing Chile’s claim that its rival fielded an ineligible player. Chile plans one last appeal.
lead_paragraph: Chile failed Friday in its latest attempt to have its South American rival Ecuador thrown out of soccer’s World Cup, another setback in a high-stakes campaign that threatened to alter the field for the sport’s showcase championship only two months before the tournament’s opening match.

headline: After 13 Years, a Zesty Haydn Survey Makes Its Mark
abstract: Jean-Efflam Bavouzet has released a rare, 11-volume collection of the composer’s 62 piano sonatas.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Efflam Bavouzet faced both good and bad news in 1989.

headline: Will the Spiraling Publicity Harm ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ at the Box Office?
abstract: A series of missteps on the promotional trail has raised questions about the film’s viability and its director, Olivia Wilde.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the hottest projects Hollywood had seen in years. Eighteen bidders. An ascendant female director. Florence Pugh, the actress of the moment, shooting upward like a rocket. “Don’t Worry Darling” was set up to be a smash.

headline: In Mourning the Queen, Some in Hong Kong Mourn the Past
abstract: A memorial for Elizabeth has given residents of the former British colony a rare platform for public, if quiet, political dissent.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Welcome to Wrexham: It’s the Future
abstract: Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds seem sincere about their investment, emotionally and financially, in a Welsh soccer team. But they are not mere observers in its story.
lead_paragraph: The first thing, and likely the most important thing, is that Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney seem to be sincere. It is hard to be absolutely certain, of course: They are both actors, after all, and a 45-minute Zoom meeting is, on balance, probably not the ideal format in which to take the measure of someone’s soul.

headline: Stocks Slide in One of Wall Street’s Worst Weeks This Year
abstract: Pessimism is deepening as bellwether companies like FedEx and General Electric warn of worsening economic and business conditions.
lead_paragraph: Stocks fell on Friday, ending one of the worst weeks of the year for Wall Street. But a parade of prominent investors and corporate executives made it clear that they believed the worst was yet to come for the economy and financial markets.

headline: Lit Trivia: How Well Do You Know Books About the U.S. Space Program?
abstract: Waiting for the Artemis 1 lunar mission to launch? Test your knowledge of nonfiction books about America’s history of space exploration.
lead_paragraph: Waiting for the Artemis 1 lunar mission to launch? Test your knowledge of nonfiction books about America’s history of space exploration.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make an heirloom tomato pizza, try orange-cardamom pancakes for breakfast and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I had a remarkable heirloom tomato pizza the other day, at Lucia of Avenue X in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Sal Carlino, the chef and owner, bakes a white pie and then shingles slices of raw tomato over the top. When you order a slice, he puts it in the oven to reheat, but only briefly, so that the tomato doesn’t really cook. It’s like bruschetta pizza. It’s really cool.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include two of the best horror films of the year, two thrillers about online exploitation and one dark fairy tale about a monster named Alli.
lead_paragraph: This supernatural thriller from the writer-director Eskil Vogt, about children with powers they don’t know how to handle, is intensely creepy and atmospheric, but also humane and heartbreaking. It’s one of my favorite horror films of the year.

headline: At eBay, Lurid Crimes and the Search for Punishment
abstract: The victims of a bizarre cyberstalking operation are trying to hold the chief executive and the culture of the company responsible.
lead_paragraph: “If you are ever going to take her down .. now is the time.”

headline: Newly Published, From Zora Neale Hurston to the Russian Revolution
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: SAY HELLO?, by Sung Mi Kim. Translated by Clare Richards. (Berbay, $18.99, ages 3 to 6.) For shy children, or anyone apprehensive when navigating new situations, this picture book about missed opportunities to greet one another is a must. Through her masterly use of evasive language and negative space, Kim whimsically exhorts us to connect.

headline: Is New York City Finally Returning to the Office?
abstract: With rising subway ridership and office occupancy, the city’s post-Labor Day return has offered early signs that New York may finally be turning over a new chapter in its recovery.
lead_paragraph: This week, Mick Magsino fired up his commuting playlist with Arcade Fire and U2 as he resumed his 40-minute subway ride to work. For the first time since the pandemic started, Mr. Magsino decided that he was going to return twice a week to his office near Times Square.

headline: Timeline: Adnan Syed’s Murder Conviction Overturned
abstract: The defendant, who was the subject of the 2014 podcast “Serial,” had been serving a life sentence for the 1999 murder of his high school classmate Hae Min Lee.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Baltimore overturned the murder conviction of Adnan Syed on Monday, releasing him from prison 23 years after he was convicted in the death of a high school classmate.

headline: Did Fauci Lead America Astray on Covid?
abstract: Responses to an essay that criticized Anthony Fauci’s handling of the pandemic. Also: Migrants as props; abortion rights; David Milch; theater’s lessons.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For More Delicious Beans, Just Add Mussels
abstract: Garlic, olive oil and rosemary make the best broth for this fast one-pot meal.
lead_paragraph: The best thing about a meal of steamed mussels is the sauce left at the bottom of the bowl. Yes, I adore the bivalves themselves — those sweet, saline nuggets plucked out of their blue-black shells. (Pro-tip: use an empty pair of shells like tongs to pluck out the meat.) But it’s their sauce — suffused with garlic, wine, and parsley — that makes me swoon, whether sipped from a spoon or sopped up with bread or crispy, golden frites if you’re very lucky.

headline: The climate philanthropists
abstract: The founder of the Patagonia clothing company is handing the business to a nonprofit group. We look at climate giving and why this move is different.
lead_paragraph: Yvon Chouinard, the founder of Patagonia, on Wednesday revealed that he and his family had given away the company and that all future profits from the apparel maker would go toward fighting the climate crisis.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Felicia Wong
abstract: The September 16, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Felicia Wong. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How “Hamilton” was (painstakingly) translated into German. Also in this edition: the women of “Wakanda Forever,” and an interview with Nick Cave.
lead_paragraph: How “Hamilton” was (painstakingly) translated into German. Also in this edition: the women of “Wakanda Forever,” and an interview with Nick Cave.

headline: Lou Reed’s Folky Velvet Underground Demo, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Weyes Blood, Kelela, Mightmare and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Cancels Public Appearances After Falling Ill
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is on bed rest and under observation by a team of doctors, according to four people familiar with his health situation.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, canceled all meetings and public appearances last week after falling gravely ill and is currently on bed rest under observation by a team of doctors, according to four people familiar with his health situation.

headline: Amid Russia’s growing international isolation, India’s leader tells Putin that today is no time for war.
abstract: Mr. Modi was speaking on the s
lead_paragraph: Underlining Russia’s increasing international isolation a day after China’s leader refrained from offering full-throated support of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India told President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday that it is no time for war.

headline: ‘The Woman King’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Gina Prince-Bythewood narrates a sequence from her film.
lead_paragraph: The director Gina Prince-Bythewood narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: Andrew Sean Greer on Writing ‘Less’
abstract: The novelist discusses his Pulitzer-winning comedy about the travels and travails of a heartbroken writer, and William Finnegan talks about surfing.
lead_paragraph: For the next few months, we’re sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcast’s archives. This week’s segments first appeared in 2017 and 2015, respectively.

headline: Watch Warriors in Training in ‘The Woman King’
abstract: The actors perform their own stunts, including a couple of flips to the dirt, in this scene from the film. The director Gina Prince-Bythewood narrates.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: China’s Discovery of Lunar Mineral Could Add to Fuller View of the Moon
abstract: Scientists found a single crystal of a new phosphate mineral while analyzing lunar basalt particles, which were collected from the moon two years ago by the Chang’e-5 mission.
lead_paragraph: Chinese scientists recently announced their discovery of a new lunar mineral among samples collected from the moon during a mission two years ago, adding to the body of knowledge of the Earth’s satellite that had been the focus of earlier space exploration.

headline: Sarah Michelle Gellar Returns to High School Drama — as the Headmaster
abstract: After a break from the spotlight, the actress is poised for a comeback, starting with a role in the Netflix film “Do Revenge.”
lead_paragraph: Sarah Michelle Gellar was jet-lagged from her commute. She had just flown back to Los Angeles from a few days filming the forthcoming “Teen Wolf” spinoff series in Atlanta. Her decision to join “Wolf Pack,” as both a star and executive producer, partly depended on the freedom to stay based in L.A. with her family and commute to the set, packing only a carry-on for each East Coast stint.

headline: Overlooked No More: Sylvia Rexach, Puerto Rican Singer and Composer
abstract: She was especially known for reinventing boleros — songs of stringent, abiding love — amid Puerto Rico’s sexist and militaristic society in the mid-20th century.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Line to See Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Reaches 5 Miles
abstract: The monumentally long, slow-moving line stretching through London along the River Thames was temporarily closed when the estimated wait time to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state reached 14 hours.
lead_paragraph: The monumentally long, slow-moving line stretching through London along the River Thames was temporarily closed when the estimated wait time to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state reached 14 hours.

headline: Review: An Oratorio Cautiously Looks Back on Women’s Suffrage
abstract: Julia Wolfe’s “Her Story,” a commemoration with an eye toward the future, premieres in the state where the 19th Amendment achieved ratification.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was here, a little more than a hundred years ago, that the 19th Amendment crossed the threshold into ratification and granted millions of women the right to vote.

headline: When the Water Cooler Is a Perk
abstract: Yes, you deserve a way to stay hydrated at the office. No, your boss isn’t crossing a line by calling you during the work day.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: N.B.A. Under Pressure to Remove Suns Owner
abstract: A sponsor, team owner and players are calling for a harsher penalty for Robert Sarver, the Phoenix Suns owner, after an investigation found he mistreated employees for years.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before the N.B.A. announced the results of an independent investigation into Robert Sarver, the majority owner of the Phoenix Suns, on Tuesday, a call took place between N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver and Tamika Tremaglio, the executive director of the players’ union.

headline: Sesame Salmon Bowls for All
abstract: Kay Chun’s recipe is an all-ages affair that’s adaptable to everyone’s tastes.
lead_paragraph: Last week I got an email from a reader named Rachel that really spoke to me, and will probably speak to anyone who’s ever had to feed children or another phalanx of picky eaters:

headline: Lowry Mays, Who Revolutionized the Radio Industry, Dies at 87
abstract: He built his company, Clear Channel Communications, from a single struggling station into one of the world’s biggest media empires.
lead_paragraph: Lowry Mays, a businessman who inadvertently acquired a local radio station in the early 1970s and then built it into a media empire called Clear Channel Communications, which revolutionized the entire industry, died on Sept. 12 at his home in San Antonio. He was 87.

headline: Álvarez vs. Golovkin No. 3 Arrives Fashionably Late
abstract: Saúl Álvarez and Gennadiy Golovkin last fought in 2018 but will have a super middleweight title bout on Saturday. After a delay for the usual boxing reasons, the timing is perfect for Álvarez.
lead_paragraph: Follow live Canelo vs. GGG fight updates.

headline: Prince William Moves Into the Spotlight as Heir to the Throne
abstract: Many royal watchers and historians are looking to William and his wife, Catherine, who rank high in popularity polls, as the long-term future of the British monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: How LinkedIn Became a Place to Overshare
abstract: “This isn’t Facebook,” users complain. But others are finding it a valuable place to talk about much more than work.
lead_paragraph: About three years ago, Joel Lalgee started posting on LinkedIn. He works in recruiting, so naturally spent a lot of time on the site, where people list their work experience, and job seekers look for their next gig. But he didn’t just write about work. He wrote about his personal life: the mental health challenges he faced as a teenager, and his life since. “Being able to share my story, I saw it as a way to connect with people and show you’re not alone,” he said.

headline: Killing of Young Gunman Highlights Shifts in Fast-Changing West Bank
abstract: The life of Ibrahim al-Nabulsi, the son of a Palestinian security official, reflects some of the dynamics at play as leaders jockey to succeed Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president.
lead_paragraph: NABLUS, West Bank — The short life and bloody death of Ibrahim al-Nabulsi encapsulated why both Palestinians and Israelis fear that a surge of violence in the occupied West Bank will not end soon.

headline: Wonking Out: What Ukraine Needs From Us
abstract: Lawyers, guns and money. OK, skip the lawyers.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been seeing what seems like a growing number of reports about Ukraine’s economic difficulties. And it definitely makes sense to focus more on the country’s economy now that the tide seems to have turned in Ukraine’s favor on the battlefield.

headline: A California Home That Conjures ‘Little Women’ on Acid
abstract: In response to her client’s request, the designer Chloe Warner delivered a layered riot of colors, patterns and styles.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that a homeowner offers an interior designer a distinct cultural reference and the complete creative freedom to channel it, but that’s what Chloe Warner, the founder of Redmond Aldrich Design, received when she took on a two-story shingled Craftsman in Piedmont, a small city nestled within the larger one of Oakland, Calif. More specifically, her client, a friend of hers whose children attended the same school as Warner’s daughter, was looking for something reminiscent of Greta Gerwig’s 2019 film adaptation of “Little Women” (1868-69) — “I felt it captured the feeling of a full house and this sense of happy chaos,” says the homeowner. But, she specified, “Little Women” on acid. This was modern-day California, after all, not 19th-century Massachusetts.

headline: How to Wear Your Backpack Properly
abstract: Try to keep heavier things closer to the body.
lead_paragraph: Try to keep heavier things closer to the body.

headline: The California County Where MAGA Took Control
abstract: In a state run by Democrats, Shasta County is a rare instance where far-right activists dominate board meetings and exert power.
lead_paragraph: REDDING, Calif. — Times are grim in the cowboy far north of California. Wildfires rage. Covid-19 lingers. Drought has stripped most of the snow from Mount Shasta and shrunk Shasta Lake.

headline: In This Playwright’s Dystopia, Forgetting Is Forbidden
abstract: Steven Fechter’s “The Memory Exam” begins with a promising setup, our critic writes, while Grant MacDermott’s marriage story “Jasper” struggles for emotional resonance.
lead_paragraph: Far from any humans who might report suspicious activity, or surveillance cameras that would record it, a tetchy little foursome emerges into a clearing deep in the woods. What they’re doing is forbidden, and if they are caught, they could be killed.

headline: Love Letter: Housework and a Hereditary Disease
abstract: While losing his vision, a man finds new meaning in simple, domestic chores.
lead_paragraph: “Contrary to self-help memes, disease is not a gift. Gifts are free; the afflicted pay for their ailments with painful treatments, mood swings and micro-humiliations.

headline: In Toronto, Films by Women About Women, but That’s Where the Similarities End
abstract: The Toronto International Film Festival returns to business mostly as usual with throngs of excited attendees and some of the year’s most anticipated new movies.
lead_paragraph: Each year, filmgoers of all persuasions, casual viewers and true believers both, descend on the Toronto International Film Festival to sample and to gorge. Cannes has the red carpet, Telluride has Oscar contenders and Sundance has the next big thing, maybe. Toronto has bulk. It’s stuffed with movies of every type, size, style and ambition. Some are destined for immortality and others will enter the Oscar marathon that has already begun. Still other titles will languish on streaming platforms; some of these will deserve better fates.

headline: Jorja Fleezanis, Violinist and Pioneering Concertmaster, Dies at 70
abstract: “Being a concertmaster is terribly demanding,” she once said, “but women can handle the job as well as men can. I know that.”
lead_paragraph: Jorja Fleezanis, a dynamic violinist and dedicated teacher who was one of the first women to serve as concertmaster of a major symphony orchestra in the United States, died on Sept. 9 at her home in Lake Leelanau, Mich. She was 70.

headline: With a New King, Arts Institutions Seek New Patrons
abstract: More than 100 of Britain’s museums, orchestras and opera houses have royal endorsements. But the queen’s death and a reshuffling of the monarchy’s top roles have left the system in limbo.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jasmine Allen, the director of the Stained Glass Museum in Ely, England, was preparing to send a letter to Prince Charles this month, asking if he wanted to extend his relationship with the esoteric museum.

headline: Judge Raymond Dearie Takes On Fraught Role in Trump Documents Case
abstract: The long-serving federal judge was named as the special master with responsibility for sifting through the materials seized from the former president.
lead_paragraph: He has prosecuted drug dealers, overseen corruption cases and authorized warrants in highly classified investigations.

headline: Uber Boss Testifies He ‘Could Not Trust’ Ex-Security Chief
abstract: Dara Khosrowshahi is a star witness at the trial of Joe Sullivan, who has been accused of obstructing justice for failing to disclose the 2016 breach.
lead_paragraph: Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, said in court on Friday that he had fired Joe Sullivan, the former Uber security chief who is on trial over a 2016 security breach, because he could no longer trust him.

headline: Video Reveals How Russian Mercenaries Recruit Inmates for Ukraine War
abstract: In a video posted on social media on Tuesday, the de facto leader of a Russian mercenary group explained to Russian convicts how they could earn their freedom by fighting in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In a video that emerged on Tuesday, the de facto leader of a Russian mercenary outfit known as the Wagner Group is seen promising convicts release from prison in return for a six-month combat tour in Russia’s war against Ukraine.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: A previously unpublished interwar novel by Simone de Beauvoir, how the world’s constitutions came to be and more.
lead_paragraph: A previously unpublished interwar novel by Simone de Beauvoir, how the world’s constitutions came to be and more.

headline: Trying to Prove You’re Not a Racist
abstract: Saying you agree with my opinions on race may only dig your hole deeper.
lead_paragraph: Since I started writing this newsletter, once about every couple of weeks I have received a missive from someone troubled by a controversy involving race, usually in the workplace.

headline: Mississippi Lifts Boil Advisory in Jackson, but Its Water System Remains Troubled
abstract: Health authorities issued the boil-water notice in late July, when testing showed the water supply might be unsafe, and heavy rains in August caused the largest treatment plant in the system to fail.
lead_paragraph: Repairs to the water system in Mississippi’s capital, Jackson, have allowed officials to lift a boil-water advisory, but further work and testing were needed to ensure it remained safe to use, Gov. Tate Reeves said this week.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: Even though the network late-night hosts didn’t win any Emmys this week, the ceremony was top of mind for them. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: Even though the network late-night hosts didn’t win any Emmys this week, the ceremony was top of mind for them. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: U.S. Discloses Decades of Justice Dept. Memos on Presidential War Powers
abstract: Executive branch lawyers secretly worked to limit the reach of a post-Vietnam War law, according to a trove of opinions from the Office of Legal Counsel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Department lawyers have secretly worked under presidents of both parties to narrowly interpret the reach of a law passed at the end of the Vietnam War meant to reassert Congress’s constitutional role in deciding whether to go to war, newly disclosed memos show.

headline: These Left-Handed Golfers Are Content to Go Their Own Way
abstract: Outnumbered on courses and ill-served by pro shops, a society of British players happily defends their turf, and their cause, from the other side of the tee box.
lead_paragraph: ROTHERHAM, England — If anyone questions Alan Haines’s left-handed golf swing, he jokingly reminds them that he happens to be the one standing on the right side of the ball.

headline: Russia and Ukraine trade blows in the south.
abstract: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian and Russian forces traded long-distance blows in southern Ukraine on Friday, bombing each other’s positions and inflicting major damage.
lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian and Russian forces traded long-distance blows in southern Ukraine on Friday, bombing each other’s positions and inflicting major damage.

headline: A Stirring Start, but Also Some Growing Pains, for a King Long in Waiting
abstract: King Charles III has had an enthusiastic public reception so far, but for this man of strong opinions, replacing the beloved queen will be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Desperate Clients Hold Up Lebanese Banks to Get Their Own Cash
abstract: The holdups are becoming increasingly common, with five on Friday alone as a financial crisis and a freeze on bank withdrawals push some depositors to the brink.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Armed customers stormed at least five Lebanese banks on Friday to demand access to their own funds, which have been trapped by Lebanon’s worsening financial collapse.

headline: ‘Phantom of the Opera,’ Broadway’s Longest-Running Show, to Close
abstract: The theatergoing audience has been slow to return after the pandemic lockdown, and the show hasn’t been selling well enough to defray its running costs.
lead_paragraph: “The Phantom of the Opera,” the longest-running show in Broadway history and, for many, a symbol of musical theater, will drop its famous chandelier for the last time in February, becoming the latest show to fall victim to the drop-off in audiences since the pandemic hit.

headline: MoMA Photo Curator Departs for French Foundation After 2 Years
abstract: Clément Chéroux, who joined the museum in 2020, will direct the Henri Cartier-Bresson Foundation in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Clément Chéroux, the chief curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, will return to his native France to direct the Henri Cartier-Bresson Foundation, a photography institute in Paris. His departure, announced Thursday by the French foundation, comes after just two years at MoMA, during which the museum was closed for the coronavirus pandemic and its programming was disrupted.

headline: Who’s the Best in Men’s Tennis? It Depends How You Measure.
abstract: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic all have credible claims to be considered the best. Here are a few ways to consider their gaudy stats.
lead_paragraph: When Roger Federer announced his retirement this week, he was showered with hosannas befitting one of the greatest men’s tennis players of all time.

headline: A ‘Terrible Picture of What the Occupiers Did’
abstract: Ukraine begins to exhume bodies from a mass grave site.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: The New, Improved James Cameron Wants to Reintroduce You to ‘Avatar’
abstract: Before the release of the sequel “Avatar: The Way of Water,” the iconoclastic filmmaker explains why he’s bringing the first film back to theaters.
lead_paragraph: The pop-cultural landscape looked considerably different in 2009. Television shows were still largely watched on television sets. “TiK ToK” referred to a hit song by Kesha. And the Marvel Cinematic Universe consisted of only two movies released the previous year.

headline: Ukraine is consolidating its gains, but Russia is shoring up its defensive lines, a Pentagon spokesman said.
abstract: WASHINGTON — Ukrainian forces continue to shore up their gains after a lightning counteroffensive against Russian troops in the northern Kharkiv region, the Pentagon’s chief spokesman said Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ukrainian forces continue to shore up their gains after a lightning counteroffensive against Russian troops in the northern Kharkiv region, the Pentagon’s chief spokesman said Friday.

headline: U.S. Immigration Debate Rings Hollow in Venezuela as Migrants Flee
abstract: More than a fifth of Venezuela’s population has fled the country, and critics said the move by Republican governors to ship migrants to other states would not dissuade others from leaving.
lead_paragraph: MARACAIBO, Venezuela — When Ana Villalobos heard that a group of Venezuelan migrants were at the center of a mushrooming political controversy in the United States, her reaction was swift and anguished.

headline: Herbert Kohler, Plumbing Mogul Who Created a Golf Mecca, Dies at 83
abstract: The billionaire chief of a family company known for its bathtubs, toilets and faucets, he brought championship play to a tiny Wisconsin town.
lead_paragraph: Herbert V. Kohler Jr., who built a century-old family business known for bathtubs, toilets and faucets into a multibillion-dollar global enterprise and turned a tiny company town into an unlikely stop for the world’s top golfers, died on Sept. 3 in Kohler, Wis. He was 83.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Beatriz Milhazes Breaks the Circle
abstract: In her first show with Pace gallery in Manhattan, the Brazilian artist both experiments and returns to figuration.
lead_paragraph: Beatriz Milhazes used to be fearful of diagonals.

headline: The Job of the Special Master in the Trump Documents Inquiry, Explained
abstract: A judge’s order detailed the tasks of the independent arbiter appointed to filter material the F.B.I. seized from the former president’s residence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The appointment of an independent arbiter, known as a special master, to filter the documents that F.B.I. agents seized last month from former President Donald J. Trump’s residence and club has heightened interest in that person’s responsibilities.

headline: Free Pizza and Easy Sleep: W.N.B.A. Upgrades Travel for Finals
abstract: For the first time ever, the W.N.B.A. is providing charter flights throughout the finals. Aces and Sun players are loving it — and hope it becomes permanent.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — There were “oohs and aahs” of excitement as the Connecticut Sun players entered their chartered plane on the way to Las Vegas for Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals, guard Nia Clouden said.

headline: Warnings From Authors Who Track Domestic Extremism
abstract: Luke Mogelson and Andy Campbell have followed groups like the Proud Boys for years. They are terrified at what they see as a growing threat.
lead_paragraph: It is rare that a chill runs down my spine when I’m interviewing someone. But that’s precisely what happened when I spoke recently with Luke Mogelson and Andy Campbell, the authors of two new books on homegrown extremism and the threat it poses to American democracy.

headline: Fuel Hike Plunges Haiti Into Near Anarchy
abstract: Discontent over economic misery spilled into the largest national protests in years, prompting international calls for action.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Escalating street protests have pushed Haiti’s already dire social crisis this week into what regional leaders described as a “low-intensity civil war,” leaving residents of the capital cut off from the outside world and scrambling for basic necessities like drinking water and food.

headline: Trump’s Team of Lawyers Marked by Infighting and Possible Legal Troubles of Its Own
abstract: Several of the former president’s lawyers are under scrutiny by federal investigators amid squabbling over competence.
lead_paragraph: To understand the pressures, feuds and questions about competence within former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team as he faces potential prosecution on multiple fronts, consider the experience of Eric Herschmann, a former Trump White House lawyer who has been summoned to testify to a federal grand jury.

headline: As India Joins China in Distancing From Russia, Putin Warns of Escalation
abstract: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
lead_paragraph: Underlining Russia’s widening isolation on the world stage, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India told President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday that it is no time for war — even as the Russian president threatened to escalate the brutality of his campaign in Ukraine.

headline: In Georgia County With Racist History, Flier Paints Abrams as Invading Enemy
abstract: Stacey Abrams is making a campaign stop in largely white Forsyth County. A G.O.P.-branded flier urged residents to “protect our neighborhoods” in a rally that was later canceled.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After a digital flier featuring the logo of the Republican Party of Forsyth County, Ga., urged residents to rally against Stacey Abrams, alarming and infuriating local Democratic leaders who said its message sounded dangerously evocative of the county’s notoriously racist past, the Forsyth Republican Party announced that it was calling the rally off.

headline: In G.O.P.-Leaning Ohio, the Vance-Ryan Senate Race Is Closer Than Once Expected
abstract: Representative Tim Ryan, the Democratic nominee for Senate, had some advantages coming out of his May primary. But in Ohio, those advantages may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: Less than two months before Election Day, the Ohio Senate race appears tighter than many once expected in a state that former President Donald J. Trump won by eight percentage points in 2020 — even as there are clear reminders of the limitations Democrats face there.

headline: Biden meets with relatives of Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan.
abstract: The president is trying to negotiate the release of the two Americans imprisoned in Russia amid poisoned relations over the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden met on Friday with family members of Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, two Americans imprisoned in Russia whose release the United States is trying to negotiate with Moscow amid poisoned relations over the war in Ukraine.

headline: It Is Long Past Time to Help New York’s Hasidic Children
abstract: Politicians have known for years about the crisis facing New York’s Hasidic schools but failed to act in any meaningful way.
lead_paragraph: It is an essential obligation of state government and foundational to life and liberty: New York requires children to go to school and to receive instruction in English and math and other basic skills that are necessary for participation in our democratic society.

headline: Migrants Flown to Martha’s Vineyard Say They Were Misled
abstract: The flights, arranged by Florida’s Republican governor, underscored how easily the fate of immigrants can be swept up in politics.
lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Migrants shipped to this elite vacation island by Florida’s Republican governor said on Friday that they had been misled about where they were being taken, prompting immigration lawyers to promise legal action as the group of Venezuelans were relocated temporarily to a federal military base.

headline: Is That Legal? How Scores of Migrants Came to Be Shipped North
abstract: The migrant drop-offs orchestrated by two Republican governors raised questions about how the law treats immigrants. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A pair of southern Republican governors this week used scores of migrants in a political stunt designed to bludgeon Democrats about the state of the nation’s immigration system, loading the migrants onto airplanes and buses bound for heavily progressive places to the north.

headline: At Mass Grave Site in Ukraine’s Northeast, a Sign of Occupation’s Toll
abstract: Russian troops held the city of Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, for six months. One burial site found this week could hold the remains of more than 400 people, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: IZIUM, Ukraine — Hundreds of graves had been cut into the sandy soil of a pine forest, isolated and unexamined. A chilly wind blew through the tree branches. Police officers spoke in hushed tones. And newly dug up bodies lay all about on the forest floor.

headline: A federal court clears the way for a Texas social media law.
abstract: The law, which had been blocked by a lower court, makes it possible to sue large social media platforms for taking down political viewpoints.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday reversed a lower court’s order blocking a Texas law that stops large social media platforms from removing political posts, a blow for tech companies that say their content moderation decisions are protected by the Constitution.

headline: Henry Silva, Actor Who Specialized in Menace, Dies at 95
abstract: He was forever cast as a thug, a hit man or some other nefarious character. But he took pride in his ability to play each bad guy differently.
lead_paragraph: Henry Silva, who for decades was high on the call list of any Hollywood casting director in search of a particularly menacing villain, died on Wednesday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Yeshiva University Halts All Student Clubs to Block L.G.B.T.Q. Group
abstract: Earlier in the week, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed a ruling to stand for now that required the university to recognize the group.
lead_paragraph: Yeshiva University abruptly announced on Friday that it had placed all undergraduate club activities on hold, the latest maneuver in the legal battle by the Modern Orthodox Jewish institution to keep from recognizing an L.G.B.T.Q. student group.

headline: Lawyer Told Archives Last Year That Trump Had No Classified Material
abstract: A lawyer representing the former president told the National Archives that boxes taken from the White House contained material like newspaper clippings.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives has told the Justice Department that a lawyer representing former President Donald J. Trump indicated to the archives last year that boxes Mr. Trump had taken to his Mar-a-Lago home from the White House included only nonclassified material like newspaper clippings, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: U.S. Asks Appeals Court to Restore Access to Sensitive Records Seized From Trump
abstract: The government, while calling a lower court’s decision “unprecedented,” did not seek to stop the installation of an outside arbiter to review other materials taken from Mar-a-Lago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department asked an appeals court on Friday to let the F.B.I. regain access to about 100 sensitive documents taken from former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Florida but did not try to block the appointment of an outside arbiter to review other materials.

headline: In Iran, Woman’s Death After Arrest by the Morality Police Triggers Outrage
abstract: Mahsa Amini was detained for allegedly violating dress rules. Her suspicious death, publicized by social media, has led to protests and condemnations by prominent Iranians.
lead_paragraph: The death on Friday of a 22-year-old woman in Iran after she was detained by the morality police has fanned new outrage over the government’s stringent efforts to enforce its hijab law, which mandates covered hair and loosefitting robes for women.

headline: Thereabout
abstract: Grant Thackray’s puzzle visits exotic and unusual lands.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we have a challenge with a low word count (64) and six debut entries, including all four long entries at the grid’s top and bottom. I was repeatedly bamboozled by excellent wordplay from Grant Thackray, who hasn’t constructed a themeless puzzle for The New York Times in over a year.

headline: Map: Tracking Typhoon Nanmadol
abstract: A map showing the storm’s path as it heads toward Japan.
lead_paragraph: A map showing the storm’s path as it heads toward Japan.

headline: After 75 Years, Cheetahs Return to India in a Grand Experiment
abstract: Scientists aim to determine whether a predator population can be restored in a place where it was hunted into extinction.
lead_paragraph: KUNO NATIONAL PARK, India — Cheetahs once prowled India among lions, tigers and leopards. They appear in ancient Hindu texts and in cave paintings, and are woven into centuries-old tapestries. The Mughal emperor Akbar kept 1,000 cheetahs in his stables.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Reclaiming a Rich Baritone From the Havoc of Five Russian Bullets
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Sept. 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I felt each and every bullet. First it hit one leg, then the leg once more. Then I saw my fingers destroyed. After that, I felt a bullet in my side and back.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 17, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the public viewing of Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin referred imprecisely to the location where the public will be able to see the coffin. While her body will lie in state at Westminster Abbey, it will be on view to the public at Westminster Hall.

headline: Canelo vs. GGG: What to Watch in the Trilogy Bout
abstract: Saúl Álvarez and Gennadiy Golovkin, the fighters nicknamed Canelo and GGG, are expected to take the ring about 11 p.m. Eastern for their bout carried on DAZN pay-per-view in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Follow live Canelo vs. GGG fight updates.

headline: The ‘Wild Field’ Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
abstract: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — On a clear spring morning eight years ago, Oleksandr Khainus stepped outside his house to go to work at the town factory when he spotted new graffiti scrawled across his fence. “Glory to Russia,” vandals had written in angry black spray paint. “Putin,” another message said.

headline: Izium discoveries renew focus on holding Russia accountable for civilian toll.
abstract: The U.N. General Assembly voted to allow Ukraine’s president to address the gathering of world leaders with a recorded message next week.
lead_paragraph: The discovery this week of hundreds of bodies buried in a forest near the northeastern Ukrainian city of Izium has cast a renewed spotlight on potential war crimes and prompted fresh calls to hold Russia accountable for any abuses committed during their occupation of the city.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Can My Landlord Charge for Spare Keys?
abstract: It seems simple enough to hold spare keys for tenants at the front desk, but if one goes missing it can create security headaches.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am a rent-stabilized tenant living in a Manhattan building with a mix of rent-stabilized and market-rate apartments. We have new management, which recently instituted a strange rule: Tenants will be charged $50 if they need to retrieve their own keys from the front desk. (They get one free retrieval.) We are no longer allowed to leave keys for family members, dog walkers, care givers or other visitors. Is it legal to charge tenants for the use of keys that they provided to the landlord?

headline: The Subprime Loans for College Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Many families can borrow most of the cost of college using a Parent PLUS loan. This will not end well.
lead_paragraph: If you want your kids to go to college but you can’t afford the bills, the federal government has a deal for you that will blow your mind.

headline: Rally With Trump? Some G.O.P. Candidates Aren’t Thrilled About It.
abstract: Whether he is invited or not, the former president keeps holding rallies in battleground states. It reflects an awkward dance as Republican candidates try to win over general-election voters.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is preparing to swoop into Ohio on Saturday to rally Republicans behind J.D. Vance in a key Senate race. Two weeks earlier, he did the same for Mehmet Oz in Pennsylvania.

headline: An eastern city under attack wonders how far Ukraine’s offensive can go.
abstract: From atop his tank’s turret, the grinning Ukrainian soldier looked almost joyous: He flashed the V for victory sign as his armored vehicle navigated a street corner in the embattled eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut, the diesel engines screaming as the tank lumbered toward the front line.
lead_paragraph: From atop his tank’s turret, the grinning Ukrainian soldier looked almost joyous: He flashed the V for victory sign as his armored vehicle navigated a street corner in the embattled eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut, the diesel engines screaming as the tank lumbered toward the front line.

headline: When Her Husband Is Guilty, What’s a Wife to Do?
abstract: In “The Complicities,” Stacey D’Erasmo introduces a woman who is rebuilding her life in the aftermath of her ex’s financial wrongdoings.
lead_paragraph: Guilt by association is a thorny concept, especially now, in our ravaged world. How much are we to blame for the many misdeeds, intimate and global, that we may not perpetrate, but from which we benefit? And if we admit culpability, to what extent are we responsible for redress? Do we stop using plastic straws? Give up international travel? Live off the grid? I often think about that famous scene in “The Sopranos,” in which Carmela’s therapist tells her she’s guilty of her husband’s crimes by virtue of domestic proximity. “You’ll never be able to quell the feelings of guilt and shame that you talked about,” the therapist says, “as long as you’re his accomplice.”

headline: An Unprovoked Killing Leaves a Void in a Bronx Neighborhood
abstract: Nathaniel Rivers, 35, was sitting in his car when a man fatally stabbed him for no reason. Months later, the crime continues to rattle residents.
lead_paragraph: In an apartment in the Norwood neighborhood of the Bronx, Sahyeedah Belis sat on her bedroom floor, Nike Air Jordan shoe boxes neatly packed with pay stubs arrayed next to her outstretched feet.

headline: My Life in Error
abstract: A copy editor recounts his obsession with perfection.
lead_paragraph: When I was a very young person, one of the jewels of my burgeoning personal library was a book about American Indians (as they would have been called back then). It was oversize, and heavily illustrated, with one of those shiny plastic cases that have a pebbled texture — the better to wipe down the book if you spilled something on it, I guess. I read and reread it, as I liked to do then with my favorite books, and still like to do now.

headline: Lip-Reading and Fashion Criticism: Meghan’s U.K. Trip Under Scrutiny
abstract: The actions of Meghan, and her husband, Prince Harry, as they mourn the queen have been the subject of biting social commentary — as usual.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — All Meghan Markle did was put on a somber outfit and a sympathetic expression and walk around in public with three other people for 45 minutes. But the pointillistic armchair analysis of that brief event — a surprise outing outside Windsor Castle last Saturday featuring Meghan and her husband, Prince Harry, and Prince William and his wife — has gone on ever since.

headline: The Spirit Behind High-End Tequila
abstract: As the founder of Casa Dragones tequila, Bertha González Nieves is a leader in an industry still dominated by men.
lead_paragraph: Bertha González Nieves, Mexico’s first official maestra tequilera — or female master distiller — talked as she poured.

headline: How Dr. Becky Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The parenting expert tries to fit it all in, from workouts and pancakes to game time and play dates.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Kennedy, or Dr. Becky to the millennials who follow her parenting advice on Instagram and other digital platforms, just published her first book, “Good Inside: A Guide to Becoming the Parent You Want to Be,” which builds on conversations from her online membership community and podcast. A clinical psychologist, Dr. Kennedy, 39, lives in an apartment on the Upper West Side with her husband and their sons, 10 and 5, and their daughter, 7.

headline: The State of New York Fashion
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the fashion week that was.
lead_paragraph: It was the weekend of New York Fashion Week, and it was raining on Tommy Hilfiger’s runway parade.

headline: A Fight Over Nantucket’s Bluff Pits Neighbor Against Neighbor
abstract: In an increasingly litigious conflict, the island’s residents are clashing over how to deal with the effects of climate change: Push back or accept what’s coming?
lead_paragraph: Houses along Baxter Road on the island of Nantucket have always been precarious real estate: property at the edge of the world with a built-in expiration date.

headline: In the City That Never Sleeps, Some Doors Now Close at 10 p.m.
abstract: Is New York still a 24-hour town?
lead_paragraph: If you see “Moulin Rouge” on Broadway on a Thursday at 8 p.m. and get out of the theater after 10:30, definitely do not take the train down to Wo Hop expecting to get some 11 p.m. lo mein. The subway is back to running all night, but the Chinatown institution that was once open 24 hours now closes at 10 p.m.

headline: The U.S. Vowed to Defend Central American Democracy. Autocrats Had Other Plans.
abstract: The Biden administration’s plan to stem migration by building the rule of law in Central America has thus far failed to stop authoritarians or persuade people to stay.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Standing in Guatemala’s National Palace last June, Vice President Kamala Harris outlined a sharp break with President Donald J. Trump’s approach to undocumented migration. Instead of building walls and deporting minors, the United States would focus on reducing corruption and impunity in Central America, giving the hundreds of thousands of migrants who leave the region each year a reason to stay.

headline: Some Kids Play Sports. These Kids Train Wild Horses.
abstract: The Devil’s Garden Colt Challenge offers a solution to California’s overpopulation of mustangs.
lead_paragraph: ALTURAS, Calif. — The young mustangs cantered restlessly in the snow around Double Devil Wild Horse Corrals in December, their coats thick and unkempt.

headline: Will Welch Leads GQ to ‘the New Masculinity’
abstract: When he got the job as top editor, a friend told him, “Yikes.” Now, with an assist from Brad Pitt, he has remade the men’s magazine for the post-#MeToo age.
lead_paragraph: Will Welch, the 41-year-old editor of GQ, towered over the other pedestrians as he walked along Church Street in Lower Manhattan on the first night of New York Fashion Week. He was dressed in a blue suit that had been custom-made for him by Ermanno Lazzarin, the proprietor of Eral 55, a men’s shop in Milan that GQ recently named one of the world’s 100 best clothing stores. Mr. Welch said he liked the fact that bespoke suits are never quite perfect: “All the fabric is cut by hand, so the pockets are always irregular.”

headline: Powerful Typhoon Thrashes Japan, With Millions Told to Evacuate
abstract: The storm, called Nanmadol, carried gales and heavy rain as it crept up nearly the entire length of the country.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Nanmadol brought torrential rain and the risk of destructive landslides to Japan’s southernmost main island on Sunday, after more than four million people were ordered to seek shelter from the powerful storm, which was expected to traverse virtually the entire length of the country.

headline: Baking Challah
abstract: Summer’s rituals are giving way to fall’s, but for the moment, you can enjoy them all.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning lately, before the sun rises, around 6:30 a.m., you can feel fall in the air in New York City. It’s that betwixt and between period, when the light is lowering but you can still get tomatoes and peaches at the market, still get away with short sleeves.

headline: Cracking Down on a Wall Street Trend: E.S.G. Makeovers
abstract: In recent years, financial firms have revamped dozens of mutual funds into E.S.G. dedicated funds — seeking to cash in on growing demand for such investments.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: ‘A Crisis Coming’: The Twin Threats to American Democracy
abstract: The United States faces two distinct challenges, the movement by Republicans who refuse to accept defeat in an election and a growing disconnect between political power and public opinion.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Sept. 12, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: When Your Dog Is a Teenager
abstract: As at so many times during early life with dogs, patience is due. It is just a phase.
lead_paragraph: The puppy I know — the young sprite we adopted at 8 weeks, whose life I’ve observed since her birth — is changing again. Quid is 6 months old and just seemed to be settling into our family of three people, two older dogs and a cat. But all at once, she is more sensitive. She has begun to startle at perfectly normal things. A container of laundry soap on the floor prompts ferocious barking (deterring the soap not at all). Even after a peaceful introduction to the bottle resting innocently on its side, she remains unconvinced that it is not a threat. My son lying on his stomach, rhythmically kicking the closet door behind him, causes Quid to run under my chair with fear. The vacuum, which she formerly followed around like a duckling would her mother, suddenly concerns her.

headline: How Low Can They Go?
abstract: G.O.P. grapes of wrath at Martha’s Vineyard.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump will be remembered for many things.

headline: Their Sport Is on the Verge of Extinction. These Runners Won’t Give It Up.
abstract: Last year, the ultramarathon governing body dumped many multiday races from their catalog. So a group of fringe runners created their own championship, and just kept running.
lead_paragraph: HAINESPORT, N.J. — The livestreaming was down, the tracker wasn’t up, the star guest was a no-show and eight hours into the 48-hour race, there was no leaderboard. A steely pride burned behind Trishul Cherns’s reddened eyes as he began to write down times on a whiteboard.

headline: What Does Queen Elizabeth’s Death Mean for Canada?
abstract: The accession of King Charles III may inspire more discussion about the relevance of the monarchy in Canada, but materially, experts say it’s business as usual.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II’s death triggered a cascade of official protocols in Canada, shifting the constitutional monarchy to a new sovereign: King Charles III.

headline: What the Martha’s Vineyard Stunt Says About the Trump Wannabes
abstract: Is Ron DeSantis really ready for prime time?
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis, the Republican governor of Florida, likes to do stunts. It is a key part of how he’s built his reputation as a fighter for conservative causes — a reputation he hopes to ride to the White House.

headline: Ukraine Wants the U.S. to Send More Powerful Weapons. Biden Is Not So Sure.
abstract: President Biden wants to avoid provoking Russia at a moment when American officials fear Vladimir V. Putin could escalate the war to compensate for recent losses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Flush with success in northeast Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky is pressing President Biden for a new and more powerful weapon: a missile system with a range of 190 miles, which could reach far into Russian territory.

headline: How the Far Right Bagged Election Success in Sweden
abstract: Campaigning on issues like immigration, religion, crime and the cost of environmental rules, the Sweden Democrats, a party with neo-Nazi roots, built its support.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Magnus Karlsson, 43, works in information technology and is about to start his own company. Articulate and thoughtful, he follows the news carefully, both in Sweden and globally.

headline: When Diversity Isn’t the Right Kind of Diversity
abstract: No member of Liz Truss’s cabinet is a white man. Why isn’t that considered progress?
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has dominated headlines this month, homages to her reign and dissections of the Harry and Meghan situation unsurprisingly pushing other news aside, especially other stories from Britain.

headline: ‘Are You American?’: The Question I Couldn’t Answer
abstract: An illustrated tale of immigration and belonging.

headline: A Sneaky Form of Climate Obstruction Hurts Pension Funds
abstract: Some state officials are putting their political views before the best interests of the firefighters and teachers they serve.
lead_paragraph: In several Republican-led states, the officials who oversee pension funds for millions of state workers are being told, or may soon be told, to ignore the financial risks associated with a warming world. There’s something distinctly anti-free market about policymakers limiting investment professionals’ choices — and it’s putting the retirement savings of millions at risk.

headline: Reimagining K-12 Education in America
abstract: Readers react to a dozen essays trying to answer “What Is School For?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Time, It’s Republicans on the Defensive on Social Issues
abstract: Republican missteps have helped to spotlight the party’s divisions on abortion and same-sex marriage, two issues on which their base is out of step with the general public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans have perfected the art of keeping the heat on Democrats on the searing social issues of the day, but this election year, it seems to be Republicans who are getting scorched.

headline: Abortion Helps Realign Puerto Rico’s Politics, Giving Conservatives an Opening
abstract: Long-dominant political parties are losing power to new ones, including one trying to limit abortion in one of the few U.S. jurisdictions where it remains unrestricted.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Three years ago, after Puerto Rico’s legislature narrowly defeated new abortion restrictions, the cardiologist and pastor Dr. César Vázquez Muñiz founded a new political party whose mission, he vowed, would include “defending life.”

headline: From L.A. to Rome, Ancient Sculptures Get Hero’s Welcome
abstract: Three statues were returned to Italy after the J. Paul Getty Museum discovered they had been looted. They will be displayed temporarily in Rome before heading to Taranto, Italy, their permanent home.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy celebrated the return of three stolen ancient terra-cotta figures, depicting “Orpheus and the Sirens,” in a ceremony on Saturday at Rome’s newly inaugurated Museum of Rescued Art.

headline: Britons Undeterred by Daylong Waits to Mourn a Queen They Loved
abstract: Prince William and Prince Harry stood vigil over their grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, at Westminster Hall as mourners streamed in to pay their respects.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.

headline: Russia continues attacking in Ukraine’s east despite recent setbacks.
abstract: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — The steady rattle of machine-gun fire resonated across the outskirts of the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut on Saturday morning. The sound, interspersed with the shriek of rockets and mortar fire, indicated one thing: The Russian troops were getting closer.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — The steady rattle of machine-gun fire resonated across the outskirts of the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut on Saturday morning. The sound, interspersed with the shriek of rockets and mortar fire, indicated one thing: The Russian troops were getting closer.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Visits Armenia Amid Conflict With Azerbaijan
abstract: The House speaker, who has previously inserted herself at the center of global conflicts, is the highest-ranking American official to visit Armenia since it gained independence 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi arrived in Armenia on Saturday, leading a congressional delegation in a show of support for the small south Caucasus nation after an outbreak of fighting with neighboring Azerbaijan resulted in the deaths of more than 200 people this week.

headline: The Quality That Sustained Queen Elizabeth Is Hobbling Putin
abstract: Why legitimacy is key for rulers.
lead_paragraph: Why is Vladimir Putin failing to win his war in Ukraine? The answers multiply: hubris, corruption and incompetence on the Russian side; military valor, canny leadership and American munitions on the Ukrainian side.

headline: As Trump Inquiry Heats Up, Garland Says Divisions Imperil the Rule of Law
abstract: Addressing new citizens on Ellis Island, the attorney general emphasized that all Americans are equal under the law.
lead_paragraph: An emotional Attorney General Merrick B. Garland addressed new citizens on Saturday at Ellis Island, the site of his family’s American origin story, and warned that the country had become dangerously divided by political factionalism, which has imperiled the democracy and the rule of law.

headline: Maximilian Lerner, Whose Espionage Skills Helped Win a War, Dies at 98
abstract: An Austrian immigrant, he was one of the so-called Ritchie Boys, who were trained at a secret Army intelligence camp to serve in World War II.
lead_paragraph: Maximilian Lerner, an Austrian-born Jew who was among the last surviving members of a World War II unit, many of them European Jews, who were recruited to learn espionage and intelligence skills and then employ them in Europe and the Pacific to help United States forces as they swept toward victory, died on Sept. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Storm Surge in Alaska Pulls Homes From Their Foundations
abstract: Communities along Alaska’s western coast were evacuating to higher ground and assessing damage from the remnants of Typhoon Merbok on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — Communities along Alaska’s western coast faced widespread flooding on Saturday as a powerful storm — the remnants of Typhoon Merbok — roared across the Bering Sea, with wind gusts tearing the siding off buildings and a storm surge pulling homes from their foundations.

headline: Nancy Pelosi visits Armenia after outbreak of deadly fighting with Azerbaijan.
abstract: Ms. Pelosi is the highest-ranking American official to visit Armenia since it gained independence 30 years ago with the end of the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi arrived in Armenia on Saturday, leading a congressional delegation in a show of support for the small nation after an outbreak of fighting with neighboring Azerbaijan. The clashes resulted in the deaths of more than 200 people this week.

headline: Kevin M. Cahill, 86, Dies; Tropical Disease Expert With a Political Bent
abstract: He treated celebrities, advised a governor and saved an Irish historical society. But he died under a cloud of sexual assault allegations.
lead_paragraph: Kevin M. Cahill, who managed to pack several careers into a single life as a leading expert on tropical diseases, a doctor to celebrities and politicians, a close adviser to Gov. Hugh L. Carey of New York and a savior to the ailing American Irish Historical Society, but who later faced allegations of sexual assault by two women, died on Wednesday at his home in Point Lookout, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 86.

headline: Power has been restored to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, a U.N. watchdog says.
abstract: Maintaining power at Europe’s largest nuclear plant has been crucial to prevent a meltdown in the shadow of fighting nearby.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a week offline, the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in southern Ukraine resumed receiving electricity from the country’s power grid, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N. nuclear watchdog, said on Saturday. The restoration came after engineers finished repairing a high-voltage line damaged by  shelling.

headline: Trump’s Former Accounting Firm Begins Turning Over Documents to Congress
abstract: Mazars USA delivered an initial set of documents related to the former president’s finances to the House Oversight Committee as part of a settlement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mazars USA, the longtime accounting firm for former President Donald J. Trump that cut ties with him and his family business this year, has begun turning over documents related to his financial dealings to Congress.

headline: Because I Said So!
abstract: Katie Hale delivers a puzzle with authoritative wit.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Katie Hale is originally from Houston and is now a stay-at-home mother in London. She works on puzzles when her girls, 6 and 9, are otherwise occupied, and says she likes “to try and come up with themes during times when I might otherwise be mindlessly staring at my phone, like on the bus. I think the moments when I’m out in the world, hearing other people talk, but not directly to me, are the best times to find inspiration.”

headline: Biden Warns Russia, Facing Losses, Against Using Unconventional Weapons
abstract: Some officials worry that the more cornered Vladimir Putin feels, particularly with recent setbacks from Ukraine’s counteroffensive, the greater the chance that he might turn to an unconventional weapon.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Torture chambers in the basements of police precincts and school buildings. Witness testimony of abuse, humiliation and murder. Seven foreign medical students from Sri Lanka held captive found alive and freed. A forest filled with graves.

headline: Canelo vs GGG: How to Watch and Stream the Fight
abstract: In the United States and around much of the world, Canelo-GGG will be on DAZN pay-per-view.
lead_paragraph: Saúl Álvarez, who is known widely as Canelo, will take on Gennadiy Golovkin in a super middleweight showdown from Las Vegas on Saturday night.

headline: A California Home That Conjures ‘Little Women’ on Acid
abstract: Designer Chloe Warner created a layered riot of colors, patterns and styles in this California home.
lead_paragraph: Designer Chloe Warner created a layered riot of colors, patterns and styles in this California home.

headline: New South Korean President Tries to Make His Mark on Foreign Policy
abstract: Yoon Suk Yeol has aligned his country more closely with the United States, but there are limits to how far he can go without angering China or provoking North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Four months into his new administration, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea has found hi​mself in trouble.

headline: The Queen Is Everywhere. What Will the Royal Makeover Cost?
abstract: Elizabeth II appears on postal boxes, stamps and coins. But placing Charles's visage on these items might not be the huge expense one would expect.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth II appears on postal boxes, stamps and coins. But placing Charles's visage on these items might not be the huge expense one would expect.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hollywood Comes to Wrexham, With Mixed Results
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It is a horrible, cyclical, prophetic hellscape that never ceases or ebbs. I love every second, but it’s torment in equal measure.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 18, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 13 about the difficulties in translating the lyrics of the musical “Hamilton” for a German version of the show misidentifies the character who sings a lyric from the song “Alexander Hamilton.” The lyric, which starts with “How does a bastard, orphan, son of a whore and a/ Scotsman,” was sung by the character of Aaron Burr, not Alexander Hamilton.

headline: Canelo Álvarez Outclasses Gennadiy Golovkin in Third Rivalry Fight
abstract: The judges scored the fight fairly close for Golovkin, but not closely enough to stop Álvarez from taking his second win over his rival.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the closest rivalries in boxing, one marked by discord and controversial judging decisions because, over two fights and 24 rounds, there was little that separated Saúl Álvarez and Gennadiy Golovkin.

headline: September 2022 Times/Siena Poll: Cross-Tabs for Hispanic and Latino Respondents
abstract: Responses from Hispanic and Latino voters collected during a survey by The New York Times and Siena College from Sept. 6 to 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Responses from Hispanic and Latino voters collected during a survey by The New York Times and Siena College from Sept. 6 to 14, 2022.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘She Was Not a Talented Singer, but I Enjoyed It Nonetheless’
abstract: Walking the dog to a favorite tune, rush hour on the No. 2 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Majority of Latino Voters Out of G.O.P.’s Reach, New Poll Shows
abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll found Democrats faring far worse than they have in the past with Hispanic voters. But overall, the party has maintained a hold on the Latino electorate.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly two years since Donald Trump made surprising gains with Hispanic voters. But Republican dreams of a major realignment of Latino voters drawn to G.O.P. stances on crime and social issues have failed to materialize, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: A ‘Time Capsule’ in Photos, Just in Case a Beach Changes
abstract: A condemned building along a beach in Queens is coming down. A photographer spent the summer visiting beachgoers who felt protected by its standing.
