lead_paragraph: An imposing building — an eyesore to some, a sentimental landmark to others — has long fortified a section of the beach at Jacob Riis Park in Queens, transforming a swath of shoreline along the Rockaway Peninsula into a summer haven for the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: Potent New Covid Boosters Are Here. Will Weary Americans Bother?
abstract: The new vaccine campaign is one of the country’s last remaining strategies, as masks have fallen away and quarantines have diminished. So far, the rollout is methodical but muted.
lead_paragraph: It was vaccination time at Ethel Brown’s long-term care home in the Bronx. Again. Ms. Brown, 95, had already gotten four Covid shots, and while she was happy to submit to a fifth, this latest booster prompted a few questions.

headline: Canelo and GGG End One of Boxing’s Fun Rivalries
abstract: For all his successes and talent, Gennadiy Golovkin is destined to be remembered as Saúl Álvarez’s foil.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Two days before they met in the ring, Saúl Álvarez and Gennadiy Golovkin sat behind a long table at a theater in the MGM Grand on the Strip. The theater normally houses Ká, one of Cirque du Soleil’s most high-flying productions, and offered an unfortunate contrast to the fighters’ perfunctory performance in answering questions from the promoter Eddie Hearn. Shortly after the news conference ended, Golovkin slunk out a side door.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Taiwan, Killing at Least 1
abstract: A southeastern county was shaken by a strong temblor for the second day in a row.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A powerful earthquake struck southeastern Taiwan on Sunday afternoon, killing at least one person, toppling at least one building and causing shaking that was felt across the island.

headline: Student Loan Subsidies Could Have Dangerous, Unintended Side Effects
abstract: Experts worry that aspects of President Biden’s debt relief plan could lure unscrupulous schools and unknowing students.
lead_paragraph: The centerpiece of the student debt-relief plan that President Biden announced last month is his decision to cancel up to $20,000 per borrower in federal loans. But the more far-reaching — and, over time, more expensive — element of the president’s strategy is his blueprint for a revamped income-linked repayment plan, which would sharply reduce what many borrowers pay every month.

headline: Apple Shot an Oscar Contender Starring Will Smith. That Was Before the Slap.
abstract: The Civil War drama “Emancipation” finished filming early this year. Now, Apple faces a quandary on what to do with the movie.
lead_paragraph: Apple has a Will Smith problem.

headline: Homes That Sold for $545,000 or Less
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Why Write? Yiyun Li’s New Novel Explores Our Urge to Invent.
abstract: In “The Book of Goose,” a literary hoax devised by two teenagers closes the distance between fiction and reality.
lead_paragraph: “Isn’t it enough just to know a story? Why take the time to write it out?” wonders 13-year-old Agnès, one of two adolescent girls at the center of Yiyun Li’s new novel, “The Book of Goose.” The question drives not only the tale Agnès proceeds to tell us, but the entire course of literary history. What moves us to share our inner lives in this way? By inscribing them on the world, can we ever capture something enduring in our speck-of-dust-in-the-universe existence?

headline: The Buildings That Drove Their Creators to Despair
abstract: Charlotte Van den Broeck’s “Bold Ventures” is an idiosyncratic tour of architectural misfires, dotted with its author’s personal anxieties.
lead_paragraph: Reading Charlotte Van den Broeck’s beguiling book about architects and melancholy on a blue and gold September day, I found it impossible not to think of the twin towers.

headline: Echoing Trump, These Republicans Won’t Promise to Accept 2022 Results
abstract: Six Republican nominees for governor and the Senate in key midterm states, all backed by Donald Trump, would not commit to accepting the November outcome. Five others did not answer the question.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly two years after President Donald J. Trump refused to accept his defeat in the 2020 election, some of his most loyal Republican acolytes might follow in his footsteps.

headline: What Joe Biden Knows That No One Expected Him To
abstract: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
lead_paragraph: We need better technologies to enable a better politics. But we need better politics to create better technologies. Maybe, just maybe, we’re on the verge of getting both.

headline: The Proud Boys and the Long-Lived Anxieties of American Men
abstract: Andy Campbell details the history of an ascendant far-right group.
lead_paragraph: Like Donald Trump’s run for office, the Proud Boys evolved out of a TV show. A British-born Canadian named Gavin McInnes had long ranted against feminism, Black activism and political correctness on his online video series, and in 2016 saw the chance to draw his fans into a movement. According to “We Are Proud Boys,” Andy Campbell’s new history of the organization, McInnes began partying and soapboxing with followers of his show after tapings, promoting “Western chauvinist” values. What started as an all-male “drinking club with a patriotism problem” would soon become one of the most visible extremist groups in the United States, with thousands of members across more than 150 chapters.

headline: The Art of Leaving Baseball Behind
abstract: Blake McFarland had a big fastball and a bad shoulder. Undeterred, he pivoted to an unexpected role: professional artist.
lead_paragraph: As Blake McFarland came bounding through the doors of Gallery 85, Patrick Powell figured he was looking at yet another football player hoping to make a connection with his boss. In a way, he was right.

headline: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
abstract: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Children’s Drownings Mark the End of a Mother’s Descent
abstract: Erin Merdy, who is charged with killing her three children, had struggled with money, men and mental health. Now, she is accused of one of New York’s worst crimes against children in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: For the mother and her three children, the three-block walk to the Coney Island beach was a familiar one.

headline: In New York City, the Demand for New Developments Is Bouncing Back
abstract: But everything is not as it was, with Covid both accelerating some nascent trends and pushing builders in new directions.
lead_paragraph: Almost three years after Covid waylaid the New York real estate industry, the city’s new development market is tiptoeing into unfamiliar territory: normalcy.

headline: Bringing Home Some ‘Hairy Joie de Vivre,’ and Taking Notes
abstract: Like many, the canine behavioral expert Alexandra Horowitz adopted a dog during the pandemic. She had extra incentive: understanding a puppy’s development. Now, she’s turned her observations into a book.
lead_paragraph: The last thing the writer and dog behavior expert Alexandra Horowitz needed in the spring of 2020 was a new puppy. Her family — three reasonable humans, two elderly dogs and one contented cat — was already “replete with animal fur,” she writes in “The Year of the Puppy,” her latest book. The pandemic was just taking hold. Why open the door to chaos?

headline: A Welsh Village Embraces Its Bond With the Queen
abstract: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
lead_paragraph: ABERFAN, Wales — As the days count down to Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral on Monday, Gaynor Madgwick has been of two minds: Should she watch the ceremony from her home in South Wales or join the crowds in London to pay her respects in person?

headline: Striking a Pose
abstract: Top outfits from the museum openings for Wolfgang Tillmans, Machine Dazzle and David LaChapelle, and LaQuan Smith’s after-party.
lead_paragraph: What happens when fashion week collides with the Armory Show and the fall art season? Lots of parties, of course.

headline: Powerful Typhoon Thrashes Japan, With Millions Told to Evacuate
abstract: The storm, called Nanmadol, carried gales and heavy rain as it was expected to creep up nearly the entire length of the country.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Typhoon Nanmadol brought torrential rain and the risk of destructive landslides to Japan’s southernmost main island on Sunday, and more than eight million people were ordered to evacuate and seek shelter from the powerful storm, which was expected to traverse virtually the entire length of the country.

headline: Math Is the Great Secret
abstract: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
lead_paragraph: As a boy in the first weeks of algebra class, I felt confused and then I went sort of numb. Adolescents order the world from fragments of information. In its way, adolescence is a kind of algebra. The unknowns can be determined but doing so requires a special aptitude, not to mention a comfort with having things withheld. Straightforward, logical thinking is required, and a willingness to follow rules, which aren’t evenly distributed adolescent capabilities.

headline: The Sunday Read: “Why Do We Love TikTok Audio Memes? Call it ‘Brainfeel.’”
abstract: Repurposed sound has taken over social media. Science tells us why.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody’s gonna know. They’re gonna know.”

headline: The Week in Business: Rail Strike Averted
abstract: Higher-than-expected inflation in August rattled financial markets. The Federal Reserve is expected to approve another big rate increase. But Social Security recipients have a reason to cheer.
lead_paragraph: With less than 24 hours until a critical deadline for negotiations, the country’s largest rail companies reached a tentative agreement with labor unions representing some 115,000 workers early Thursday morning. An impasse in bargaining brought workers to the brink of a strike that could have started as soon as Friday, with far-reaching consequences for the already mangled supply chain as well as inflation and Amtrak service. The main sticking points had to do with scheduling and sick time: Labor groups were asking that workers be allowed to see a doctor or attend to a personal matter without risking disciplinary action. White House officials got involved in trying to bring the two sides to a deal both because of the economic impact of a work stoppage and the political impact on President Biden and his party before the midterm elections. Martin J. Walsh, the Labor secretary, helped broker the tentative agreement, which gives workers one additional paid day off and the ability to go to medical appointments without penalty, labor unions said. It still needs to be ratified by union members — a process that could take weeks — but workers have agreed not to strike while the votes are tallied.

headline: The View From Russia
abstract: Russians near Ukraine are starting to hear the sound of explosions, and their worries are growing.
lead_paragraph: The Ukraine military’s recent advances are a potential turning point in the war. For Russians living close to the border, that is a source of increasing anxiety. For Russians farther away, the war is barely a part of daily life. I spoke to my colleague Valerie Hopkins, a Moscow correspondent who reported last week from a city near the border, about the contrast.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 19, 2022
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: By Day, Richie Weeks Sorted Mail. At Night, He Was a Disco Mastermind.
abstract: The New York producer, songwriter and artist punched the clock at the post office as he amassed an archive of tracks previously unheard until now.
lead_paragraph: When Richard (Richie) Weeks recalls his working life, the 78-year-old Bronx native sounds as if he’s describing two divergent selves.

headline: Pelosi, in Armenia, Condemns Azerbaijan Over Clashes
abstract: Fighting last week, the deadliest between the two countries since 2020, was “initiated by the Azeris,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said, while also calling for a negotiated settlement.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi expressed strong support for Armenia on Sunday and condemned “illegal and deadly attacks by Azerbaijan” on its neighbor, openly taking sides in a dispute where American officials have been careful to mediate discreetly.

headline: Russia Deploys Iranian Attack Drones, Ukrainian Military Says
abstract: A Ukrainian colonel said attacks that took out howitzers and armored vehicles were carried out by Iranian-made drones that had not previously been used outside of the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: KOROPOVE, Ukraine — A new and, Ukrainian officers say, frighteningly effective weapon has appeared in the war on the Russian side: Iranian-made attack drones.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Pasta with butternut squash, roasted sesame tofu and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s the second week of the National Football League season, with the Patriots-Steelers game at 1 p.m. in the East, and the Seahawks-49ers matchup at 4:05. That’ll make for excellent chili making all afternoon, with dinner to follow in advance of a new episode of “House of the Dragon” on HBO. (Totally get it if you’re watching Premier League football instead. But we’re an American band.)

headline: Clearview AI, Used by Police to Find Criminals, Is Now in Public Defenders’ Hands
abstract: After a Florida man was accused of vehicular homicide, his lawyer used Clearview AI’s facial recognition software to prove his innocence. But other defense lawyers say Clearview’s offer rings hollow.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Our Memory Is Flawed. Luckily, God’s Isn’t.
abstract: What a parent’s dementia reveals about God and humanity.
lead_paragraph: In August, my sister and I took my mom on a trip to Galveston Island on the Texas Gulf Coast. It’s a special place to my mom. She and my late father went there for their honeymoon over five decades ago, and she’s been back many times since. There’s a particular restaurant where she likes to get shrimp bisque. She likes the cheery sea wall and the chocolate shop downtown. But mostly she wants to watch the waves and the children playing along the shore.

headline: Our Assumptions About the Maternal Instinct
abstract: Readers react to an essay about how the maternal instinct is a myth. Also: A third-party alternative; the work environment; new baseball rules; billionaires.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Russian attack during an evacuation of psychiatric patients kills four Ukrainian health care workers.
abstract: Four Ukrainian health care workers were killed on Sunday when Russian forces launched an attack during an evacuation of psychiatric patients from a hospital in Kharkiv Province in the northeast of the country, according to the head of the regional military administration, Oleh Synyehubov.
lead_paragraph: Four Ukrainian health care workers were killed on Sunday when Russian forces launched an attack during an evacuation of psychiatric patients from a hospital in Kharkiv Province in the northeast of the country, according to the head of the regional military administration, Oleh Synyehubov.

headline: Strong Earthquake Topples Building in Taiwan
abstract: A 6.8 magnitude earthquake in Taiwan killed at least one person and collapsed at least one building in the town of Yuli in Hualien County.
lead_paragraph: A 6.8 magnitude earthquake in Taiwan killed at least one person and collapsed at least one building in the town of Yuli in Hualien County.

headline: ‘The Woman King’ Surprises With $19 Million at the Box Office
abstract: The Gina Prince-Bythewood historical drama, starring Viola Davis, did at least 25 percent better than analysts had expected.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t have to be all sequels and superheroes.

headline: Russian Pop Music Icon Comes Out Against the War in Ukraine
abstract: Alla Pugacheva, whose stardom has spanned from the Soviet era to after the Cold War, said the invasion of Ukraine had turned Russia into a “pariah.”
lead_paragraph: Russia’s defining 20th-century pop star, Alla Pugacheva, declared her opposition to the invasion of Ukraine on Sunday, emerging as the most significant celebrity to come out against the war as President Vladimir V. Putin faces growing challenges on and off the battlefield.

headline: Review: A Molten Song Recital, Without Comic Relief
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo doubled down on melancholy in a superb concert at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: There wasn’t comic relief on offer at Emily D’Angelo’s recital on Friday at the Park Avenue Armory. Not a giggle, not a wink. Her rare smile during the performance was wistful. The subjects she sang about were, for the most part, longing, death and tears.

headline: ‘The World Has Changed’: Cameron Mackintosh on Closing ‘Phantom’
abstract: In an interview, the storied British producer said that weakening box office and rising production costs led to the decision to end the longest run in Broadway history.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Mackintosh is one of the most successful producers in musical theater history. His list of credits includes several of the defining hits of the late 20th century: Big budget, lavishly staged spectacles including “Cats,” “Les Misérables” and “Miss Saigon.” But looming over all of them has been the longest-running Broadway show of all time: “The Phantom of the Opera.”

headline: Virginia Dwan, Behind-the-Scenes Force in the Art World, Dies at 90
abstract: At her galleries and with her financial resources, she supported artists working on art’s frontiers and later donated works to museum collections.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Dwan, who through her galleries in Los Angeles and New York and her personal financial support helped fuel the explosion of artistic innovation of the 1960s and beyond, and who later enriched the collections of the National Gallery of Art and other institutions with extensive donations from her personal collection, died on Sept. 5 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 90.

headline: After ‘Phantom,’ Which Shows Will Be the Longest-Running on Broadway?
abstract: Hints: They both reached for the gun. I’m working on my roar! Everyone deserves the chance to fly. Have fun in hell!
lead_paragraph: “The Phantom of the Opera” has been running on Broadway longer than many of the industry’s hoofers have been alive. But on Friday, the show announced that it will close Feb. 18, a few weeks after celebrating its 35th anniversary.

headline: Is Choosing Death Too Easy in Canada?
abstract: Since the government expanded the eligibility for assisted death last year to include those with disabilities, critics have been saying there should be more checks and balances.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Powerful Typhoon Hits Japan
abstract: Typhoon Nanmadol brought heavy rain and destructive landslide risk to Japan’s southernmost main island, after millions were ordered to seek shelter from the storm.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Nanmadol brought heavy rain and destructive landslide risk to Japan’s southernmost main island, after millions were ordered to seek shelter from the storm.

headline: Exhumations in Izium will continue for two more weeks, its mayor says.
abstract: It will take another two weeks to exhume all of the bodies from hundreds of unmarked graves Ukrainian officials discovered after recapturing the northeastern city of Izium, the city’s mayor said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It will take another two weeks to exhume all of the bodies from hundreds of unmarked graves Ukrainian officials discovered after recapturing the northeastern city of Izium, the city’s mayor said on Sunday.

headline: Trump Rally Plays Music Resembling QAnon Song, and Crowds React
abstract: In Ohio, a dark address by the former president featured music that was all but identical to a theme song for the conspiracy theory movement.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump appeared to more fully embrace QAnon on Saturday, playing a song at a political rally in Ohio that prompted attendees to respond with a salute in reference to the cultlike conspiracy theory’s theme song.

headline: The Return of Combat Joe
abstract: President Biden’s combative side comes out periodically. That’s when he’s at his best.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Joe Biden goes on the offensive, there are observations that he’s being combative, as if it were foreign to him, as if it were a new strategy he had only now begun to employ.

headline: Review: In ‘Nehanda,’ the Band Played On
abstract: The choreographer and performer Nora Chipaumire’s new six-hour work at the Alexander Kasser Theater invokes ancestral spirits.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The Queen is dead. Long live the King.

headline: Sending Out an S.O.S.
abstract: If you saved me and my sister on a cold, rainy night in Alaska 34 years ago, I would like to thank you.
lead_paragraph: There’s a story I tell my sons to remind them that, despite much evidence to the contrary, humans have the capacity to be amazingly kind.

headline: Wegmans Discontinues Self-Checkout App, Citing Losses
abstract: Self-checkout systems are intended to make shopping convenient, but they also can lead to more thefts, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Citing losses, the supermarket chain Wegmans announced that it had halted the use of its self-checkout app in which customers scanned their groceries as they shopped.

headline: Guest List for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Includes Everyday Honorees
abstract: Among those invited to Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral are almost 200 people who were honored for various forms of public service this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At Queen Elizabeth’s state funeral, in the solemn celebration at Westminster Abbey among royalty, heads of state and prime ministers, there will be an 88-year-old London woman who records audiobooks for the blind and a man who led a campaign to save his local soccer club near Manchester.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral
abstract: Plus a powerful typhoon lashes Japan and cheetahs return to India.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral is today at Westminster Abbey. The service, which begins at 11 a.m. London time (6 p.m. in Hong Kong, 8 p.m. in Sydney), will end a 10-day period of official mourning in Britain.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Growing Fight Over What Young People Can Read?
abstract: Parents, activists, school board officials and lawmakers are challenging books about race, gender and sexuality at a pace not seen in decades. What is your opinion of this?
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: To honor Banned Books Week, we will be posting a series of lesson plans and writing prompts. You can find the other pieces in “Related,” below.

headline: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
abstract: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Every culture wants to memorialize its dead. Every family needs the missing to be identified to reach closure. Perhaps that is why a wartime mass grave offends something so deep in the human conscience.

headline: Virginia Reverses School Protections for Transgender Students
abstract: The state’s Department of Education issued guidelines that would require students to file legal documents to be called by different pronouns.
lead_paragraph: In a move that could further inflame the debate over how to handle transgender rights in schools, Virginia will no longer allow students to use facilities marked for the gender they identify with and will mandate that they file legal documents if they wish to be called by different pronouns. Those directives were among several guidelines for schools that the Virginia Department of Education announced on Friday in a reversal of transgender policies that the state outlined last year.

headline: Make-Up Specialist
abstract: Leslie Young and Andrea Carla Michaels get down to business.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Monday theme entries tend to be placed in predictable positions. They are usually the longest Across entries, and you may be able to figure out where they would be within a few squares.

headline: Biden Pays Homage to Queen Elizabeth, Calling the Monarch ‘Decent, Honorable’
abstract: The U.S. president will be one of dozens of world leaders attending the funeral on Monday for a royal who had ruled for nearly as long as the president has lived.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With a framed photograph of Queen Elizabeth II perched to his right, President Biden on Sunday paid homage to a monarch he had twice declined to bow to on the advice of his mother, but one he had also admired.

headline: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Forces Face Mobilized Inmates and Drones
abstract: Ukraine has been pushing a counteroffensive in the east and south, applying greater pressure to Russian forces, but there is no indication of any mass Russian withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — In battlefields in the rolling hills of the Donbas in eastern Ukraine, and near the Black Sea in the south, Ukrainian troops have stubbornly tried to inch forward without losing control of territory, facing an opponent whose forces have been bolstered by inmates-turned-fighters and by Iranian drones.

headline: Las Vegas Aces Win First W.N.B.A. Championship
abstract: The Aces shook off their reputation for being better in the regular season by holding off several rallies by the Sun.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — With a championship on the line for a team with some of the W.N.B.A.’s biggest stars, the Las Vegas Aces leaned on Riquna Williams, who had scored in double digits just twice this postseason.

headline: What We Learned From Week 2 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: Kyler Murray and the Cardinals had Sunday’s best comeback, Russell Wilson’s Broncos offense needs more time to cook, and the Giants are … working on some things.
lead_paragraph: No more Week 1 rust, no more excuses. Fifteen teams entered Week 2 looking to avoid starting the season in an 0-2 hole. That desperation sparked collapses in Baltimore in Cleveland and Las Vegas or chest-thumping finishes for Miami, the Jets and Arizona. Depends on your vantage point.

headline: How the Jets Stunned the Browns, 31-30
abstract: The Jets are 1-1 — their first .500 record since 2018 — after pulling off a two-score comeback in under two minutes against the Cleveland Browns. Here’s how they did it.
lead_paragraph: The Jets are 1-1 — their first .500 record since 2018 — after pulling off a two-score comeback in under two minutes against the Cleveland Browns. Here’s how they did it.

headline: After Texas Sent Him to Washington, One Migrant Launches a New Life
abstract: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
lead_paragraph: When Lever Alejos of Venezuela arrived at the southern border penniless in July, he gladly accepted a free bus ride to Washington, D.C., courtesy of the state of Texas. He had no family or friends to receive him, and spent one night in the plaza across from Union Station. He soon settled into a homeless shelter.

headline: Biden Calls Trump ‘Irresponsible’ Over Mar-a-Lago Documents
abstract: Speaking to “60 Minutes,” the president also declared the Covid-19 pandemic to be “over” in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden said in an interview aired on Sunday evening that former President Donald J. Trump had been “totally irresponsible” for keeping top-secret documents at his residence and private club in Florida, but he said he had not asked for specifics about the documents in order to stay out of the Justice Department’s potential decision to charge Mr. Trump criminally.

headline: As Judge Pursues Maris, He’s Chasing a Triple Crown as Well

lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — A funny thing happened on Aaron Judge’s way to hitting a ton of home runs: a ballooning batting average and a second, different chase at history.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Wedding Crashers
abstract: The repercussions of Rhaenyra and Daemon’s illicit adventures continue to reverberate throughout the realm.

headline: Queen Elizabeth: A Visual Dictionary
abstract: The things that made the queen the queen.
lead_paragraph: Over her seven decades on the throne, Queen Elizabeth II understood the power of visuals. The first British monarch to have a televised coronation, she watched the world turn its attention from the radio to the TV set, and by the time she died this month at 96, having celebrated her Platinum Jubilee just a few months earlier, she — well, the royal family — had an Instagram account and a YouTube channel.

headline: Their Dad Was Like a Brother. Now Pacman Jones Is Family.
abstract: Adam Jones and Chris Henry were once N.F.L. poster athletes for misdeeds. Raising Henry’s children alongside his own, Jones is hoping to help them all avoid the same mistakes.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Pressure on Russian forces in southern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The pressure on Russian forces in southern Ukraine deepened over the weekend. Ukrainian forces conducted strikes on Russian military strongholds, targeted sites used by local officials loyal to the Kremlin and continued to hit the supply lines for thousands of Russian soldiers on the western bank of the Dnipro River.

headline: Ukrainian officials try to build pressure to hold Russia accountable for war crimes.

lead_paragraph: Monday’s service is the first time cameras will be allowed into the funeral of a British monarch. In 1952, King George VI’s funeral procession — but not the service itself — was broadcast on television.

headline: In Recovery After Storm, Alaska Faces Hard Days Ahead
abstract: Geography and climate add to the challenges for the hard-hit isolated communities as the cold months draw closer.
lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — In the village of Golovin, 50 miles east of Nome, initial reports indicated that up to a dozen of the 48 houses there had been inundated with water.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: The Story So Far: Where 6 Investigations Into Donald Trump Stand

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump has set up his office on the second floor of his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida as part replica of the Oval Office and part homage to his time in the real White House.

headline: Railroads’ Strategy Thrilled Wall Street, but Not Customers and Workers
abstract: Freight railways pushed to streamline their operations and improve their profit margins. Critics say the approach left the system stretched thin.
lead_paragraph: America’s first commercial railroads were built almost two centuries ago. Freight rail has been a symbol of the nation’s economic might and ingenuity ever since.

headline: Widespread business and public service closures put Britain’s economy on hold.
abstract: On Monday, as Queen Elizabeth II is laid to rest, much of Britain will pause.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, as Queen Elizabeth II is laid to rest, much of Britain will pause.

headline: Bus Taking People to Quarantine Crashes in China, Killing 27
abstract: The deaths renewed an anguished debate over the price of China’s “zero Covid” policy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A bus that was carrying dozens of people to a quarantine facility crashed over the weekend in southwestern China, killing at least 27 of them and setting off a renewed, anguished debate about the country’s zero-tolerance Covid policies.

headline: Our 50 Favorite Restaurants of 2022
abstract: The places in America we love most right now.
lead_paragraph: The places in America we love most right now.

headline: I Just Got a Big Promotion. Do I Need a Fancier Wardrobe Too?
abstract: A reader wonders if he should buy new clothes now that he has a senior position.
lead_paragraph: First of all, congratulations on the new job. The question of how you dress for it, however, is a lot more complicated than just “to suit or not to suit?” It’s really about communication and what values you are trying to model.

headline: A Red-Hot Affair With a Younger Man, and the Writing It Kindled
abstract: “Getting Lost,” a diary by the French writer Annie Ernaux, recounts an all-consuming Paris romance.
lead_paragraph: His fingernails are ragged. He wears designer suits but his choice of underwear, cheap Russian tighty-whities, is poignant. When he gets drunk, he talks about Stalin. He likes the dumbest game shows. Maybe he’s K.G.B. He does not know how to unfasten garters.

headline: What I Saw as the Country’s First National Climate Adviser
abstract: The private sector now sees climate as an opportunity for job creation and economic revitalization.
lead_paragraph: This week, as the world’s leaders gather in New York for the U.N. General Assembly, the United States will deliver a message many thought was not possible: We are going to cut greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030, and zero them out by 2050.

headline: At Summer’s End, a Moment of Wild Surprise
abstract: As equinox nears, the lovely cycle life is happening just behind the place in my garden where the goldenrod and the asters look so beautiful together.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Then, just like that, the light changed, taking on the autumnal slant that turns dust motes into flecks of fire and deepens the color of songbirds’ feathers, so bright and new now after the August molt. Suddenly it is fall, whatever the temperature might suggest.

headline: Lesson Plan: Using Statistics to Understand Extreme Heat
abstract: Why are heat waves becoming hotter and more frequent? In this lesson, students will analyze historical temperature data and create box-and-whisker plots to find out.

headline: Ready for More of ‘Less’? Andrew Sean Greer’s Hapless Hero Is Back.
abstract: In “Less Is Lost,” the sequel to his Pulitzer Prize-winning comic novel, the author’s writer protagonist, now over 50 and in need of cash, takes to the road once again.

headline: Jenny Xie Explores the Subversive Power of the Concealed and the Overlooked
abstract: In her new poetry collection, “The Rupture Tense,” Xie peeks at the past — her family’s, and China’s — to examine the consequences of “how we see, what we see, and also what we allow to remain unseen.”
lead_paragraph: The poet Jenny Xie was exploring the library stacks at the Shanghai campus of N.Y.U., where she was on a fellowship, when a book with a bright red cover caught her eye. In it, she found hundreds of photos of China’s Cultural Revolution.

headline: Our Predecessors Built a World of Winners and Losers. It’s Time for Something Different.
abstract: As the world transitions to recovery from the pandemic, the inequities are only widening, both between and within countries.
lead_paragraph: Our international rules-based order through which the world’s nations pursue global peace and development is crashing into the limits of its founding vision. What our predecessors built some eight decades ago, after the Second World War — from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to the United Nations — is in desperate need of repair. But it remains essential, and salvageable.

headline: How a Bombshell Secret Brought a Fractured Family Together
abstract: Three siblings reunite in Amanda Svensson’s turbulent novel “A System So Magnificent It Is Blinding.”
lead_paragraph: At first, the triplets at the center of Amanda Svensson’s novel “A System So Magnificent It Is Blinding” appear to be archetypal siblings: a boy and two girls born in 1989 to a slightly neurotic Swedish family that’s eventually splintered by divorce. By 2016, though, Sebastian is working as a scientist at a shadowy medical research institute in London; Clara is foraging on remote, forbidding Easter Island in the company of a doomsday cult; and the chromophobic Matilda is living in Berlin, fumbling through ersatz stepmotherhood while trying to avoid anything colored blue. The sudden disappearance of their feckless father and an accompanying bombshell announcement by their fretful mother bring them into contact to confess old secrets, heal old wounds and, perhaps, glue the fractured brood back together.

headline: You Cannot Be Too Cynical About Trump (or His Imitators)
abstract: The former president has company in the nether regions.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Any plans to hop a flight to Martha’s Vineyard?

headline: Food Supply Disruption Is Another Front for Russian Falsehoods
abstract: As the war in Ukraine has put pressure on the global markets for food, Russia has spread conspiracy theories that blame the West.
lead_paragraph: When the Dutch government announced plans in June to reduce certain greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 70 percent, farmers erupted in protest. The change requires sharply cutting the waste produced by livestock operations, potentially forcing some of them out of business. They clogged traffic on highways with their tractors, dumped manure in the streets and set bales of hay on fire.

headline: Trump Adviser’s Trial May Shed Light on Foreign Influence Campaigns
abstract: Thomas Barrack, a Los Angeles private equity executive, is accused of working secretly for the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Thomas J. Barrack Jr., an informal adviser to former President Donald J. Trump accused of acting as an unregistered agent of the United Arab Emirates, could shed light on how foreign governments jockeyed for access to the Trump administration — efforts that may have created lucrative opportunities for businessmen close to the White House.

headline: Life Is Hazardous for Urban Raptors. These Women Offer Hope.
abstract: Injured birds of prey have a fighting chance to recover thanks to the volunteers at Owl Moon Raptor Center in Boyds, Md.
lead_paragraph: It’s quiet on the back roads of Boyds, Md., where a small compound studded with bird feeders breaks up the monotony of the surrounding cornfields.

headline: How Health Care Workers Got Me Through the Pandemic
abstract: From home aides to doctors, people in health care fields offered more than just medical advice for people getting through the pandemic. They offered comfort.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the I Want to Thank You series. We asked readers to tell us about who helped get them through the pandemic; this is a selection of their stories about health care workers. We’ve published an article about family and friends, and a forthcoming article will focus on inspirational figures.

headline: ‘Crippling’ Energy Bills Force Europe’s Factories to Go Dark
abstract: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
lead_paragraph: The furnace, heated to 1,500 degrees Celsius, was glowing red. Workers at the Arc International glass factory loaded it with sand that slowly pooled into a molten mass. Nearby on the factory floor, machines transformed the shapeless liquid with a blast of hot air into thousands of delicate wine glasses, destined for sale to restaurants and homes worldwide.

headline: Inflation Remains Voters’ Top Concern. Can Republicans Keep Their Focus?
abstract: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
lead_paragraph: Zach Nunn, an Iowa Republican challenging one of the House’s most vulnerable Democrats, had been talking for months about rising prices when a Texas congressman two weeks ago invited him to visit the Mexican border — to see the fentanyl confiscated, hear tales of dying migrants and witness overwhelmed border agents.

headline: A Rural Doctor Gave Her All. Then Her Heart Broke.
abstract: Physicians suffer one of the highest burnout rates among professionals. Dr. Kimberly Becher, one of two family practitioners in Clay County, West Virginia, learned the hard way.
lead_paragraph: CLAY, W.Va. — For most of her life, Dr. Kimberly Becher has moved fast. She was married at 21, started medical school with a 3-month-old and has trained for two marathons. In the halls of her clinic, between a bank and a Baptist church in Clay — the county seat of Clay County with a population of 396 — she walks fast, often looking down at her phone as she speeds around corners. She talks fast, too, organizing her staff and speaking crisply with a mountain accent.

headline: On Anniversary of Hurricane Maria, Storm Leaves Puerto Rico in the Dark
abstract: Hurricane Fiona reminded residents that the agonizingly slow work of giving the island a stable power grid remained unfinished.
lead_paragraph: SALINAS, P.R. — Hurricane Fiona deluged Puerto Rico with unrelenting rain and terrifying flash floods on Monday, forcing harrowing home rescues and making it difficult for power crews to reach many parts of the island.

headline: Eric Adams Considers Housing Migrants on Cruise Ships
abstract: New York City’s shelter system has been overwhelmed with new arrivals, but advocates for the homeless say the idea is insulting.
lead_paragraph: As New York struggles to find housing for a wave of migrants, Mayor Eric Adams is seriously considering housing them on cruise ships — a proposal that homeless advocates have called insulting and alienating.

headline: Advocacy Groups Are Helping Drive a Rise in Book Bans
abstract: A report from the free speech organization PEN America looked at the role of politics and advocacy groups in the growing number of book bans in schools across the country.
lead_paragraph: At least 50 advocacy groups pushed to ban books during the last school year, according to a report that the free speech group PEN America released on Monday, highlighting how challenges to reading material have become a political issue across the country.

headline: Can the U.K. Remain United Without the Queen?
abstract: Over her 70-year reign, the monarch helped bind the four nations of the United Kingdom together. Her death heralds a period of greater uncertainty for that union.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Queen Elizabeth today will be one of the most extraordinary public spectacles of the last several decades in Britain, accompanied by an outpouring of sadness, reverence and respect.

headline: Democracy Challenged
abstract: Representative government faces its most serious threats in decades.
lead_paragraph: This is an election year unlike any we’ve experienced in recent decades. Not only do candidates of both major parties in the United States have starkly different views on the pressing issues of the day, including climate change, war, taxes, abortion, education, gender and sexual identity, immigration, crime and the role of government in American life. They also disagree on democracy itself, especially one of its essential pillars — willingness to accept defeat at the polls.

headline: Read the Order of Service for Queen Elizabeth II’s State Funeral
abstract: The service for the queen’s funeral at Westminster Abbey on Sept. 19 included a reading from Prime Minister Liz Truss, a sermon from the archbishop of Canterbury, and hymns.
lead_paragraph: The service for the queen’s funeral at Westminster Abbey on Sept. 19 included a reading from Prime Minister Liz Truss, a sermon from the archbishop of Canterbury, and hymns.

headline: At Windsor, the queen will be interred with her husband, who died last year.
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II spent much of the pandemic at Windsor Castle. She will be interred in the King George VI Memorial Chapel, next to Prince Philip, her husband of 73 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shortly before 4 p.m., Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin will arrive at Windsor, the turreted castle where she spent most of her final days, quarantining during the coronavirus pandemic. In April 2021, she buried Philip, her husband of 73 years, in an austere funeral at St. George’s Chapel in Windsor that was memorable for poignant images of the queen, isolated and masked, as she sat alone in a choir stall.

headline: Russian Missile Hits Close to Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine
abstract: A CCTV camera captured a Russian missile exploding less than 1,000 feet from the South Ukraine Nuclear Power Plant. The footage was released by the Energoatom State Company.
lead_paragraph: A CCTV camera captured a Russian missile exploding less than 1,000 feet from the South Ukraine Nuclear Power Plant. The footage was released by the Energoatom State Company.

headline: An Italian Villa Where Architecture Is a Family Affair
abstract: Most homes hold the history of their owners, but Il Palazzetto is as much a monument to its designers as to its inhabitants.
lead_paragraph: WHEN ALDO BUSINARO acquired Il Palazzetto in 1964, the proud Palladian-style villa outside Monselice, an ancient town a 30-minute drive south of Padua in northeast Italy, was all but unlivable. Purchased by Businaro’s grandfather in 1924, when it was already near derelict, the house was used for agricultural storage, its only residents farm tools, surplus grain and dormice for decades, except for a brief stint during World War II. Still, determined to transform it into a family home, Businaro uprooted his wife, Lucia, and their three sons from Padua, and moved in the following year. Federico, the middle child, now 58, remembers that initially they slept all together in the one room whose ceiling didn’t leak; Lucia cooked their meals on a camping stove. Built in 1627 for Francesco Giovanni Tassello, a prosperous doctor, Il Palazzetto stands at the center of a 50-acre estate of fertile farmland. An 8,600-square-foot cube with a red clay-tile roof and ivy-covered tan plaster facade, the house is a so-called minor villa, yet Tassello clearly had major ambitions: Above the trompe l’oeil columns and doorways that decorate the 20-foot-high walls of the salon on the second floor, a ribbon of frescoes depict scenes from Virgil’s “Aeneid.” But Tassello became ill with bubonic plague before he could finish the sweeping entrance he’d almost certainly planned for the house, which meant the villa the Businaros inherited was in disrepair and incomplete.

headline: Crowds gather in Windsor as they await the arrival of the queen’s coffin from London.
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II will be interred in St. George’s Chapel at Windsor Castle later on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, England — Thousands of people, some carrying British flags, gathered on Monday along the approach to Windsor Castle that Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin will take on its final journey.

headline: Warnings Signs Multiply Ahead of Pivotal Fed Meeting
abstract: Economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates by 75 basis points this week, adding to fears a recession is coming.
lead_paragraph: It’s rates week. The Fed will join the central banks of England, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland in determining whether to raise interest rates further in an effort to blunt rising inflation. More and more economists and investors are worried that the global economy could be hobbled by the continuous tightening of monetary policy.

headline: ‘They don’t make them like her anymore’: A crowd in Hyde Park bids goodbye to the queen.
abstract: Tens of thousands of people gathered in the park in central London to watch Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral service.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tens of thousands of people gathered on Monday in Hyde Park to watch Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral, video of which was displayed on large screens. They sat on camping chairs, blankets, ladders and stools, brought their own breakfast or bought sausage and fish and chips from the several food trucks installed for the occasion.

headline: With a Playoff Spot in Reach, the Mets Control Their Destiny
abstract: Looking postseason-ready in a sweep of the Pirates, the Mets have thus far stayed ahead of Atlanta in the N.L. East.
lead_paragraph: Atop the National League East with a record of 93-55, the Mets are closing in on a playoff spot. With 14 games left in the regular season, the only real question left is whether they will enter the postseason with a division title — and possibly a first-round bye — or a wild-card spot.

headline: U.S. Hostage Exchanged for Afghan Drug Lord in Prisoner Swap
abstract: The Taliban said it had freed an American engineer, Mark R. Frerichs, in exchange for the release of a prominent Afghan tribal leader convicted of drug trafficking.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban government of Afghanistan on Monday said that it had freed an American engineer, Mark R. Frerichs, in exchange for the release by the United States of a prominent Afghan tribal leader who had been convicted of drug trafficking.

headline: McDonald’s Begins to Reopen Restaurants in Ukraine This Week
abstract: Three outlets will open in Kyiv for delivery, before a wider reopening in the capital and west of the country over the next two months.
lead_paragraph: Three McDonald’s restaurants will reopen in Kyiv this week, a company spokeswoman said on Monday, fulfilling a pledge the chain made last month to bring employees back to work even as the war persists.

headline: Zelensky Meets With BlackRock Chief to Discuss Reconstruction Fund
abstract: The world’s largest asset manager advised Ukraine on how to revive the country’s shattered economy by attracting public and private investment.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with Laurence D. Fink, the head of BlackRock, the world’s largest manager of assets, to discuss how to attract investment in the country’s war-ravaged economy.

headline: Mini to Maestro, Part 3: Advanced Puzzles
abstract: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
lead_paragraph: This is Part 3 of a three-part series on learning to solve crossword puzzles. Be sure to check out Part 1 and Part 2.

headline: Sean Hayes to Star in Broadway Play About Oscar Levant
abstract: “Good Night, Oscar,” by Doug Wright, explores the life of a pianist who became famous as a witty guest and host of midcentury radio and television shows.
lead_paragraph: It was two decades ago when a friend first suggested to Sean Hayes that he consider playing Oscar Levant. He still remembers his reaction: “Who the hell is Oscar Levant?”

headline: Mini to Maestro, Part 2: Intermediate Solving
abstract: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
lead_paragraph: This is Part 2 of a three-part series on learning to solve crossword puzzles. Be sure to check out Part 1 and Part 3.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Stars Say Goodbye to HBO’s Biggest Hit
abstract: In a joint interview, Milly Alcock and Emily Carey discussed their now-completed stint in the HBO epic. “We were forced to hang on to each other for dear life,” Alcock said.
lead_paragraph: They anchored the earliest episodes of one of the biggest shows on television, but Milly Alcock and Emily Carey have no idea what they’re doing next — including whether or not they’ll ever return to the “Game of Thrones” prequel, “House of the Dragon,” in flashbacks or otherwise.

headline: Shopping for Brooms
abstract: Why do you need a well-designed broom? Because you’re more likely to use it.
lead_paragraph: When your floors are littered with dirt, wood shavings or spilled cereal, having a well-designed broom and dustpan at the ready can make the cleanup a lot easier.

headline: What You Get for $2.5 Million in California
abstract: A 1905 bungalow in Berkeley designed by Julia Morgan, a three-bedroom ranch house in Los Angeles and a midcentury-modern home in Cupertino.
lead_paragraph: A 1905 bungalow in Berkeley designed by Julia Morgan, a three-bedroom ranch house in Los Angeles and a midcentury-modern home in Cupertino.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1905 bungalow in Berkeley designed by the architect Julia Morgan, a three-bedroom ranch house in Los Angeles and a midcentury-modern home in Cupertino.
lead_paragraph: Julia Morgan, the first woman licensed as an architect in California, has a close association with the city of Berkeley, where she designed the Berkeley City Club; St. John’s Presbyterian Church; several structures at the University of California, Berkeley, campus; and this home, built for a zoology professor and his wife. Made primarily from old-growth redwood, it has had just three owners and was the recipient of a Berkeley Architectural Heritage Association Preservation Award in 2010.

headline: Mini to Maestro, Part 1: Crosswords for Beginners
abstract: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
lead_paragraph: This is Part 1 of a three-part series on learning to solve crossword puzzles. Be sure to check out Part 2 and Part 3.

headline: These California Bills Are Still Awaiting Gov. Gavin Newsom’s Signature
abstract: Proposals include restrictions on solitary confinement and noisy vehicle exhaust systems.
lead_paragraph: Days after a record-breaking heat wave baked California, Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a sweeping package of climate bills devised to cut emissions and reduce reliance on fossil fuels. These actions from the state, the world’s fifth largest economy, add momentum to worldwide efforts to rein in pollution from the combustion of oil, gas and coal that is overheating the planet.

headline: ‘I Would Be Booing Myself,’ Broncos Coach Admits After Win
abstract: For the second week in a row, Denver fans were left scratching their heads about Nathaniel Hackett’s play-calling and time management.
lead_paragraph: After their beloved team lost in Week 1, Denver Broncos fans were fuming at their new coach, Nathaniel Hackett, who had made a baffling decision at the end of a Monday night loss in Seattle.

headline: After Putin acknowledges Xi’s ‘concerns,’ Russia and China pledge closer cooperation.
abstract: Senior officials from Russia and China have agreed to carry out more joint military exercises and enhance defense cooperation, according to statements on Monday, signaling that whatever misgivings Beijing may have over the war in Ukraine, the nations’ strategic partnership was only growing closer.
lead_paragraph: Senior officials from Russia and China have agreed to carry out more joint military exercises and enhance defense cooperation, according to statements on Monday, signaling that whatever misgivings Beijing may have over the war in Ukraine, the nations’ strategic partnership was only growing closer.

headline: One Big Problem for Ukraine Is Clear: Glass
abstract: Russian bombs. Soaring energy costs. Severed trade links. It’s getting hard to fix all the shattered windows in Ukraine, and winter is coming.
lead_paragraph: CHERNIHIV, Ukraine — There was one topic of conversation among the women bundled up in front of a bombed-out building the other day as they waited in a long line at a humanitarian food truck, a nippy wind swirling around them.

headline: Five Years Later, Fiona Brings Back Painful Memories of Maria.
abstract: Hurricane Maria landed in Puerto Rico as a Category 4 storm on Sept. 20, 2017.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Fiona’s arrival in Puerto Rico came almost exactly five years after Hurricane Maria struck, a devastating storm from which the island never fully recovered.

headline: Volkswagen Sets Price Range for Porsche’s Blockbuster I.P.O.
abstract: The public offering values the luxury sports car maker at up to $75 billion.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen said late Sunday that it planned to sell shares in Porsche, the luxury sports car brand it owns, at a valuation of up to $75 billion, setting the stage for one of the biggest stock market debuts of the year.

headline: Defending R. Kelly and Bill Cosby, the Same Combative Lawyer
abstract: Jennifer Bonjean has become known for her aggressive approach as she has defended men accused of sexual misconduct in several of the highest profile cases of the #MeToo era.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Bonjean, a defense lawyer who has the words “not guilty” tattooed on her right arm, called one woman who accused R. Kelly of sexual abuse a “pathological liar.” She accused another of extortion. She tried to pick their accounts apart, and attacked prosecutors for stripping her client, the former R&B star, of “every single bit of humanity that he has.”

headline: Mexico Has Tequila. Peru, Pisco. In Colombia, a Push for Viche, Now Legal.
abstract: Invented by formerly enslaved people, viche, a cane sugar liquor, was long banned, a sort of Colombian moonshine. Now, it’s a symbol of the country’s often ignored Afro-Colombian culture.
lead_paragraph: CALI, Colombia — As a child, Lucía Solís watched her family bury a stash of cherished but prohibited cane sugar liquor, called viche, in the woods, fearful of police seizures and even arrest.

headline: Watch Pedro Pierluisi, Puerto Rico’s governor, give live updates on Hurricane Fiona.
New York City Faces Potential Fiscal Crisis as $10 Billion Deficit Looms
abstract: A persistent pandemic-driven downturn has caused revenue from business and personal-income taxes to fall in New York City, while tourism and job losses have yet to recover.
lead_paragraph: New York City, battered by economic headwinds and mired in a stubborn pandemic-driven downturn afflicting employment, tourism and tax revenue, is teetering on the brink of a severe budget crisis.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: With the Jewish High Holy Days approaching, we have a plan for challah, honey cake and more.
lead_paragraph: And all of a sudden, the Jewish High Holy Days are nearly upon us. This is how it feels to me every year; just as soon as we settle into our back-to-school routines, it’s time to stop and dip some apples in honey to ensure a sweet new year. Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur are here.

headline: ‘One Foot in the Present, One Foot in the Past:’ Understanding E.M.D.R.
abstract: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Review: ‘Marie It’s Time’ Pieces Together a Woman in Fragments
abstract: This three-actor play initiates a dialogue with Georg Büchner’s “Woyzeck,” examining men’s violence against women.
lead_paragraph: Girlish, perilous, sexy and bleak, Minor Theater’s “Marie It’s Time,” at HERE, resurrects a marginal character from an influential work of modern drama. Then it kills her again. In this three-actor play, the playwright Julia Jarcho and the director Ásta Bennie Hostetter initiate a dialogue with Georg Büchner’s “Woyzeck,” an expressionist take on true crime left unfinished at the time of Büchner’s early death.

headline: In the eastern Donbas, a slew of contradictions.
abstract: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — On a clear spring morning eight years ago, Oleksandr Khainus stepped outside his house to go to work at the town factory when he spotted new graffiti scrawled across his fence. “Glory to Russia,” vandals had written in angry black spray paint. “Putin,” another message said.
lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — On a clear spring morning eight years ago, Oleksandr Khainus stepped outside his house to go to work at the town factory when he spotted new graffiti scrawled across his fence. “Glory to Russia,” vandals had written in angry black spray paint. “Putin,” another message said.

headline: Burnout, Productivity and Other Tales of the Office
abstract: Readers discuss new aspects of the workplace during the pandemic. Also: A political balance; Vladimir Putin and Mikhail Gorbachev; student newspapers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bad Bunny, No. 1 Again, Puts a Spotlight on Inequities in Puerto Rico
abstract: Days before his latest album notched its 11th week atop the Billboard 200, the pop superstar released a music video paired with a documentary by Bianca Graulau.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another hundred-odd-million streams and yet another No. 1 for Bad Bunny, the Puerto Rican pop superstar whose album “Un Verano Sin Ti” has dominated the upper rungs of the Billboard chart since it came out in May.

headline: Wall Street Is on Edge as It Tries to Guess What the Fed Is Thinking
abstract: Ahead of a pivotal Federal Reserve meeting on Wednesday, prominent investors and business leaders have warned that the worst may be yet to come for the markets.
lead_paragraph: Will Jay Powell be hawkish or dovish when the Federal Reserve meets on Wednesday? The collective mood of investors going forward, already soured after last week’s stock market tumult, depends on the answer to that question.

headline: See the Destruction Left in Hurricane Fiona’s Wake
abstract: Photos and video show the extent of the damage, including in Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Guadeloupe.
lead_paragraph: Islands in the Caribbean are reeling from the damage caused by Hurricane Fiona. In Puerto Rico, the storm knocked out power across the entire island. Photographs and videos show the extent of the damage to the islands in Fiona’s path.

headline: From Coronation to Funeral: Bookends to the Life of a Queen, and a Generation
abstract: For 70 years, Elizabeth II was the anchor of a nation’s identity. Charles III now will take on, or recast, that role.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has become a kind of badge of honor among baby boomers to recall how they watched on tiny black-and-white television sets on that day in June 1953, when Elizabeth II was crowned as postwar Britain’s first and thus far only queen.

headline: Three Reasons Puerto Rico Is in the Dark
abstract: Hurricane Fiona’s devastation partly reflects several factors that preceded the storm.
lead_paragraph: More than a million people in Puerto Rico were without power on Monday, and many were without running water, after Hurricane Fiona dropped 30 inches of rain on the mountainous island, causing widespread damage to homes and infrastructure. President Biden authorized the Federal Emergency Management Agency to mobilize and coordinate aid. Gov. Pedro Pierluisi told residents to remain at home and in shelters.

headline: Nissan Recalls Over 203,000 Pickups That May Roll Away While Parked
abstract: Owners of Nissan Titan and Frontier pickups should use the parking brake, the company and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said.
lead_paragraph: Nissan has voluntarily recalled more than 203,000 of its pickup truck models because of a defect that can cause the vehicles to roll away while in park, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said.

headline: Waving Goodbye to ‘Dear Evan Hansen’
abstract: Sam Primack, the final actor to play Evan Hansen on Broadway, reflects on the musical and clearing out that rack of striped blue polos.
lead_paragraph: Sam Primack almost made it.

headline: Don’t Let Republicans Off the Hook on Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: Democrats are letting the G.O.P. off easily by postponing a vote until after the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Why is it always on the Democrats to compromise?

headline: Her Majesty’s Last Broadcast
abstract: The funeral for Queen Elizabeth II honored a seven-decade public life. It also felt like a capstone to the mass TV era that defined her reign.
lead_paragraph: Television introduced Queen Elizabeth II to the world. It was only fitting that television should see her out of it.

headline: In Parks and on Post Boxes, Crowds Say Farewell to the Queen
abstract: The death of Queen Elizabeth II brought droves of people together in central London, where mourning has distracted many from Britain’s political tumult and cost-of-living crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They came in droves to central London, arriving before dawn and flocking to blockaded streets. Some had camped overnight. Others made hourslong journeys in the darkness to score a prime location for the royal spectacle.

headline: This Acrobatic Hunting Trick Is Straight Out of the Spider-Verse
abstract: A small Australian spider uses a Cirque du Soleil-worthy tactic to prey on fierce ants.
lead_paragraph: Spiders have no shortage of strategies to capture their prey. Some hunt in packs, others set traps and some even mimic the pheromones of their prey’s mate. But even so, less than 1 percent of spider species go after ants. The six-legged insects are fierce, and many are venomous adversaries with sharp, hedge-trimmer-like mandibles.

headline: Windsor, Queen’s Final Resting Place, Has a Long Association With Her
abstract: Queen Elizabeth spent much time as the castle outside London. Her husband is also buried there.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, England— Queen Elizabeth’s final journey began more than a week ago in Scotland when her coffin left Balmoral, the country estate she adored, where she sought tranquillity, and where she died.

headline: Social Media Companies Still Boost Election Fraud Claims, Report Says
abstract: The report, by New York University’s Stern Center for Business and Human Rights, argues that the companies fuel false conspiracies about election fraud despite promises to combat them.
lead_paragraph: The major social media companies all say they are ready to deal with a torrent of misinformation surrounding the midterm elections in November.

headline: Alain Tanner, Leading Director in Swiss New Wave, Dies at 92
abstract: With his brainy works of neorealism, he made films that helped establish Switzerland as a film center in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Alain Tanner, a pioneering director in the Swiss New Wave movement that took off in the 1970s, known for his cerebral, left-leaning films that challenged bourgeois complacency, died on Sept. 11 in Geneva. He was 92.

headline: In a Season of Frustration, the Brewers Are Still Fighting
abstract: A regular-season force that fizzled in last year’s postseason, the Milwaukee Brewers hope adversity this year will lead to better results in October. They have to get there first.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — In baseball, being too good can sometimes be a curse.

headline: Judge Vacates Murder Conviction of Adnan Syed of ‘Serial’
abstract: Mr. Syed, 41, had been serving a life sentence for the 1999 murder of his high school classmate Hae Min Lee. The judge gave prosecutors 30 days to proceed with a new trial or drop the case.
lead_paragraph: In a remarkable reversal, Adnan Syed walked out of prison on Monday for the first time since he was a teenager, having spent 23 years fighting his conviction on charges that he murdered his former high school girlfriend, a case that was chronicled in the first season of the hit podcast “Serial.”

headline: The New York City Ban on Foie Gras Is Delayed
abstract: A lawsuit halts the city’s prohibition of the delicacy for now, David Joachim releases a new version of his “Food Substitutions Bible,” Steelport Knife Co. has a new bread knife with heft, and more.
lead_paragraph: The ban of foie gras in New York City will not go into effect on Nov. 25, as a lawsuit brought by two Hudson Valley farms winds its way through the legal system. On Sept. 15, a New York State Supreme Court judge issued an injunction regarding the ban of the fattened livers of ducks and geese, first passed by the New York City Council in 2019. The court ruled that the two Hudson Valley duck farms, La Belle Farm and Hudson Valley Foie Gras, which sued in May over the ban, can continue to sell the livers to restaurants in New York City and issued a preliminary injunction on enforcing the law by the city while the matter makes its way through the court system. The passage of the prohibition was a triumph for animal rights activists, but the farms’ owners cited economic hardship, including the loss of business and 400 jobs, if the ban were to go into effect. They also claimed that the City Council exceeded its authority because the law had to do with farming practices outside the city.

headline: Top Aide Who Fueled Eric Adams’s Rise Will Resign at End of Year
abstract: Frank Carone, a Brooklyn power broker who has drawn scrutiny for his past business dealings, says he will lead the mayor’s re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: One of Mayor Eric Adams’s closest advisers, who has helped formulate and work out some of the mayor’s thorniest policy challenges, has informed administration officials that he will resign at the end of the year.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Mexico on Anniversary of 2 Major Temblors
abstract: The magnitude 7.6 earthquake, centered near the boundary of Colima and Michoacan states, killed at least two people. It came on the same day as devastating quakes in 1985 and 2017.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A magnitude 7.6 earthquake shook Mexico’s central Pacific coast on Monday, killing at least two people, damaging thousands of structures and setting off a seismic alarm in the rattled capital on the anniversary of two earlier devastating quakes.

headline: Law Enforcement Funding Package Splits Democrats Ahead of Midterm Elections
abstract: A measure to provide more money for local police departments has become mired in a long-running debate among Democrats about the politics of crime, as Republicans step up attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Legislation to increase funding for local police departments has hit a snag on Capitol Hill amid deep Democratic divisions, as progressives balk at steering more money to law enforcement and moderates clamor for action that could blunt Republicans’ efforts to paint them as soft on crime ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: Most of the 146 bodies exhumed in Izium so far were civilians, a Ukrainian official said.
abstract: Most of the 146 bodies exhumed so far in the northeastern Ukrainian city of Izium were civilians, and some of the bodies showed signs of torture, the leader of the regional military administration, Oleh Synyehubov, said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Most of the 146 bodies exhumed so far in the northeastern Ukrainian city of Izium were civilians, and some of the bodies showed signs of torture, the leader of the regional military administration, Oleh Synyehubov, said Monday.

headline: Valery Polyakov, Who Took the Longest Journey in Space, Dies at 80
abstract: Seeking to demonstrate the safety of long space missions, he worked out on his trip and returned 437 days later looking “like he could wrestle a bear,” one astronaut said.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Valery Polyakov, a physician and astronaut who held the world record for consecutive days spent in outer space, 437, has died. He was 80.

headline: Near Miss at a Nuclear Site
abstract: A Russian missile strike near another Ukrainian nuclear plant escalates fears of disaster.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict

headline: The Choreography of Public Mourning
abstract: The events around Queen Elizabeth’s death have unfolded with an astonishing amount of formal, choreographed movement.
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has been remarkable for many things: The outpouring of love and affection from her citizens and across the globe; the 20-hour, through-the-night queue to shuffle slowly past her coffin as it lay in state; the virtual cessation in Britain of reporting on any other news.

headline: Thousands Pay Tribute as Britain Says Final Farewell to Its Queen
abstract: More than 100 world leaders, including President Biden, attended the funeral for Queen Elizabeth II, and Britons lined the streets for a procession that took her to her final resting place at Windsor Castle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II was laid to rest on Monday after a majestic state funeral that drew tens of millions of Britons together in a vast expression of grief and gratitude, as they bade farewell to a sovereign whose seven-decade reign had spanned their lives and defined their times.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Britain Buries Queen Elizabeth II
abstract: Plus a preview of the U.N. General Assembly and growing nuclear fears in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II was buried in St. George’s Chapel at Windsor Castle, next to her husband, Prince Philip. It concluded the period of official mourning — a time of unifying grief and disorienting change.

headline: The Second Coming of the Appletini
abstract: As nostalgia grips drinkers, bartenders are giving vilified ’90s concoctions like the lychee martini and the lemon drop an upgrade — and ushering in a new martini era.
lead_paragraph: In April, a bar called Martiny’s — pronounced like the drink — opened near Gramercy Park in Manhattan. As one might expect from a place named after the world’s most famous cocktail, there is a martini on the menu. It is purple.

headline: Coach Leonard Hamilton: ‘The Worse the Program, the More I Became Interested’
abstract: Hamilton, the Florida State men’s basketball coach, was presented with the Joe Lapchick Character Award in New York last week.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Hamilton was on the ninth floor of the stately New York Athletic Club with its million-dollar views over Central Park, accepting the Joe Lapchick Character Award at a luncheon on Friday. Outside, a chauffeur waited to whisk him across the Hudson River to a private plane that would deliver the Florida State men’s basketball coach back to Tallahassee, Fla.

headline: Physics Body Concedes Mistakes in Study of Missile Defense
abstract: Two scientists said the American Physical Society had erred in evaluating their plan to use drones to shoot down North Korean long-range missiles.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest body of physicists admitted on Monday that a report it had issued seven months ago contained errors that downplayed the effectiveness of a novel plan for shooting down missiles.

headline: O.S.C.E. condemns 13-year prison term for two staff members in occupied territory as ‘repugnant.’
abstract: A court in Russian-occupied eastern Ukraine on Monday sentenced two Ukrainian staff members of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to 13 years in prison on treason charges, a move the regional security organization castigated as “inhumane and repugnant.”
lead_paragraph: A court in Russian-occupied eastern Ukraine on Monday sentenced two Ukrainian staff members of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to 13 years in prison on treason charges, a move the regional security organization castigated as “inhumane and repugnant.”

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ford Says It Will Spend $1 Billion More in Third Quarter Because of Supply Chain Problems
abstract: The automaker said shortages of parts are continuing to hurt its ability to make and sell vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Monday that the costs of parts would be $1 billion higher in the third quarter of the year than it had expected because of inflation and shortages of some components.

headline: Scholars Ask Congress to Scrap Winner-Take-All Political System
abstract: More than 200 political scientists wrote an open letter to lawmakers proposing sweeping changes to federal elections. The overhaul would be a heavy lift.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing we know about America’s creaking democracy, it’s this: Whenever it seems fundamentally broken, people get together to try to fix it.

headline: Strike Near Another Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Escalates Fears of Disaster
abstract: A powerful Russian missile hit 300 yards from the plant far from the front lines, Ukraine said, a reminder that despite its recent retreat, Russia can still threaten nuclear sites.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A powerful Russian missile exploded less than 900 feet from the reactors of a Ukrainian nuclear power plant early Monday, according to Ukrainian officials, a reminder that, despite battlefield setbacks, Russia can still threaten disaster at any of Ukraine’s four active nuclear plants.

headline: Pentagon Orders Review of Its Overseas Social Media Campaigns
abstract: The move comes after Twitter and Facebook shut down misleading accounts that they determined were sending messages to promote U.S. foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials told the military that they were concerned about its efforts to spread pro-American messaging on social media, prompting the Pentagon to order a review of secretive operations to influence populations overseas, U.S. officials said.

headline: DeSantis’s Migrant Flights Aim to Jolt Midterms, and Lay Groundwork for 2024
abstract: The Florida governor’s move sending migrants to Martha’s Vineyard from Texas brought liberals’ condemnation, and more such flights may follow.
lead_paragraph: For months, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas and Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona have been busing migrants across the country, using immigrants as political props as they try to score points in the midterm elections and bolster their conservative bona fides.

headline: Trump Was Warned Late Last Year of Potential Legal Peril Over Documents
abstract: A former White House lawyer sought to impress on him the need to return material he had taken with him upon leaving office.
lead_paragraph: A onetime White House lawyer under President Donald J. Trump warned him late last year that Mr. Trump could face legal liability if he did not return government materials he had taken with him when he left office, three people familiar with the matter said.

headline: California Woman Who Faked Her Own Abduction Gets 18 Months in Prison
abstract: Sherri Papini’s disappearance in 2016 prompted an extensive and costly three-week search. She admitted this year that she had made it all up to collect disability benefits from Social Security.
lead_paragraph: A California woman who faked her own kidnapping in 2016 and fabricated an elaborate tale to tell the authorities, prompting an extensive and costly search for made-up perpetrators, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison, the Justice Department said.

headline: Robert Fripp Lightens Up
