abstract: No one expected to see the leader of King Crimson dancing in a tutu on YouTube. In a rare interview, the guitarist explains “an entirely different trajectory.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Fripp became a rock star without acting like a showman. As the guitarist and leader of King Crimson — the band he founded in 1969 — Fripp, 76, has written music that’s barbed, visceral, complex and ambitious, seizing the vanguard of progressive rock yet reaching a broad audience.

headline: Biden Says the Pandemic Is Over. But at Least 400 People Are Dying Daily.
abstract: The president made the remark in an interview that aired on CBS’s “60 Minutes” on Sunday night. By Monday, the backlash was in full swing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With 400 to 500 Americans still dying every day of Covid-19, President Biden has declared that “the pandemic is over.”

headline: Arrests at Southwestern Border Exceed 2 Million in a Year for the First Time
abstract: The historic pace of undocumented immigrants entering the country continued as the Biden administration tried to steer clear of immigration issues with the midterm elections approaching.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time, the number of arrests of undocumented immigrants along the southwestern border exceeded two million in one year, according to newly released government data, continuing a historic pace of undocumented immigrants coming to the country.

headline: Russia is struggling to attract new recruits for its army, a U.S. official says.
abstract: WASHINGTON — Russia is struggling to attract recruits for its army amid its setbacks in Ukraine, while the United States is open to potentially sending Western tanks to Kyiv, a senior U.S. defense official said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is struggling to attract recruits for its army amid its setbacks in Ukraine, while the United States is open to potentially sending Western tanks to Kyiv, a senior U.S. defense official said on Monday.

headline: Criminal Investigation Is Opened After Migrant Flights to Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: The sheriff of Bexar County, Texas, said it was clear that many of the 48 migrants flown to Massachusetts had been misled and lured away to score political points.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — A county sheriff in Texas announced on Monday that he had opened a criminal investigation into flights that took 48 migrants from a shelter in San Antonio to the island resort of Martha’s Vineyard last week.

headline: Chris Redd Is Latest Cast Member to Leave ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: Redd, who contributed impersonations of Kanye West and Mayor Eric Adams, is leaving “Saturday Night Live,” where four new featured players are joining the show.
lead_paragraph: The number of departing “Saturday Night Live” cast members has now risen to eight: Chris Redd, who has been with “S.N.L.” since fall 2017 and has played characters including Kanye West and Mayor Eric Adams of New York, will not be returning this season, NBC said on Monday night.

headline: Buldak, the Fiery Korean Chicken Dish, Gets the Pizza Treatment
abstract: J. Kenji López-Alt pushes the limits of Korean fire chicken as a topping for a New York style pizza. It’s like barbecue chicken pizza, but hotter.
lead_paragraph: Buldak, or “fire chicken,” is a modern Korean dish known for its intense spiciness thanks to a sweet marinade heavy on chile paste and pepper flakes. The chicken can be cooked in a number of ways — on a grill or fried, for example — before it’s broiled with a bubbly and browned blanket of mozzarella. It’s a great drinking food.

headline: Put Two and Two Together
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein and Rachel Fabi double up for a puzzle that’s triple the fun.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Well, well, well, what do we have here? A puzzle by Rebecca Goldstein and some other constructor whose name sounds awfully familiar. That’s right, in an alignment of circumstances I have been anxiously anticipating, today I face the enormous challenge of writing about a puzzle that I, your intrepid Wordplay columnist, co-constructed.

headline: Videos Show Trump Allies Handling Georgia Voting Equipment
abstract: The footage raises new questions about efforts by Trump affiliates in a number of swing states to gain access to and copy sensitive voting software after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Newly released videos show allies of former President Donald J. Trump and contractors who were working on his behalf handling sensitive voting equipment in a rural Georgia county weeks after the 2020 election.

headline: In One Corner of Kosovo, Cheers Still Ring Out for Putin
abstract: Many ethnic Serbs, nursing grievances against NATO for a 1999 bombing campaign that broke Serbia’s grip on the territory, see President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia as a potential savior.
lead_paragraph: MITROVICA, Kosovo — When Europeans and Americans recoiled in horror this spring at evidence of Russian atrocities in Ukraine, Nebjosa Jovic, a university administrator in northern Kosovo, decided he had to act: He organized a street protest to cheer Russia on.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 20, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about Republican nominees backed by Donald J. Trump who would not commit to accepting this year’s election results misstated the number of Republicans who ignored or declined to answer a question about accepting the November election results. It was six, not five.

headline: Quotation of the Day: With Sadness and Uncertainty, Britons Close an Elizabethan Age
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Few leaders receive the outpouring of love that we have seen.”

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The funeral of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II was laid to rest yesterday after a majestic state funeral that drew millions of viewers across the country and was accessible to billions around the world. It was the culmination of 10 days of mourning since the queen’s death on Sept. 8 in Scotland — a highly choreographed series of rituals that came amid a deepening economic crisis and a fraught political transition in Britain.

headline: Sweden Is Becoming Unbearable
abstract: The idea of Sweden as a land of equal opportunity, safe from the plagues of extreme left or extreme right that haunt other countries, is gone.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — “Helg seger.”

headline: Winter Forecast: Gas and Electric Bills Will Soar
abstract: Utility companies warn that customers can expect increases of as high as 32 percent during the cold weather.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at why utility bills in New York will probably be significantly higher this winter. We’ll also look at 34 garage doors that became the canvas for an attention-getting art installation.

headline: Late Night Recaps the Queen’s Funeral
abstract: “There is no iPhone at the end of that line, all right?” Trevor Noah said of the long lines of mourners on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: epicure
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word epicure has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 18 in “What We Write About When We Write About Food” by Ligaya Mishan:

headline: Norway’s $1.2 Trillion Investment Fund Sets 2050 Climate Target
abstract: The “net zero” carbon goal aligns the fund, which has stakes in over 9,000 companies, with many other large asset managers.
lead_paragraph: The huge government fund that invests Norway’s oil revenue said on Tuesday that it was going to step up its efforts to persuade companies to slash their carbon dioxide emissions by 2050.

headline: Protests Erupt in Iranian Cities After Woman’s Death in Custody
abstract: The 22-year-old’s death sparked outrage across social, religious and political factions. Four people were reported to have been killed by the security forces.
lead_paragraph: Antigovernment protests erupted in cities across Iran on Monday in response to a young woman’s death in the custody of the country’s morality police, with security forces firing on crowds in the northwest and killing four men, according to three Iran-focused human rights organizations.

headline: Broadway Favorites
abstract: What are your favorite Broadway musicals, whether you’ve seen them live or not?
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s longest running show, “The Phantom of the Opera,” just announced that it will close just after its 35th anniversary. Have you ever seen a production of the show, or heard the music from it?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Godwit’s Long, Long Nonstop Journey
abstract: Researchers marvel at the bird’s record-holding migratory flight of 7,000 or so miles from Alaska to New Zealand at this time of year. No eating or refueling along the way.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of bar-tailed godwits are taking advantage of favorable winds this month and next for their annual migration from the mud flats and muskeg of southern Alaska, south across the vast expanse of the Pacific Ocean, to the beaches of New Zealand and eastern Australia.

headline: When Fossils Are Accidentally Dug Up, the Job Site Becomes a Science Lab
abstract: Several significant discoveries have started with a construction worker unearthing a bone and calling in an expert.
lead_paragraph: KENT CITY, Mich. — It all started with a very large femur.

headline: How a Quebec Lithium Mine May Help Make Electric Cars Affordable
abstract: The project also illustrates how difficult it is to get lithium out of the ground and break China’s dominance in processing the metal and turning it into batteries.
lead_paragraph: About 350 miles northwest of Montreal, amid a vast pine forest, is a deep mining pit with walls of mottled rock. The pit has changed hands repeatedly and been mired in bankruptcy, but now it could help determine the future of electric vehicles.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Debate Over the Teaching of U.S. History
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn why the teaching of history is under the microscope and how debates in school board meetings and statehouses across the country have affected social studies teachers.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What’s Actually Being Taught in History Class”

headline: YouTube’s Dislike Button Rarely Shifts Recommendations, Researchers Say
abstract: New research from Mozilla shows YouTube users have little control over what is recommended to them.
lead_paragraph: For YouTube viewers dissatisfied with the videos the platform has recommended to them, pressing the “dislike” button may not make a big difference, according to a new research report.

headline: ‘Serial’: Season 2
abstract: “Serial” is a podcast from the creators of “This American Life," hosted by Sarah Koenig. “Serial” tells one story — a true story — over the course of a season.
lead_paragraph: Twenty minutes after then-Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl had walked away from his remote Army outpost in Afghanistan in the middle of a summer night, carrying little more than vacuum-packed chicken, knives, water and a compass, he began to realize just how dire his predicament was.

headline: Who Is Going to Therapy in America?
abstract: Covid. Donald Trump. Forest fires. Eight Americans from across the country on why they recently started going to therapy.
lead_paragraph: Covid. Donald Trump. Forest fires. Eight Americans from across the country on why they recently started going to therapy.

headline: It’s Not Just You
abstract: America’s mental health crisis isn’t just about feelings. It’s about money, power and politics, too.
lead_paragraph: America’s mental health crisis isn’t just about feelings. It’s about money, power and politics, too.

headline: Understanding Green Infrastructure
abstract: I went to Newport Bay, Calif., where Orange County Coastkeeper, a local nonprofit, is building an oyster bed to rehabilitate marine life and protect the shore. The group could receive funds from the Inflation Reduction Act.
lead_paragraph: I went to Newport Bay, Calif., where Orange County Coastkeeper, a local nonprofit, is building an oyster bed to rehabilitate marine life and protect the shore. The group could receive funds from the Inflation Reduction Act.

headline: What Is the Purpose of Teaching U.S. History?
abstract: Schools have been caught up in spirited debates over what students should — and should not — learn about the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: Teachers, please note that we have also published a related lesson plan that draws on the same interactive Times feature.

headline: Do You Need a ‘Correct Attitude’ to Understand Your Mind?
abstract: Psychiatry too often ignores how a patient’s perspective can depend on culture, race, ethnicity and faith.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, when I was reporting on clinics for people in the earliest stages of psychosis, I met many young patients who were struggling to express what was happening to their minds. They described their condition as disabling, but it was still so new that it had not remade their identities or social worlds. When I asked one woman to describe her symptoms, she told me there was no language. She said, “It’s like trying to explain what a bark sounds like to someone who’s never heard of a dog.”

headline: To Really Understand the Ocean, We Need to Go Back in Time
abstract: “Historical ecology” can help us save the seas.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago the world’s oceans were viewed as too gargantuan for humans to influence. This view was voiced most notably in 1883 by the English biologist Thomas Huxley, who in his inaugural address to the International Fisheries Exhibition in London asserted that “all the great sea fisheries are inexhaustible.”

headline: We Have Reached Peak ‘Mental Health’
abstract: Has the term become so expansive as to be meaningless?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I received a referral for a new patient with a history of depression who’d made a serious suicide attempt. Perhaps unsure how to describe these episodes, the referring clinician wrote vaguely that the person had a “history of mental health.”

headline: In ‘Reboot,’ Everything Old Is New, to Streaming
abstract: This new Hulu comedy pokes fun at TV’s obsession with bringing back past shows.
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting at Hulu’s offices, over coffee and luxury bottled water, half a dozen executives entertained a pitch for a new series. Well, not exactly new. The idea: Reboot the beloved early ’00s comedy about a blended family, “Step Right Up.” Though it ended abruptly after its lead departed, the show has, surprisingly, found a robust audience on streaming, particularly among, an analytics specialist notes, the family and “live-to-laugh” quadrants.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Can We Trust the Polls?
abstract: Polling error is not inevitable, and there are signs that 2022 may be different.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday, I wrote about the early “warning signs” in this year’s Senate polling. Then three days later, I helped write up the results of a new national survey: a New York Times/Siena College poll showing Democrats up by two percentage points in the generic ballot among registered voters.

headline: Mental Health Is Political
abstract: Many in power would prefer to kick questions like “What caused the mental health crisis?” and “Who benefits?” out of sight. Don’t let them.
lead_paragraph: What if the cure for our current mental health crisis is not more mental health care?

headline: The Gamification of Humanity
abstract: In “You’ve Been Played,” a self-identified gamer warns against the dangers of imposing artificial incentives on all aspects of our lives.
lead_paragraph: When did daily life come to feel so much like a competition? In “You’ve Been Played,” Adrian Hon traces how and why gamification — the application of video-game principles like experience points, streaks, leader boards, badges and special challenges — has come to suffuse nearly every aspect of human existence in the digital era. Examples range from exercise (Nike, Strava), housework (Chore Wars) and brushing your teeth (Pokémon Smile), to — more disturbingly — going to school (ClassDojo) or work (Amazon warehouses’ PicksInSpace).

headline: The Single Best Guide to Decarbonization I’ve Heard
abstract: The energy expert Jesse Jenkins walks me through the path to our climate goals.
lead_paragraph: In August, Joe Biden signed into law the Inflation Reduction Act, which included $392 billion towards a new climate budget — the single largest investment in emissions reduction in U.S. history. The CHIPS and Science Act and the Bipartisan Infrastructure Act bring that number up to around $450 billion. All of that spending is designed with one major objective in mind: to put the United States on a path to a decarbonized economy, with the goal of reaching net zero emissions by 2050.

headline: The Redistricting Mess Comes to New York’s City Council
abstract: The Council’s 51 districts are being redrawn, but an initial effort that put Manhattan’s upscale Sutton Place in a Queens district drew lots of criticism.
lead_paragraph: For several long months, New York’s efforts to redraw state congressional maps were caught in a fractious, litigious battle, ultimately leading to ugly intraparty fights and the ouster of incumbent House members.

headline: ‘Serial’: Season 1
abstract: “Serial” is a podcast from the creators of “This American Life," hosted by Sarah Koenig. “Serial” tells one story — a true story — over the course of a season.
lead_paragraph: It’s Baltimore, 1999. Hae Min Lee, a popular high school senior, disappears after school one day. Six weeks later, detectives arrest her classmate and ex-boyfriend, Adnan Syed, for her murder. He says he’s innocent — though he can’t exactly remember what he was doing on that January afternoon.

headline: Speeding Up Your Daily Walk Could Have Big Benefits
abstract: In the largest study to incorporate activity tracker data, picking up the pace paid dividends for long-term health.
lead_paragraph: Many of us regularly wear an activity tracker, which counts the number of steps we take in a day. Based on these numbers, it can be hard to make sense of what they might mean for our overall health. Is it just the overall number of steps in a day that matter, or does exercise intensity, such as going for a brisk walk or jog, make a difference?

headline: Egypt Feels Pain of Global Disruptions Wrought by War and Pandemic
abstract: The country’s economy has been very hard hit by cascading crises which have disrupted worldwide trade.
lead_paragraph: When the state-owned factory where Hesham el-Atar worked for 15 years was liquidated this month, he had a feeling it was linked to international pressure on the Egyptian government to reduce its role in the economy amid a severe downturn.

headline: What Comes Next in the Fed’s Fight Against Inflation?
abstract: Wall Street will watch the central bank’s economic forecasts closely on Wednesday, when another jumbo-size rate increase is expected.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is expected to deliver a third straight supersize interest rate increase this week as it wages its most aggressive fight against inflation since the 1980s — and it could signal even more to come.

headline: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
abstract: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
lead_paragraph: Q. During the two weeks before my period every month, I get premenstrual symptoms so severe that they are seriously affecting my work, social life and romantic life. I’ve heard that S.S.R.I. antidepressants can help, but should I really go on meds for something so cyclical?

headline: Glenn Youngkin Knows Exactly What He’s Doing
abstract: The governor believes he needs to cater to and actually support election questioners and deniers to have a shot at leading the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: It’s obvious. Glenn Youngkin, the Republican governor of Virginia, wants to be president.

headline: Billions in Climate Deal Funding Could Help Protect U.S. Coastal Cities
abstract: Communities across the country hope to tap into funds from Democrats’ new climate law to restore coastal habitats, part of a program that emphasizes nature-based solutions.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BAY, Calif. — Claire Arre, a marine biologist, waded through the sand in search of an Olympia oyster on a recent sunny afternoon, monitoring the bed her organization had built to clean up the surrounding watershed and contemplating all that could be done if she could get her hands on federal funding to expand the work.

headline: Your Mental Health Isn’t Just About You
abstract: Conversations about mental health are everywhere. So why do we still feel so bad?
lead_paragraph: Conversations about mental health are everywhere. So why do we still feel so bad?

headline: ‘Very Harmful’ Lack of Data Blunts U.S. Response to Outbreaks
abstract: Major data gaps, the result of decades of underinvestment in public health, have undercut the government response to the coronavirus and now to monkeypox.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — After a middle-aged woman tested positive for Covid-19 in January at her workplace in Fairbanks, public health workers sought answers to questions vital to understanding how the virus was spreading in Alaska’s rugged interior.

headline: In Istanbul’s Private Retreats of the Sultans, Time Stands Still
abstract: The elegant pavilions and summer palaces known as kasir offer a glimpse of history and an intimate and enticing slice of Ottoman life.
lead_paragraph: Inside one of the elegant pavilions known in Istanbul as a kasir, the clamor and chaos of big city life recedes. The noise of car horns and shouting vendors is replaced by near silence. Listen carefully for the imagined whisper of silk rustling in the breeze or the echo of a once vital conversation abruptly curtailed. In these discreet and sophisticated structures and summer palaces, built only for the sultans, time stands still. Ostensibly intended as private retreats away from the formality of the courts at Topkapı and Dolmabahçe palaces, in reality kasir were places to scheme and plot. Each is a snapshot of a particular moment in history and an intimate and enticing slice of Ottoman life.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to ‘Fly’ on a Trapeze
abstract: Tom Moore made a name for himself as a film, TV and theater director. But his dream has always been to “fly” on the trapeze, high in the air. And that’s what he is doing at age 79.
lead_paragraph: It’s Never Too Late is a series about people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.

headline: The Enduring Wisdom of ‘Goodnight Moon’
abstract: It’s the first book many babies receive as a gift, and one of the few that parents will keep when their child is grown. Why does this 75-year-old story have such staying power?
lead_paragraph: The first 25 times I read “Goodnight Moon,” I cried. Not in a dainty, tear-dabbing way; I’m talking Niagara waterworks, heaving sobs and a red nose.

headline: Dinner in Seven Ingredients (or Even Fewer!)
abstract: These 24 recipes show you how to make the very most of very little.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a ton of ingredients for a meal that sings.

headline: A Buyer With a Vision Builds Her Own Hamptons Home
abstract: Dismayed by overpriced Hamptons real estate — ‘and nothing was really what I wanted’ — she decided to build her own house instead of buying one.
lead_paragraph: Dismayed by overpriced Hamptons real estate — ‘and nothing was really what I wanted’ — she decided to build her own house instead of buying one.

headline: One Frustrated Hamptons Buyer Opts for an Alternative: Build It Yourself
abstract: Dismayed by overpriced Hamptons real estate — ‘and nothing was really what I wanted’ — she decided to design her own house instead of buying one.
lead_paragraph: When Amanda Brezing began looking for a summer house in the Hamptons in 2017, she encountered a common problem.

headline: ‘Serial’: Season 3
abstract: “Serial” is a podcast from the creators of “This American Life," hosted by Sarah Koenig. “Serial” tells one story — a true story — over the course of a season.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of Season 3 of “Serial,” Sarah Koenig considers a relatively simple court case in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which includes Cleveland and serves as the setting for the season.

headline: At a Moment in London Like No Other, Fashion Forges Ahead
abstract: London Fashion Week clashed with the funeral of Britain’s longest reigning monarch. The city’s designers, respectfully, chose to soldier on.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Sunday night — the eve of the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II — the queue of people waiting to pay their last respects to the late monarch stretched so far through the heart of the British capital that it could be seen from space.

headline: Film Club: ‘What the Pandemic Can Teach Us About Endings’
abstract: Do you think we will ever feel like the pandemic is really over? Or, do we need to rethink our need for Hollywood endings?
lead_paragraph: We have all been waiting a long time for the pandemic to end. For masks, restrictions, boosters and canceled plans to once and for all come to a close.

headline: Adnan Syed, Freed
abstract: We talk with Sarah Koenig, host of the “Serial” podcast.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans know about the 1999 murder of Hae Min Lee because of the podcast “Serial.” Over 12 episodes in 2014, “Serial” documented the killing of Lee, a high school student near Baltimore, and the conviction of her ex-boyfriend, Adnan Syed.

headline: Here’s what to expect as world leaders address the United Nations.
abstract: World leaders’ speeches at the annual session of the United Nations General Assembly began Tuesday with a notable change of protocol: The president of the United States will not be speaking on the first day.
lead_paragraph: World leaders’ speeches at the annual session of the United Nations General Assembly began Tuesday with a notable change of protocol: The president of the United States will not be speaking on the first day.

headline: Why Adnan Syed Was Released From Prison
abstract: After decades of proclaiming his innocence and a podcast series dedicated to his case, a Mr. Syed won a reversal of his murder conviction.
lead_paragraph: Adnan Syed was accused of the 1999 killing of his classmate and ex-girlfriend Hae Min Lee, whose body was found buried in a car park in Baltimore.

headline: Mets Clinch Playoff Spot With Scherzer’s 200th Win
abstract: After achieving a suddenly rare milestone, Max Scherzer focused on the bigger picture: The Mets qualified for the postseason for the first time since 2016.
lead_paragraph: The frustration could have been palpable. Max Scherzer, in his first start for the Mets since Sept. 3, was perfect through six innings on the road in Milwaukee, but his day was already done.

headline: These Women Used the Rule of Law to Challenge Trumpism
abstract: In “Lady Justice,” Dahlia Lithwick celebrates the female lawyers, judges and others who stood up to the administration.
lead_paragraph: In 1873, the U.S. Supreme Court decided that women had no constitutional right to practice law. Indeed, as Dahlia Lithwick notes in this stirring book, a justice explained that the “natural and proper timidity and delicacy which belongs to the female sex evidently unfits it for many of the occupations of civil life.” But, in reaction, women mobilized to change the laws — and, ultimately, to become lawyers themselves.

headline: Yvon Chouinard Is the Founder of Patagonia. He’s Also My ‘Dirtbag’ Friend.
abstract: Yvon Chouinard has given away his company in his fight to save the planet.
lead_paragraph: Yvon Chouinard still possesses, in the proud parlance of the climbing community, the “dirtbag” sensibility. In the 1960s, he lived to climb and made do selling handmade climbing gear so he could devote himself to the mountains.

headline: Who gets to use gas?
abstract: Some African countries, which have done little to cause the climate crisis, say they should. Many climate activists on the continent call the idea “folly.” We unpack the debate.
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter is devoted to one of the most consequential arguments roiling the climate world: Which countries, if any, should start new gas projects now, and for what purpose?

headline: In His Vancouver Home, a Lighting Designer Embraces a Natural Glow
abstract: By combining soft illumination with bold furniture, Omer Arbel creates unexpected energy in the small rooms of his bungalow.
lead_paragraph: OMER ARBEL USED to live on the cliff’s edge. He had a windswept shack perched on a promontory overlooking the industrial port of Vancouver, British Columbia, the sort of experimental space — “no handrails,” he says, “and sharp things everywhere” — befitting an avant-garde architect and lighting designer. Then in 2015 he met a ballerina, Rachel Meyer, and after having a child together two years later, they decided to find a more conventional home, one fully at odds with his personal aesthetic.

headline: Es Devlin’s Next Stage
abstract: The British designer, whose new installation will be unveiled at Tate Modern this week, made her name in theater. These days, you’re as likely to find her work in art galleries, stadium gigs and fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Es Devlin was sitting in her garden communing with nature. Or rather, she was waving her phone, trying to get a bird song identification app to pick up chirrups from the surrounding trees. “Definitely two birds talking to each other, isn’t it?” she said. “I always want to know what they are. I’ve got a bit obsessed.”

headline: An Anti-E.S.G. Activist Takes on Apple and Disney
abstract: A prominent critic of investing that factors in climate and social considerations wants to use shareholder pressure to refocus companies on profits.
lead_paragraph: A conservative investor, with backing from Peter Thiel and Bill Ackman, has two new targets in his anti-E.S.G. campaign. Yesterday, Vivek Ramaswamy sent letters to the C.E.O.s of Apple and Disney, urging them to refrain from making political statements on behalf of their companies, or hiring decisions based on race, sex or political beliefs.

headline: Erdogan says Russia should return all captured Ukrainian territory.
abstract: Erdogan has positioned himself as a mediator between Ukraine and Russia and hosted preliminary peace talks in Istanbul in March.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said on Monday that Russia should return all Ukrainian territory it has captured, and indicated that negotiations that he has been helping mediate are moving in that direction.

headline: For New Yorkers, 6 p.m. Is the New 8 p.m.
abstract: Why are restaurants in the city filling up at hours that were once unfashionably early?
lead_paragraph: I WAS EATING French fries at the Odeon when I noticed that a server had begun to repeatedly check in. “Oh,” I realized, “she needs the table back.” It was 6:22 p.m. The restaurant was full. Once, 11:40 p.m. had been “a little too early for Odeon,” according to “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s 1984 chronicle of druggy downtown Manhattan, which featured the spot’s red neon marquee on its original paperback cover. “We sometimes didn’t get busy until, like, 8:30,” says Roya Shanks, the restaurant’s longtime maitre d’. But lately, she reports, there are “waves of people making 5 o’clock reservations” — unheard of just a few years ago. Farther uptown, at Danny Meyer’s Ci Siamo and Gramercy Tavern, “People sit down at 6:30, and our restaurant is full,” says Megan Sullivan, the director of operations for Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group. “Eight o’clock is what was hot for New Yorkers,” adds Roni Mazumdar, a co-owner of Dhamaka, a difficult-to-reserve Indian restaurant on the Lower East Side. “Now, people email, ‘Can I come in for that 6:00 reservation?’”

headline: 1922: Ex-Kaiser to Marry Princess Hermine
abstract: Wilhelm II, who abdicated as emperor of Germany in the midst of defeat in World War I, had become a widower in 1921.

headline: Ukraine advances deeper into areas that were held by Russia.
abstract: The Ukrainian military has not declared victory yet in Bilohorivka, given that control over towns has proved tenuous in the past. Reclaiming it would signal that Russia no longer has full control of the Luhansk region.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have battled their way back into territory in eastern Ukraine, officials said on Tuesday, reclaiming areas lost under months of relentless fire of Russian artillery. It is part of a remarkable turnaround from June, when the Ukrainian Army was nearly out of ammunition and struggled to slow the Russian assault.

headline: Spotify Makes a Bet on Audiobooks
abstract: The streaming service that transformed the music industry is expanding into audiobooks, and will offer more than 300,000 titles on a pay-per-book model.
lead_paragraph: Spotify made the lucrative audiobook market more competitive on Tuesday, when it debuted a new hub on its app with more than 300,000 titles, among them books by best-selling authors like Colleen Hoover, Michelle Obama and Stephen King.

headline: To Expand, Arts Centers Seek to Build Their Own Community
abstract: Hoping to firm up finances or secure a permanent home, museums and theater groups across the nation are teaming up with developers to add housing, retail and restaurants to their sites.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Linda C. Harrison became chief executive and director of the Newark Museum, she strolled through the four-and-a-half-acre campus in the heart of the city and examined two parking lots on the site.

headline: Storms Slow California’s Mosquito Fire, but Bring Flash Flood Risk
abstract: The state’s biggest blaze of the year is now 39 percent contained.
lead_paragraph: We’ll start with the good news: Rainfall has brought relief to firefighters battling the Mosquito fire, California’s biggest blaze of the year. Showers that began on Sunday have allowed firefighters to roughly double the containment of the 76,000-acre fire, which erupted west of Lake Tahoe during a record-breaking heat wave.

headline: Seven Looks That Defined New York Fashion Week
abstract: Big pants, small bags and other memorable takeaways from the fashion week that was.
lead_paragraph: Big pants, small bags and other memorable takeaways from the fashion week that was.

headline: A Virginia University Will Pay Hazing Victim’s Family Nearly $1 Million
abstract: Adam Oakes, a 19-year-old freshman at Virginia Commonwealth University, died last year after being told to drink a bottle of Jack Daniel’s whiskey.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Commonwealth University has agreed to pay $995,000 to the family of Adam Oakes, a student who died last year from alcohol poisoning at a fraternity party and whose death drew renewed scrutiny of hazing in Greek organizations across the country.

headline: Bad Bunny Leads 2022 Latin Grammy Nominations With 10
abstract: Rosalía has eight nods, while Jorge Drexler and Christina Aguilera have seven each for the awards, which will be held on Nov. 17 in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Bad Bunny, the chart-topping Puerto Rican star, dominates the nominations for the 23rd annual Latin Grammy Awards, leading stars from across the spectrum of Latin music, like Shakira, Rosalía, Carlos Vives and Jorge Drexler.

headline: Maker of the Theragun Massage Device Raises $165 Million
abstract: Therabody will use the money to invest in digital content and acquisitions, and is set to announce new products.
lead_paragraph: Therabody, the maker of the Theragun hand-held massage device, a cult favorite among athletes, has raised $165 million, the DealBook team reports. The fund-raising round, which was led by the private equity firm North Castle Partners, comes as wellness businesses seek to regain their footing as the pandemic recedes.

headline: Colin Hanks Finds Perfection in ‘What We Do in the Shadows’ and Tacos at Every Meal
abstract: The actor, who moves out of his comfort zone in Peacock’s “A Friend of the Family,” talks about his love affair with soccer and the pleasure of a shaved head.
lead_paragraph: When Colin Hanks learned that he was being considered for “A Friend of the Family,” he thought, “Awesome — it sounds fabulous.”

headline: ‘Four Saints in Three Acts’ Review: An Opera Becomes a One-Man Show
abstract: The actor David Greenspan is a tour-de-force, taking on all the roles of Gertrude Stein and Virgil Thomson’s large-cast opera from 1934, sans music.
lead_paragraph: One minute the actor David Greenspan is giving the preshow speech, as welcoming and easy as can be, explaining that the theater has held the curtain a few minutes because of trouble with the subway, and asking us, the audience, to turn off our phones.

headline: Chamath Palihapitiya, a ‘SPAC King,’ Will Wind Down Two Funds
abstract: Interest in special purpose acquisition companies has waned as the fear of rising inflation pushes investors toward more conservative assets.
lead_paragraph: Over the past three years, Chamath Palihapitiya refashioned himself from venture capitalist to mogul in the world of special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACS, the once-obscure financial vehicles also known as blank-check funds that rocketed in popularity — and stock market value — during the pandemic.

headline: Western Nations Will Take Temperature on Proposed Russian Oil Price Cap
abstract: The United States and its European and Asian allies are at a pivotal point this week on sanctions on Russia and the urgent issue of energy prices as they discuss how to increase punishments on Moscow at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its European and Asian allies are at a pivotal point this week on sanctions on Russia and the urgent issue of energy prices as they discuss how to increase punishments on Moscow at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

headline: How to Hunt Like an Octopus
abstract: High-speed video recordings reveal that the cephalopod’s eight arms aren’t moving randomly when they go in for the kill.
lead_paragraph: In its small glass aquarium, an octopus is coiled placidly in its den.

headline: The ‘Cost’ of Voting in America: A Look at Where It’s Easiest and Hardest
abstract: New Hampshire and Mississippi are at the bottom. Oregon and Washington are the top. For the first time since the 2020 election, researchers ranked all 50 states based on how easy it is for a voter to cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire and Mississippi are at the bottom. Oregon and Washington are the top. For the first time since the 2020 election, researchers ranked all 50 states based on how easy it is for a voter to cast a ballot.

headline: Lots of Food Gets Tossed. These Apps Let You Buy It, Cheap.
abstract: Several companies say they are tackling food waste by connecting people with unsold food from restaurants and grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: Every Sunday at 2 p.m., Marisela Godinez, the owner of El Mesón Tequilería, a Mexican restaurant in Austin, Texas, used to fill a 12-gallon bucket, plus another half-bucket, with leftover food from the restaurant’s all-you-can-eat brunch buffet. “We threw out a lot of food,” she said.

headline: Justice Dept. Charges 48 in Brazen Pandemic Aid Fraud in Minnesota
abstract: The defendants were charged with stealing $240 million intended to feed children, in what appears to be the largest theft so far from a pandemic-era program.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it had charged 48 people with running a brazen fraud against anti-hunger programs in the coronavirus pandemic, stealing $240 million by billing the government for meals they did not serve to children who did not exist.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jesse Jenkins
abstract: The September 20, 2022 episode of ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jesse Jenkins. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Does the world want 1.1 billion people to stop smoking–or not?
abstract: PMI Stop Smoking
lead_paragraph: PMI Stop Smoking

headline: NBC Revives Tarnished Golden Globe Telecast, Citing Reforms
abstract: The company said it was bringing the awards show back under a one-year agreement, to be broadcast on Jan. 10 and streaming on Peacock.
lead_paragraph: The Golden Globe Awards telecast, which sloshes money through the entertainment economy, will return in January with an even bigger platform. NBC canceled the show in 2021 amid an ethics, finance and diversity scandal that continues to simmer.

headline: New York City Subway System to Install Security Cameras in Train Cars
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the installations, which grew from a pilot project after a mass shooting in Brooklyn, would allay riders’ anxieties.
lead_paragraph: With subway ridership stubbornly stuck at about 60 percent of prepandemic levels, Gov. Kathy Hochul said Tuesday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority would install two security cameras on every car to lure back people frightened of crime and bolster a system whose finances were teetering.

headline: Will North Carolina’s Senate Race Break Democratic Hearts Again?
abstract: Since a blue wave in the state in 2008, winning elections hasn’t been easy for Democrats. But polling is evenly divided as Cheri Beasley and Ted Budd compete.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The pep rally at the Lenny Boy Brewing Company Friday night was a packed and raucous show of confidence as Democratic officials greeted the “next senator” from North Carolina, Cheri Beasley, and the Mecklenburg County faithful asked about her plans for after her inevitable triumph come Election Day.

headline: New York City Ends Private Employer Vaccine Mandate and Pushes Boosters
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams received the new booster on Tuesday, as he ended the Covid vaccine mandate and continued to roll back pandemic restrictions.
lead_paragraph: New York City will no longer mandate that private employers require all of their workers to be vaccinated for Covid-19, and children will no longer have to be vaccinated in order to participate in sports or other after-school activities, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Tuesday, as he continued to roll back restrictions that had defined an earlier stage of the pandemic.

headline: Met Appoints New Leader of Modern and Contemporary Art
abstract: David Breslin of the Whitney Museum, who replaces Sheena Wagstaff, will help shepherd the Met’s new $500 million wing and its curatorial programs.
lead_paragraph: In a decision eagerly awaited by the art world, the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday announced that David Breslin would become its curator in charge of Modern and Contemporary Art, indicating that he will play an important role in the new wing now under development for that department.

headline: America’s Most Interesting Opera Destination? The Midwest.
abstract: Barrie Kosky and Yuval Sharon, two of opera’s finest directors, open new productions in Chicago and Detroit.
lead_paragraph: New York City, despite its bona fides as a cultural capital, can be surprisingly provincial when it comes to opera.

headline: Republican Governors to Migrants: Go Away
abstract: “Govs. Greg Abbott and Ron DeSantis are using asylum seekers as political tools,” a reader writes. Also: President Biden and the pandemic; abortion prosecutors; arms for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Multiplying Horror of Ti West
abstract: With “X” and “Pearl,” the writer and director has released two related horror movies in the last six months, with a third on the way. The filmmaker discusses his quick building of a little horror universe.
lead_paragraph: There’s something unusual about Ti West’s latest film, “Pearl,” now in theaters. The movie is a 1918-set prequel to “X,” West’s homage to ’70s grindhouse, but that isn’t strange. It’s not the gruesome story of a young woman who tries to slaughter her way from farm life to silver-screen stardom. It’s not the Douglas Sirk style with a slasher sensibility.

headline: ‘Firebuds’ Gives a Face to Emergency Workers, and Their Vehicles
abstract: A new Disney animated series aims to instill helpfulness, commitment to service and a sense of community in its young viewers.
lead_paragraph: From the genteel Thomas the Tank Engine to the rough-and-ready racecar Lightning McQueen, children’s entertainment has been filled with talking cartoon vehicles that run on feelings as much as on fuel.

headline: How long should I wait to get a bivalent booster if I recently had a shot or contracted Covid?
abstract: You are allowed to get the shot two months after a previous dose, but some experts suggest waiting a little longer.
lead_paragraph: In August, the Food and Drug Administration authorized updated booster shots for people who are at least two months out from their last Covid shot (whether it was the original vaccine or a booster). You might want to wait longer between shots, though. While an advisory panel to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention voted to recommend the same interval between doses, several members voiced concerns.

headline: Does the bivalent booster entirely replace the other boosters?
abstract: The F.D.A. no longer authorizes the previous booster doses for people over 12.
lead_paragraph: The new booster shot is a bivalent vaccine, meaning that it targets two versions of the coronavirus: the original strain and the Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5, which became the dominant subvariants in the United States over the summer. The previous booster shot targeted only the original version of the virus.

headline: What London Wore While Remembering the Queen
abstract: Keeping calm and carrying on.
lead_paragraph: A sense of uncertainty hung over London Fashion Week in the days leading up to the shows. Queen Elizabeth II had died just one week earlier, and with a national period of mourning in place, it was unclear if designers would carry on with their presentations. Ultimately, they did — though more modestly than originally intended — but the week was not without its figurative casualties. (The entire slate on Monday, the day of the state funeral, was predictably scrapped, as was the runway show by the weekend’s biggest label, Burberry.) The circumstances resulted in a subdued affair; if there were a term for minimalist panache, this season embodied it. But by Sunday, the calendar was in full bloom, with a succession of grand events stretching from David Koma in the afternoon to Erdem at sunset — as if there were a collective exhale and readiness to fully embrace what a fashion week has to offer before the royal funeral.

headline: Special Master Expresses Skepticism of Declassification Claims by Trump’s Lawyers
abstract: The former president insists he shouldn’t have to state in a legal proceeding that he declassified the documents, while casting doubt on their status.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge expressed skepticism on Tuesday about the efforts by former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team to avoid offering any proof of his claims that he had declassified sensitive government documents that were seized from his Florida estate last month.

headline: Maury Wills, Master of the Stolen Base, Is Dead at 89
abstract: His speed (and his bat) helped the Los Angeles Dodgers win four pennants and three championships. He was voted the National League’s M.V.P. in 1962.
lead_paragraph: Maury Wills, the star Los Angeles Dodger shortstop who revived the art of base-stealing in the 1960s and became one of the most exciting ballplayers of his time, died on Monday night at his home in Sedona, Ariz. He was 89.

headline: ‘Andor’ Review: Star Wars Without the ‘Star Wars’
abstract: The franchise’s latest series on Disney+ sticks to the story but flushes a lot of the usual trappings out the airlock.
lead_paragraph: As the big science-fiction and superhero franchises have proliferated, their mantra has been that television is a place for diversification and creative freedom — to do something different, within reason. Hence Marvel’s strenuously meta “WandaVision” or Paramount’s goofy, animated “Star Trek: Lower Decks.”

headline: N.B.A. Fines Anthony Edwards $40,000 for Anti-Gay Remarks
abstract: Edwards, a Minnesota Timberwolves guard, used homophobic language to refer to a group of people as they stood outdoors. A video of the remarks was posted to Instagram.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. fined Minnesota Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards $40,000 on Tuesday for anti-gay remarks that he made in an Instagram video that circulated online this month.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘When I Hate My Husband’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when I hate my husband, I think about our place in Boston and the night a skunk fell into the basement window well outside of our bedroom. “That’s not a kitten,” John said when I woke him. He went to the rescue anyway, out into the rain and the darkness with a beach towel and an ironing board. I can still see him, soaked and shivering, grinning at me as the skunk climbed out and waddled away. I think about that man and the gorgeous absurdity of that moment, and even when I hate him, I love him. — Cara Byington

headline: A Finnish Scholar Wants to Change How We See American History
abstract: In “Indigenous Continent,” Pekka Hamalainen aims to upend the nation’s grand narrative, putting Native people and Native power at the center.
lead_paragraph: Americans may know the story of Crazy Horse, the Lakota warrior who led the rout of United States Army forces at Little Bighorn, or of Chief Joseph, the Nez Percé leader whose eloquent protest against his people’s forced removal to a reservation still echoes today.

headline: The Royal Museum With a White-Cube Gallery Inside
abstract: After an 11-year closure, the Royal Museum of Fine Arts in Antwerp, Belgium, reopens with a bright new space for modern art.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP, Belgium — From the outside, it’s difficult to see the impact of the $105 million, 11-year renovation and expansion of the Royal Museum of Fine Arts, one of Belgium’s most prestigious and important museums.

headline: A Lawyer Finds Her Happily-Ever-After as a Romance Writer
abstract: After leaving a law career to focus on fiction full-time, Jasmine Guillory is publishing her eighth novel, “Drunk on Love.”
lead_paragraph: Jasmine Guillory likes H.E.A.

headline: U.S. Shores Up Ukraine Support as Energy Crisis in Europe Looms
abstract: The Biden administration is trying to keep its allies on board as the Russian invasion has sent energy prices soaring.
lead_paragraph: In promising Ukraine billions of dollars in long-term military aid, the Biden administration is seeking to prove that U.S. support in the war can outlast Russia’s determination.

headline: Dates With a Book, Meals for Roller Skaters and More Reader Requests
abstract: Looking to celebrate a quiet birthday on your own? No problem.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time again! If you’re just joining us, every month I play concierge and help guide subscribers through the dense and delicious jungle that is New York City dining. This week, we have a reader who wants to know where they should celebrate their birthday solo, a roller skater looking for late-night bites near Prospect Park and a vegetarian book lover who wants nothing more than a nice place to read over a cocktail.

headline: From Mourning to Crises: U.K. Prime Minister Pivots to Mounting Woes
abstract: Liz Truss’s government will roll out major initiatives to confront an array of economic and social problems: soaring energy costs, surging inflation and pressure on public services.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The flowers have been cleared. Union Jacks no longer fly at half-staff. Ads have replaced Queen Elizabeth II’s image on bus shelters. A day after burying their revered monarch, Britons returned to normal life on Tuesday to confront a torrent of pressing problems they had set aside in 10 days of mourning.

headline: Despite War and Griner’s Arrest, American Men Hoop in Russia
abstract: While American female basketball players have largely stayed away from Russia, dozens of American men have sought pay and career development in the country.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine and the imprisonment of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner in Russia have roiled geopolitics and all but shut down the pipeline of American female professionals playing in Russian leagues to earn far more than they can make in the United States.

headline: Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Return to Center Stage. Their Own.
abstract: After going dark during Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign, the Clinton Global Initiative is back.
lead_paragraph: After a six-year hiatus, the Clinton Global Initiative returned to New York City this week, bringing together leaders from the worlds of nonprofit, government and business, with a few celebrities sprinkled in for good measure. It has been an eventful few years since they last gathered in 2016.

headline: Putin kept Russia and the world waiting hours for a speech that never happened.
abstract: The Kremlin did not explain why it was delayed — or even that it had been planned at all. But the caginess telegraphed the rapid speed — and apparent improvisation — with which Moscow is plotting out its next moves.
lead_paragraph: It felt like a possible turning point in Moscow’s seven-month war against Ukraine: President Vladimir V. Putin, with Russia reeling from losses on the battlefield, was going to make a prime-time address to the nation.

headline: Arnold Tucker, 95, Celebrated but Overshadowed Quarterback, Is Dead
abstract: Though he helped lead Army to three national titles, he was eclipsed by two storied running backs, and his death in 2019 was largely overlooked.
lead_paragraph: Arnold Tucker was an All-America quarterback who helped lead Army to undefeated seasons and national championships in the mid-1940s, received a coveted award as the country’s outstanding amateur athlete and would one day be enshrined in the College Football Hall of Fame.

headline: ‘Beetlejuice’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The show had a bumpy, boisterous run, and will now begin a tour.
lead_paragraph: “Beetlejuice,” an exuberantly ghoulish musical that was so on brand it came back from the dead, will end its Broadway run on Jan. 8, the show’s producers announced Tuesday.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hard Drives With Client Data Turn Up on Auction Site
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said the firm had agreed to pay a $35 million fine.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney has agreed to pay a $35 million fine to settle claims that it failed to protect the personal information of about 15 million customers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday.

headline: As fighting intensifies in Ukraine’s east, a frontline town is cut off from the world.
abstract: After the Ukrainian military’s sweeping victory in the northeast last week, the fate of Siversk, in the Donbas region, appears once more undecided.
lead_paragraph: SIVERSK, Ukraine — The eastern Ukrainian town of Siversk, for weeks the northernmost Ukrainian-held settlement in the Donbas before Russian-occupied territory began, was a military way station for much of the spring and into summer.

headline: Jack Charles, Grandfather of Aboriginal Theater, Dies at 79
abstract: One of Australia’s leading Indigenous actors, he had a resonant voice, a charismatic personality and a troubled personal life that often landed him in jail.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Jack Charles, one of Australia’s leading Indigenous actors and activists, who has been called the “grandfather of Aboriginal theater” and who spent years in prison for burglaries that he saw as acts of reparations, died on Sept. 13 in Melbourne. He was 79.

headline: Tropical Storm Gaston Expected to Weaken
abstract: Forecasters said the storm, which was expected to bring rain to the Azores, would likely be downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Gaston will bring a few inches of rain to the Azores in the North Atlantic on Sunday before weakening, forecasters said.

headline: U.S. Investigates Racial Bias Claims in Kansas City Police Employment
abstract: A Justice Department inquiry, prompted by reports of discrimination in hiring, promotion and disciplinary actions, was welcomed by the city’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has begun investigating possible patterns of racial discrimination in the hiring and promotion of Black police officers in Kansas City, Missouri, according to city officials.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Moves Toward Annexation
abstract: Plus leaders address a world in peril at the U.N. General Assembly and protests sweep Iran.
lead_paragraph: Officials installed by Moscow in four occupied Ukrainian regions announced plans to hold “referendums” on formally joining Russia, according to state news media. The votes will begin on Friday and last for five days.

headline: Al Gore calls the World Bank chief a ‘climate denier.’
abstract: The former vice president also said President Biden should seek to have the Trump-nominated bank leader, David Malpass, removed from his role.
lead_paragraph: President Biden should work for the removal of the head of the World Bank, former Vice President Al Gore said on Tuesday, calling him a “climate denier” at an event coinciding with the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Mike Birbiglia to Return to Broadway With a New Show This Fall
abstract: The comedic storyteller, who previously brought a solo show to Broadway in 2018, has a new act for a new age.
lead_paragraph: Mike Birbiglia, the comedic storyteller who has mined his experiences with romance, fatherhood and sleep disorders for narrative purposes, will return to Broadway this fall with a new show prompted by swimming.

headline: Health Panel Recommends Anxiety Screening for All Adults Under 65
abstract: The guidance comes as Americans are coping with illness, isolation and loss from the pandemic, as well as other stressors like inflation and rising crime.
lead_paragraph: A panel of medical experts on Tuesday recommended for the first time that doctors screen all adult patients under 65 for anxiety, guidance that highlights the extraordinary stress levels that have plagued the United States since the start of the pandemic.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An Obituary 80 Years in the Making
abstract: The first Times advance obituary for Elizabeth was written in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The first Times advance obituary for Elizabeth was written in 1940.

headline: Russia’s Invasion Shadows U.N. Assembly Amid ‘Colossal Global Dysfunction’
abstract: Presidents Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Emmanuel Macron of France used the gathering as a stage to cast themselves as would-be peacemakers in the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Divided by war, strained by shortages and faced with the cataclysm of global warming, dozens of world leaders convened at the United Nations in New York on Tuesday for the first full, in-person General Assembly since the pandemic began.

headline: John W. O’Malley, Leading Catholic Historian, Dies at 95
abstract: He wrote groundbreaking histories of the Second Vatican Council, the late medieval church and the Jesuits, of which he was a member.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. John W. O’Malley, a Jesuit scholar whose depth of learning, clarity of prose and analytic prowess regarding topics as divergent as late-medieval rhetoric and the lasting impact of the Second Vatican Council earned him a reputation as the dean of Catholic historians, died on Sept. 11 in Baltimore. He was 95.

headline: Russia Signals Annexation of Parts of Ukraine, Raising Stakes in Fighting
abstract: Kremlin-backed officials in four partially occupied regions announced referendums on joining Russia, as Moscow tightens its grip and hints at escalation.
lead_paragraph: After stunning battlefield setbacks, Russia moved to cement its grip on territory it occupies in eastern and southern Ukraine, as Kremlin proxies there announced plans on Tuesday for referendums on annexation to Russia, indicating a possible escalation of the war.

headline: Royal Shakespeare Company Names Two Directors for Top Job
abstract: In an unusual move for a major British theater, Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey will jointly helm the major British theater troupe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey were named early Wednesday morning here as joint artistic directors of the Royal Shakespeare Company, the major theater ensemble based in Stratford-upon-Avon, Shakespeare’s birthplace.

headline: Fossils Solve Mystery of an Ancient ‘Alien Goldfish’
abstract: Closer examination of Typhloesus fossils suggests that the organism, which swam 330 million years ago, was similar to modern sea slugs.
lead_paragraph: The early fossil record is littered with bizarre creatures that do not resemble anything living today. And few of those evolutionary enigmas are as perplexing as Typhloesus, an ancient sea animal so strange that paleontologists have referred to it as an alien goldfish.

headline: Donors Worry About a Cash Crunch for Voter Registration Groups
abstract: Several nonprofit groups that work to register voters are privately sounding the alarm about their finances, warning donors that they will have to begin scaling back their programs just as the country enters the homestretch of the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Several nonprofit groups that work to register voters are privately sounding the alarm about their finances, warning donors that they will have to begin scaling back their programs just as the country enters the homestretch of the midterm elections.

headline: Three Paths Toward an Endgame for Putin’s War
abstract: But here are three possibilities.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Last week was an interesting week to be in Europe talking to national security experts, officials and business executives about Ukraine. Ukraine and its allies had just forced Russian invaders into a chaotic retreat from a big chunk of territory, while the leaders of China and India had seemed to make clear to Vladimir Putin that the food and energy inflation his war has stoked was hurting their 2.7 billion people. On top of all that, one of Russia’s iconic pop stars told her 3.4 million followers on Instagram that the war was “turning our country into a pariah and worsening the lives of our citizens.”

headline: New York Scrambles to Send Aid to Caribbean Battered by Hurricane Fiona
abstract: Organizations and officials in New York, a city with deep ties to both Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, have moved quickly to help with recovery efforts.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly five years after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, organizations and officials in New York are responding to another storm that has unleashed heavy rains, flash floods and mudslides on the island and the nearby Dominican Republic since Sunday.

headline: European Interest in China Investments Wanes
abstract: Spending by European companies on new factories and other “greenfield” investments, long a key source of capital and technology for the Chinese economy, is falling steeply.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — European corporate investment in China, a key source of Western technology and capital since China began opening up its economy four decades ago, is falling steeply and now mostly limited to a handful of multinationals, three new reports show.

headline: Sydney Museum Sends Visitors Into an Oil Tank (and an Artist’s Imagination)
abstract: An underground oil tank makes a mysterious art gallery for Adrián Villar Rojas. It’s part of the $245 million Sydney Modern Project opening in December.
lead_paragraph: When the Art Gallery of New South Wales in Sydney, Australia, began planning a campus expansion almost a decade ago, to add a building for contemporary art, it wasn’t clear what would become of the two giant, abandoned World War II-era oil tanks located underneath the new site. The museum’s answer: Let artists have at them. It has transformed one of the tanks into a vast, unnerving sort of gallery space and turned it over to the darkly imaginative Argentine installation artist Adrián Villar Rojas for a sweeping exhibition. Called “The End of Imagination,” it will open on Dec. 3, along with the $245 million expansion, known as the Sydney Modern Project.

headline: Super-Vision
abstract: Win big with Matthew Stock’s Wednesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever wondered what your superpower would be if you were a comic book hero? I know for sure that mine would not be super-vision — my poor eyesight is the stuff of legend. And I don’t think anyone would find “excellent time management” or “the ability to bike really far” to be particularly compelling powers for a superhero. But there is no question in my mind what superpower today’s constructor, Matthew Stock, already possesses: the power of superhuman crossword construction.

headline: The Border Crisis Could Still Be Biden’s Opportunity
abstract: But first it would help to admit that the border is not secure.
lead_paragraph: What is the best way to honor and preserve the American tradition of welcoming immigrants? Treating them as stage props, as Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida did last week by flying some 50 unsuspecting Venezuelan refugees to Martha’s Vineyard, isn’t it — even if progressive reaction was beyond parody: If Edgartown feels stressed by having to host a few dozen unexpected guests for a day, how are the residents of places along the border supposed to feel about the thousands coming in uninvited every day?

headline: Judge Orders New Bankruptcy Officials in Alex Jones Case
abstract: Citing a “lack of candor,” including over the Infowars fabulist’s lavish spending, the judge ordered substantive changes to his company’s oversight.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the trial of Alex Jones.

headline: With His 60th Home Run, Aaron Judge Continues March on History
abstract: Judge, the Yankees’ superstar outfielder, became the sixth player to reach the milestone and is one short of tying Roger Maris’s American League record of 61.
lead_paragraph: Sixty is a big, fat round number.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 21, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 22, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An earlier version of a chart with an article on Sunday about the challenges that threaten American democracy was labeled incorrectly. The chart describes only Senate representation by state, not Electoral College representation as well.

headline: Writer Who Says Trump Raped Her Plans to Use New Law to Prove It
abstract: E. Jean Carroll, a former advice columnist for Elle, had already sued the former president for defamation after he branded her a liar
lead_paragraph: In May, New York passed a law giving adult sexual assault victims a one-time opportunity to file civil lawsuits, even if the statutes of limitations have long expired.

headline: Quotation of the Day: What War? What Arrest? American Men Sign Up for Russia.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 21, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody’s going to say, ‘Why would you go there?’ But at the end of the day, you still have mouths to feed.”

headline: Migrants Who Were Flown to Martha’s Vineyard Sue Florida Governor
abstract: The Venezuelans who unexpectedly found themselves on a Massachusetts island say in their suit that Florida officials made “made false promises and false representations” to them.
lead_paragraph: The migrants who were flown from Texas to Martha’s Vineyard last week filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and other state officials who orchestrated the flights to Massachusetts, saying that they had engaged in a “fraudulent and discriminatory scheme.”

headline: The 49ers Bet Big on a Quarterback Upgrade but Ended Up Settling Anyway
abstract: The 49ers tried to move on from Jimmy Garoppolo, but the value of game-managing quarterbacks is highest to teams with sudden openings to fill.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco 49ers tried their best to move on from Jimmy Garoppolo. They drafted and groomed a successor last year. They advertised Garoppolo’s availability to all would-be trade suitors. They even politely excused him from training camp this summer.

headline: N.F.L. Players’ Union Quietly Seeks New Leadership
abstract: The group’s executive director, DeMaurice Smith, was nearly ousted from the role after negotiating a contentious 2020 labor deal. Candidates are lining up to replace him as soon as next year.
lead_paragraph: It has been two years and Seattle Seahawks safety Quandre Diggs is still sore about how his union negotiated its latest labor deal.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Officials installed by Moscow in four occupied Ukrainian regions announced plans to hold “referendums” on formally joining Russia, according to the state news media. The votes, which will last five days beginning Friday, are widely seen as a precursor to annexation and a potential escalation of the war. They are also a sign of Moscow’s growing desperation.

headline: Russia’s gas cutoff is ravaging manufacturers in Europe.
abstract: ARQUES, France — For years, cheap energy helped turn Arc International into the world’s largest producer of glass tableware, and a vital employer in a working-class region of northern France.
lead_paragraph: ARQUES, France — For years, cheap energy helped turn Arc International into the world’s largest producer of glass tableware, and a vital employer in a working-class region of northern France.

headline: Global leaders condemn planned referendums in Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine.
abstract: Global pressure is mounting on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as world leaders condemn referendums by Kremlin proxies that could set the stage for Russian annexation of occupied parts of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Global pressure is mounting on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as world leaders condemn referendums by Kremlin proxies that could set the stage for Russian annexation of occupied parts of Ukraine.

headline: Word of the Day: moniker
abstract: This word has appeared in 170 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word moniker has appeared in 170 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 19 in “Mourning Technoblade: Fans Grieve a Minecraft Star They Never Met” by Amanda Holpuch:

headline: Trevor Noah Feels for Trump as He Sits on the Sidelines
abstract: Ron DeSantis is stealing the ex-president’s thunder, Noah says — “he’s slowly becoming the Republican Party now.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: ‘We Haven’t Learned Our Lesson’: Victims Recall Martial Law in the Philippines
abstract: Ferdinand E. Marcos placed the country under military rule 50 years ago this week. With his son now in power, those who lived through those dark days fear their stories will be lost.
lead_paragraph: They were community organizers and unionists. Teenagers and pro-democracy activists.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Your Childhood Home
abstract: What are your memories of the home in which you grew up?
lead_paragraph: Do you still live in the home you grew up in? If so, how has it changed over the years? Do you hope your family will live there for a long time to come?

headline: Forever Giant: Buster Posey Joins San Francisco Ownership Group
abstract: Posey, the catcher who was a centerpiece of three championship teams, will also be on the Giants’ board of directors.
lead_paragraph: Buster Posey had a charming little habit as a hitter when he questioned an umpire’s call. Posey, who retired last fall after a dozen sterling seasons for the San Francisco Giants, was too polite to turn and mouth off. He telegraphed his opinion with a slow, subtle movement of his head and, perhaps, a pained smile. An umpire attuned to subtext would get the message.

headline: How We Chose the Most Exciting Restaurants in America
abstract: For months, eight of our intrepid reporters, critics and editors dined their way through the country in search of culinary bliss.
lead_paragraph: Priya Krishna, a New York Times Food and Cooking reporter, sat alone at Lom Wong, a Thai restaurant in Phoenix, surrounded by a dozen dishes like green papaya salad with charcoal-grilled chicken, stir-fried noodles with straw mushrooms and head-on langoustine, and pork belly curry over jasmine rice.

headline: United Nations Gridlock Is Back in the Latest Sign of a Receding Pandemic
abstract: The first day of the U.N. General Assembly brought street closings and detours, but also more crowds for the city’s stores and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Drivers are staying away from Midtown Manhattan if they can. Workers returning to the office are taking the subway or allowing extra time for the bus. Deliveries are delayed or canceled.

headline: Staying Up Late to Find Out Why New York No Longer Does
abstract: More bars and restaurants are closing their doors at earlier hours, and more New Yorkers are grabbing dinner earlier in the evening. One of our reporters set off to find out why.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at why closing times in the city that never sleeps are earlier than they used to be.

headline: German Government Nationalizes Uniper in Move to Secure Energy Supply
abstract: The utility company, once Germany’s largest importer of Russian gas, has been squeezed since Moscow cut the flow of the fuel, leading to a full takeover.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In its latest outlay to secure energy for Europe’s largest economy, the German government on Wednesday announced the nationalization of Uniper, a company responsible for providing more than a third of Germany’s natural gas.

headline: Putin Announces an Expansion of the War Effort
abstract: In a rare address, which was prerecorded, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced a partial mobilization of his military, effective immediately, stoking speculation that Mr. Putin could officially declare war and a nationwide draft.
lead_paragraph: In a rare address, which was prerecorded, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced a partial mobilization of his military, effective immediately, stoking speculation that Mr. Putin could officially declare war and a nationwide draft.

headline: U.S. Gas Prices End Streak of Declines Just Short of 100 Days
abstract: Falling fuel costs have recently helped temper overall inflation, but the effect may be waning.
lead_paragraph: A 98-day stretch of declines in the average U.S. national gasoline price ended on Wednesday, a sign that the effect of falling fuel costs, which have recently helped temper overall inflation, might be waning.

headline: On a Grim Anniversary, 230 Pilot Whales Are Stranded in Tasmania
abstract: “At least 95 percent will die, because the ocean’s just so fierce,” said a boat skipper on the scene, where 470 whales were also beached in 2020.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a sobering scene: a phalanx of pilot whales, each up to 13 feet long and weighing a little under a ton, lining a remote beach in the Australian island state of Tasmania.

headline: Inside the Completely Legal G.O.P. Plot to Destroy American Democracy
abstract: Imagine a legal Jan. 6. It’s bureaucratic, boring, invisible — and it might actually succeed.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a legal Jan. 6. It’s bureaucratic, boring, invisible — and it might actually succeed.

headline: How Often Do You Text Your Friends Just to Say ‘Hi’?
abstract: New research suggests casual check-ins might mean more than we realize. Do you underestimate how much your friends would like hearing from you?
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you texted, called, emailed or messaged a friend just to say “hello”?

headline: Newly Published, From Neuron Forests to Cryptocurrency
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: MELAG: Town of Fables, by Bong Redila. (Fantagraphics, paper, $24.99.) Redila’s wistful vignettes, rendered in the author’s intricate and imaginative pen-and-ink drawings, span the multiple realities of a Filipino dreamscape where flying trains carry amorphous creatures, children encounter bottled genies in landfills and homes float among the clouds.

headline: How Republicans Could Win Control of the House
abstract: The political winds that once favored Republicans in the coming midterm elections appear to have shifted in the Democrats’ favor, but in the quest for the House, geography may be destiny.
lead_paragraph: The political winds that once favored Republicans in the coming midterm elections appear to have shifted in the Democrats’ favor, but in the quest for the House, geography may be destiny.

headline: After Dobbs: Feminism Beyond the Gender Binary
abstract: Jennifer Finney Boylan and Thomas Page McBee on what the feminist movement owes the trans community.
lead_paragraph: As the feminist movement has regrouped in the wake of the Supreme Court decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, one of the more surprising debates that has emerged has been one about semantics. Some feminists argue that using inclusive phrases like “pregnant person” in reproductive rights advocacy minimizes the experiences of cisgender women. So where do trans and nonbinary people fit within feminism’s big tent?
