abstract: “Our Missing Hearts” explores a fictional world where Chinese Americans are spurned and books are recycled into toilet paper.
lead_paragraph: The definition of “dystopia” in the Oxford English Dictionary is bald and to the point: “An imaginary place in which everything is as bad as possible.”

headline: I Have Worked, Played and Loved in Other Countries Because I Can’t at Home
abstract: In Singapore, queer people see progress only from a distance.
lead_paragraph: I was at a watch party last month, waiting excitedly for the expected announcement that Singapore would finally decriminalize consensual sex between gay men.

headline: Moderate Republicans No Longer Have a Home, and It Started With My Defeat
abstract: A former congressman on their decline and how it’s hurting the party.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 30 years, the Republican Party has effectively eliminated its moderate and liberal voices — as well as the conservative voices that put country over party. The consequences of this takeover by an increasingly right-wing faction include the threats to democracy that have become increasingly prominent since the Jan. 6 riots.

headline: Into the Wilds of Quebec in an Electric Car
abstract: A network of fast charging stations in the Canadian province could serve as a template for how to make road trips easier for drivers of electric cars.
lead_paragraph: Congress has allocated billions of dollars to build a network of electric vehicle charging stations along major U.S. highways. Quebec already has one, reaching deep into the province. The system offers a glimpse of how essential access to charging will be to the success of electric cars.

headline: The Classic American Novel That Andrew Sean Greer Detests
abstract: “I couldn’t read more than a page of ‘Last of the Mohicans,’” says the novelist, whose new book is “Less Is Lost.” “Not only is it wildly offensive, it’s unintelligible gibberish. There. I said it. Come after me.”
lead_paragraph: “The Luminous Novel,” by Mario Levrero. “Booth,” by Karen Joy Fowler. “The Swank Hotel,” by Lucy Corin. “Time Will Darken It,” by William Maxwell. “The Wrong End of the Telescope,” by Rabih Alameddine.

headline: Roxanne Lowit Knew That People Make the Party
abstract: Marc Jacobs, Christy Turlington, Fran Lebowitz and others remember the singular talent of an on-the-scene photographer.
lead_paragraph: The death of the photographer Roxanne Lowit on Sept. 13 caught many people in the fashion world by surprise. Maybe because the shows and parties haven’t been in full swing the last three years, but in all likelihood, it was more because the once ubiquitous Ms. Lowit — who was 80 years old at the time of her death from a fatal stroke — had been missing in action for some time.

headline: The Republic
abstract: American democracy is under threat. But for some candidates and voters, democracy isn’t even the destination anymore.
lead_paragraph: In kicking off the midterms, Joe Biden talked about American democracy as a shared value, enshrined in the country’s founding — a value that both Democrats and Republicans should join together in defending. But there is another possible view of this moment. One that is shared by two very different groups: the voters who propelled Biden to the presidency … and the conservative activists who are rejecting democracy altogether.

headline: Marry Now, Pay Later: New Services Put Weddings on Installment
abstract: The “buy now, pay later” approach has infiltrated the wedding industry via new programs created specifically to finance events.
lead_paragraph: Angela Millin, like many brides-to-be, quickly began planning her wedding after becoming engaged in April 2021.

headline: Deanna Raybourn Puts Power in the Hands of Older Women
abstract: In “Killers of a Certain Age,” the longtime historical novelist dips a toe in contemporary waters — and celebrates an oft-ignored age group.
lead_paragraph: Why should young people hog all the heart-pounding adventure, not to mention the shelf space reserved for world-class assassins?

headline: Thrifty Strategies for Senior Travelers
abstract: Not all age-related deals are equal. Here are some perks to look for and pitfalls to avoid, along with tips on how to stretch your budget.
lead_paragraph: For many older Americans, travel is a priority coming out of the pandemic. A late 2021 survey by AARP, the nonprofit organization representing Americans 50 and older, found members planned to take four trips on average in 2022, just below prepandemic figures, and spend more, with the typical budget for travel at nearly $8,400, up from roughly $6,500 in 2019.

headline: In India, Debunking Fake News and Running Into the Authorities
abstract: Alt News, an independent website, has emerged as a leading debunker of misinformation in the nation, but highlighting hate speech against minorities has put it on a collision course with the government.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — The two men were unlikely candidates to work in the news business.

headline: Is the Hyperloop Doomed?
abstract: Though some efforts continue, the once-promising technology has run up against significant challenges — most notably creating an entirely new transit infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our series on the Future of Transportation, which is exploring innovations and challenges that affect how we move about the world.

headline: How to Beat High Mortgage Interest Rates
abstract: Consider loans with shorter terms and tactics that build equity.
lead_paragraph: It was hard enough for home buyers when the coronavirus pandemic made finding available homes so difficult. Now, with mortgage rates for 30-year, fixed-rate loans climbing over 6 percent in September, from a low of around 2.6 percent at the start of 2021, affording those homes is also much more challenging.

headline: The Inside Joke That Became Trump’s Big Lie
abstract: The lie that Trump won the 2020 election has grown so powerful because it is yoked to an older deception: the idea that American politics is a joke.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s so-called big lie is not big because of its brazen dishonesty or its widespread influence or its unyielding grip over the Republican Party. It is not even big because of its ambition — to delegitimize a presidency, disenfranchise millions of voters, clap back against reality. No, the lie that Donald Trump won the 2020 election has grown so powerful because it is yoked to an older deception, without which it could not survive: the idea that American politics is, in essence, a joke, and that it can be treated as such without consequence.

headline: Trump Support Remains Unmoved by Investigations, Poll Finds
abstract: Even during peak crises during his presidency, views of him were static. Post-presidency polls have continued the trend.
lead_paragraph: The American public’s views of former President Donald J. Trump have remained remarkably stable across a number of different measures in recent months, even as he faces multiple investigations and as he remains a central figure in the midterm elections, according to the most recent New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: 3-K for All? Adams Retreats From Expanding N.Y.C. Preschool Program.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams is reassessing how New York City’s so-called 3-K for All program, a top priority of his predecessor, fits into his administration’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s free universal prekindergarten program, widely regarded as Bill de Blasio’s signature policy achievement as mayor, proved so popular that he vowed to expand it quickly to include all 3-year-olds.

headline: Why Omicron Might Stick Around
abstract: Omicron, the 13th named variant of the coronavirus, seems to have a remarkable capacity to evolve new tricks.
lead_paragraph: Where is Pi?

headline: Bad News From the Fed? We’ve Been Here Before.
abstract: Fed rate increases are causing pain now. But an inside look at the Volcker era shows that conditions were far worse when the Fed tried different tacks to tame inflation.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s decision to raise interest rates again is hardly a positive development for anyone with a job, a business or an investment in the stock or bond market.

headline: How Many Ants Are There on Earth? You’re Going to Need More Zeros.
abstract: There are 20 quadrillion ants worldwide, according to a new census, or 2.5 million for every living human. There are probably even more than that.
lead_paragraph: Right now, ants are scurrying around every continent except Antarctica, doing the hard work of engineering ecosystems. They spread seeds, churn up soil and speed up decomposition. They forage and hunt and get eaten. You may not know how much you rely on them.

headline: Guns, Gorillas and Netflix: A Belgian Prince in Congo
abstract: Emmanuel de Merode is trying to protect Virunga National Park, catching the eye of Hollywood, and its philanthropists, along the way. “Complicated” doesn’t even begin to describe the story.
lead_paragraph: RUMANGABO, Democratic Republic of Congo — “Emmanuel was over at my house for dinner the other night,” Ben Affleck said in an interview, “and despite the fact that he’s spent most of his life in Virunga, he’s been shot, he’s seen people he’s loved killed, my 16-year-old daughter said: ‘Why is it appropriate you do this? You’re not Congolese.’”

headline: A Girl Survived a Suicide Bombing in Afghanistan. Then She Vanished in Texas.
abstract: Lina Sardar Khil was 3 when she barely escaped a terrorist attack during the fall of Afghanistan. While living in San Antonio, she went out to play — and has not been seen since.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — For years Riaz Sardar Khil, a soldier with the Afghan army, assisted U.S. troops during their mission overseas. He was rewarded with an immigration visa to start a new life in America. Three years ago, Mr. Sardar, his wife and a newborn daughter resettled in a sprawling apartment complex in a working-class neighborhood in San Antonio.

headline: The 25 Most Influential Postwar Women’s Wear Collections
abstract: A group of fashion experts — editors, historians and a designer — convened over Zoom to make a list of the clothes that shaped the world.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s a little white dress over a New York City subway grate or a cone bra on a statement-making pop star, the clothes we wear have the power to project all kinds of messages. The very existence of certain garments and silhouettes is often proof of moments of significant social change; we communicate the things we cannot say through the clothes we wear, which in turn can determine how we move about the world and where we’re allowed to go. In many ways, any history of fashion, however incomplete, is a history of us all. It’s also a survey of tailoring, textiles, innovation, infighting, business, bravado and, above all, beauty — ugliness, too.

headline: Putin confidant Viktor Medvedchuk is the most prominent captive released in a prisoner swap.
abstract: The Ukrainian politician and oligarch had acted as the Kremlin’s primary agent of influence in Ukraine for years.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Medvedchuk, the most prominent captive released by Ukraine in a prisoner swap with Russia, is a close friend of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia who had acted as the Kremlin’s primary agent of influence in Ukraine for years.

headline: Wildfire Smoke Is Erasing Progress on Clean Air
abstract: New maps reveal a picture of daily exposure to wildfire smoke in better geographic detail than ever before.
lead_paragraph: New maps reveal a picture of daily exposure to wildfire smoke in better geographic detail than ever before.

headline: Putin’s Escalation of the War in Ukraine
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has announced the mobilization of 300,000 Russians in an attempt to bolster his faltering invasion.
lead_paragraph: In a speech on Wednesday, President Vladimir V. Putin said that he would require hundreds of thousands more Russians to fight in Ukraine — and alarmed the West by once again raising the specter of nuclear force.

headline: Europe’s Shrinking Waterways Reveal Treasures, and Experts Are Worried
abstract: Drought combined with extreme heat this summer have painted a dramatic picture of Europe’s drying rivers and reservoirs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rusted chunks of metal from an old pickup truck disintegrate in the sun. Its windows, tires and interior are long gone, and so are any operable parts. It sits against a collection of hollowed-out homes and derelict buildings, all ruins of Aceredo, a former village in northwest Spain that was submerged three decades ago when a hydropower dam flooded the valley.

headline: Bad to Worse for Russia
abstract: Vladimir Putin’s call-up of more troops highlights Russia’s continuing struggles in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The war news has gone from bad to worse for Vladimir Putin over the past two weeks.

headline: ‘Catherine Called Birdy’ Review: Ye Olde Lady Bird
abstract: Bella Ramsey plays a 13th century adolescent in Lena Dunham’s winning film.
lead_paragraph: To flip through the pages of a 13th century manuscript, one might believe the medieval era was beleaguered by more snaky dragons and man-murdering bunnies than temperamental tween girls. Young women’s stories weren’t recorded — certainly not in their own hand, as literacy was low and paper costs were high — an absence that has prodded later generations to imagine the adolescent of the Middle Ages as demure and obedient, neither seen nor heard. Here comes “Catherine Called Birdy,” a headstrong comedy written for the screen and directed by Lena Dunham, to fill in that silence with a shriek.

headline: ‘Railway Children’ Review: A Nostalgia Trip, With Lessons
abstract: This winsome reboot of a British children’s classic, directed by Morgan Matthews, also addresses racial segregation in the armed forces during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The Railway Children universe originates in Edith Nesbit’s 1905 serialized novel about a mother and three children at the turn of the century who leave London to live just off a country rail line. A popular 1970 adaptation starring the British actress Jenny Agutter followed (among others), but the most recent “Railway Children” is set during World War II. The three youngsters in Morgan Matthews’s winsome new film, are shipped to the northern countryside as part of the evacuation of children that occurred during German air raids.

headline: ‘Carmen’ Review: You Will Live in Bliss
abstract: After her priest brother dies, a woman masquerades as a village’s irreverent new spiritual leader in this delightful drama.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a lineage from Bizet to Beyoncé, Carmen is a name associated with temptation. The new drama “Carmen” is not based on the famous opera and tells an original story, but its heroine calls her community toward earthly delights nonetheless.

headline: ‘Nothing Compares’ Review: Sinead O’Connor’s Rise and Fall
abstract: This new documentary shows many faces of Sinead O’Connor and highlights her genuinely incomparable voice.
lead_paragraph: The ascent of singer-songwriter Sinead O’Connor’s star was arguably matched by its implosion, which began when, with the longtime abuses of the Catholic Church in Ireland and around the world in mind, she tore up a photograph of Pope John Paul II on “Saturday Night Live,” exclaiming, “Fight the real enemy.”

headline: Gio Ponti’s Surrealist Playground, Revisited
abstract: How two designers reinterpreted Casa di Fantasia, Ponti’s perspective-boggling apartment in Milan.
lead_paragraph: REIMAGINING A LEGENDARY interior by a Modernist icon is a test not only of vision but of courage: Are you confident enough to put your mark on a space where greatness once ran wild? That was the challenge for the Lebanese designer Nicolas Moussallem and his French Lebanese studio partner, David Raffoul, both in their early 30s, who were recently asked to recast — and preserve what remained of — a famed Milan apartment known as Casa di Fantasia, created near the Piazza Piemonte in 1952 for a married couple, Mario and Lisetta Lucano, by Giovanni “Gio” Ponti.

headline: Andy Byford, Ex-M.T.A. Leader, Steps Down as London Transport Commissioner
abstract: Mr. Byford, who was revered as “Train Daddy” during his tenure as the chief of the New York City subway, said he would move back to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Andy Byford, who rose to prominence during a high-profile stint as New York City’s subway chief, announced his resignation as the head of London’s transit system on Thursday, saying that he would be moving back to the United States.

headline: Bank of England Raises Rates Another Half a Point at an Uncertain Time
abstract: Britain is fighting inflation, which is running near its fastest pace in decades. Policies to cap energy costs and cut taxes complicate the outlook.
lead_paragraph: As Britain goes through a period of vast change, with a new government and new monarch, the central bank is steadily increasing interest rates to try to keep high inflation from becoming embedded in the nation’s economy.

headline: After a Big Rate Increase, Markets Fear a Recession
abstract: The Federal Reserve has more jumbo-size interest rises planned, stoking fears of downturns in the housing, labor and stock markets.
lead_paragraph: For a third straight meeting, the Fed raised its benchmark interest rate by 75 basis points — and it’s hardly done. Count on an additional 1.25 percentage points’ worth of increases this year, the Fed chair Jay Powell said yesterday, which would bring the Fed funds rate to 4.4 percent by the end of 2022, and 4.6 percent next year.

headline: ‘They Are Watching’: Inside Russia’s Vast Surveillance State
abstract: A cache of nearly 160,000 files from Russia’s powerful internet regulator provides a rare glimpse inside Vladimir V. Putin’s digital crackdown.
lead_paragraph: A cache of nearly 160,000 files from Russia’s powerful internet regulator provides a rare glimpse inside Vladimir V. Putin’s digital crackdown.

headline: On the Runway, Money Is the New Sex
abstract: In this season’s fashion, there’s nothing hotter than looking like a million bucks.
lead_paragraph: This past May, as a foreboding heat washed over Manhattan, Demna, Balenciaga’s artistic director and a master satirist of our dystopian digital age, became the first designer to stage a runway show on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Following the ceremonial ringing of the bell, models emerged in double-breasted wool coats and silk jacquard pussy-bow blouses from the brand’s resort 2023 collection, which they wore over full-body latex bondage suits with talonlike nail details, some of them gripping leather briefcases or takeout coffee cups as they navigated a crowd including Ye, formerly known as Kanye West, Mayor Eric Adams and the makeup artist Alexis Stone, who attended as Dolly Parton. The plan had been for the presentation to take place in the Ramble, a section of Central Park as famous for cruising as for bird-watching; the Georgian fashion designer had been thinking about the exchange of desire and his own complicity in such transactions. However, when it proved tricky to obtain a permit, Demna turned his attention to an even headier fetish: money. The invitations were stacks of fake $100 bills.

headline: Japan Intervenes to Prop Up the Sliding Yen
abstract: The currency’s decline to a point not seen in 24 years prompted the rare action as officials keep interest rates low.
lead_paragraph: Japan announced on Thursday that it had intervened to prop up the value of the yen for the first time in 24 years, seeking to stanch the currency’s continuing slide against the dollar.

headline: ‘Invisible Demons’ Review: Capturing an Air Quality Crisis
abstract: The filmmaker Rahul Jain assembles a series of devastating panoramas in this documentary about air and water pollution in New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: The title of “Invisible Demons,” a patiently observed documentary, refers to the tiny toxic particles polluting the air in the Indian capital of New Delhi. But the name may also denote another culprit: the leadership officials removed from the crisis who fail to find a solution for city residents.

headline: Why Fog Is So Vital to Life in California
abstract: Some scientists are concerned that San Francisco’s most iconic meteorological phenomenon is on its way out.
lead_paragraph: Coastal fog isn’t unique to the California coast, but few places in the world are so deeply linked with the ghostly meteorological phenomenon. Even the emoji for “foggy” shows what appears to be the Golden Gate Bridge shrouded in clouds.

headline: Making a Meal of the Philadelphia Fringe Festival
abstract: A handful of works deal with the many questions of nourishment and nurture. How we feed. How we are fed.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday night, a group of about a dozen of us walked into a woman’s vagina. It was red, French-accented and soft. This was near the climax of “The Path of Pins or the Path of Needles,” a cynosure of this year’s FringeArts Festival in Philadelphia, which began on Sept. 8 and runs until Oct. 2.

headline: Zach Bryan Is Music’s Most Reluctant New Star
abstract: The Navy veteran — who blends folk, rock and country — has had a breakthrough year with his major-label debut, “American Heartbreak.” But fame isn’t what he’s after.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — In late May, Zach Bryan released “American Heartbreak,” a bracing and shaggily elegant 34-song country-folk opus that served as his major-label debut. It opened at No. 5 on the Billboard album chart, an astonishing mark for a singer who less than a year before had been in the Navy, putting out music on the side.

headline: A Baltimore Hotel With Four-Poster Beds and Flamingos Aplenty
abstract: Plus: a clamshell chandelier, photography capturing deforestation and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: A Renaissance for the Italian Rainbow Cookie
abstract: Plus: pastoral-patterned knitwear and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: After working for three decades with gold and oxidized silver, the Brooklyn-based artist and jewelry maker Darcy Miro experienced a revelation with a fistful of clay during a visit to a Fort Greene ceramics studio in 2019. “So many years of burning myself and getting metal shards stuck in my feet and my hands — and then I felt the clay,” she says. “The sensuality was unparalleled.” Miro, 49, bought her own kiln shortly after and started making small ceramic pieces, then moved on to bigger and bigger ones. The result is an exuberant debut collection of furniture that includes a desk bearing a sculpted hand; a sofa covered with polka-dot ring- and pretzel-shaped pottery and upholstered in ethically sourced alpaca fur; and a coral-inspired vase with protruding eyeballs. While she’s no longer solely focused on producing metal cuffs and rings, Miro wants her furniture to feel every bit as precious as her jewelry. “If you can have one thing and you love art,” she says, “well, maybe that thing is also a desk. So now you have art and a desk.” — Gillian Brassil

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, Midtown and Spuyten Duyvil.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, Midtown and Spuyten Duyvil.

headline: Homes for Sale in the Bronx and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Spuyten Duyvil, Yorkville and Midtown.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Some men flee Russia, fearing they could be called up to fight.
abstract: Since the announcement of a new troop mobilization, civilians have realized they could not count on staying out of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Since President Vladimir V. Putin’s announcement on Wednesday of a new troop call-up, Russian men who had previously thought they were safe from being forced to the front lines have realized they could not count on staying out of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: 4-Day Workweek Brings No Loss of Productivity, Companies in Experiment Say
abstract: More than 70 companies in Britain are undergoing a six-month experiment in which their employees get a paid day off each week. So far, most companies say it’s going well.
lead_paragraph: Most of the companies participating in a four-day workweek pilot program in Britain said they had seen no loss of productivity during the experiment, and in some cases had seen a significant improvement, according to a survey of participants published on Wednesday.

headline: From Prison to the Art Gallery
abstract: Formerly incarcerated artists are making waves in the collecting world, hoping to create pathways, and dignity, for their peers.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, in the recreation center of the Fairton Federal Correctional Institution, a medium-security prison for men in South New Jersey, an art collective was born.

headline: A Star-Studded Goodbye to All That
abstract: Among the well-wishers at Joan Didion’s memorial service in New York.
lead_paragraph: “I know why we try to keep the dead alive,” the actress Vanessa Redgrave said on Wednesday evening, speaking from a lectern at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where she was accompanied by her son-in-law, the movie star Liam Neeson. “We try to keep them alive in order to keep them with us.”

headline: Season Two, Episode 1: Dustwun
abstract: Bowe Bergdahl had a plan. He would create a crisis, in order to call attention to another crisis.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 2: The Golden Chicken
abstract: “A dead soldier is worth nothing,” one Taliban fighter said. But with Bowe Bergdahl in hand alive, the insurgent group knew it had scored.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 3: Escaping
abstract: During his first year in Taliban captivity, Bowe Bergdahl had one thing on his mind: getting out.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 4: The Captors
abstract: After two attempts to escape from the Taliban, Bowe Bergdahl was often confined to a metal cage.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 5: Meanwhile, in Tampa
abstract: The C.I.A., the F.B.I., YouTube and the Portland Police Department? As various organizations scrambled, they realized there was no handbook for getting Bergdahl back.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 7: Hindsight, Part 1
abstract: Bowe Bergdahl’s actions make sense — if you’re Bowe Bergdahl.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

abstract: Did the Army miss something critical?
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

abstract: You don’t hold peace negotiations with friends.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 10: Thorny Politics
abstract: The announcement of Bowe Bergdahl’s rescue started out simple. It quickly got complicated.
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Two, Episode 11: Present for Duty
abstract: The Season Two finale: What is Bowe Bergdahl’s fault, and what isn’t?
lead_paragraph: In May 2014, a U.S. Special Operations team in a Black Hawk helicopter landed in the hills of Afghanistan. Waiting for it were more than a dozen Taliban fighters and a tall American, who looked pale and out of sorts: Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Season Three, Episode 1: A Bar Fight Walks Into a Justice Center
abstract: A young woman is slapped on the butt. So why’s she the one in jail?
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 2: You’ve Got Some Gauls
abstract: What happens when a judge believes he knows defendants better than they know themselves?
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 3: Misdemeanor, Meet Mr. Lawsuit
abstract: The smell of raw marijuana, plus acting nervous, plus hands in pockets equals — what?
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 4: A Bird in Jail Is Worth Two on the Street
abstract: What happens when the right evidence points to the wrong man?
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 5: Pleas, Baby Pleas
abstract: Don’t tell the judges, but in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, the prosecutors have the most power in the justice center.
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 6: You in the Red Shirt
abstract: What is life like for a man who puts a police officer in jail?
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 7: The Snowball Effect
abstract: The trash-talking of a man with a history of violent run-ins with the police starts to reveal a message.
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

abstract: A teenager decides to cooperate with the police.
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: Season Three, Episode 9: Some Time When Everything Has Changed
abstract: The state of Ohio decides where Joshua belongs.
lead_paragraph: “Serial” is heading back to court. This time, in Cleveland, Ohio. But not for one extraordinary case; instead, “Serial” wanted to tackle the whole criminal justice system. To do that, the team members figured they would need to look at something different: ordinary cases.

headline: A Record the Mets Would Rather Not Have
abstract: Mets batters have been hit 106 times with 11 games still to play: “It’s like a broken record at this point.”
lead_paragraph: The 2022 Mets season will be remembered for the franchise’s first trip to the playoffs in six years, the pitching of Max Scherzer and the all-around play of shortstop Francisco Lindor.

headline: 2 Michael Jackson Impersonators Look Identical. The Resemblance Ends There.
abstract: Two imitators of the King of Pop in Buenos Aires offer a study in contrasts, reflective of Argentina’s deep economic divide. One man financed 13 surgeries, while the other draws on his sideburns.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Alan Garcia starts each work day on a cracked plastic stool, hunched over a small vanity mirror, caking on makeup to lighten his skin.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Americans Moving
abstract: Over the past decade, how has the population of the ten largest counties changed compared with the rest of the country?
lead_paragraph: In 2011, there were approximately 312 million Americans. A decade later in 2021, there were 25.4 million more Americans. The change in population is because of natural causes (births and deaths) and immigration.

headline: Architectural League Leader Is Stepping Down After 37 Years
abstract: Rosalie Genevro, who has led the Architectural League of New York since 1985, will exit her position in June.
lead_paragraph: Rosalie Genevro, who has led the Architectural League of New York for 37 years, is stepping down from her position as executive director at the nonprofit organization, the league announced Thursday in a news release.

headline: ‘The Greatest Beer Run Ever’ Review: Vietnam on the Rocks
abstract: Zac Efron plays a man trying to deliver brewskis to his Vietnam War buddies in Peter Farrelly’s film.
lead_paragraph: In the early winter of 1968, the 26-year-old civilian Chickie Donohue arrived in Vietnam with a duffel bag of brewskis and an errand that could be reasonably called idiotic, patronizing, suicidal — and, even, as this shaggily appealing comedy insists, “The Greatest Beer Run Ever.” Donohue (Zac Efron) has been double dog dared by his drinking buddies back home in Inwood, then a working-class Irish neighborhood in Manhattan, to hand-deliver a beer to four of their buddies serving in the war. “A sudsy thank you card!” Donohue exclaims, delighted by his own moxie. His farcical mission is mostly true and just the sort of crowd-pleaser about lunkhead enlightenment that intoxicates the director Peter Farrelly in the wake of his Oscar for “Green Book.”

headline: Mississippi Welfare Scandal Spreads Well Beyond Brett Favre
abstract: Millions earmarked for the needy in the nation’s poorest state instead went to projects that benefited the well-to-do, the state alleges, including a volleyball stadium at Mr. Favre’s alma mater.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘On the Come Up’ Review: Battle Rap’s Next Big Thing?
abstract: This film adaptation of the Angie Thomas novel follows a teenage rapper with a dream.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen “8 Mile” or the more recent cinematic delight “The Forty-Year-Old Version” you already know that in a movie with battle rap at the center, the would-be MC with something to prove always chokes in the first battle. “On the Come Up,” the new movie based on the Angie Thomas novel of the same name and directed by Sanaa Lathan, is no different.

headline: Biden, Putin and the War of Words Over Ukraine
abstract: Readers react to speeches by both leaders and speculate about the outcome of the conflict. Also: San Francisco’s fog; against censorship.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Magnificent Poem Jars of David Drake, Center Stage at the Met
abstract: Before the Civil War, an enslaved artisan from South Carolina created storage vessels that transcend ceramic traditions.
lead_paragraph: At the center of “Hear Me Now: The Black Potters of Old Edgefield, South Carolina,” a revelatory exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, stands a majestic artifact: a stoneware storage jar that may qualify as one of 19th-century America’s great sculptures. It measures over two feet high, with a slightly rippling surface layered with drips of glaze in contrasting earth tones, from deep umber to ocher.

headline: What Explains the Alarming Democrat-on-Democrat Sabotage in North Carolina?
abstract: The heir apparent to the current governor is the target of an absolutely baffling prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Josh Stein, the attorney general of North Carolina, has plenty of detractors, but if you ask knowledgeable Democrats in the state to name their party’s most likely nominee for governor in 2024, they’ll probably say Stein. Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat in his second term, can’t run for a third consecutive term, and no one in his party is better positioned to succeed him than Stein.

headline: ‘Athena’ Review: Oh Brothers, Where Art Thou?
abstract: A besieged French housing project is the setting for Romain Gavras’s relentlessly kinetic action movie.
lead_paragraph: “Athena” begins in a state of maximum tension and escalates from there. An angry crowd has gathered outside a police station near a high-rise housing project in the suburbs of Paris. A video of the killing of a local teenage boy, apparently by uniformed officers, has gone viral, igniting long-smoldering resentments. Violence breaks out quickly, and before long, the talk on social networks and news broadcasts will be forecasting not civil unrest, but outright civil war.

headline: As freed Ukrainian soldiers return, joy and relief ripple across the country.
abstract: After the largest prisoner exchange of the war, Ukrainians celebrated while anger coursed through the ranks of Russian mercenaries and military bloggers.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Diana Pashko has spent many sleepless nights since her husband, a Ukrainian soldier who fought in the southern port city of Mariupol, was taken prisoner in May by Russian forces. But on Wednesday night, she said, “it was impossible to sleep from the excitement.”

headline: World Bank Leader, Accused of Climate Denial, Offers a New Response
abstract: David Malpass touched off a furor, including calls for his removal, when he refused to acknowledge that fossil fuels are warming the planet.
lead_paragraph: David Malpass catapulted onto the international stage three years ago when he was nominated by President Donald J. Trump to become president of the World Bank. He was charged with improving the economies of poor nations, many of which are being battered by extreme weather fueled by climate change.

headline: The Remarkable, Resilient Loren Connors
abstract: Three decades ago, the New York guitarist was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease. His output still hasn’t slowed.
lead_paragraph: If Loren Connors was going to get to his gig, the guitarist knew he would need to crawl. It was late January 2007, two months after he had smashed into a Brooklyn sidewalk and broken his hip while carrying an armload of art, resulting in major surgery and an 11-day hospital stay.

headline: Want to Be a Better Cook? Trust Your Senses.
abstract: Paying attention to sight, smell, sound and feel will steer you in ways that simply following a recipe cannot, Yewande Komolafe writes.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite episodes of “This American Life” begins with a conversation between the host Ira Glass and the culinary griot and author Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor. In the episode, Mr. Glass decides to test Ms. Smart-Grosvenor’s claim that she can tell when chicken is done frying by simply listening to the oil. He plays recordings of hot grease: the initial sizzles of battered chicken nestling into the pan, the more vigorous bubbles as the oil heats back up, the final rumbles as the chicken transforms.

headline: What’s Driving the Protests in Iran?
abstract: Dozens of cities have been embroiled in protests that were prompted by a young woman’s death in custody but that have escalated amid anger over religious rules and a rock-bottom economy.
lead_paragraph: The antigovernment protests that have erupted in cities across Iran in response to a young woman’s death in the custody of the country’s morality police have struck a national nerve.

headline: For First Time in at Least 25 Years, No Democrat Has Top Grade From N.R.A.
abstract: Not a single Democrat running for Congress received an A in the group’s candidate ratings, which were once a powerful influence in U.S. elections.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic break from the National Rifle Association is complete: For the first time in at least 25 years, not a single Democrat running for Congress anywhere in the country received an A in the group’s candidate ratings, which were once a powerful influence in U.S. elections.

headline: These Artists Bring Pickles to the Party
abstract: In major museums, as well as at club nights and its own bar, the collective Slavs and Tatars casts a humorous eye over the region between the former Berlin Wall and the Great Wall of China.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Visitors who wandered into the Slavs and Tatars installation in the Arsenale at the 2019 Venice Biennale found a serenely bubbling fountain, a PVC curtain printed with bold graphics and a working vending machine stocked with bottles of sauerkraut juice. Each custom bottle label sported a picture of a cabbage chained to a foot, like a ball and chain, and the words “Brine & Punishment,” a reference to Dostoevsky’s “Crime and Punishment.” The machine had to be restocked several times.

headline: Contractor at Center of Navy Bribery Scandal Is Captured in Venezuela
abstract: Leonard Glenn Francis, who is known as Fat Leonard, was taken into custody by Interpol as he was trying to board a flight from Venezuela to Russia.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy Malaysian contractor who orchestrated one of the longest-running bribery scandals in the history of the United States Navy has been captured in Venezuela, two weeks after he cut off his ankle monitor and escaped home arrest in San Diego, an Interpol official said Wednesday.

headline: Water Problems in Syria Give Rise to Deadly Cholera Outbreak
abstract: The highly contagious disease has spread quickly in the country’s north, where millions of people displaced by a decade-long war are living, and many rely on untreated water from rivers containing raw sewage.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A deadly cholera outbreak has been spreading in northern Syria over the past two weeks in areas where millions of people displaced by the country’s long civil war are suffering from a lack of clean water and health care, according to aid organizations that have warned of another potential humanitarian crisis.

headline: Judge Temporarily Suspends Indiana Abortion Ban
abstract: The state prohibition had been in effect for only a week, and now abortions are legal again while a court fight goes forward.
lead_paragraph: An Indiana judge temporarily halted the state’s ban on most abortions on Thursday, a week after the law took effect.

headline: ‘S-Town’
abstract: The story of a man who despises his Alabama town and decides to do something about it.

headline: Catholics Outnumber Protestants in Northern Ireland for the First Time
abstract: Newly released census results may fuel calls for a referendum on uniting Ireland, experts say, but not right away.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the first time, Catholics outnumber Protestants in Northern Ireland, census figures released on Thursday show — confirmation of a long-anticipated but still striking shift with implications for the region’s future.

headline: Bill to Grant Afghan Evacuees a Path to Residency Hits Snags
abstract: The White House and members of both parties had hoped to attach the legislation to a must-pass spending bill this month. But some Republicans have raised security concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the lawn outside the Capitol this week, the flags of two countries flew in protest: America’s and Afghanistan’s from before it fell to the Taliban.

headline: A Pesto for Every Pantry and Mood
abstract: Use the Ligurian sauce as a guideline and make tastier sandwiches, soups, pastas, gratins and more.
lead_paragraph: I don’t worry too much about my food obsessions, which fade in and out all year long. They have a way of naturally sorting themselves out: The habit will become too expensive to sustain (I’m thinking of the boxes of stretchy, wrinkly, extremely satisfying yuba noodles that I buy and want to eat constantly!). Or the season will end on something I can’t get enough of, like those big, frilly, extra-fragrant bunches of basil at the farmers market.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 1
abstract: “If you keep your mouth shut, you’ll be surprised what you can learn.”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: Can you get the flu shot and the new booster at the same time?
abstract: Combining vaccines may be more convenient, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Yes. Some public health officials are strongly recommending getting both the flu shot and the new bivalent booster at once — Dr. Asish Jha, who leads the White House’s pandemic response, remarked in a press briefing that “God gave us two arms: one for the flu shot and the other one for the Covid shot.”

headline: Herschel Walker’s Company Said It Donated Profits, but Evidence Is Scant
abstract: The Georgia Republican candidate claimed his business donated 15 percent of its profits to charities. Three of the four groups named as recipients say they didn’t receive money.
lead_paragraph: Back when he was a businessman running a food-distribution company, Herschel Walker, the Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia, said his company offered its customers more than just burgers and hot wings.

headline: Here’s what Jones has said about Sandy Hook.
abstract: Alex Jones spent years accusing the family members of Sandy Hook shooting victims of being actors in a hoax and suggesting that their children were still alive.
lead_paragraph: Alex Jones began lying about the Sandy Hook shooting within hours after it occurred and continued until he was sued. But because Mr. Jones was removed from virtually all major social media platforms in 2018 and refused to provide evidence in the Sandy Hook litigation, lawyers for the families had to dig deep to show the jury what he actually said about the shooting on his radio and online show.

headline: ‘A Lot of Panic’: Russian Men, Fearing Ukraine Draft, Seek Refuge Abroad
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin’s new military call-up has sent young men who don’t want to fight in Ukraine heading to the borders.
lead_paragraph: A little more than 12 hours after he heard that Russian civilians could be pressed into military service in the Ukraine war, the tour guide said he bought a plane ticket and a laptop, changed money, wrapped up his business, kissed his crying mother goodbye and boarded a plane out of his country, with no idea when he might return.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 2
abstract: “Has anybody called you?”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 3
abstract: “Tedious and brief.”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 4
abstract: “If anybody could find it, it would be me.”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 5
abstract: “Nobody’ll ever change my mind about it.”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 6
abstract: “Since everyone around here thinks I’m a queer anyway.”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: S-Town: Chapter 7
abstract: “You’re beginning to figure it out now, aren’t you?”
lead_paragraph: S-Town is a podcast from Serial Productions, a New York Times Company.

headline: ‘My Imaginary Country’ Review: Chile in Revolt
abstract: Patricio Guzmán, Chile’s cinematic conscience, chronicles the uprising that shook the country starting in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The most powerful images in “My Imaginary Country” are of the demonstrations in the streets of Santiago, Chile, that began in October 2019. Hundreds of thousands of Chileans took to the streets, at first to protest a subway fare increase, and eventually to demand sweeping changes to the nation’s economic and political order. They were met with tear gas, baton charges and plastic bullets aimed at their eyes. Some fought back with cobblestones chiseled from the street, which they hurled at the police.

headline: The Tonga Volcano Shook the World. It May Also Affect the Climate.
abstract: Scientists say water vapor injected into the stratosphere by the volcanic eruption in January may have a slight, though temporary, warming effect.
lead_paragraph: The eruption of an underwater volcano in the Pacific Ocean in January that was so large it produced a global shock wave also spewed huge amounts of water vapor into the upper atmosphere, where it may cause a small, short-term spike in global warming, scientists said Thursday.

headline: ‘Sidney’ Review: A Lovingly Assembled Career Portrait
abstract: Sidney Poitier is memorialized in this thorough, and thoroughly conventional, documentary.
lead_paragraph: “Sidney,” a documentary about the actor and filmmaker Sidney Poitier, who died in January, is a compendium of hero worship. The director is Reginald Hudlin, but, in tone and temperament, this lovingly assembled encomium is peak Oprah Winfrey. As one of the film’s producers and a close friend of Poitier (whom she calls her “great Black hope”), Winfrey glows with emotional authenticity. Her breakdown at the end is unexpectedly moving, if not entirely unexpected.

headline: Russian Men Flee the Country to Avoid Fighting in Ukraine
abstract: Men rushed to catch flights out of Russia after President Vladimir V. Putin announced a call-up that could force up to 300,000 civilians into fighting in the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Men rushed to catch flights out of Russia after President Vladimir V. Putin announced a call-up that could force up to 300,000 civilians into fighting in the country’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: House Candidate Says He Served in Afghanistan, but Air Force Has No Record of It
abstract: J.R. Majewski, a Republican trying to unseat Representative Marcy Kaptur in Ohio, was deployed for six months to Qatar.
lead_paragraph: J.R. Majewski, a Republican House candidate in northern Ohio, has frequently promoted himself as a combat veteran who served in Afghanistan after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, but the U.S. Air Force has no record that he served there, unraveling a central narrative of his political ascension that has been heralded by former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: As Roger Federer Retires, Two Great Rivalries Come to an End
abstract: A look at the great matches between Federer and Rafael Nadal as well as Federer and Novak Djokovic.
lead_paragraph: Live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Growing Fight Over What Young People Can Read
abstract: In honor of Banned Books Week, we asked teenagers their opinions about the book challenges spreading across the country. Here is what they said.
lead_paragraph: This week, in honor of Banned Books Week, we invited teenagers to share their experiences with and opinions on the book bans spreading across the United States via our writing prompt, “What Is Your Reaction to the Growing Fight Over What Young People Can Read?”

headline: How do I know if my symptoms are from Covid or the flu?
abstract: There are slight differences in symptoms, but the best way to tell which infection you have is through a test.
lead_paragraph: Covid and the flu share deceptively similar symptoms: coughing, full-body aches, fevers. Both illnesses can give you a runny nose, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting and shortness of breath; both can leave you fatigued, feeling worn out and depleted.

headline: ¡Basta de Apagones! The Rot in Puerto Rico Runs Deeper Than Its Disastrous Power Company.
abstract: It is our own people who rob and abuse us.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Hurricane Fiona made landfall on Sunday morning. By 1 p.m. the entire island had been plunged into darkness. Days later, roughly a million homes and businesses in Puerto Rico still lacked power and access to clean water, my own home included. As I sit in a cafe and write, I am overwhelmed by the feeling of déjà vu.

headline: What You Need for a Roadside Emergency
abstract: The items that'll prevent a mild inconvenience from becoming a mini disaster.
lead_paragraph: The items that'll prevent a mild inconvenience from becoming a mini disaster.

headline: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
abstract: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
lead_paragraph: For the first live taping of Popcast, held at Gertie in Brooklyn, members of The New York Times pop music team explored the ways music is evolving today by highlighting some of this year’s breakout stars. The conversation touched on the British rapper Central Cee, the Bronx drill rapper Ice Spice, the country-folk singer Zach Bryan, the alt-rock revivalist Blondshell, the haunted pop crooner Ethel Cain and more.

headline: ‘Petrov’s Flu’ Review: Roaming a Grim, Rowdy Underworld
abstract: In this fever dream of a movie by Kirill Serebrennikov, a Russian man wanders a wild urban landscape that he regularly hallucinates his way out of.
lead_paragraph: When the phantasmagoric “Petrov’s Flu” opens on a crowded bus — a nightmare of jostling, babbling bodies — it seems obvious that there’s more troubling its hero than a typical seasonal malady. Sweaty and unsteady, he navigates through the other surging, grumbling passengers. Then a man yanks him off the bus, someone hands him a gun and Petrov is suddenly in a firing squad mowing down prisoners — and then he gets back on the bus and rejoins the clamorous horde he never wholly escapes. Welcome to Russia!

headline: Corporate Charter for Renaissance Man Food Services
abstract: A public record from Delaware for Renaissance Man Food Services, a company created in 2002 by Herschel Walker, now a Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia. The “certificate of formation” said nothing about charitable giving despite a claim on one of Mr. Walker’s corporate websites that a practice of making donations was part of the corporate charter.
lead_paragraph: A public record from Delaware for Renaissance Man Food Services, a company created in 2002 by Herschel Walker, now a Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia. The “certificate of formation” said nothing about charitable giving despite a claim on one of Mr. Walker’s corporate websites that a practice of making donations was part of the corporate charter.

headline: Corporate Charter for H. Walker Enterprises
abstract: A public record from Delaware for H. Walker Enterprises, a holding company created in 2002 by Herschel Walker, now a Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia. The “certificate of formation” said nothing about charitable giving despite a claim on one of Mr. Walker’s corporate websites that a practice of making donations was part of the corporate charter.
lead_paragraph: A public record from Delaware for H. Walker Enterprises, a holding company created in 2002 by Herschel Walker, now a Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia. The “certificate of formation” said nothing about charitable giving despite a claim on one of Mr. Walker’s corporate websites that a practice of making donations was part of the corporate charter.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends an old animated favorite, a twisty new romantic thriller and a throwback reality show.
lead_paragraph: ‘Bob’s Burgers’

headline: With a Sound Forged in War, Iannis Xenakis Embraced Chaos
abstract: The Greek-French composer, who was born 100 years ago, created a revolution in music.
lead_paragraph: “Greeks are like that,” the composer Iannis Xenakis said in 1967. “They are a people continually in search of themselves, always ready to launch out into all kind of rapid, violent actions, and end up by not finding themselves.”

headline: ‘The American Dream and Other Fairy Tales’ Review: A Spotlight on Income Inequality
abstract: This documentary by Abigail E. Disney and Kathleen Hughes is a critique of the Walt Disney Company, but its lessons are basic and obvious.
lead_paragraph: “The American Dream and Other Fairy Tales,” a questionably well-intentioned documentary about income inequality by Abigail E. Disney and Kathleen Hughes, lays bare the rotten core of the American dream and its promise of upward mobility. In other words, it’s dedicated entirely to stating the obvious. Unless, perhaps, you live under a rock — or in a $100 million penthouse.

headline: Nazi Sympathizer Is Sentenced to 4 Years Over Role in Jan. 6 Attack
abstract: The defendant’s “racist and antisemitic motivation” for trying to halt the election certification process set his case apart from dozens of other rioters, a judge said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday sentenced a Nazi sympathizer who had served in the Army reserves to four years in prison for storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, saying his “racist and antisemitic motivation” for trying to halt the election certification process set his case apart from dozens of other rioters who have been charged.

headline: New York Drill Rappers Say They Were Removed From Rolling Loud Festival
abstract: At least three local artists were cut from the traveling rap show, scheduled for this weekend in Queens, at the request of the New York Police Department, their representatives said.
lead_paragraph: At least three rappers with ties to the booming New York drill scene — which has risen in popularity in recent years, even as law enforcement officials and politicians like Mayor Eric Adams have questioned its relationship to local gun violence — have been removed from the lineup of the traveling rap festival Rolling Loud, scheduled for this weekend at Citi Field in Queens, at the request of the New York Police Department, the artists’ representatives said.

headline: Blackpink and the Limits of K-Pop Maximalism
abstract: The genre’s more-is-more moment might be coming to an end, and younger acts like Aespa and NewJeans point a way forward.
lead_paragraph: As K-pop was broadening its global ambitions in the late 2000s and early 2010s, it was also expanding its appetite, becoming the hungriest pop music scene on the planet. It feasted especially on American pop, hip-hop, R&B and dance music, alchemizing it all into a maximalist fantasia, creating an aesthetic of absurdist excess that became, for a while, that world’s most progressive and most popular approach.

headline: Departures Narrow Democrats’ Path to Hold the House
abstract: Democrats are defending more than a dozen seats in which the incumbent has said they will not run for re-election, complicating their effort to stop Republicans from reclaiming the House majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hurrying from the House floor to a waiting car on a recent afternoon, Representative Cheri Bustos, Democrat of Illinois, rattled off an exhaustive analysis of her conservative-leaning district in one minute flat, listing the number of family-owned farms in the area and landing on the argument her party believes could save their House majority: that the Republican running for the seat has “extreme views on women’s health issues.”

headline: Maarten Schmidt, First Astronomer to Identify a Quasar, Dies at 92
abstract: His 1963 breakthrough revealed one of the furthest objects from Earth and opened new questions about the evolution of the universe.
lead_paragraph: Maarten Schmidt, who in 1963 became the first astronomer  to identify a quasar, a small, intensely bright object several billion light years away, and in the process upended standard descriptions of the universe and revolutionized ideas about its evolution, died on Sept. 17 at his home in Fresno, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Pressing World Cup Question for U.S.: Who’ll Score the Goals?
abstract: An American team that cycled through strikers during the qualifying period needs to settle on one before heading to Qatar. The good news is some of the options are hitting their stride.
lead_paragraph: COLOGNE, Germany — Evaluating any soccer player, with all the multifaceted layers of performance, all the twists and turns of action on the field, poses a complicated challenge. Yet the game’s strikers are so frequently reduced to a kind of rudimentary binary:

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Fiction is well represented in our recommendations this week, with books ranging from debut story collections (“Bad Thoughts,” by Nada Alic, “If I Survive You,” by Jonathan Escoffery) to thrillers (“Broken Summer,” by J.M. Lee) to novels by established literary heavyweights (Ian McEwan’s “Lessons,” Édouard Louis’s “A Woman’s Battles and Transformations”). There’s also a quirky novel about a tech employee in Queens, a novel set in a Filipino and Mexican community in Texas, and a talky, timely, tough and funny novel by Angie Cruz, “How Not to Drown in a Glass of Water,” about an unemployed mother seeking a new beginning.

headline: Pandemic Unemployment Fraud Estimate Rises to $45.6 Billion
abstract: A federal watchdog tripled its earlier estimate of benefits that the U.S. government paid to people who weren’t entitled to them.
lead_paragraph: A federal watchdog investigating the distribution of pandemic relief funds has tripled its estimate of the amount of money paid out in unemployment insurance that can be attributed to certain forms of fraud.

headline: ‘A Jazzman’s Blues’ Review: Tyler Perry Revisits a Jim Crow-Era Romance
abstract: The writer-director returns to his first screenplay — a dark melodrama with soulful musical numbers — after two decades.
lead_paragraph: “A Jazzman’s Blues,” Tyler Perry’s melodrama about ill-fated teenagers who fall in love in rural Georgia, marks the writer-director-studio head’s return to his first screenplay, w‌hich he wrote in 1995. In the meantime, he broke through with a slew of Madea comedies, and whetted the skills required to deliver the faceted beauty of Bayou — his richest male character to date — with dramas like 2010’s “For Colored Girls.”

headline: Does the world want to stop smoking?
abstract: PMI Stop Smoking
lead_paragraph: PMI Stop Smoking

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Men Flee Russian Conscription
abstract: Plus Japan props up the yen and Cambodia concludes its Khmer Rouge trials.
lead_paragraph: One day after President Vladimir Putin announced a plan to bring 300,000 civilians into military service, thousands of Russians received draft papers and boarded buses to training sites. Many others left the country in a rush, paying rising prices to catch flights to Armenia, Georgia, Montenegro and Turkey, some of the countries that allow Russians to enter without visas.

headline: Central Banks Accept Pain Now, Fearing Worse Later
abstract: Federal Reserve officials and their counterparts around the world are trying to defeat inflation by rapidly raising interest rates. They know it will come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Federal Reserve lifted interest rates sharply and signaled more to come, central banks across Asia and Europe followed suit on Thursday, waging their own campaigns to crush an outbreak of inflation that is bedeviling consumers and worrying policymakers around the globe.

headline: Boeing Reaches $200 Million Settlement With Regulators Over Its 737 Max
abstract: The S.E.C. said Boeing had misled investors by suggesting that human error was to blame for two deadly crashes, and omitting the company’s concerns about the plane.
lead_paragraph: Boeing reached a $200 million settlement with U.S. securities regulators on Thursday to resolve an investigation into claims that the aircraft manufacturer and a former chief executive had deceived investors about problems with its 737 Max plane that led to two deadly crashes in 2018 and 2019.

headline: Russian Men Receive Draft Papers
abstract: Video verified by The New York Times appears to show new conscripts saying goodbye to loved ones before being loaded into buses.
lead_paragraph: Video verified by The New York Times appears to show new conscripts saying goodbye to loved ones before being loaded into buses.

headline: U.S. to Drop Charges Against Judge Accused of Helping Immigrant Escape ICE
abstract: Prosecutors had charged Shelley M. Richmond Joseph, a district court judge in Newton, Mass., with allowing an undocumented immigrant to sneak out the back door of a courthouse in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department moved on Thursday to end the criminal prosecution of a Massachusetts judge and a court officer who had been charged with helping an undocumented immigrant escape from an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer at a courthouse in 2018.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Broken Hearts, Anxiety and Exercise
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Want to Watch the Yankees on Friday? There’s an App for That.
abstract: A game between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox in which Aaron Judge could be gunning for his 62nd home run will be broadcast only on Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Come Friday night, no matter where Aaron Judge stands in his chase for 61 home runs — or more — one thing appears certain: Yankees fans won’t be able to watch the game the way they normally do.

headline: Shy Raccoons Are Better Learners Than Bold Ones, Study Finds
abstract: Wildlife management strategies focused on aggressive raccoons may be inadvertently boosting the proportion of more clever ones in cities.
lead_paragraph: Residents of almost any city in North America know how frustratingly clever raccoons can be. They break into garages, pilfer supposedly unreachable bird feeders and ransack trash bins, even defeating lids specifically designed to thwart them.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Woman! Life! Freedom!’: Videos Show Widespread Protests in Iran
abstract: Antigovernment demonstrations in Iran are spreading after Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police. Videos shared on social media show Iranians protesting in the face of crackdowns by the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Antigovernment demonstrations in Iran are spreading after Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police. Videos shared on social media show Iranians protesting in the face of crackdowns by the authorities.

headline: A.C.L.U. Says Immigration Detention Facility Should Be Shut Down
abstract: The situation at a New Mexico detention facility revives a long-running debate over the government’s reliance on private prisons to house immigrants, many of them seeking asylum.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union is calling on the Biden administration to close one of its privately run immigration detention centers after a Brazilian asylum seeker killed himself while he was being held in the New Mexico facility.

headline: 4 Takeaways From the Sandy Hook Damages Trial of Alex Jones
abstract: Even before Mr. Jones erupted in a rant in the final hour, the day’s proceedings in a Connecticut courtroom had been contentious.
lead_paragraph: In a mostly slow-burning then suddenly explosive day of testimony, the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones took the stand on Thursday in a trial that will determine how much he and his company must pay in damages to people he defamed after the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Man Who Patted Giuliani’s Back Is Set to Have Assault Charge Dismissed
abstract: Daniel Gill said the encounter at a Staten Island ShopRite happened as he expressed displeasure at the former New York mayor’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: A grocery store worker who was accused of assaulting Rudolph W. Giuliani at a Staten Island supermarket in June after patting his back while insulting him will have his charges dismissed and sealed in six months without admitting any guilt, as long as he commits no other legal infractions in that time.

headline: Federer and Nadal Were the Best of Rivals. In the End, They’ll Be Partners.
abstract: One of the greatest rivalries in tennis history will end in harmony on Friday when Roger Federer plays his final competitive match with Rafael Nadal as his doubles partner.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Roger Federer’s doubles match with Rafael Nadal at the Laver Cup.

headline: House Passes Police Funding Bills, With Democratic Rifts on Vivid Display
abstract: Progressive objections to the legislation threatened to sink it at the last moment, prompting a scramble among Democrats that highlighted the party’s divisions over policing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday passed bipartisan legislation to increase funding for local police departments, after Democrats overcame bitter divisions in their ranks over a package aimed at blunting Republican efforts to portray them as soft on crime ahead of midterm elections.

headline: ‘Lou’ Review: Unfinished Business
abstract: A child’s kidnapping ignites a protracted bid for redemption in this down-and-dirty thriller.
lead_paragraph: Whatever else one might say about the Netflix thriller “Lou,” making it must have been murder. Pummeled by near-constant rain, soaked in swampy mud and battered by frequent bouts of hand-to-hand combat, the movie’s headliners look to have suffered miserably.

headline: Secretary of State Races Turn Rowdy During the Homestretch
abstract: Democrats are outspending Republicans in Georgia, Michigan, Minnesota and Nevada, where they see their opponents as threats to democracy.
lead_paragraph: In a normal election year, races for secretary of state are sleepy affairs, and their campaigns struggle for media coverage amid the hurly-burly of more prominent Senate, governor and House contests.

headline: California Regents Hear Out Pac-12 on Whether to Block U.C.L.A.’s Move to Big Ten
abstract: The leaders of the sprawling University of California educational system are considering whether they should halt the move by U.C.L.A.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When members of the University of California Board of Regents met Thursday to discuss whether to quash U.C.L.A.’s move to the Big Ten Conference, they had an unexpected item to consider: a letter enumerating why the decision to join the conference was a bad idea — even a financial loser — for one of the state’s flagship public universities.

headline: Ukraine War Comes Home to Russians as Putin Imposes Draft
abstract: As Vladimir Putin’s “special military operation” enters a new chapter, Russians are being plucked from villages around the country for training and military service.
lead_paragraph: A day after President Vladimir V. Putin announced a call-up that could sweep 300,000 civilians into military service, thousands of Russians across the country received draft papers on Thursday and some were being marched to buses and planes for training — and perhaps soon a trip to the front lines in Ukraine.

headline: Trump Claims He Declassified Documents. Why Don’t His Lawyers Say So in Court?
abstract: Judges this week highlighted the gap between Mr. Trump’s public claims that he declassified everything and his lawyers’ reluctance to repeat that claim in a courtroom.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump claimed on Wednesday that when he was in the White House, his powers were so broad he could declassify virtually any document by simply “thinking about it.”

headline: ‘I’m Done Saying I’m Sorry,’ Alex Jones Tells Sandy Hook Families in Court
abstract: In testimony in a Connecticut trial to assess the damages done by his Sandy Hook lies, the Infowars fabulist lashed out.
lead_paragraph: WATERBURY, Conn. — Alex Jones’s initial day of testimony in a trial for damages after years of lying about the Sandy Hook shootings ended in chaos.

headline: War, Inflation and Squandered Credibility
abstract: What does the chair of the Federal Reserve understand that Vladimir Putin doesn’t?
lead_paragraph: What does Jerome Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, understand that Vladimir Putin doesn’t?

headline: Banned Books, Censored Topics: Teaching About the Battle Over What Students Should Learn
abstract: Suggestions for using recent Times and Learning Network articles, videos, podcasts, student forums and more.
lead_paragraph: Parents, activists, school board officials and lawmakers are challenging books at a pace not seen in decades. At the same time, schools are mired in debates over what students should learn about in U.S. history. In the last two years, dozens of state legislatures introduced bills that would limit what teachers can say about race, gender, sexuality and inequality.

headline: Why New York Is Resorting to Tents to House Surge of Migrants
abstract: With over 10,000 asylum seekers crowding homeless shelters, the city will erect temporary structures to hold new arrivals for their first few days.
lead_paragraph: As migrants from Latin America poured into New York City this spring, the city tried to make space for them in its homeless shelters. It was not enough.

headline: As Trump’s Legal Woes Mount, So Do Financial Pressures on Him
abstract: The lawsuit filed by New York’s attorney general is the latest indication of how an array of investigations is affecting the former president’s business and personal wealth.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s fraud lawsuit that was filed on Wednesday against former President Donald J. Trump seeks to recover $250 million from his company and essentially run him out of business in the state.

headline: Officials Hopeful That Monkeypox Can Be Eliminated in the U.S.
abstract: Cases are declining nationally, and the deputy coordinator of the White House monkeypox response team said he expected that, over time, they would drop to a trickle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With monkeypox cases on the decline nationally, federal health officials expressed optimism on Thursday that the virus could be eliminated in the United States, though they cautioned that unless it was wiped out globally, Americans would remain at risk.

headline: Texas Prosecutor Loses Attempt to Spare a Murderer From Execution
abstract: The state criminal appeals court shut down a district attorney’s argument that John Henry Ramirez should not be executed because the death penalty was “unethical.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals on Thursday denied a motion to postpone the execution of a prisoner scheduled to be killed next month for the murder of a convenience store worker.

headline: How to Exercise Safely as It Gets Colder and Darker
abstract: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
lead_paragraph: As the days shift to become shorter, darker and cooler, I have begun to worry about whether I’ll be able to continue taking daily outdoor walks. My strolls, which I can sometimes only squeeze in during the evening, feel crucial for my mental and physical health, so I don’t want to stop — but I don’t want to take undue risks, either.

headline: Opening Paul Allen’s Treasure Chest
abstract: It’s been a closely guarded secret which masterworks in the Microsoft co-founder’s collection will be auctioned at Christie’s in November. Here, highlights of a billionaire’s bounty.
lead_paragraph: Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, was strongly attracted to landscapes as “a way of looking outward,” which may be why he felt moved to spend more than $40 million on Gustav Klimt’s 1903 autumnal oil, “Birch Forest,” in 2006.

headline: Read the Pac-12 Letter to the University of California Regents
abstract: Letter from the commissioner of the Pac-12 Conference to the University of California Board of Regents, objecting to a move by U.C.L.A. to go to the Big Ten Conference.
lead_paragraph: Letter from the commissioner of the Pac-12 Conference to the University of California Board of Regents, objecting to a move by U.C.L.A. to go to the Big Ten Conference.

headline: Jury Rules Against Project Veritas in Lawsuit
abstract: The conservative group was found to have violated wiretapping laws and fraudulently misrepresented itself to a Democratic consulting firm, to which it was ordered to pay $120,000.
