(Yes, I know, we have no spans today, and a great puzzle doesn’t need spans, but there is something about those big walls of open white space that’s exciting.)

headline: With His 700th Homer, Albert Pujols Gives Us One Last Surprise
abstract: A farewell tour turned into a showcase for Pujols, the veteran Cardinals slugger, as he joined the most exclusive of home run clubs long after many had written him off.
lead_paragraph: It was June 2001, the first half of the first season of a career nobody saw coming. Albert Pujols was back in Kansas City, Mo., where he had played two years earlier for a community college that had never produced a major league player. Now, as a St. Louis Cardinals rookie, he was somehow batting .350 with a lot of home runs. But how good was he, really?

headline: ‘Shrines of Gaiety’ Finds Kate Atkinson in a Dickensian Mood
abstract: In this fizzy picaresque, the novelist conjures a London coming alive after World War I, where a nightclub empire offers refuge — and hides secrets.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old story about the time Kate Atkinson took home her first major literary award, then known as the Whitbread Prize and now called the Costa, for her bravura 1995 debut, “Behind the Scenes at the Museum.” Even in the midst of bestowing it, the committee’s chairman, an august academic named Richard Hoggart, felt compelled to say that Atkinson had written a postmodern novel, though he doubted whether she knew it.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Grief and Fury in Myanmar As Children’s Blood Is Spilled
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Sept. 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Mommy. I just want to die. I can’t stand the pain.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 24, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about New York’s plan to erect temporary structures to house a recent surge of asylum seekers described incorrectly the housing costs at city shelters. It typically costs $135 per day to house a single adult and $190 to house a family, not between $135 and $190 per person.

headline: For Dreadlocked N.F.L. Players, Hair Is a Point of Pride
abstract: N.F.L. players who wear dreadlocks risk being tackled by their hair and face helmet-fitting challenges. But they say expressing their identities and showing off their style is worth it.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until his junior year of college, in 2015, that Aaron Jones decided to rebel and form his hair into dreadlocks.

headline: After Years Away, One of Basketball’s Greats Returns at 41
abstract: Lauren Jackson, a hero of Australian women’s basketball and a three-time W.N.B.A. most valuable player, has rejoined her national team after injuries knocked her out of the sport in 2014.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — It was an inconspicuous return. Just over a year ago, Lauren Jackson, one of the greatest players in women’s basketball history, returned to the suburban courts of Albury, a small regional city in southeastern Australia, to play social basketball. No crowds, no fuss. Just hoops.

headline: More Than 700 Children Have Died in a Measles Outbreak in Zimbabwe
abstract: It is driven by a decline in child immunization during the pandemic and the influence of an anti-vaccination evangelical church.
lead_paragraph: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe — A measles outbreak has killed more than 700 children and infected thousands of others across Zimbabwe, highlighting the risks of faltering childhood immunization campaigns around the globe.

headline: Louise Fletcher, 88, Dies; Oscar Winner for ‘One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest’
abstract: She was largely unknown to the public when she was cast as what the American Film Institute called one of cinema’s most memorable villains.
lead_paragraph: Louise Fletcher, the imposing, steely-eyed actress who won an Academy Award for her role as the tyrannical Nurse Ratched in “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” died on Friday at her home in the town of Montdurausse, in Southern France. She was 88.

headline: Maps: Tracking Hurricane Ian
abstract: A map showing the storm’s path as it heads toward South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: A map showing the storm’s path as it heads toward South Carolina.

headline: Zelensky tells Ukrainians living under occupation to avoid conscription ‘by any means.’
abstract: With Russia laying the groundwork to formally annex areas it is occupying, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine directly asked Ukrainians to help the nation’s war effort even from within the occupied territory.
lead_paragraph: With Russia laying the groundwork to formally annex areas it is occupying, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine directly asked Ukrainians to help the nation’s war effort even from within the occupied territory.

headline: Word of the Day: phalanx
abstract: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word phalanx has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 4 in “Seven Days That Closed Out a Career” by John Branch:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Discount Data That Some Colleges Won’t Publish
abstract: Want to know how few students pay full price, or the odds of getting merit aid? The so-called Common Data Set can help, but some schools don’t post it.
lead_paragraph: By now, many people shopping for college have gotten the message that not everyone pays the list price. But what percentage do get some kind of discount, how much is it and what sorts of students get one?

headline: G.O.P. Senate Hopefuls Leave Campaign Trail for Beltway Money Circuit
abstract: Their fund-raising dwarfed by their Democratic rivals, Republican nominees including Blake Masters and Mehmet Oz have been in Washington gathering cash from lobbyists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rushing to raise money and close yawning gaps with their Democratic rivals, every Senate Republican nominee in a competitive race is taking precious time from the campaign trail to come to Washington this week and next to gather money before Congress leaves for the fall.

headline: Defying travel warnings, Hasidic Jewish pilgrims flock to Ukraine.
abstract: Tens of thousands of Hasidic Jews traditionally travel to Uman to mark Rosh Hashana with a visit to the burial site of a revered 18th-century rabbi.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Hasidic Jews from Israel and other countries are making their way to Uman, a city in central Ukraine, for a traditional pilgrimage over Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, defying stern travel warnings issued by the Israeli government and the pleas of Ukrainian officials who had asked them to stay away because of the war.

headline: Iran Protests Surge to Dozens of Cities
abstract: Iranians fed up with oppressive rules and a battered economy have faced bullets, tear gas and arrests to demand an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
lead_paragraph: The largest anti-government protests in Iran since 2009 gathered strength on Saturday, spreading to as many as 80 cities, even as the authorities escalated a crackdown that has reportedly killed  dozens of people and brought the arrests of prominent activists and journalists, according to rights groups and news media reports.

headline: Honey, I Shrunk the Couples Counselor
abstract: Two survivors of pandemic parenting needed a relationship tuneup. Could a new virtual therapy module called Ours do the trick?
lead_paragraph: On a recent sticky summer evening, Andrew and I assumed our trademark marital position: hovered over the iPad in bed.

headline: LinkedIn Ran Social Experiments on 20 Million Users Over Five Years
abstract: A study that looked back at those tests found that relatively weak social connections were more helpful in finding jobs than stronger social ties.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: My Condo Has No Gas. Can I Get a Discount?
abstract: The law requires every building owner to provide residents with gas or electricity for cooking. Financial remedies are a more complicated matter.
lead_paragraph: Q: I own an apartment in a large Midtown condo. Because of a gas leak, Con Edison shut off gas to the building, so residents can no longer use their gas ranges or gas dryers. The condo association is working to locate and correct the problem, which could take up to a year. The board supplied each unit with a hot plate and has given us discounts on wash and dry through the building valet. I pay $3,500 a month in common charges for two bedrooms and a hot plate. Is this not a reduction in service? Shouldn’t we get some sort of concession for the inconvenience?

headline: Lost Hope of Lasting Democratic Majority
abstract: Revisiting an influential book and the notion that demographics are destiny.
lead_paragraph: Today we wish a belated and maybe not-so-Happy 20th Birthday to “The Emerging Democratic Majority,” the book that famously argued Democrats would gain an enduring advantage in a multiracial, postindustrial America.

headline: A Sibling Disappears, and the Mystery Repeats Itself
abstract: Confronting sudden loss in her own life, Namwali Serpell has written “The Furrows,” a disquieting portrait of the human mind, warped by grief.
lead_paragraph: After Chisha died, she came back to her sisters.

headline: She’s Insensitive to Pain, but Only the Physical Kind
abstract: In Stephanie LaCava’s novel “I Fear My Pain Interests You,” a young actress manages the strains of family and failed romance.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie LaCava’s poignant, filler-less second novel begins with Margot Highsmith, an actress in her early 20s, flying from New York to Montana after a vague breakup with a much older man identified only as the Director. Margot is going to stay indefinitely at an unused rural house owned by her friend Lucy’s parents. In a story full of emotional pain, with family and relationship dynamics ranging from moderately to very dysfunctional, Lucy seems to be the one consistently positive presence in Margot’s life. “She said to beware of casting myself as a victim,” Margot reflects. “I may have wanted something else, but I stayed for what wasn’t offered. It wasn’t abuse. Not this time, anyway.”

headline: How Erica Jong, Writer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: What gets this best-selling novelist going? Cappuccinos, movies with her grandchildren and her go-to notebook.
lead_paragraph: Erica Jong used to spend Sundays in her Connecticut home with her husband, Ken Burrows, a lawyer, but in recent years, the weekend commute became more of an ordeal for the couple. (She is 80, he is 81.) These days, they are living full time in their apartment on the Upper East Side, with their two black standard poodles, Simone and Colette.

headline: Arbitration Has Come to Senior Living. You Don’t Have to Sign Up.
abstract: In the blizzard of paperwork needed to get into a nursing home or assisted living, some residents unwittingly surrender the right to a day in court.
lead_paragraph: What the Jinks family wanted was to sue the memory care facility where their father, Charles, was attacked by another resident.

headline: An Indiana Family Lives in the Gym (Literally)
abstract: Kyle and Lauren Petry made an offer on a former high school gym that had been renovated into living space. Then social media caught wind of the listing.
lead_paragraph: WILKINSON, Ind. — Many people in basketball-obsessed Indiana claim to eat, sleep and breathe the game. This summer, in a microscopic rural town about 30 miles outside Indianapolis, a house went up for sale that would give its occupants little other choice.

headline: How Paul LePage, Running to Lead Maine, Benefited From Florida Tax Breaks
abstract: Mr. LePage, a former governor who is seeking to reclaim the office, has along with his wife benefited from property tax breaks reserved for permanent Florida residents, public records show.
lead_paragraph: As governor of Maine for two terms until 2019, Paul LePage, a Republican, gained a reputation as one of the pre-Trump era’s most unfiltered politicians.

headline: In Alaska, Slowing Down to Take Things In
abstract: There are fewer miners now, but nature enthusiasts visit the town of McCarthy to learn field sketching, a technique that’s equal parts art and science.
lead_paragraph: With rain hitting the roof, the temperature outside hovering in the low 50s and a cast iron stove keeping things warm inside the cabin that, on this July weekend, is serving as an art studio and classroom, I feel a nap coming on. Summer days in Alaska. They are not always the bluebird skies promised in travel ads.

headline: This Surveillance Artist Knows How You Got That Perfect Instagram Photo
abstract: A tech-savvy artist unearthed video footage of people working hard to capture the perfect shot for Instagram. It is a lesson in the artifice of social media and the ubiquity of surveillance.
lead_paragraph: David Welly Sombra Rodrigues, a 35-year-old French teacher, loves to travel. After the pandemic forced him to offer his language lessons virtually, he seized the moment, relocating from Brazil to Europe, where he could hop on trains to new cities to his heart’s delight, all of which he documented on Instagram.

headline: Millennials Want to Retire at 50. How to Afford It Is Another Matter.
abstract: Dreams of stopping work, or doing only fulfilling work, 15 years before their parents did are colliding with the realities of amassing enough money to do so.
lead_paragraph: Although Devangi Patel, 33, has been working as a cardiothoracic anesthesiologist at a large medical center outside Atlanta for only two years, her goal is to afford to walk away from her job at 50.

headline: Moving? Here’s How to Keep Your Costs Low.
abstract: In August, the average cost of a local move in the United States reached a record high of $454, up 12 percent from a year ago, according to one analysis.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Moriarty felt the pain of sticker shock when he received six quotes from movers for an April move from Naperville, Ill. to Aurora, Ill. “I had previously moved a few years ago and the cost was double what it was then,” said Mr. Moriarty, a digital marketing consultant.

headline: The School Shooting Is Fake. Can It Prepare an Officer for a Real One?
abstract: A $50 million facility in upstate New York is trying to teach officers the thing they’ll need most during the next mass shooting: bravery.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Italian Voters Appear Ready to Turn a Page for Europe
abstract: With the hard-right candidate Giorgia Meloni ahead before Sunday’s election, Italy could get its first leader whose party traces its roots to the wreckage of Fascism.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s hard-right leader, resents having to talk about Fascism. She has publicly, and in multiple languages, said that the Italian right has “handed Fascism over to history for decades now.” She argued that “the problem with Fascism in Italy always begins with the electoral campaign,” when the Italian left, she said, wheels out “the black wave” to smear its opponents.

headline: They Were Entitled to Free Care. Hospitals Hounded Them to Pay.
abstract: With the help of a consulting firm, the Providence hospital system trained staff to wring money out of patients, even those eligible for free care.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, senior executives at one of the country’s largest nonprofit hospital chains, Providence, were frustrated. They were spending hundreds of millions of dollars providing free health care to patients. It was eating into their bottom line.

headline: Silicon Valley Slides Back Into ‘Bro’ Culture
abstract: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Marc Andreessen show how the tech industry’s insular culture remains largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, Mark Zuckerberg spent hours touting his love of jiujitsu, wrestling and UFC on Joe Rogan’s podcast, which is known for its hypermasculinity. Watching TV was not active enough, Mr. Zuckerberg said. Compared with social media, TV was “beta.”

headline: How a Hospital Chain Used a Poor Neighborhood to Turn Huge Profits
abstract: Bon Secours Mercy Health, a major nonprofit health system, used the poverty of Richmond Community Hospital’s patients to tap into a lucrative federal drug program.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — In late July, Norman Otey was rushed by ambulance to Richmond Community Hospital. The 63-year-old was doubled over in pain and babbling incoherently. Blood tests suggested septic shock, a grave emergency that required the resources and expertise of an intensive care unit.

headline: For Suburban Texas Men, a Workout Craze With a Side of Faith
abstract: In Katy, outside Houston, many men have taken up F3, a no-frills fitness group where members push themselves physically but also bond emotionally.
lead_paragraph: KATY, Texas — By day, Glenn Ayala is a 50-something account manager who spends much of his time behind a desk. But at Rick Rice Park in the early morning darkness, doing push-ups and jogging with a 20-pound rucksack on his back, he is known as K9, and he is with his people.

headline: Runners and Cyclists Use GPS Mapping to Make Art
abstract: Fitness apps and the power of live satellite tracking have allowed runners, cyclists and others to draw hearts, animals, birthday wishes — and even homages to Vermeer — across their local landscapes.
lead_paragraph: In 1665, Johannes Vermeer dabbed the last drop of paint onto a canvas in his Dutch studio, completing his masterpiece “Girl With a Pearl Earring.”

headline: A Year When Everything Is Going Right for Western Canada’s Farmers
abstract: This year’s harvest will be bountiful, with prices more than offsetting increased costs for items like fuel.
lead_paragraph: Driving around Saskatchewan earlier this month, I found it impossible to miss the harvest activity. Tractors were kicking up clouds of dust in the fields, grain trucks were rolling down the highways, and I occasionally had to pull off onto the shoulder to avoid large pieces of farm equipment.

headline: How to Slow Down
abstract: In an age of instant everything, drawing invites us to slow down and appreciate the world around us.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, on a lark, I signed up for a figure-drawing class. I hadn’t had art instruction of any sort since grade school, when I’d demonstrated scant talent in my preferred medium, construction paper and Elmer’s glue. My adventure in continuing education was similarly undistinguished. But if I didn’t leave the course with a portfolio of beautifully realized portraits, I did learn that drawing isn’t an activity reserved for artists who do it well. It can be a way of observing and making sense of the world.

headline: Putin is tightening his grip on the reins of the war as Russian losses mount.
abstract: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has thrust himself more directly into strategic planning for the war in Ukraine in recent weeks, American officials said, including rejecting requests from his commanders on the ground that they be allowed to retreat from the vital southern city of Kherson.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has thrust himself more directly into strategic planning for the war in Ukraine in recent weeks, American officials said, including rejecting requests from his commanders on the ground that they be allowed to retreat from the vital southern city of Kherson.

headline: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
abstract: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
lead_paragraph: AT THE KHERSON FRONT, Ukraine — The commander banged on the door furiously.

headline: Silicon Valley Had Its Heyday. Can Tech Ecosystems Now Grow Inland?
abstract: The AOL co-founder Steve Case sees a need for entrepreneurial hubs beyond the coasts. “Let’s have it be a few dozen cities,” he says.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: As the Postseason Nears, the Yankees are Getting Healthy
abstract: Numerous players have returned from the injured list, taking some of the burden off Aaron Judge’s massive shoulders.
lead_paragraph: On the brink of making history, Aaron Judge has had all eyes on him this week in his pursuit of 61 home runs this season, which would tie the American League record set by Roger Maris in 1961.

headline: Russia’s draft is drawing criticism from far-flung regions and even pro-war hawks.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s surprise draft to reinforce his invasion of Ukraine has run into growing resistance across Russia as villagers, activists and even some elected officials asked why the conscription drive appeared to be hitting minority groups and rural areas harder than the big cities.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin’s surprise draft to reinforce his invasion of Ukraine has run into growing resistance across Russia as villagers, activists and even some elected officials asked why the conscription drive appeared to be hitting minority groups and rural areas harder than the big cities.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Sept. 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Solo Soulless Saboteurs
abstract: Putin and Trump, dragging the world down with them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the internet age, it’s almost impossible to get away with anything. (See: Adam Levine.)

headline: ‘Somebody Planted the Guns’: In Canada, a Raided, Distrusting Village Blames the Police
abstract: When a cache of weapons was found in a tiny Canadian village that has become a symbol of the far right, it didn’t take long for new conspiracy theories to start circulating.
lead_paragraph: COUTTS, Alberta — The village’s only restaurant offers smiles and two pamphlets, one denouncing Covid-19 vaccines for children, the other saying the United Nations’ mission includes creating a “microchipped society” for “tracking and controlling.”

headline: Understanding the Fight Between Armenia and Azerbaijan
abstract: The hostilities that flared again last week reflect decades of animosity over a mountain region, but the consequences could be far wider. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met the foreign ministers of Armenia and Azerbaijan in New York this week for the first direct talks since more than 180 people were reported killed last week in fighting between the two countries. The flare-up subsided within days, but the high-level meeting reflects worries that the causes of the conflict — and the full-scale war that preceded it in 2020 — are nowhere near resolved.

headline: Why Japan Is Angry About a State Funeral for an Assassinated Leader
abstract: The fallout from Shinzo Abe’s death has taken a number of unexpected turns, casting a critical light on both his long-governing party and a fringe religious group.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Nearly three months after Shinzo Abe, Japan’s most influential and longest-serving prime minister, was gunned down in broad daylight at a campaign stop, his death is still reverberating, though in ways few would have predicted.

headline: Let’s Talk About the Economic Roots of White Supremacy
abstract: It’s not just about racism.
lead_paragraph: In my Tuesday column on the political incentives within the Republican Party, I made an analogy to the struggle over civil rights in the midcentury Democratic Party. I brought up the Dixiecrats and mentioned their opposition to labor rights as well as civil rights.

headline: What Issue Is Most On Your Mind for the Midterm Elections?
abstract: We want to know what’s motivating your vote ahead of Election Day.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Election Day, Times Opinion needs your help to understand what motivates each generation to vote.

headline: What’s Next for the Royal Corgis?
abstract: Considering the future of the short yet noble canines.

headline: Hilary Mantel Was the Magician and the Spell
abstract: Part of the particular wonder of reading her is the knowledge that no one else has ever written like that before nor will again.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I remember standing with Hilary Mantel in the offices of the literary agency we shared. It was autumn 2008, several months before “Wolf Hall” was published. I knew she was writing a novel about Thomas Cromwell when I pointed out of the window and said that certain important events in his life and the lives of those he knew must have happened not far from here. We were in Holborn, an old part of London, where you can still see surviving Tudor architecture. “Oh yes,” she said. She mentioned a nearby street and launched into a description of a dinner there attended by Cardinal Wolsey, Cromwell’s patron, nearly 500 years before.

headline: The Midterm Race That Has It All
abstract: This congressional race in Washington State shows the November elections in microcosm.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, Wash. — In March, five months before he became the Republican nominee in a Washington State congressional race, Joe Kent appeared on a webcast hosted by a Gen-Z white nationalist group called the American Populist Union. Kent, who would soon be endorsed by Donald Trump, was there to explain his disavowal of Nick Fuentes, a smirking 24-year-old far-right influencer whom The New York Times has described as “a prominent white supremacist.”

headline: Women’s Lives Put at Risk Under State Abortion Bans
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about how ban exceptions would work.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pharoah Sanders, Whose Saxophone Was a Force of Nature, Dies at 81
abstract: He first gained wide recognition for his work with John Coltrane. He went on to a fertile, prolific career, releasing dozens of albums as a leader.
lead_paragraph: Pharoah Sanders, a saxophonist and composer celebrated for music that was at once spiritual and visceral, purposeful and ecstatic, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Russia’s Defense Ministry shakes up its leadership.
abstract: Russia’s Defense Ministry announced a high-level leadership shake-up on Saturday after an embarrassing rout of its forces in northeast Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s Defense Ministry announced a high-level leadership shake-up on Saturday after an embarrassing rout of its forces in northeast Ukraine.

headline: Federer’s Goodbye a Reminder of the Events and Shots That Make His Legacy
abstract: Federer kept alive a one-handed backhand, tried rushing the net on returns and helped popularize the between-the-legs shot. And with the Laver Cup, he showed that tournaments can be different, too.
lead_paragraph: After Roger Federer bid a teary and moving farewell to competitive tennis late Friday night in London, one of his legacies to the game is clear.

headline: E.P.A. Will Make Racial Equality a Bigger Factor in Environmental Rules
abstract: The agency is creating an office of environmental justice to address the disproportionate harm that climate change has caused in low-income areas and communities of color.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a new national office of environmental justice, the Biden administration’s latest effort to rectify the disproportionate harm caused by pollution and climate change in communities of color and in low-income cities, towns and counties.

headline: Protests Surge in Iran as Crackdown Escalates
abstract: Dozens have reportedly been killed by security forces as demonstrations continue to spread across Iran. Protests began after Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police.
lead_paragraph: Dozens have reportedly been killed by security forces as demonstrations continue to spread across Iran. Protests began after Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police.

headline: How Seriously Should We Take Putin’s Nuclear Threat in Ukraine?
abstract: Russia is flailing and losing. The nuclear threat is growing.
lead_paragraph: At a 1985 banquet marking the 30th anniversary of National Review, with Ronald Reagan in attendance, William F. Buckley Jr. gave a speech celebrating the American nuclear deterrent, and the willingness of the American president to use it. Those weapons and that willingness, Buckley declaimed, had sustained American freedom through the Cold War, so that future generations could look back and be grateful that “at the threatened nightfall, the blood of their fathers ran strong.”

headline: Roxanne Lowit, Fashion Photographer With a Backstage View, Dies at 80
abstract: Her candid shots at fashion shows captured stars of the industry as themselves and showed that the spectacle behind the curtain often rivaled the main event.
lead_paragraph: Roxanne Lowit, an omnipresent fashion photographer whose candid shots of top designers and models frolicking backstage at the world’s fashion shows revealed that the spectacle behind the curtain often rivaled the main event on the catwalk, died on Sept. 13 in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 80.

headline: At least 745 people are detained in protests across Russia.
abstract: Demonstrations against President Vladimir V. Putin’s “partial mobilization” policy continued, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on dissent.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of Vladimir V. Putin’s call-up that could sweep 300,000 civilians into military service continued to show their disapproval across Russia on Saturday, with at least 745 people detained, according to OVD-Info, a human rights watchdog that monitors police activity.

headline: ‘They Have Nothing to Lose’: Why Young Iranians Are Rising Up Once Again
abstract: Amid growing repression, a sickly economy and bleak prospects, the death of one young woman was all it took.
lead_paragraph: The 22-year-old woman emerged from the Tehran subway, her dark hair covered with a black head scarf and the lines of her body obscured by loose clothing, when the capital city’s Guidance Patrol spotted her. They were members of Iran’s notorious morality police, enforcers of the conservative Islamic dress and behavior rules that have governed daily life for Iranians since the 1979 revolution, and newly energized under a hard-line president who took office last year.

headline: Two Renovated Museums Offer a Peek at Spy Secrets — at Least for Some
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency both recently overhauled their showcases of espionage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the United States’ intelligence agencies have completely renovated their museums of spycraft, displaying dramatic stories of notable U.S. spies and informants, as well as paraphernalia from intelligence work. But one of the museums will remain off limits to the public.

headline: Ukraine Fights to Reclaim Territory as Russia Holds Annexation Referendums
abstract: Ukraine’s president has urged citizens to resist the Russians in occupied territories, where voting is underway in what Western officials have called “sham” referendums on joining Russia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces defiantly pushed back against threats by Russia to annex territory it controls on Saturday, while Moscow replaced a top general in charge of logistics after a series of snafus that contributed to recent battlefield losses by Russian troops.

headline: In a U.N. speech, Russia’s foreign minister says ‘the future of the world order’ is at stake.
abstract: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, used his speech at the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday to lash out at the United States and its Western allies and divert attention from recent developments in the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, used his speech at the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday to lash out at the United States and its Western allies and divert attention from recent developments in the war in Ukraine.

headline: Take Two
abstract: Meghan Morris’s Sunday debut strikes a delicate balance.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Meghan Morris is an appellate public defender in Denver, where she lives with her partner and twin kindergartners. This is her third Times puzzle, and her first Sunday grid.

headline: The U.S. says Russia isn’t preparing to use nuclear weapons, yet.
abstract: Biden administration officials have expressed concern that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could detonate a tactical nuclear weapon — perhaps in a demonstration blast over the Black Sea or Arctic Ocean, or in Ukrainian territory — but on Saturday said there is no evidence yet that he is moving those weapons or preparing such a strike.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials have expressed concern that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could detonate a tactical nuclear weapon — perhaps in a demonstration blast over the Black Sea or Arctic Ocean, or in Ukrainian territory — but on Saturday said there is no evidence yet that he is moving those weapons or preparing such a strike.

headline: Puerto Ricans Fear Extended Blackout After Hurricane Fiona
abstract: Residents, who pay some of the highest electricity rates in the United States, say they have little patience for the kind of outages they faced after Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Michelle Rivera trudged slowly up the stairs of her apartment building, stopping to collect her breath and regain the strength to carry one more gallon of water to her home on the eighth floor. It was Friday, the sixth day of a power blackout in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Fiona.

headline: Jim Post, Known for a Memorably ‘Groovy’ Hit Song, Dies at 82
abstract: He and his wife, Cathy Conn, had a Top 10 single with “Reach Out of the Darkness” as Friend & Lover in 1968. It’s still played today, but it was their only hit.
lead_paragraph: Jim Post, best known as half of the duo Friend & Lover, whose only hit was a memorable one — “Reach Out of the Darkness,” which proclaimed with flower-power earnestness, “I think it’s so groovy now that people are finally gettin’ together” — died on Sept. 14 in Dubuque, Iowa. He was 82.

headline: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile Off Its East Coast
abstract: The exercise was Pyongyang’s first ballistic missile test in nearly four months and came days after the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan arrived in a South Korean port.
lead_paragraph: North Korea launched a short-range ballistic missile off its east coast on Sunday in its first ballistic missile test in nearly four months, the South Korean military said.

headline: The New India: Expanding Influence Abroad, Straining Democracy at Home
abstract: As India rises, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has faced little pushback as he weaponizes institutions to consolidate power and entrench his Hindu nationalist vision.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On the margins of a summit meant as a show of force for a Russian leader seeking a turnaround on the battlefield, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India leaned in with a different message.

headline: Quotation of the Web: With No. 700, Pujols Wins His Race Against the End
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “That home run off me is old enough to drink. It’s old enough to order a beer at the bar. I was doing good by baseball, though, just trying to help the game out. I did my part.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 25, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 14 this weekend about a trove of Ernest Hemingway materials now part of a new archive at Penn State, relying on information from a historian, misstates which years of Ernest Hemingway’s fishing log were included in a newly opened archive. It includes his log from the years 1934-1935, not 1932-1933.

headline: Zelensky calls on Russians to resist Putin’s conscription.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine encouraged Russians to resist their country’s conscription drive on Saturday, his latest effort to blunt President Vladimir V. Putin’s attempts to broaden the war.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine encouraged Russians to resist their country’s conscription drive on Saturday, his latest effort to blunt President Vladimir V. Putin’s attempts to broaden the war.

headline: Super Typhoon Noru Heads for Philippines After ‘Explosive’ Surge
abstract: Forecasters warned of heavy rains and winds that could bring flooding and landslides to densely populated areas of the country.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Super Typhoon Noru was on course to slam into the densely populated main island of Luzon in the Philippines on Sunday night, with forecasters warning of heavy rains and winds that could cause devastating flooding and landslides.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Suddenly, a Sanitation Worker Jumped Out of the Truck’s Cab’
abstract: Finding relief on a hot day, taking the long way to the airport and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Notebook, Food and a Bear Canister: A Reporter Hits the Trail
abstract: To understand the changing challenge of hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, a reporter spent three days intercepting people walking from Southern California to the Northern Cascades.
lead_paragraph: I had just finished three days of reporting on the Pacific Crest Trail when the McKinney fire started in Northern California. On the trail, I had interviewed hikers about wildfire risk, and there answers were hypothetical. Soon after, a real fire was changing their plans. In follow-up emails, I learned that one hiker had spent a sleepless night watching ash swirl around his tent. Others were escorted north of the blaze by emergency officials.

headline: Sundance Liked Her Documentary on Terrorism, Until Muslim Critics Didn’t
abstract: The film festival gave Meg Smaker’s “Jihad Rehab” a coveted spot in its 2022 lineup, but apologized after an outcry over her race and her approach.
lead_paragraph: Meg Smaker felt exhilarated last November. After 16 months filming inside a Saudi rehabilitation center for accused terrorists, she learned that her documentary “Jihad Rehab” was invited to the 2022 Sundance Festival, one of the most prestigious showcases in the world.

headline: Ghosts of New York’s Glamorous Past Haunt an Empty Pub
abstract: A bar from the Stork Club, once a gathering spot for Grace Kelly, Ernest Hemingway, Elizabeth Taylor and Marilyn Monroe, collects dust in a downtown tavern that went out of business.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old Irish pub in Manhattan’s financial district, Jim Brady’s, that closed at the start of the pandemic and has been sitting empty ever since. The stockbrokers and construction workers who once drank there now walk past with indifference.

headline: Whatever Happened to the Starter Home?
abstract: The economics of the housing market, and the local rules that shape it, have squeezed out entry-level homes.
lead_paragraph: As recently as the 1990s, when Jason Nageli started off, the home-building industry was still constructing what real-estate ads would brightly call the “starter home.” In the Denver area, he sold newly built two-story houses with three bedrooms in 1,400 square feet or less.

headline: When Your Star Has Faded but There’s Time Left to Shine
abstract: Jonathan Coe’s novel “Mr. Wilder and Me” explores the late career of a legendary Hollywood director.
lead_paragraph: One of the difficulties of writing stories about a certain class of English person is that so many of them have already written stories about themselves. There’s a lot of flattened grass underfoot. Jonathan Coe’s latest novel, “Mr. Wilder and Me,” begins on familiar terrain: Calista heads to Fortnum & Mason, the posh department store in central London, to buy a present for her daughter, who is flying to Sydney for university in the morning. Afterward, she drops into the bar of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts for a coffee. Calista is a composer and she runs into a producer she knows, who has been trying since the 1980s to make a film out of a novel by Kingsley Amis, “a name which, back in those days, still carried a certain cachet.”

headline: What Inspired Two Iranian Immigrants to Start a Global Film Series
abstract: Cinema Tehran brings people together through screenings, chats and food.
lead_paragraph: When Arya Ghavamian was growing up in Iran, a satisfying film experience was hard to come by. After the 1979 revolution, the Islamic Republic had cracked down on Iran’s robust film industry, denouncing it as an obscene and immoral product of Westernization.

headline: A Formative Friendship Cut Short by Tragedy
abstract: In “Stay True,” Hua Hsu, a staff writer for The New Yorker, recounts his relationship with an Asian American college friend, whose search for identity quietly shaped the author’s own.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Historical Novels With a Few Tricks Up Their Sleeves
abstract: Special powers, avian obsession and visions of the future fuel these transporting and entertaining tales.
lead_paragraph: Historical fiction thrives in the empty spaces scholars have yet to fill. And thanks to poetic license, sometimes magic realism can also lurk in those shadows. Superstition? Sleight of hand? Sorcery? Each of these three novelists has a unique trick to play.

headline: Remembering a Deadline Single by the Sundown Kid
abstract: Every year as Rosh Hashana approaches, a longtime reporter thinks back to 1971 when he was running out of time and Ron Blomberg, the Yankees’ only Jewish player, came through.
lead_paragraph: It was the bottom of the ninth inning, and I was at the height of agitation.

headline: While You’re in the Air, Pilots’ Key Partners May Be Working From Home
abstract: Two airlines allow dispatchers, who share operational authority over flights, to do their jobs remotely. Some in the industry take issue with that.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people boarded flights this summer, eager for an escape more than two years into a stifling pandemic. What many may not have realized is that at least some of the dispatchers who planned and managed those flights — mapping out routes, monitoring weather forecasts and more —  were doing the job from home.

headline: Dodging Blackouts, California Faces New Questions on Its Power Supply
abstract: Extreme heat is testing the way energy is generated, delivered and traded — and raising the prospect of perpetual emergencies.
lead_paragraph: California finds itself on edge more than ever with a lingering fear: the threat of rolling blackouts for years to come.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: On the Thai Island of Koh Tao, Can Tourism and the Environment Coexist?
abstract: Travel to Southeast Asia is picking up again, and an island known for snorkeling and diving, part of a popular circuit, wants tourists back. But can development and nature stay in balance?
lead_paragraph: On the high-speed ferry from Koh Samui, one of Thailand’s biggest islands, to the smaller neighbor of Koh Tao, known for its budget scuba diving and snorkeling and idyllic beaches and bays, it seemed like old times.

headline: A Bed-Stuy Mansion Has Become Rubble. Residents Ask: How, and Why?
abstract: Despite pleas, protests and petitions, a developer tore down the 120-year-old Jacob Dangler House. Residents are still reflecting on what happened.
lead_paragraph: To neighbors of the Jacob Dangler House in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, the French Gothic palatial building was a meeting space, a community center, and a place for baby showers, weddings and funeral repasts.

headline: On the Edge of Delhi, a Dynamic Cultural Scene Takes Shape
abstract: Beneath an ancient tower, contemporary galleries, studios, bars and clubs are popping up in three neighborhoods, drawing art lovers, fashionistas and nightlife seekers.
lead_paragraph: “Delhi is a soldiers’ town, a politicians’ town, journalists’, diplomats’ town. It is Asia’s Washington, though not so picturesque,” wrote Jan Morris, the acclaimed British travel writer, half a century ago.

headline: My Parents Are Hackers Out of Necessity
abstract: Both skateboarding and navigating daily life with a disability involve surprisingly similar ways of engaging with the built environment.
lead_paragraph: About 15 years ago, I accompanied my mother during her first visit to the nonemergency wing of the Los Alamitos Medical Center in California. I was 14 at the time, obsessed with skateboarding. Mom, who has cerebral palsy, used a walker back then and decided to give the accessible entrance a try. It was a gently ascending switchback ramp, roughly 80 feet long. The ramp was ideal for wheelchair users, but its length and 180-degree turn made it difficult for my mother. She was winded by the time she got to the door and had to sit on a nearby bench to rest before continuing. Even on her best days, switchbacks exhausted her.

headline: Deadlier Than the Titanic: A Ferry Set Out With About 1,900 Aboard. Only 64 Survived.
abstract: Tourists, vendors, babies, hundreds of university students and a soccer team from Senegal perished in a little-known ferry disaster 20 years ago. Survivors and families of victims still want justice.
lead_paragraph: ZIGUINCHOR, Senegal — Up on the deck, dozens of university students played cards. In the first-class cabins below, passengers watched the movie “Air Force One.” In an overcrowded third-class compartment, a teenage soccer team on its way to a tournament belted out songs.

headline: An Anti-Muslim Symbol From India Is Paraded on Main Street, New Jersey
abstract: Bulldozers have become symbols of oppression in India. The appearance of a wheel loader, which resembles a bulldozer, in a New Jersey parade has exposed fault lines in the region.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — The India Day Parade featured a pretty standard lineup of festival fare.

headline: Kyoto Wants You Back, but It Has Some Polite Suggestions
abstract: The city, one of Japan’s most-visited before the pandemic, desperately needs tourism’s money, but it would like to avoid the excesses of Instagram-driven itineraries.
lead_paragraph: In the months before March 2020, the food sellers in Kyoto’s Nishiki market often wished for an end to the seemingly endless stream of photo-hungry visitors from abroad who always seemed to be underfoot.

headline: Exploring ‘The Land of Morning Calm’
abstract: A traveler gets beyond Seoul’s sprawl to explore tranquil thatched mountain hamlets, peaceful Buddhist temples and unhurried ‘slow food’ towns in rural South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Before South Korea became globally known for its beauty products, kimchi and pop groups, it was known as the Land of the Morning Calm. The name has long been used to refer to the Korean Peninsula, before the division of South and North Korea, because of its tranquil, temple-dotted mountains and serene forests where dawn breaks on the Asian mainland.

headline: Plenty of Glitz
abstract: Top looks from the Kering Foundation dinner, the Creative Capital benefit and comedy night with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
lead_paragraph: The fashion circus may have moved on to Europe, but there was still plenty of glamour to go around.

headline: A Quartet of Debuts
abstract: New designers at Ferragamo, Bally, Etro and Missoni.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Gucci is still the great success story of Milanese fashion: A heritage name gone stale and then revolutionized by a new designer and turned into an influence and cash machine that keeps going and going. It’s the gold ring every competitor is chasing. Including, this season, Ferragamo, Bally, Missoni and Etro.

headline: Playing Twinsies at Gucci
abstract: Plus gremlins, goddesses, Paris Hilton at Versace and a triumph at Bottega Veneta. Things are getting funky in Italy.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The night before Italy went to the polls on Sunday for its first general election in five years, almost 20,000 people thronged the square in front of the Duomo. It was raining, but they stood side by side, jittering in mass anticipation. A raised stage had been constructed before the soaring cathedral, and on either side stood towers of floodlights and two enormous screens.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks’
abstract: Researchers are trying to figure out the right hour of the day to do everything. Can their studies sync us up with better health?
lead_paragraph: The concept of having a “body clock” is a familiar one, but less widespread is the awareness that our body contains several biological clocks. Understanding their whims and functions may help us optimize our lives and lead to better overall health, according to scientists.

headline: Do Not Bring Your ‘Whole Self’ to Work
abstract: Beware the latest fad from Human Resources.
lead_paragraph: For those lucky enough to have worked from home over the past two and a half years or seven years or whatever it was, it’s back to the office time. We are finally R.T.O. and I.R.L., at least until the next wave hits. And some people can’t wait.

headline: Eliud Kipchoge Smashes His Own Marathon World Record
abstract: Kipchoge ran the Berlin Marathon in a time of 2:01:09. Tigist Assefa shocked the women’s field by running her second marathon in 2:15:38, a course record.
lead_paragraph: Two questions come to mind any time Eliud Kipchoge toes the starting line of a marathon.

headline: Giorgia Meloni Wins Voting in Italy, in Breakthrough for Europe’s Hard Right
abstract: Her nationalist party was the top vote-getter, leaving Ms. Meloni poised to be Italy’s first female prime minister and the first with post-Fascist roots.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy turned a page of European history on Sunday by electing a hard-right coalition led by Giorgia Meloni, whose long record of bashing the European Union, international bankers and migrants has sown concern about the nation’s reliability in the Western alliance.

headline: The Week in Business: The Fed Hits the Brakes
abstract: There’s gloom on Wall Street. JetBlue and American Airlines face an antitrust trial. And investors can begin buying shares of the luxury sports carmaker Porsche.
lead_paragraph: At the Federal Reserve’s much-anticipated meeting on Wednesday, policymakers announced a rate increase of three-quarters of a percentage point, the third in a row of that size. They also reminded Americans that it would probably not be the last, predicting that borrowing costs would rise to 4.4 percent by the end of the year from the current range of 3 to 3.25 percent. “It would be nice if there was a way to just wish it away, but there isn’t,” Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said of the high inflation he is trying to tame with rate increases. Other central banks have been taking similar actions. On Thursday, the Bank of England raised its key rate half a percentage point, lifting it to the highest level since late 2008.  While inflation in the United States has begun to show some signs of moderation, policymakers in Britain are still awaiting its peak.

headline: The Morning: The back story of the migrant buses
abstract: Republican governors’ immigration stunts are actually helping some migrants.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida created a firestorm this month for what he did to about 50 migrants, mostly from Venezuela, who had recently crossed the southern border: He put them on two planes that took them to Martha’s Vineyard, the famously liberal and upscale vacation destination in Massachusetts. He was following the lead, albeit more explosively, of his fellow G.O.P. governor Greg Abbott of Texas, in sending migrants to progressive strongholds.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 26, 2022
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Hello, fellow kids: Italian politicians turn to TikTok for votes.
abstract: Lawmakers set up TikTok accounts to try to reach undecided voters before Sunday’s elections. Hilarity ensued.
lead_paragraph: Italian politicians are on a virtual hunt for undecided voters.

headline: A Show With a Cryptic Title but No Code to Crack
abstract: “300 el x 50 el x 30 el,” the Belgian troupe FC Bergman’s ambitious theatrical installation, will open BAM’s Next Wave festival with an elaborate set that recreates a rural settlement onstage.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian theater collective FC Bergman was still young when it landed an invitation to a prestigious festival in its town, Antwerp, in 2011. “They said, ‘You have one evening — do something,’” Marie Vinck, a company member, recalled in a recent video conversation.

headline: NASA Is About to Crash Into an Asteroid. Here’s How to Watch.
abstract: The DART mission has been flying to its target since launching last year. On Monday night, it will connect.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on NASA’s DART mission to crash into an asteroid.

headline: Germany’s Chancellor Has ‘a Lot’ for Ukraine. But No Battle Tanks.
abstract: Military assistance to Kyiv has become something of a litmus test of Olaf Scholz’s ability to lead Europe through its most significant security crisis since World War II.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany gets right to the point when asked why his country will not send battle tanks to Ukraine: It is “a very dangerous war,” he said.

headline: Ukraine warns of growing attacks by drones Iran has supplied to Russia.
abstract: As Moscow finds itself isolated internationally, and as its arsenal has been depleted in Ukraine, it has turned for military support to countries including Iran.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Drone strikes hit a military target in the southern port city of Odesa on Monday, the third day in a row that unmanned aerial vehicles have attacked there, the Ukrainian military said.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: A tofu and cabbage stir-fry, fish tacos and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Rosh Hashana, the two-day celebration of the Jewish New Year, gets underway this evening: solemn prayers at synagogue followed by festive eating at home.

headline: The U.S. says it has warned Russia of ‘catastrophic consequences’ if it uses nuclear weapons in Ukraine.
abstract: Biden administration officials have warned Russian officials in private conversations of “catastrophic consequences” if Moscow uses nuclear weapons in its invasion of Ukraine, the U.S. national security adviser said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials have warned Russian officials in private conversations of “catastrophic consequences” if Moscow uses nuclear weapons in its invasion of Ukraine, the U.S. national security adviser said on Sunday.

headline: Why Religious Freedom Matters, Even if You’re Not Religious
abstract: “If speech is popular, it doesn’t really need constitutional protection,” David French says.
lead_paragraph: When David French and I first met around 2010, our friendship felt unlikely. He was deeply involved in Republican politics and had served in Iraq. I had never voted Republican and was committed to nonviolence. But his courage of conviction and kindness amid disagreement made us fast friends. (David became an independent in 2016, after Donald Trump received the Republican presidential nomination.)

headline: Hundreds Are Detained in Russia Amid Protests
abstract: A human rights watchdog said at least 745 people were detained across Russia while protesting President Vladimir V. Putin’s “partial mobilization” policy, which could sweep 300,000 civilians into military service.
lead_paragraph: A human rights watchdog said at least 745 people were detained across Russia while protesting President Vladimir V. Putin’s “partial mobilization” policy, which could sweep 300,000 civilians into military service.

headline: Will U.S. Democracy Survive the Threats?
abstract: Readers discuss what one writer calls “the bitter ideological civil war raging in America today.” Also: Women’s voices; living wills; a childhood home.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Celebrities Are Just the Start of the Expanding ‘Jeopardy!’-verse
abstract: Despite the loss of the show’s longtime host, viewership has held mostly steady, emboldening a move to spinoffs and tournaments, including a revival of “Celebrity Jeopardy!”
lead_paragraph: Michael Davies, who has been an executive producer of “Jeopardy!” for over a year, has proposed numerous ways to expand the game show’s brand at a delicate moment of transition, but “Celebrity Jeopardy!” wasn’t one of them.

headline: Just Jaeckin, Whose ‘Emmanuelle’ Was a Scandalous Success, Dies at 82
abstract: His first film, the story of a young woman’s erotic adventures, was initially blocked by French censors but became a runaway hit.
lead_paragraph: Just Jaeckin, a fashion photographer turned film director whose first movie, “Emmanuelle,” became a box-office sensation when it was released in 1974 after being blocked by French censors because of its soft-core depiction of a young woman’s erotic adventures, died on Sept. 6 in Saint-Malo, France. He was 82.

headline: Greg Lee, a Key Member of Two U.C.L.A. Title-Winners, Dies at 70
abstract: A master of the assist, he played alongside Bill Walton and Jamaal Wilkes on teams that John Wooden led to the N.C.A.A. championship in 1972 and 1973.
lead_paragraph: Greg Lee, the point guard for Coach John Wooden’s unbeaten U.C.L.A. teams that captured the 1972 and 1973 N.C.A.A. basketball tournament championships, died on Wednesday in San Diego. He was 70.

headline: The Met Opera Takes on ‘Medea’ in the Shadow of Maria Callas
abstract: The Met’s first production of Cherubini’s work, in the Italian version, opens the season. The soprano Sondra Radvanovsky is aware of the pressure.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s talk about the elephant in the room,” the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky said after a recent rehearsal of Luigi Cherubini’s “Medea” at the Metropolitan Opera. “Everybody knows this opera because of Maria Callas.”

headline: Soviet Monuments Become Latest Target of Backlash Against War in Ukraine
abstract: Across Eastern and Central Europe, statues honoring Soviet troops for their role in defeating the Nazis in World War II have in recent weeks come down or been slated for demolition.
lead_paragraph: REZEKNE, Latvia — Deported to Siberia by the Soviet secret police as a child and stranded there for more than a decade, Dr. Juris Vidins has for years cursed the large statue of a Red Army soldier looming over the center of his hometown in eastern Latvia. An inscription at its base honors the Soviet “liberators” who drove out the Nazis in 1944 — and who sent his father to a prison camp and the rest of the family to a frozen wilderness.

headline: Zelensky urges allies to step up pressure on Putin amid ‘nuclear blackmail.’
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned on Sunday that President Vladimir V. Putin’s threat to use nuclear weapons in Russia’s war against Ukraine was no bluff as he urged the United States and other Western allies to intensify the pressure on the Russian leader as his troops falter on the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned on Sunday that President Vladimir V. Putin’s threat to use nuclear weapons in Russia’s war against Ukraine was no bluff as he urged the United States and other Western allies to intensify the pressure on the Russian leader as his troops falter on the battlefield.

headline: Women and Gen Z Drive ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ Box Office
abstract: Harry Styles powered the critically drubbed and controversy-entangled movie to a solid $19.2 million in estimated ticket sales at North American cinemas.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate the interest in ogling a cute guy on a big screen.

headline: ‘They are not happy with how we love each other’: Gay parents fear a Meloni victory.
abstract: In her election campaign, Giorgia Meloni pledged to oppose surrogacy and adoption by gay couples.
lead_paragraph: When Giorgia Meloni, the hard-right leader who is likely to become Italy’s next prime minister, said on Italian TV this month that she opposed adoption by gay couples and that having a mother and a father was best for a child, Luigi, 6, overheard her and asked his father about it.

headline: Beto O’Rourke on Abbott’s Dehumanizing Stunts and Why He Hopes an Upset Looms in Texas
abstract: In an interview, he told me about how he views his campaign to unseat the Republican governor of Texas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Beto O’Rourke of Texas.

headline: Roger Waters Concert in Poland Called Off After Ukraine Views Prompt Anger
abstract: In online exchanges with Ukraines first lady, the Pink Floyd co-founder said Ukraine should seek peace with Russia and blamed the United States for encouraging the conflict.
lead_paragraph: One of Poland’s biggest music venues has canceled a concert by Roger Waters, the co-founder of the rock band Pink Floyd, after he was roundly criticized there for his view that Ukraine should pursue peace with Russia.

headline: Fall for Dance Review: Some Tap, a Pas de Deux and a Monastic Chorus
abstract: The annual smorgasbord at New York City Center features dancers from Music from the Sole, the Bavarian State Ballet and Alvin Ailey.
lead_paragraph: With its something-for-everyone ethos, the Fall for Dance festival, nearly 20 years old, continues to pack the house at New York City Center and two-plus years of a pandemic have made no discernible dent in its popularity.

headline: Rihanna to Perform at Super Bowl Halftime
abstract: The singer’s highly anticipated return to the stage will include the first halftime show under the N.F.L.’s new sponsorship deal with Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna will perform at the Super Bowl in Glendale, Ariz., on Feb. 12 as the N.F.L. enters the first year of a new deal with Apple Music as primary sponsor of the halftime show, replacing Pepsi.

headline: Two Americans return home months after being captured fighting in Ukraine.
abstract: Applause erupted as Alex Drueke and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh descended an escalator at an airport in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday. Side by side, the two men shared a quick glance before embracing their loved ones for the first time in months.
lead_paragraph: Applause erupted as Alex Drueke and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh descended an escalator at an airport in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday. Side by side, the two men shared a quick glance before embracing their loved ones for the first time in months.

headline: Belle, Sebastian and Me
abstract: Following the world’s twee-est band down the Pacific Coast after a divorce and the death of a parent.
lead_paragraph: May 31, 2022, Seattle, Paramount Theater

headline: Review: The Inescapable Vibrations of ‘Violet’
abstract: This 2011 work by the American-born, Europe-based choreographer Meg Stuart feels overextended.
lead_paragraph: The lights go up on five dancers standing at the back of the stage, evenly spaced, facing outward. It’s the configuration of a police lineup or of the audition scene in “A Chorus Line.” But this is “Violet,” by the American-born, Europe-based choreographer Meg Stuart, and for a long while no one moves at all.

headline: Nancy Hiller, Who Broke a Glass Ceiling in Woodworking, Dies at 63
abstract: One of the few women in her profession, she steadily built a quiet but forceful reputation as one of the best cabinetmakers in the country.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Hiller never planned on becoming one of America’s most renowned cabinetmakers and among just a handful of women in that male-dominated trade. She just needed a decent chair.

headline: The Megastate G.O.P. Rivalry Between Abbott and DeSantis
abstract: Publicly, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has not criticized the migrant flights from his state by Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. Privately, the Florida governor’s stunt stung the Texas governor’s team.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida wanted to irritate a set of wealthy, liberal elites when he flew migrants to Martha’s Vineyard from Texas, delivering them a slice of the humanitarian crisis simmering along the nation’s southern border.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Protests Grow in Iran
abstract: Plus anger builds in Japan over Shinzo Abe’s state funeral and Russia tries to conscript Ukrainians.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s largest antigovernment protests since 2009 gathered strength on Saturday, spreading to as many as 80 cities.

headline: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
abstract: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In the occupied city of Kherson, some Ukrainian men believe that if they break their own arms, maybe the Russians will not force them into military service. Others are hiding in basements. Some are trying to run even though they are forbidden to leave the city, residents said, and virtually everyone is afraid.

headline: Death of Iranian Woman Ignites Fury Among Fellow Kurds
abstract: The protests that have swept Iran following the death of a woman in police custody have been especially intense in the country’s minority Kurdish population.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The protests that have thrust Iran into turmoil since the death of a young woman in police custody have been striking for the way they have cut across ethnic and social class divides, but there is one group that has risen up with particular fury.

headline: I Must Be Dreaming!
abstract: Margaret Seikel’s puzzle will motivate your Monday.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Wake up, solvers. It’s time for a Monday puzzle! And it’s a fantastic fifth New York Times Crossword appearance from the constructor Margaret Seikel, whose puzzle is sure to leave you feeling as though you can overcome any challenge you might face today.

headline: What We Learned From Week 3 in the N.F.L.
abstract: In a battle of headliner quarterbacks, Tom Brady vs. Aaron Rodgers needed more co-stars; Trevor Lawrence and the Jaguars look legit; and the Bills could’ve used some help with the Dolphins’ receivers.
lead_paragraph: Kansas City and Buffalo each lost heartbreakers (to the Colts and the Dolphins, respectively) that came down to their final drives, defeats that should temporarily shake up pundits’ power rankings. The Panthers shocked the Saints and the Titans upset the Raiders, though those are likely to have lingering impact on New Orleans and Las Vegas, franchises that had expected to contend but find themselves with one combined win.

headline: Former Texas Police Officer Acquitted in 2020 Shooting Death of Black Man
abstract: Officer Shaun Lucas, who is white, shot 31-year-old Jonathan Price four times. After the encounter, he was fired.
lead_paragraph: A white police officer who shot and killed a 31-year-old Black man in Texas two years ago and whose response was deemed “not objectively reasonable” by a preliminary investigation was acquitted of murder by a jury on Thursday.

headline: Video Shows When Train Hit Patrol Car With Woman Handcuffed Inside
abstract: The crash took place after a Sept. 16 arrest near Platteville, Colo. The 20-year-old woman was being treated for serious injuries at an area hospital, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Video released by Colorado authorities on Friday shows the moment when a freight train smashed into a patrol car in which a handcuffed woman was sitting, as the vehicle straddled the railroad tracks following her arrest on Sept. 16.

headline: U.S. Warns Russia of ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ if It Uses Nuclear Weapons
abstract: The comments by the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, illustrate how quickly the rhetoric has intensified as Russia has faltered on the battlefield in recent months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s national security adviser said on Sunday that the United States had warned Russia that there would be “catastrophic consequences” for the country if Moscow used nuclear weapons in its increasing desperation to hold on to territory in Ukraine, adding that in recent days the United States has “spelled out” how the world would react in private conversations with Russian officials.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: A Scandal Spills Over
abstract: This week’s episode kicks off the next phase of the story as a long-simmering status quo finally becomes untenable.
lead_paragraph: This week on “House of the Dragon,” we were reminded that a lot can happen in 10 years.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Elections in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Italians headed to the polls yesterday in national elections, and exit polls suggest that the country is poised to elect Giorgia Meloni, the hard-right leader of a party descended from post-Fascist roots.

headline: S&P 500 Hits Lowest Level of 2022 as Global Sell-off Continues
abstract: The drop to the new low, after stocks staged a brief recovery this summer, shows how uncertain the environment for investors has become.
lead_paragraph: Markets around the world trembled on Monday, extending a losing streak that has been fueled by mounting panic that the global economy is going to take a hit.

headline: Brett Favre’s Most Memorable Stat May Be $8 Million Meant for the Poor
abstract: His role in the misappropriation of welfare money has infuriated people in his native Mississippi and prompted some fans to call for his removal from the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: The website for Brett Favre’s foundation, Favre 4 Hope, describes a mission of the charitable organization that the Hall of Fame quarterback founded in 1995: providing financial aid to groups “that provide services to underserved and disabled children in Mississippi and Wisconsin.”

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 26, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 26, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and ‘Hostages’
abstract: The sketch comedy show begins its 48th season. And HBO airs a documentary about the Iran hostage crisis.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 26-Oct. 2. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Adams to New York’s 3-K for All: Yes, No, Maybe.
abstract: There may not be spots for all in the city’s fledgling preschool program for 3-year-olds. Also, a message of endurance in a synagogue’s stained-glass window.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at why Mayor Eric Adams is pulling back on plans to expand the city’s 3-K for All preschool program. We’ll also look at a new stained-glass window in an Upper West Side synagogue with a history.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Let’s Do It Legit’: Drug Arrestees Vie for First New York Pot Licenses
abstract: People who have been punished for marijuana offenses are applying to open the state’s first retail cannabis dispensaries.
lead_paragraph: Anytime the police approached the street in the Bronx where Hector Bonilla used to hang out, his friends would toss away their marijuana on the ground, he said.

headline: More Trans Teens Are Choosing ‘Top Surgery’
abstract: Small studies suggest that breast removal surgery improves transgender teenagers’ well-being, but data is sparse. Some state leaders oppose such procedures for minors.
lead_paragraph: Michael, 17, arrived in the sleek white waiting room of his plastic surgeon’s office in Miami for a moment he had long anticipated: removing the bandages to see his newly flat chest.

headline: To Defend Democracy, Is Brazil’s Top Court Going Too Far?
abstract: Brazil’s Supreme Court has acted as the primary check on President Jair Bolsonaro’s power. Now many are worried the court is posing its own threat.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The group chat on WhatsApp was a sort of digital locker room for dozens of Brazil’s biggest businessmen. There was a shopping mall tycoon, a surf wear founder and Brazil’s big-box-store billionaire. They complained about inflation, sent memes and, sometimes, shared inflammatory opinions.

headline: Factory Jobs Are Booming Like It’s the 1970s
abstract: U.S. manufacturing is experiencing a rebound, with companies adding workers amid high consumer demand for products.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since American manufacturing entered a long stretch of automation and outsourcing in the late 1970s, every recession has led to the loss of factory jobs that never returned. But the recovery from the pandemic recession has been different: American manufacturers have now added enough jobs to regain all that they shed — and then some.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Migrant Busing Crisis
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how Republican governors are sending migrants to Democratic cities and towns to protest the high number of arrivals at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “With Faraway Migrant Drop-Offs, G.O.P. Governors Are Doubling Down” by Will Sennott, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eileen Sullivan and Patricia Mazzei

headline: Matty Bovan Brings Milan to Life
abstract: While Armani threads the needle and Ferrari hits a speed bump.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Backstage at the Matty Bovan show at the tail end of Milan Fashion Week, Stefano Gabbana of Dolce & Gabbana was hugging Mr. Bovan, the young British designer, and beaming with excitement. “This brings new energy for Milan!” said Mr. Gabbana happily.

headline: In Milan, an Urge to Walk Tall
abstract: From Etro to Giuseppe Zanotti, designers have embraced the power of the platform.
lead_paragraph: During Fashion Week, we will be spotlighting the small details we saw on the runways that surprised or delighted us. Bring on the sculptural shoes and antique fork jewelry.

headline: Elizabeth Banks Thinks This Interview Is Dangerous for Her
abstract: “The studio head is going to read it and be like, ‘Wow, that Liz Banks has got a lot to say.’ ”
lead_paragraph: “The studio head is going to read it and be like, ‘Wow, that Liz Banks has got a lot to say.’ ”

headline: Is Anger an Underrated Emotion?
abstract: What have you been taught about anger? Do you think we view this feeling too negatively?
lead_paragraph: How often do you get angry? What do you do when you feel anger rising up inside of you? Are you quick to react? Do you try to push it down? Do you lose control?

headline: She Lost Her Brother Years Ago. Why Does She Keep Seeing Him?
abstract: In Namwali Serpell’s novel “The Furrows,” a childhood tragedy brings a lifetime of strange encounters.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever walked between two great big airplane hangars and it made you feel very small and very strange?” the art dealer Richard Bellamy is said to have asked. “Well, that’s minimalism.”

headline: The Joy of Finding People Who Love the Same Books You Do
abstract: To be read to is a form of holiness.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I used to think of myself as a minor sort of Anglophile. As a child I knew the names of all six wives of Henry VIII — and other random details of English royal history — because I loved “Masterpiece Theater.” In college I watched the courtship of Charles and Diana in real time. Nearly 40 years later, I watched their Netflix counterparts make the same calamitous mistake in “The Crown.” And yet, of the nonstop television coverage of the actual queen’s actual death, I watched not a single minute. Well, she was old, I thought. She had a good run. So much for being an Anglophile.

headline: What’s the Best Laptop Bag That Doesn’t Look Like a Laptop Bag?
abstract: A reader navigating a hybrid work environment is looking for a new bag.
lead_paragraph: Sadly, magic solutions are more the stuff of fairy tales than fashion. Yet pretty good solutions exist. Even when it comes to the thorny question of how to carry around your laptop, a problem that has taken on new urgency as our work habits have changed, erasing that old desktop-at-work, laptop-for-home-and-travel divide.

headline: Where Are All Our Post-Covid Patients?
abstract: Post-Covid care has become a luxury.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, during the worst of the Covid pandemic, my colleagues and I told ourselves what now seems like a naïve story.

headline: Two-Buck Chuck: Wine of the People or a Cultural Wedge?
abstract: Fred Franzia built a cult following with his Trader Joe’s wine, but it comes at a cost to the wine business.
lead_paragraph: Mention Two-Buck Chuck, the nickname for the famously cheap Charles Shaw wines made by Bronco Wine Company, and you are likely to get two completely different reactions from wine drinkers.

headline: Biden’s Cautious Foreign Policy Is Imperiling the United States
